column2: WASHINGTON, April 20--Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, proposed today that Congress completely rewrite the immigration and naturalization laws.

In a complicated movement that will cost more a mile than any traveled route in the history of circusdom, Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus will play under canvas June 9 and 10 in Westbury, L. I.

Prof. Louis F. Budenz has testified that Prof. Owen Lattimore was used by the Communist high command to assist in the infiltration of American organizations such as the Institute of Pacific Relations.
KANSAS CITY, April 20 (AP)-- The American Academy of General Practice today revoked the membership of Dr. Hermann N. Sander, mercy case physician.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, was elected last night president of the Protestant Council of the City of New York at the annual meeting in the West Side Young Men's Christian Association. 5 West Sixty-third Street. A new set of bylaws strengthening the council was adopted.
"Throw potatoes at composers whose music you don't like, don't just sit back and take more of it," Gian-Carlo Menotti told the Women's City Club at a luncheon yesterday in the New Weston Hotel.
Fantasy is being added to falsehood in the almost incredible case of the several hundred Americans who are trying to get out of Communist-controlled China.

LONDON, April 20--To all intents and purposes the stock market ceased today to be influenced by the budget. Nearly all shares directly affected by the Chancellor of Exchequer's proposals remained at or near yesterday's levels.

The Veterans Administration will be allowed to continue limited operations at the state-owned Halloran Hospital on Staten Island until Dec. 31, 1952, when, it is expected, its new 1,250-bed facility in Manhattan will be completed, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)-- Frank R. McNinch of Charlotte, N. C., former chairman of both the Federal Power Commission and the Federal Communications Commission, died tonight at Georgetown University Hospital. His age was 77. He had been in ill health for some time and developed pneumonia on Wednesday.

CLEVELAND, April 20--The Methodist Council of Bishops issued a statement late today condemning John T. Flynn's current best seller, "The Road Ahead," as a propaganda attack on the Protestant Church endangering the nation's free state.
CHICAGO, April 20--A Chicago housewife today won the applause of 350 credit managers by telling them their professional faults.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP)-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight termed former Secretary of State George C. Marshall "a pathetic thing ... completely unfit" to have held that high post.

DETROIT, April 20--Theodore J. Richter, judge of the Wayne County circuit court and an implacable foe of hasty marriages for nearly three decades on that bench, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in suburban Grosse Pointe after an illness of fourteen months. He was 68 years old.

Two decades ago Paul Green, who is best remembered by local theatregoers for his war play, "Johnny Johnson," and, more reGently, for his dramatization of "Native Son," wrote a folk fantasy with music called "Tread the Green Grass," combining elements of the drama, dance, music and pantomime.

While stating his impartial position regarding citrus fruit outlets, Dodge Taylor, chairman of the Florida Citrus Commission, said yesterday that it had become evident that the industry's future depended on frozen concentrates.

To place the A. N. T. A. Playhouse, formerly the Guild Theatre, on a self-supporting basis, the American National Theatre and Academy, which recently purchased the house, yesterday announced the first booking. Late in June the new ownership will be inaugurated with "Getting Married."

In celebration of Israel's second anniversary as a state, both the Israeli Government, through its consulate here, and Mayor O'Dwyer issued proclamations yesterday designating next Sunday as Israel Independence Day.

Two popular novelties in the New York City Opera Company's repertoire will receive extra performances in the company's final week of the season, beginning Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. They are "Turandot" and "The Love for Three Oranges."

MOSCOW, April 20--The 30year-old words of Lenin--"Let American capitalists not touch us. We will not touch them"--were cited today in an article on the foundations of peaceful relations between the Soviet Union and the United States.
Last October President Truman vetoed a bill carrying a ten-year plan for the rehabilitation of the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes.

England's hopes of annexing the top prize in the international tournament of the Southern Counties Chess Union at Southsea were dampened somewhat when Jonathan Penrose, 16-year-old London champion, lost for the first time to Arthur B. Bisguier, junior champion of the United States, according to a report received yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20--A proposed report of the Senate labor-management subcommittee recommends that Congress remove the ban on hiring halls, it was learned today.

Clyde Scott Stilwell of 230 East Forty-eighth Street, assistant to the president of the New Jersey Zinc Company and former vice president of the National Biscuit Company, died Wednesday night in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 63.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The Bureau of the Budget, in a revision of President Truman's January budget estimates, informed Congress today that Federal deficits in the 1950 and 1951 fiscal years would aggregate about $1,000,000,000 more than originally expected.

ROME, April 20--At its final session today the European Recovery Program trade union advisory conference approved a resolution advocating the liberalization of trade, higher living standards and full employment of available resources and manpower.
Three dress shows held yesterday afternoon at Saks-34th Street proved to a host of customers that fashion is well within reach of most pocketbooks.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 20--Responding to the news that the United States Information Service library had been ordered closed next Saturday noon, about 5,000 Czechs--nearly as many as had visited it during the previous month--jammed the library today in a ceaseless flow throughout the day.

The threat of a strike against twenty-three plants of the Continental Baking Company across the country after May 1, based upon a new plan of the Baltery and Confectionery Workers International Union of America, A. F. L., to introduce nation-wide collective bargaining to the industry, was made known yesterday.

Seven major foreign tours will take approximately 100 American track and field athletes abroad this year, it was announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Uriion. Invitations have been received to send delegations as follows:
The importance of research and the development of new equipment in the vital task of keeping this country militarily strong was stressed yesterday by Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton.

A pledge that Chile would stand in the forefront of the western world's fight against communism and would seek to hold back the "barbarous avalanche of tyranny" was given by President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla of Chile in addresses here yesterday.

Attended by the same degree of pomp and ceremony that marked the official inaugural of the 1950 campaign last Tuesday, major league baseball's second round of opening games will be staged today. The occasion will be most gala in New York, with both the Yankees and Dodgers on view at home for the first time.

LONDON, April 20--The Scottish Trades Union Congress, first major organization in the labor movement to consider the effects of the 1950-51 budget presented by the Labor Government this week, voted by a narrow margin today to uphold the Government's wage restraint policy.

CHICAGO, April 20--Plans of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen for a quick shutdown of freight and passenger service on four big railroad systems were jolted today by an announcement by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers that members could cross picket lines if they chose.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 21 (AP) --Russia and China have signed a trade agreement whereby Russia will furnish industrial equipment in exchange for China's raw materials.

LONDON, April 20--The unofficial London dock strike that began yesterday over the expulsion from the Transport and General Workers Union of three dock workers who had taken a prominent part in last summer's Communistbacked port tie-up continued to spread today.

The city administration called yesterday for help from Congress in easing the problems of Puerto Rican migration at their source by extending to this country's Caribbean citizens more of the benefits enioved by mainlanders.
THERE is a little bit of Walter Mitty in all of us. We would like to be other than we are--braver, handsomer, more dashing and resourceful.

Registering their fifth successive weekly decline, business loans made by New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday dropped $83,000,000, the largest weekly decline this year. The principal factor in the current decline ...

Standards for measuring manual output in any industry in the country will be available soon as the result of a research project sponsored jointly by New York University and the Society for the Advancement of Management. This was announced yesterday at opening sessions of the society's Fifth ...

Further reduction of tariff rates on handbags will be vigorously opposed by the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry, it was made known yesterday by Abraham Mittenthal and Max Berkowitz, co-directors of the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 20--President Truman told the American Society of Newsaper Editors today that the United States must make itself "heard round the world in a great campaign of truth" to combat the advance of communism.

DETROIT, April 20--Don Raleigh gave the Detroit Red Wings another application of "sudden death" tonight. The slight center drove home a goal in 1 minute 38 seconds of overtime to give the New York Rangers a 2-to-1 victory in the fifth game of the final series for the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world.

Beating out magazines for the first time since 1942, newspapers led all types of media in the amount spent with them by national advertisers during 1949, it was announced yesterday by Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau ...
Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois is in a fair way to become as unpopular a member of the upper house as he is a courageous and useful one, and that is saying a great deal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 --"The Plymouth Adventure," a new novel by Ernest Gebler about the Pilgrim colony, which MetroGoldwyn-Mayer acquired for the screen six weeks ago, will be filmed early next year, with Spencer Tracy, Deborah Kerr and Van Johnson heading the cast, the studio announced today.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP)-- The Tigers made a sweep of their two-game series with the Indians today by winning, 5 to 4.

Less than twenty-four hours after Jesse Jones called for dissolution of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Dr. Benjamin H. Beckhart, professor of banking at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, yesterday also ...

WASHINGTON, Friday, April 21 (AP)--Mrs. James B. Patton of Columbus, Ohio, was elected president general today of the Daughters of the American Revolution She defeated Mrs. Edwin Stanton Lammers of Dallas, Tex. Mrs. Patton, who succeeds Mrs. Roscoe O'Byrne of Brookville, Ind., will hold office for three years.

The increasing acceptance of glassware as one of the important decorative arts is clearly shown in an exhibition, "Twentieth Century Glass," opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Almost 400 pieces, owned by the museum or borrowed from private collectors, have been arranged according ...

WASHINGTON, April 20--A Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee heard a procession of Mayors and municipal law enforcement officers today request the help of Federal legislation... to curb widespread bookmaking. The subcommittee is considering a bill to restrict intestate transmission of gambling information.

The New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association will form a non-partisan committee of several hundred attorneys to give free advice to both tenants and landlords as to their rights under the new state rent control bill, Herman Hoffman, president, announced yesterday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 20 (AP)--Bermuda's skippers won the second and third races of their series with the United States OneDesign team today, thus taking a 2-1 lead.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 20--The delegation of Egypt, criticizing the press again for its reports that King Farouk had broken up a romance between two of his youthful subjects in order to marry the girl himself, formally asked the United Nations today to set up penalties for any "offenses" committed by the press against sovereigns of a foreign nation.

Deafness or any hearing impairment is often of critical importance in contributing to mental illness in basically insecure persons. This largely overlooked element in disturbances of the mind must receive increasing study from psychiatrists and hearing specialists working in cooperation.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 20 (AP)--Bob Toski, the young professional golfer who won the Army All-American Open in India in 1945, served notice today he expects to cause favored Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., plenty of trouble in the third annual Cavalier Specialists golf tournament.

Varied designs from the drawing boards of Alfred and Augusta Bartholomew Dillon, ranging from wallpapers and rugs to fabrics and napkins, are currently on exhibition in their studio-home at 124 East Thirtieth Street.

Torrential rains interspersed with light but steady showers drenched the city's watersheds yesterday, flooding basin tributaries and causing Schoharie, smaller of the two Catskill reservoirs, to spill over beginning at 8:20 o'clock last night.
A long struggle to save an ancient side-wheeler ferryboat from the wrecker's beach and make her a part of a permanent maritime exhibit appeared near realization yesterday.
President Truman, possibly more than most of his predecessors, has been having trouble finding the right men for the jobs it is his duty to fill.
WASHINGTON, April 20--President Truman signed the $3,500,000,000 Housing Act of 1950 today without a word of comment.

A new chapter in the easymoney market for home purchasers was written yesterday with the announcement of a further cut in interest rates permitted on small-house mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

Mount Sinai Hospital, 100th Street and Fifth Avenue, cared for 15,998 in-patients and 21,863 outpatients last year at a cost of $4,789,568, according to the ninetyseventh annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Dr. Philip C. Jessup, Ambassador at Large and adviser to Secretary of State Dean Acheson, and George W. Perkins, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, will leave for London this week-end for preliminary talks on the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers' conference next month.

The marriage of Miss Lillian Emery Sagar, daughter of William Sutcliffe Sagar of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Lillian Walworth Sagar, to Frederick D. Forsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Forsch of 14 East Eighty-third Street, took place here yesterday afternoon at Fairfax Hall, 24 East Seventy-third Street.

THE Yankees and the Dodgers, having opened their seasons on foreign fields, will return home for formal openings of their own today. The Bronx Bombers will square off against their former manager, Bucky Harris, and his Washington Senators. The Brooks will square off against their former manager, Leo Durocher, and his New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Acceptance of fees by members of Congress for making speeches before business organizations that maintain lobbies seeking to shape or reshape the course of legislation raised questions before the House lobby investigation today.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Louis F. Budenz, formerly a Communist leader in the United States, swore today that he had been "officially informed" in years past by the highest American Communists that Prof. Owen Lattimore had been a ...

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, indicated last night that principals, administrative assistants, clerks and other non-teaching school personnel would receive salary increases of $150 a year.

Pointing out that advertising agencies sometimes lack incentive to develop new methods, Richard H. Moulton, research director of General Foods Corporation, declared yesterday that clients should require their agencies to be competitive in their research departments. Speaking at a meeting of the American Marketing Association ...
The black salmon anglers can plan to leave for the Miramichi almost any day now, for the ice has moved out of the Cains and the Miramichi is clear below the junction with that river.

For the program of the last Thursday night concert of the present Philharmonic-Symphony season, Dimitri Mitropoulos presented three works of highly contrasted character and one work which is unique and unapproached in modern music-Sibelius' Fourth Symphony--at Carnegie Hall yesterday evening.

KABUL, Afghanistan, April 20 --Neutral observers believe that diplomatic intervention by friendly powers is requir ed to terminate the stalemate in the relationships among Pakistan, Afghanistan and India, which are suffering politically and economically from the aftermath of Indian independence and partition.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 20-- The Social Commission of the United Nations today turned down a United States proposal to replace the three-year-old United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund with a new child welfare program.
ROME, April 20--The Italian Government is preparing to protest to Belgrade against alleged illegalities and violences committed during last Sunday's election in Zone B of the Trieste Free Territory.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP)-- Efforts were made in Congress today to block a cutback in postal service ordered by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 20 --Mrs. Florence Cooney Ellerhusen of near-by Towaco, a landscape and portrait painter, died today in All Souls Hospital here after a month's illness. She was the wife of Ulric H. Ellerhusen, sculptor, and sister of the late Gov. Frank H. Cooney of Montana.

Fresh contemporary fabrics in inviting colors keynote the model Salem Ridge house at Ridgewood, N. J., decorated and furnished by Altman's. The first of a new group of homes priced around $25,000, to be built by the Lovel Building Company of Ridgefield, N. J., it will he opened to the public tomorrow.
Details of proposed building construction work in the city for which plans were filed yesterday follows:

LONDON, April 20--Warwick Deeping, one of the most prolific modern writers of light fiction, whose "Sorrell and Son" probably was his best-Known work, died at his home in Weybridge today. He was 73 years old.

CHICAGO, April 20--Backspreading between July and November soybeans was effective today in narrowing the price difference here around 3 cents a bushel at one time, the July position being sold and the November bought, the latter selling within cent of the seasonal peak at one time.

Spurning such lightsome pursuits as Saturday night dances and comic books, 500 pint-sized stargazers in New York's Junior Astronomy Club are concentrating on assiduous searching of the heavens at odd hours of the night, learned dissertations on astrophysics and the production of quiz kids for Harvard.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 20 (AP) --A bank president, the heir to a spark-plug fortune and two insurance men tgday gained the semifinal round of the fiftieth annual North and South amateur golf tournament.

With bluntness not often used by the head of one state toward the government of another, President Truman yesterday denounced Soviet Russia for using false and slanderous propaganda and called for an intensified campaign of truth in the cause of peace and freedom.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)-- Congress was asked today to vote about $28,000,000 a year to keep the country's tramp ships in service.

The three-story building at 71 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, containing two stores and four apartments, has been sold by John Offerman to an investing client of the Bulkley Horton Company, broker in the transaction.

Walter Fredericks, tenor from Camden, who made an impromptu but well-received debut on April 2, sang last night the role of Calaf in the City Opera Company's production of "Turandot" at the City Center.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 20 (AP) --The Syracuse Nationals stayed in the final play-off series for the National Basketball Association championship by defeating the Minneapolis Lakers tonight, 83 to 76. The result left Minneapolis ahead in the best-of-seven game series, three games to two.

Onions are a "must" for every marked basket this week-end as stores offer an abundance of all varieties. There are the yellow globes for a thrifty 6 cents a pound; mild, sweet Bermudas (8 cents a pound) from the Southwest, and white "boilers," some from new Southern crops alld others left over from local harvests last fall.

HONG KONG, April 20--Press reports from Nationalist headquarters on Hainan published here this morning conceded that 7,000 Chinese Communist troops had been established in two areas on the north coast of the island.

The Armco Steel Corporation of Middletown, Ohio, the nation's seventh largest producer of steel, announced yesterday the development of a new method of charging open-hearth furnaces which promises to increase their steel output "substantially" and to cut operating costs.
The annual report of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, showed net sales of $280,831,558 for the fiscal year ended with January.

The annual awards of the Mystery Writers of America were announced last night at a dinner in the Henry Hudson Hotel. The prizes, small busts of Edgar Allan Poe, called "Edgars," were chosen by nation-wide balloting of members, and were awarded to:
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP)-- The big Connie Mack celebration really got rolling today as baseball's grand old man prepared for the home opener of his fiftieth season as manager of the Athletics.

When a racing strip is sloppy, as the Jamaica oval was yesterday, a jockey's best friend is a frontrunner. Cowboy Jim Nichols had one in the main act of the show. At the moment, the Warben Stables' Fighting Fan is his No. 1 equine pal.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 20 --Barring unforeseen last-minute difficulties, the way was finally cleared tonight for King Leopold III to return to Belgium on the basis of his proposal to transfer temporarily his royal powers to Prince Baudouin, his 19-year-old son.

NEWARK, April 20 (AP)--The West Shore division of the New York Central Railroad asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for permission to cut out eleven trains carrying some 1,000 passengers daily.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 20 --Barring unforeseen last-minute difficulties, the way was finally cleared tonight for King Leopold III to return to Belgium on the basis of his proposal to transfer temporarily his royal powers to Prince Baudouin, his 19-year-old son.

NEWARK, April 20 (AP)--The West Shore division of the New York Central Railroad asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for permission to cut out eleven trains carrying some 1,000 passengers daily.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said after a White House visit today that he was always encouraged when he discussed United Nations problems with President Truman.

Well-known women of society are aiding the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Consul" on the night of May 3 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Accident Prevention Program of the New York Green Cross.

JERUSALEM, April 20--Zionist leaders from four continents conferring in Jerusalem favor perpetuation of the Zionist movement despite the achievement of its declared goal of attaining a publicly and legally assured Jewish state.
The first American performance of Ian Parrott's Theme and Six Variants was ptayed by Eunice Eaton, pianist, last night in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 20--There are five American citizens in addition to the President who particularly realized the political importance of Mr. Truman's April 13 statement to his press conference about current "prosperity."
ALBANY, April 20--Several bills making pay increases and additional retirement benefits mandatory for different groups of New York City school teachers were vetoed today by Governor Dewey.

A series of Italian feature-films with English subtitles will be presented by WOR-TV, beginning Saturday, April 29, at 5:30 P. M. The initial showing will feature the musical drama, "La Traviata," based on Verdi's opera, with Maria Cebotari in the starring role.

The threat of a two-coast general maritime strike lessened somewhat last night as reports from the negotiations between East and Gulf Coast shipowners and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., indicated more hopefulness.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP)-- Five Government witnesses swore today that John Maragon, onetime White House habitue, has passed himself off as an agent for Presidential aide Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan while communicating with Federal agencies for private companies.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Brig. Gen. James P.S. Devereux, retired, hero of the Marine Corps' gallant but unsuccessful defense of Wake Island in the early stages of the Pacific War, announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination to the House of Represantatives from the Second Maryland District.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The Twentieth Century Fund and the National Planning Association joined today in a warning that unless a workable substitute for the European Recovery Program could be found before 1952, its abrupt ending "might precipitate a crisis fraught with grave dangers to world peace."

Senator William Benton of Connecticut was honored at a testimonial dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night, at which he was lauded as the driving force behind the Voice of America and for his advocacy of a "Marshall Plan in the field of ideas" as a means of achieving world peace.
The Peace Treaty with Italy, which entered into force on Sept. 15, 1947, envisages the formation of the Free Territory of Trieste.

As Brooklyn's racket investigating grand jury returned an indictment yesterday against three more persons, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County announced that policemen formerly attached to the Nineteenth Division in Brooklyn would be subpoenaed to appear before the grand jury on Monday.

A plan serving the twin purposes of getting the United States represented in the equestrian competition at the 1952 Olympics and filling the void at the big fall indoor horse shows left through the disbanding of the United States Army team was announced yesterday.
The Italian demarche to the United Nations Commission on Eritrea, asking again for the independents of that former colony, is doubtless a last desperate card in what is clearly a losing game.

More than 200 artists, trade union and community leaders, social workers and students of the Art School of the Educational Alliance, attended a dinner last night at the alliance, 197 East Broadway, in celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the art school by its director, Abbo Ostrowsky.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 20 --Miss Anna Freud of London, psychoanalyst daughter of Sigmund Freud, founder of psychoanalysis, held her first press conference in the United States today and for an hour answered or parried questions on psychiatric matter ...

BERLIN, April 21--The three western commandants in Berlin approved today the request of the West Berlin City Assembly to hold city-wide free municipal elections. At the same time the Western powers turned on their most powerful propaganda machinery to exploit the proposal.

DAVIS, Calif., April 21--Regents of the University of California today discarded the mandatory nonCommunist loyalty oath that they had prescribed for university employes. In its place, the Regents prescribed for the faculty a form of contract that contained a noncommunist clause.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Tangible evidence of a rapid revival of intra-European trade and a recovery of production in Marshall Plan countries was seen by officials here today in a request of the Netherlands for cancellation of almost half of a $15,000,000 loan granted by the International Bank for Reconstruction ...
ROME, April 21--The Government was severely attacked in the Chamber today for its foreign policy in general and for its handling of the Trieste problem in particular.

CHICAGO, April 21--Grain prices mounted rapidly on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of soybeans, which closed 2 to 4 cents a bushel higher, with the May and July contracts at new seasonal highs. May

WASHINGTON, April 21--Representative William L. Pfeiffer of Kenmore, N. Y., chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, announced today that he would not be a candidate for reelection to Congress from New York's Forty-second District, which includes Niagara County and part of the city of Buffalo.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 21-- Psychologists have failed to provide the understanding of man that the public has a right to expect because they have confined themselves almost exclusively to the study of "isolated individuals, isolated experiences and isolated relationships." Dr. Hadley Cantril ...

CLEVELAND, April 21--The Methodist Federation for Social Action, an organization that in the February issue of Reader's Digest was charged with being friendly to Communist views, was disavowed by the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church today.

Mayor O'Dwyer's anger at the leaders of the Liberal party for failure to endorse him for re-election last year, which he made evident in his speech at the dinner of the Democratic State Committee Wednesday night, shows no sign of abatement, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21-- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, disclosed at his press conference today that he would follow up his talk with President Truman yesterday by calling on British Prime Minister Attlee and French Premier Bidault to discuss the principal disputed issues before the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 21--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to reduce or eliminate excise taxes on furs, jewelry, luggage, handbags and a number of other articles, the revisions involving annual revenue losses estimated at $250,000,000. Taxes on baby oil, powder and lotions would be ended.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer has sent to Congress a detailed memorandum outlining his advocacy of a strong United States merchant marine and promising complete independence of action to the new Federal Maritime Board under the Department of Commerce.

One could almost have guessed that the Russians would seize the opportunity to make a bad situation worse, as they have now done with Trieste. No one knows as well as they that fishing is best in troubled waters.

A glowing account of medieval pageantry to be re-enacted in York, England, in the first fortnight in June next year as part of the Festival of Britain was described yesterday by John Bowes Morrell, Lord Mayor of York, and Arthur S. Rymer, York's Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Prof. Owen Lattimore today derided testimony by Prof. Louis F. Budenz against him and demanded an investigation of a lobby for Pro-Nationalist China which he contended was running "a campaign of character assassination" against all who disagreed with its objectives.

She is not so indispensable as she thinks. At least, she is not so indispensable as she inferred, that no doubt being a form of thought. She has been away for a good long time, now, and everything still is going along nicely.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Potomac Electric Power Company of this city filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $30,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, due on May 1, 1985, and 710,700 shares of common stock, par value $10.

One hundred thousand persons are scheduled to march in the Loyalty Day parade next Saturday on Fifth Avenue, J. Joseph Smith, New York County Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and grand marshal of the parade, said last night.

ARMONK, N. Y., April 21-- Rumsen Farm Bulldozer, liver and white pointer dog belonging to Harry Warne of Frenchtown, N. J., won the open derby today as the annual three-day meet of the Southern New York Field Trial Club began on the Paterno Estate.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 21-- The question of whether King Leopold III should return to Belgium before transferring his royal powers to his son and, if he did, how long he should reign before the transfer took place, held up tonight the signing of an agree

PHILADELPHIA, April 21--Dr. Harold J. McNally, Associate Professor of Education at Columbia University, said here today that democratic living and attitudes of mind could not be taught by requiring teachers to sign loyalty oaths.

For the first time in a decade European and other nations have displaced the United States as the major source of imports by Brazil, Jose Garrido-Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, 551 Fifth Avenue, disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 21--The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen instructed its members today to operate troop, hospital and milk trains in the strike called for next Wednesday against four large railroad systems. But the union warned that mail trains were no different from "any other train."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)-- Following is the text of two State Department statements, one ordering Czechoslovakia to close her Consulate in Chicago and the other demanding an apology for secret police acts against a United States Embassy employe in Prague:

Hailed in a manner befitting world champions, the Yankees interrupted their round-the-clock homecoming reception yesterday to spend three profitable hours in their spacious Stadium just to show the folks exactly how they do it.

The stock market resumed the advance yesterday after Thursday's setback, although emphasis remained on the television issues. Crosscurrents were at work, though, in various sections of the list and, aside from some further share gains by the TV group, the lift for the composite rate held at 0.34 point.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP)-- The Government presented testimony in John Maragon's perjury trial today that the one-time White House intimate got $3,893 in fees from a Chicago perfume company while he was on a State Department mission to Greece.

Officials of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., rejected a management counter proposal yesterday but there were indications that the union's Monday strike deadline might be extended at the request of the state.

HONOLULU, April 21--Samuel W. King, president of Hawaii's State Constitutional Convention, today filed a report with Gov. Ingram M. Stainback on the Convention's action, Thursday night, in ousting Frank G. Silva, delegate from the Island of Kauai.
In this city a fifth of all the hospital beds are unsuitable because they are located in buildings that are not fire-resistant. The greater number are in the Borough of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 21--With the civil-rights issue as a rallying point, some Republicans have been talking of forming their own counterpart of "Americans for Democratic Action" to function inside the G.O.P. and attempt "to liberize, modernize and humanize" its approach to current problems.

ALBANY, April 21--Legislation forever barring the Black River Regulating District from constructing any dams on the south branch Of the Moose River for flood control or power-generating purposes was approved today by Governor Dewey at the urging of sportsmen and conservationists.

WASHINGTON, April 21--The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to suspend reduced railroad rates on iron and steel articles shipped at a minimum of 80,000 pounds in official territory. The rates will go into effect on May 1.

Ben Lee and Manny Rabal have purchased a tract of land in the Sutton Park section of Lawrence, L.I., from D.K. Schwartz and H. Ginsberg and plan to improve it with forty-one large dwellings to be priced at about $26,500. The project will be known as Sutton Estates. Title was insured by the

TOKYO, April 21--Discontent with the State Department has become widespread among Americans working in Asia. In a three-month trip to Formosa and Hong Kong this correspondent found few compatriots who defended present American policies.

JERSEY CITY, April 21--Thirteen exact reproductions of the Liberty Bell arrived here today aboard the American Export Line's steamship, Excalibur, to sound the tocsin for the Treasury Department's Savings Bond Drive, starting May 15.
WASHINGTON, April 21--The House's Buchanan investigating committee looked into the so-called real estate lobby today.
Joe Gould, who managed former heavyweight champion James J. Braddock, died yesterday in his home at 25 Central Park West at the age of 53.
CINCINNATI, April 21--Ambasbassador at Large Philip C. Jessup said here tonight that "Asia was important before Soviet communism began and will be important after it passes from the scene."
WASHINGTON, April 21--The "secrecy policy" of the Atomic Energy Commission was attacked and defended today at the meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

Settlement of the long drawn out contract dispute between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and a deck officers' union was achieved early yesterday morning as the deadline neared for a threatened two-coast stoppage of all waterfront activity. The strike was to have started tonight at midnight.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 21--Dr. Raymond Allen, a trustee of the Institute of Pacific Relations, said here tonight in a speech to the Washington State Editors and Publishers Association that the institute was not and never had been a Communist organization.

The British Automobile and Motorcycle Show at the Grand Central Palace has been of interest from several points of view. In this exhibit the visitor has been able to see in one assembly examples of British craftsmanship ...
Two architects, an engineer and two designers of book jackets are among those responsible for the patterns in a fresh-looking group of fabrics introduced yesterday by L. Anton Maix.

An order temporarily restraining Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians from picketing Station WINS was signed yesterday by Justice Kenneth O'Brien in Supreme Court. The court action also prohibits the musicians from posting pickets at places where WINS programs originate, such as Yankee Stadium and night clubs.
Jay Robinson, the Le Beau in the current production of "As You Like It," is planning a revival of "The Green Bay Tree" for Broadway next fall.

An official of the United States Department of Agriculture announced yesterday that an immediate investigation would be made of a report that the Board of Education of Belleville, N.J., had been dumping foodstuffs that the Belleville High School cafeteria received under the Federal school lunch program.

The Traffic Commission postponed yesterday the effective date of the daytime ban on big trucks in the garment area for seven weeks. It set the new date as June 17 and warned that no further extension would be granted.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 21-- Extracts from the adrenal glands of cattle have been used successfully to convert an inert substance, originally derived from soya beans, into the most sought-after and most active form of cortisone produced by the human adrenals, it was reported today at the annual meeting here of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

In a garden setting of spring flower's and greens, Miss Sylvia Wigglesworth Maitland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Maitland of 755 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Martin McGregor Horner of Woodmere, L. I., son of Mrs. Louis J. Horner of Newark, ...

LONDON, April 21--London's cabbies, whose fares have not been raised since 1933, were told today that beginning Monday they could charge an extra threepence for every ride to compensate for the higher cost of gasoline since Sir Stafford Cripps in his budget raised the tax by ninepence a gallon.

ROME, April 21--There is a distinct possibility that Adam Stephen Cardinal Sapieha, Archbishop of Cracow, may be refused permission to re-enter Poland, according to well-informed Roman Catholic circles.

HONG KONG, Saturday, April 22--While the Nationalists last night officially reported complete victory over the Communist forces invading Hainan and the capture of two Russians "attached to the Communist invading party," unofficial sources close to the Nationalists ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) --Philadelphia honored Connie Mack today as the 87-year-old patriarch showed the home folks his fiftieth edition of the Philadelphia Athletics--the team he hopes will bring him that long-sought "one more pennant."
WASHINGTON, April 21--The House ended its first week of voting on the $29,000,000,000 omnibus appropriations bill today with the economy drive yet to make any significant headway.

HAVANA, April 20--The Cabinet recognized today the debt owed by the Government to the United Railways of Havana as a means of facilitating the sale of these properties to a group of Americans and Cubans who now are negotiating with the British owners.
Among current offerings of especial interest in New York galieries are five exhibitions of paintings.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 22--A United States Air Force C-54 plane carrying thirty-five persons crashed last night into a mountainside sixty miles southwest' of Tokyo in the general region of Mount Fuji.

TOKYO, April 21--Opposition parties in the Japanese Diet today accused the conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida and inferentially Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters of "trampling" the post-war constitution and creating anti-American feeling in Japan through a policy of railroading unpopular legislative measures.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21--The Social Commission of the United Nations today voted to give a new lease on life to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.
An undetermined number of telephone workers left their jobs yesterday in several parts of the country in what was described as the possible beginning of the longthreatened national strike.
Futures pushed upward on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 2 points lower to 37 points higher on the day, with the far months showing the greatest strength.

More encouraging fishing news is arriving from both the North and South, for Maine lakes are clearing quite rapidly and the channel bass are making life interesting for early season anglers at Oregon Inlet on the North Carolina coast.
Business management was urged yesterday to spend all its income, if necessary, to "save the American way of life" from political power-seekers.
The Soviet Union dismissed yesterday as "clearly absurd" the demands contained in the United States note charging that Russian fighters had shot down an unarmed United States Navy

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP)--Bob Rush, hurling his way out of repeated jams in the early innings, outdueled Harry (The Cat) Brecheen to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 2-0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals in their home opener before 22,137 today.
LONDON, April 21--The threeday-old unofficial London dock strike, which Labor Minister George Isaacs has condemned as Communist-inspired, grew gradually worse today.

Members of the Young Women's Christian Association have been urged to attend churches of their choice tomorrow, when the third annual national Y. W. C. A. week begins. Special sermons will be preached by many clergymen, and Y. W. C. A. speakers will be heard at many church meetings all week.

Strong opposition to all forms of farm subsidies, including the Brannan plan, was voiced officially for the first time yesterday by the National League of Wholesale Fruit and Vegetable Distributors, whose membership includes more than 1,000 growers, shippers and wholesale distributors east of the Mississippi River.

Recent heavy rains and reduced consumption of water on this week's Dry Thursday brought from Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney yesterday a hint that lawn sprinkling and swimming pool bans might be relaxed this summer if present trends continued.
WASHINGTON, April 21--President Truman asked Congress today to continue the rent-control policy to the middle of 1951.

WASHINGTON, April 21--The new administration of the Daughters of the American Revolution, headed by Mrs. James B. Patton of Columbus, Ohio, as president general, was sworn in today with expressions of amity from the opposing factions.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 21-- The engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William O. Dillingham of their daughter, Laura Jeanne, to Cornelius Edmonstone Smyth, son of Cornelius J. Smyth, former Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Smyth of Gainesville, Fla., and New York.

The President's call for a campaign of truth has had wide repercussions. Not only the American press but newspapers in Great Britain, France and other continental countries hail his words with an eagerness that suggests that a high-power crusade to counter Soviet propaganda is overdue.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 21 --The telephone numbers of thirteen New Yorkers who have been phoning bets to New Jersey bookies were given to the New York District Attorney yesterday by Walter G. Winne, Prosecutor of Bergen County, who said that some of the bettors undoubtedly represent gambling interests.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Secretary of State Dean Acheson, surveying the effects of several recent actions by the Soviet Union, expressed his belief today that the world situation was serious and tense, but not yet heading into an armed conflict.
ALBANY, April 21--Governor Dewey came to the end today of his task of approving or vetoing the accumulation of bills left with him by the adjournment of the State Legislature.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 21--Secretary General Trygve Lie, who sought to mediate in many difficult disputes in the United Nations has taken on the job of deciding how much of a increase-- if any--the judges of the International Court of Justice have coming to them.

Ervin J. Bookout has been appointed Eastern sales manager by Cochrane Corporation, Philadelphia, manufacturer of water conditioning equipment and steam power plant specialties.
"Some days," Lippy Leo Durocher used to say when he managed the Dodgers, "a fellow can't lay up a dime."

In his annual report to Governor Dewey, Keith Lorenz, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, maintains that the question of jurisdiction over labor disputes between the national and state boards on labor relations is still so confusing that it is the major problem now facing the latter board.

PINEHURST, N. C. April 21 (UP) --Wynsol K. Spencer of Newport News, Va., blended a cool head and a hot putter into a stunning upset victory over defending champion Frank Stranahan today, 2 and 1, in the semi-finals of the North and South Amateur Golf Tournament.

The University of Michigan's project to honor its 520 gold star sons by establishing a memorial to them in the form of a research institute that is to lift atomic energy to a higher and more beneficent level deserves all the public support that it can muster.
MADRID, April 21--The Protestants of Spain were accused today by the Falangist organ Arriba of keeping their churches going on foreign funds and of proselytizing with political motives.
LONDON, April 21--The Conservatives have decided to challenge the Government on two major aspects of the budget of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
WASHINGTON, April 21--Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, appealed to Congressional leaders today for prompt aid to unemployed workers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 21 (AP)--Allen Griffin, head of a United States economic mission to Southeast Asia, expressed confidence today that the peoples of this area "will show within one year that they reject communism."

DETROIT, April 21--Lynn Patrick permitted his New York Rangers to enjoy a day of comparative rest and relaxation today. The Blue Shirts' coach held a noon practice only for the scrubs who had not been seeing action in the series with the Detroit Red Wings, allowing the regulars to remain off the ice.

Seeking to obtain a finer nylon yarn for 60 gauge full-fashioned stockings, hosiery manufacturers are urging E.I. du Pont de Nemours, Inc., to begin commercial production of 10 denier mono-filament yarn, it was learned yesterday.

The Excelsior Savings Bank sold to the Lodegra Realty Corporation the five-story building containing two stores and thirteen apartments on lot 25 by 100 feet at 1574 Lexington Avenue in a deal negotiated by Louis C. Moser Co. and Pearl V. Morton, co-brokers. The sale was for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $9,000.

Five leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations told President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla of Chile yesterday that the campaign he was waging against communism in his country would be aided if labor rights were "respected" and no "legitimate workers" placed in concentration camps.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21-- "A Rose Is Not a Rose," a forthcoming magazine story by Samson Raphelson, has been acquired for the screen by Metro-GoldwynMayer, the studio disclosed today.

LONDON, April 21--The stock markets ended budget week tonight firmer than had been expected considering the absence of positive incentives in the new budget and the condition of labor unrest on the docks. In fact, there has been a slight lifting of the recent apathy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 21--A Cabinet crisis was forecast in West German Government circles today, reflecting increased discontent with what is regarded as Western Allied "interference" in Bonn's economic affairs.

Six young hoodlums, arrested last March 26 on the upper East Side in connection with alleged assault and robbery of several persons, were arraigned yesterday before General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan on various charges.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Representative Rea Beck Bosone, Democrat of Utah, introduced a bill today "to start the wheels turning to take American Indians off Government wardship."

WASHINGTON, April 21--Secretary of State Dean Acheson dismissed today as "outworn arguments" and "wholly false allegations" Soviet charges that the United States had violated the terms of the Italian Peace Treaty relating to Trieste.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 (AP) --William Goetz' Your Host blistered the track at Keeneland today as he set a new record for seven furlongs and planted himself firmly as a major contender for the Kentucky Derby.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 21 (AP)--A weary, bedraggled old man sat in a cell today awaiting his return to Oregon State Prison after thirty-four flight-filled years of freedom.

Former President Herbert Hoover led a list of individuals and organizations receiving prizes for "speaking up for freedom" from Freedoms Foundations, Inc., in a ceremony here yesterday attended by 100 persons at Town Hall.

Operations of the Childs Company in the first two months this years resulted in a loss of $156,000, followed by an estimated loss of $55,000 in March, stockholders of the restaurant chain were informed yesterday at their annual meeting here.

Percy G.B. Gilkes started his fifty-ninth year yesterday as a Federal Government employe. He is the chief clerk of the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

Twenty-five in number, ranging in age from 8 to 14, dressed in striped trousers and cut-down dinner jackets with black ties, the young men of the Mexico City Boys Choir made their first appearance last night in Carnegie Hall.

At the annual meeting of Brown Bigelow yesterday in Chicago, Charles A. Ward, president, attributed the record net profit of $2,909,517 for the fiscal year ended with last January directly to planned cost and expense reductions.

The Big Show went to Bellevue yesterday morning for the fortysixth consecutive year. The breezes were sharp and the sun played hide-and-seek, but that was of small account to the record-breaking crowd of 6,000 young and old, the majority of whom forgot their pains as the circus worked its magic.

WASHINGTON, April 21--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on April 18, according to the Bureau of Labor statistics. The index was 152.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent above four weeks ago and 2.8 per cent below the comparable week of 1949.
Persons who write letters to judges denouncing them for a decision or for failure to render one quickly enough were criticized bitterly from the bench yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

The chips are down at scale weights in the $40,000 added Wood Memorial today. Eleven colts, each carrying 126 pounds, and one filly, who gets a sex allowance and will take up 121, are in Jamaica's most important spring stakes, for 3year-olds. Nine of the entrants are Kentucky Derby nominees.

By selling cakes and pies she baked at home, Mrs. Helen Scott of Stamford, Conn., has earned an average of $45 a week for the last three years. She tells about it in a booklet designed to guide other housewives who wish to supplement the family income but who don't want to work away from home.
ALBANY, April 21--The Board of Regents formally appointed Dr. Lewis A. Wilson today as acting Commissioner of Education and acting president of the University of the State of New York.

BALTIMORE, April 21--Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said today he doesn't fear communism, fascism or socialism, but he does fear the dead hand of polities on American business.

HONG KONG, Sunday, April 23--The Nationalist situation on Hainan deteriorated rapidly last night. Private reports from the island said that the top military and political leaders had fled Hoihow, the capital, by ship and plane during the afternoon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22-- A campaign, centering in Rhode Island, where more than 60 per cent of the Leavers lace industry in America is concentrated, has been started to make lace a permanent factor in feminine fashions. Group exhibitions dominate the many art shows scheduled for this week. Of outstanding interest is the eighth annual exhibition of work by the Audubon Artists, opening on Thursday at the National Academy.

It is a long-standing tradition among leaders of the political Opposition in Britain that, however outspoken their criticism of the Government may be when they are at home, they are expected to refrain from such attacks once they are outside the country.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP)--Lefthander Billy Pierce turned in a brilliant relief pitching job today as the Chicago White Sox beat the Detroit Tigers, 5--4, to snap Detroit's four-game winning streak. It was Chicago's first victory in five starts.

A radio description of the running of the Kentucky Derby will be carried by the Columbia Broadcasting System from Churchill Downs on Saturday, May 6, from 5:15 to 5:45 P.M. A film recording of the classic also will be presented over the C.B.S. television network the next day at 10:30 P.M.
With rain spreading a wet blanket over the local theatre of baseball operations, Greater New York's three major league entries prepared themselves last night for the third shift in the 1950 schedule.

While gross time charges for the major television networks continued to show comparatively large gains in recent months, they have not seriously cut into network radio time charges, according to figures released over the week-end by Publishers Information Bureau.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, April 24 (AP)--A Swedish Coast Guard official said today a book in English containing a list of radio stations and a piece of wood marked "Made in the United States" have been found in the Baltic, east of the Island of Oeland.

CHICAGO, April 23--Bullish enthusiasm ran high on the Board of Trade last week, with all deliveries of wheat except December and all futures in corn and soybeans selling at new high prices for the crop year to date, May soybeans going into new ground for any delivery since December, 1948.

The year 1949 was the "worst employment year in the shipping industry since 1923," with thousands of seamen "on the beach" and many officers forced to ship as unlicensed personnel to obtain jobs, according to the annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.
ROME, April 23 (UP)--Twothirds of Italy's shipyards are idle today, although thirty-four ships-- including twelve for foreign buyers --are on the ways or in the final stages of commission.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony passed another milestone over the week-end. It completed its 108th season by giving its 4,844th and 4,845th concerts. Dimitri Mitropoulos, who will be the musical director next season, was the conductor.

Domestic cotton prices moved into new high ground for the current session last week, and at the close of trading on the Cotton Exchange on Saturday, active futures contracts were up four to eightynine points.

ATLANTA, April 23 (AP)--William A. Alexander, head football coach at Georgia Tech for twentyfive years, died in his sleep today. The 60-year-old mentor, who had suffered several heart attacks in the last year, was found dead by his wife this morning. He had retired early after watching a Tech scrimmage session yesterday afternoon.
The appointment of Martin J. Winsch as passenger traffic manager of Boyd, Weir Sewell, steamship agents and ship brokers, was announced yesterday by James M. Spagnoli, vice president of the company.
VIENNA, April 23--Msgr. Franz Jachym created a sensation today when he refused in front of the altar of Saint Stephen's Cathedral to be consecrated a Roman Catholic Bishop.

The search for evidence of graft paid to the police by Brooklyn gamblers has resulted in the seizure of the bank account records of several plainclothes policemen for study by investigators for District Attorney Miles F. McDonald, it was learned yesterday.

(Jack) Coffey, graduate manager of athletics.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stelle Brown of 133 East Eightieth Street, and Tranquillity Farm, Asheville, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lathrop, to Maxwell Evarts Cox, son of Mrs. Archibald Cox of Plainfield, N.J., and Forbes House, Windsor, Vt., and the late Mr. Cox.

BERLIN, April 23--Protestant and Catholic clergy in the Soviet zone of Germany united today in the most vigorous, outspoken attack on Russian communism since the Red-controlled Eastern German Government was organized less than a year ago.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) had a consolidated net income last year of $268,869,501 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $8.91 each on the 30,183,394 capital shares outstanding, according to the annual report issued for publication today. This compares with $365,604,976, or $12.44 each on 29,385,435 shares, in 1948. Gross income was $2,934,685,762, compared with $3,332,187,275.

Mary Davenport, a statuesque young American contralto with a silken voice of exceptional range and beauty, made a successful New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It should mean a big step forward in a career that already had started promisingly.
Customs collections in the Port of New York last month were $3,500,000 higher than receipts in February and $1,489,000 above March, 1949, Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, announced yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 23-- Adding another blue ribbon to the four she carried off yesterday, Circus Rose, the surprising 5-year-old Virginia-bred gray mare, was named jumping champion as the two-day twentieth annual Boulder Brook spring horse show came to a close in the Club's riding hall tonight.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 23--West Germany's industrial output has climbed back to its pre-war level, an official announcement said today.

PITTSBURGH, April 23--Steel sales people last week were a little flabbergasted at the amount of new steel business. They had expected to be quite busy, but the realization of how much the steel strike last fall and the coal strike early this year had cost in delayed deliveries was an eye-opener.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 23--Parliament, which opens here tomorrow, will be called upon to form for the first time a national state made up predominantly of Palestinian Arabs.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23 (AP)--The second bombing of a Negro home in ten days has brought an all-out police investigation and a call for action by Birmingham's "right-thinking citizenship."

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that for the first time the board has acquired space in two privately owned housing developments in which to conduct classes for kindergarten and elementary grade children living in or near the projects.

After seven rounds of the world championship challengers' chess tournament in Budapest, with a total of four games adjourned, Isaac Boleslavsky, David Bronstein and Paul Keres, all Soviet players, were still in a triple tie fox first place, according to a report from Hungary yesterday.
Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, celled for additional efforts to establish real world peace.

Alan O. Mann has been named assistant to William N. Freyer, vice president and assistant to the president of Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc. Thomas B. Nestor and Vincent Petillo will assist Mr. Mann.

CINCINNATI, April 23--The American Council for Judaism went on record in a series of resolutions here today condemning every phase of the Zionist movement in this country, including one that denounced the "efforts of Zionist leaders to stimulate the emigration of Americans of Jewish faith to Israel."

"THIS volume, like the others, claims only to be a contribution to the history of the Second World War." These modest words were written by Winston Churchill in his preface to "The Grand Alliance,"* which is the third volume of his majestic "The Second World War." Mr. Churchill is right. This is only a contribution. The final word may never be written.

WASHINGTON, April 23--An economist for the Brookings Institution, a private research organization, declared today that United States participation in the International Trade Organization would be in the best long-term interests of the country.

Water storage in the city's upstate reservoirs increased by 914,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday. At that hour the reservoirs held 203,744,000,000 gallons, or 80.5 per cent of capacity; this compared with 249,731,000,000 gallons a year ago, when they were filled to 98.7 per cent of capacity.

Compulsory licensing of all American patents, as now proposed in Congress, would work to the detriment of individual inventors and small manufacturers, according to T. Last night the Ballet Theatre returned to the Center Theatre where ten years ago it made its momentous bow to the world, and if the occasion was necessarily less sensational in character, it was nevertheless a very welcome one, indeed. LOUIS, April 23 (AP)-- Pitcher Bob Lemon hurled the Cleveland Indians to a 9-6 victory over the St. Louis Browns in the opener of a double-header here today and then homered as a pinchhitter in the second game to spark his team to a 7-5 triumph called at the end of the seventh because of darkness.

William M. Schuyler, editor of The American Year Book, and a director of its publishers, Thomas Nelson Sons, died Friday night of a heart attack in his apartment at the Margaret Hotel, Brooklyn. Asserting that a three-party coalition offered the only chance of defeating Representative Vito Marcantonio, John Ellis, who ran against him two years ago on the Republican and Liberal party tickets, announced yesterday that he was available for a coalition nomination.

BERLIN, April 23 (AP)--The Russians are waging a purge in the Baltic republics to protect coastal defense secrets in the general area where they charge an American plane attempted to make photographs, the official United States newspaper here reported today.

"Peter Pan," sub-titled "The Boy Who Would Not Grow Up," has entertained countless youngsters, let alone their elders, since London first witnessed it in 1904. Through the efforts of Peter Lawrence and R.L. Stevens, the James M. Barrie classic will be revived tonight at the Imperial, starting at 8 o'clock.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 --William Powell, inactive for nearly a year, has been assigned by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to the chief role in "Interruptions; Interruptions," one of the subjects to be included in the studio's package film, "Big Country."

AMSTERDAM, April 23--Annual reports of Dutch industrial concerns show that the favorable trend begun in 1948 continues. The point that is stressed is that prices for Dutch goods compare more than favorably with those of foreign goods, so that any freer European commercial traffic would be of definite benefit to Holland.

Interest in ready-to-wear and accessories centered upon promotional items suitable for summer selling last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Dress departments were seeking dark sheers, light-weight satins, tissue failles and organdies for May and June selling.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP)-- The Pirates today literally walked over Cincinnati, 5--3, for their fifth victory in a row as five passes in the sixth inning provided the Bucs' winning margin. Wally Westlake delighted the 18,049 fans, by slamming his fourth home run in three days.
MADRID, April 23--The Spanish Government is preparing new efforts to obtain the release of Spanish war prisoners still held in the Soviet Union, according to well informed sources here.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) --Tom Wright, substituting for the ailing Ted Williams, and Al (Zeke) Zarilla each made three hits and Lefty Mel Parnell pitched a sixhitter to give the Red Sox a 12to-2 victory over the Athletics and an even break in a twin bill at Shibe Park today.

Retirement from Columbia Uni versity's Teachers College eight years ago as Professor Emeritus of Education didn't mean a rest for Dr. George D. Strayer. The 73year-old educator, widely conceded to know more than any other man about the nation's public school system, recently completed his fiftieth major educational survey, a six-month study of the university system of Georgia.

More than 150 examples of Danish porcelain from the factory of Bing Grondahl in Copenhagen are included in an exhibit opening this morning on the fourth-floor gallery of Black, Starr Gorham, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. The showing will continue through Saturday.
A plea for sympathetic understanding and intelligent help for the nation's 300,000 voiceless and inert children who are victims of cerebral palsy was voiced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board disclosed today that it would seek continued operation of the Aleutian air bases needed to fly Northwest Airlines' route to the Orient by way of Alaska.

LONDON, April 24--As the last major speaker for the Conservatives in the debate on the budget, Winston Churchill made it clear tonight that there was no fooling about the test of party strength that is coming up Wednesday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24-- Broderick Crawford will play the leading role in "The Seeker and the Sought" at Columbia after he finishes "Born Yesterday" if Sid ney Buchman's plans for the project are carried out, it was learned today.

At its maintenance base at San Francisco, Pan American World Airways has adopted a new-type "vertical build-up stands" that suspend 5,000-pound aircraft engines in such a way that mechanics performing overhauls and inspections can rotate the engines with their fingertips.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Two men directly concerned with administration of Federal rent control since its inception told the Senate today that there was an impelling need to continue regulation at least for another year.

The printing industry in the United States should be more centralized to facilitate improvement research, C.E. Kenneth Mees, director of research of the Eastman Kodak Company, said in an address yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 24--National insistence on maintaining protected agricultural markets has become the largest single obstacle to further progress toward European economic integration.

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for April will be lower than for the month a year ago because of one less shopping day, Robert E. Wood, chairman, informed stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Apri1 24 --Ring Lardner Jr., the motion picture writer, advertised his ten-room beach home for sale today under the heading "Owner Going to Jail."
If Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower ever accepts a nomination for the Presidency he will be certain of the support of the man who helped him get his appointment to the United States Military Academy.

With the first spring breezes the urge to move outdoors suddenly takes hold. Homemakers catering to their family's whims will find a tremendous variety of furniture available for summer use, from inexpensive Chinese peel to aluminum in improved designs and luxurious wrought iron and rattan.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 24 (AP)--The Government short wave radio said tonight that a new spy trial involving five Rumanian citizens formerly employed at the United States and British legations here would open in Bucharest tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 24-- Without a dissenting vote, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights decided today to include in its future international covenant a provision to guarantee to all peoples the right to freedom of expression.

WASHINGTON, April 24--John Foster Dulles, starting his new job as consultant to Secretary of State Dean Acheson, told reporters today he was confident that the American people were again developing the spirit necessary to meet their part of the Soviet challenge.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 2 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 24--A 4-to-4 division by the Supreme Court today sustained the action of a lower tribunal in dismissing an anti-trust suit after the Federal Government would not open Federal Bureau of Investigation secrets.

BERLIN, April 24--Underlying the discussions today at the opening of the Evangelic Church Synod in the Soviet sector was a critical topic of conditions facing the clergy and church members in the territory of the Eastern German Democratic Republic. No statement on them is expected till Thursday or Friday.

Musical artists are continuing to transfer their allegiances back and forth between Columbia Records and RCA Victor records. Risk Stevens and Dorothy Kirsten, both Metropolitan Opera singers, yesterday changed concerns.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 24-- Fire fifty yards from the building housing the University of California's 184-inch atom smasher destroyed a research and engineering structure last night and early today. Nine hours later another blaze, soon extinguished, broke out in a plating shop about 700 yards away.
WASHINGTON, April 24--A return of the corporate excess-profits tax in modified form, but to raise an estimated $1,000,000,000 annually, was proposed to Congress today.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 24--The two houses of Jordan's Parliament, sitting together today at the opening session, voted with some dissensions or abstentions the unification of Arab Palestine and Transjordan into the single Kingdom of Hashemite Jordan.
President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla of Chile called last night for a "last effort" to persuade the Soviet Union to collaborate with the universal security system provided by the United Nations Charter.

The New York City Housing Authority, faced with the biggest mass rent hold-out since it was established a decade ago, started summary proceedings yesterday to evict twenty-three tenants in a West Side development.

Columbia College students cut short their 11 o'clock classes yesterday morning to stage a surprise demonstration in honor of Dr. Harry J. Carman, who must retire as dean June 30 in accordance with university regulations.

Rejection by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations of a proposal made by Local 32 B, Building Service Employes International Union, A.F.L., to arbitrate deadlocked issues, made imminent yesterday a strike by 18,000 building service employes.

"He looks like a big shot," said the picture-gazer, one of a group of youngsters gathered around Katharine B. Ford, guide of schoolchildren, on a visit to the Vienna art treasures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 24--Financial advisers to the Allied High Commission met with Dr. Fritz Schaeffer, Finance Minister of the Federal Republic, this evening in the first attempt to redraft the German tax law rejected by the High Commission last week, an action that created a crisis in the relations between the Western Allies and the Germans.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 24-- Informed circles understand the two and a half year old Kashmir dispute will be the main topic of discussion between Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Pakistani Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan in their two-day meeting here beginning Wednesday.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced last night that his office had begun an investigation to determine whether current "erroneous reports" that The New York Herald Tribune was on the verge of being sold were "part of a systematic campaign" in violation of state law.

The shooting down of a plane carrying ten unarmed American airmen by Soviet fliers over the Baltic calls attention again to the tragedy that has overwhelmed the three Baltic nations whose territory is now being converted into a Soviet military base.

A "flash" wave of selling engulfed the stock market yesterday. Some recovery developed under the leadership of the aircrafts. The heaviest pressure was confined to fifteen minutes in the forenoon when the ticker reporting tape was one to two minutes behind floor transactions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 24--State Representative Charles J. Schuh Jr., floor leader for Gov. Fuller Warren in the House of Representatives last year, was shot and killed this morning in his law office here by a 71-year-old itinerant worker.

CHICAGO, April 24--Spyros Skouras, president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, declared here today that television and the movies, by linking fortunes, will launch a "golden era for theatres unlike any they have ever known."

BOSTON, April 24--Times have changed for the Dodgers in Boston, where their luck used to be mostly bad. Tonight, while 18,478 Hub fans, ignoring the cold, yelled wildly for a ninth-inning rally to come through, the Brooks emerged with a 6-4 victory, thanks to the superb knuckle-ball relief pitching of Willie Ramsdell.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday questioned six teachers--all active members of the Teachers Union-- regarding membership in the Communist party. A seventh teacher, the union's president, was scheduled to appear before Dr. Jansen, but the appointment was changed to today.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 24--The opponents of the welfare state want "welfare," but for themselves in the form of Government subsidies to business, it was charged tonight by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Minnesota Democrat.

DUMBARTON, Scotland, April 24--In tomorrow's Parliamentary by-election here, the people of this Scottish constituency, which sprawls around Loch Lomond, will render the first representative public verdict on the results of the general election and perhaps on the new budget.
