WASHINGTON, April 24 (U.P.)-- Dean Rusk, Deputy Under-Secretary of State, revealed today that this Government and the Philippines were negotiating a broad program aimed at restoring internal order in the islands and bolstering the sagging Philippine economy.

Two of the leading Republican county organizations in the state moved yesterday to persuade Governor Dewey to run for a third term. The moves were taken in the face of the Governor's known reluctance.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Senate Finance Committee reached a first major decision today on the Administration bill to expand the nation's Social Security system by agreeing that 7,000,000 more workers should be covered on a compulsory basis and 1,500,000 more if they chose.
Gay play and casual fashions provided the cue for a showing of California designs yesterday at Gimbels.
The Greater New York Fund campaign for $8,000,000 to meet the costs of 423 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies was opened last night with a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The water situation has taken a turn for the worse, with consumption increasing two weeks in a row for the first time since midFebruary, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24--A second-straight afternoon of idleness awaited the Yankees when they moved to the City of Brotherly Love today to begin a two-game set with the Athletics. When they detrained at the North Philadelphia Station, shortly before noon, the world champions were informed that Connie Mack already had called off the game.

Bank Account, fast-stepping daughter of the famous Shut Out, brought her owner, Edward M. O'Brien, a big thrill yesterday when she scampered to victory in the featured $10,000 added Rosedale Stakes at Jamaica before a crowd of 22,031.
A combination of hail, rain and cold forestalled plans for a Giant reception to Eddie Sawyer's Phillies yesterday at the Polo Grounds without any visible show of regret from Manager Leo Durocher.

LONDON, April 24--As preparations began in London today for the series of meetings that will be held next month by the United States, British and French Foreign Ministers, Western diplomats emphasized that the proceedings should be considered as "talks" and not a formal conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 24-- Warren R. Austin, chief United States representative to the United Nations, said today that "the United States will not allow war to occur, and she will maintain peace because nobody will dare start one."

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 24-- Israel is not prepared to accept Jordan's annexation of eastern Palestine as fait accompli on the part of King Abdullah. In view of the Jordanian-British alliance acceptance would be viewed here as meaning sanctioning British military bases right up to Israel's frontiers.

Plans by David Heilweil and Derrick Lynn-Thomas to establish "theatre-in-the-round" presentations in the ballroom of the Hotel Edison are progressing. Contracts to book the hotel space have been drawn and are expected to be signed within forty-eight hours, it was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Lynn-Thomas.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24-- While Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, on a speech-making tour in Bihar State, warned India today that the country was at a crucial stage in its history, favorable developments in the relations between India and Pakistan continued to appear in various parts of the country.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP)--Three members, Denver, Sheboygan, Wis., and Waterloo, Iowa, today quit the National Basketball Association and immediately announced plans for an eight-or ten-team rival circuit.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The National Mediation Board announced tonight that the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen had postponed its strike on four railroads for two weeks at the Government's request.

WASHINGTON, April 24--President. Truman declared tonight that no known Communist had a Government job, and he challenged any one asserting otherwise to come forward with facts.

The Board of Estimate voted at an executive session yesterday to increase the proposed 1950-51 executive budget by $2,630,672, to bring it to $1,246,082,466. Even before the addition the budget was at a record total.

PORT ISABEL, Tex., April 24 (AP)--Five Texas shrimping trawlers seized by a Mexican Government gunboat were taken into the Tampico, Mexico, harbor at daybreak today. Mexico alleges that they were caught fishing in Mexican territorial waters. The boats, from Port Isabel and Brownsville, were seized yesterday.

DETROIT, April 24--The Detroit Red Wings celebrated practically all around the clock today. They won the Stanley Cup and they put the historic trophy to use often, filling it over and over again with what the poet called "the 'prisoned laughter of the peasant girls of France."

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, advocated today Federal prohibition of the interstate transmission of horse race odds, bets and track prices paid for any purpose whatever, including publication in bona fide newspapers.

BILL ALEXANDER of Georgia Tech was one of football's Old Guard. He ranked at the top as a strategist and as a gentleman. For a quarter of a century he coached the famed Rambling Wreck of Georgia Tech. Although only losing coaches are traditionally supposed to build character, the kindly Alexander built character and won far more than his share of games.

City rainmakers refused again yesterday to take credit for the rainfall over the watersheds that followed the third experiment by ground crews in spraying clouds with silver-iodide. However, Dr. Wallace E. Howell, the city's rainmaking consultant, said that a "quick casual check" indicated that the rainfall was heavier over the watersheds than in surrounding areas.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 26-- The nation's chronically ill, now totaling 26,500,000 persons, will rise to 30,000,000 by 1980 if current trends continue, Dr. W. Palmer Dearing, deputy surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, predicted today.
BAYPORT, L.I., April 26--Federal Judge Murray Hulbert died here today in his country home. He would have been 66 years old on May 14.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- President Truman unveiled tonight in the National Press Club a plaque listing twenty-five American and Allied war correspondents who were killed in the Pacific Theatre of Operations in World War II.

Evan Hill, a journalism student at Boston University, received $500 cash and a gold medal yesterday as first prize winner in the ninth annual journalism contest conducted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

TOKYO, April 20--Japanese shipping interests increasingly are pressing the United States for an opportunity to recapture the share of the international overseas carrying trade lost to Japan by the Pacific war.

WASHINGTON, April 26--"Underground" agents of free, democratic trade unionism flourish in Communist China despite severe repression by the Communist regime, according to an authoritative source. This informant disclosed today some of the methods used by the Communists in seeking to dominate the lives of the Chinese workers.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts is considering receiving bids May 17 on an issue of $20,000,000 of bonds maturing serially over twenty years.

A survey of marketing possibilities in the principal ale markets in this country by a top official of the English concern of Bass, Ratcliff Gretton, Ltd., producer of Bass' Ale, brought reports here yesterday that production here is under consideration.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Camille Gutt, chairman of the board of directors and managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was among a group of fund dignitaries who left here today for Cuba to participate in ceremonies connected with the opening of the new National Bank of Cuba. Fund officials are interested ...
A bright future in terms of increased advertising volume was depicted yesterday for the nation's newspapers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 --Hobart Cavanaugh, stage and screen character actor, died late last night at the hospital of the Motion Picture Country Home here. His age was 63. With him at the time were his wife, the former Florence Heston, and a daughter, Patricia.

HARTFORD, April 26--Larry Adler, harmonica player accused by a Greenwich, Conn., housewife of strong Communist sympathies, denied today in United States District Court that he had ever been a Communist, a pro-Communist, a traitor, or a Communist sympathizer.

Supporting their teachers' salary demands, 10,000 screaming high school students took part in a series of day-long demonstrations yesterday. Three thousand thronged a barricaded City Hall Park that was guarded by 100 foot and mounted policemen. One jeering group attempted to charge the Hall itself in a vain attempt to see Mayor O'Dwyer.

NEW DELHI, India, April 26-- The warm reception for Indian Prime Minister Nehru in Karachi today is believed here to have helped cement a new friendly relationship between the two neighboring countries.
If Mayor O'Dwyer really wants to find someone to make it rain maybe he ought to visit Kansas on his next vacation.

Many entertained with parties at the "Gay Thirties" dinner dance held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York. Proceeds will further the work of the beneficiary, which ...

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 26-- A ban on the construction of "look alike" houses here was adopted early this morning by the village board after a public hearing held last night. Officials said they knew of no exact precedent for the ...

The modified 1950-51 budget of $1,246,082,466, which was approved informally by the Board of Estimate at an executive meeting last Monday, remained unchanged yesterday after the board had held another closed session.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 26--Developments in Iraq, an increasing hostility to the United States in Syria, and an unencouraging outlook for dollar oil in Europe and other soft currency areas indicate trouble for the large desert oil interests of the United States on the Persian Gulf.

With prospective deficits for 1950 and 1951 looming larger and larger, the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives seems to be in full flight before the pressure for tax reduction. On Thursday and Friday of last week the committee went ...

A record attendance of stockholders at the General Foods Corporation annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday, about two-thirds of them women, were told that first quarter earnings were higher than a year ago and that 1950 "looks promising."

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Securities and Exchange Commission fixed May 3 today as the last date upon which interested parties might request a hearing on the $58,000,000 bond financing proposal of the Ohio Edison Company of Akron.

LONDON, April 26--Britain's Labor Government survived a combined assault tonight by the Conservatives and Liberals. The Government had a majority of five on two critical votes. The issues were related.

The sale by the Ednaloy Realty Corporation of the twelve-story store and loft building at 49 to 53 East Twenty-third Street to the Fabriton Corporation for investment was announced yesterday by Rossbach Associates, Inc., the brokers in the transaction.

TOKYO, April 26--In a major political move, Japanese opposition parties today formed a united front to oppose a separate peace treaty between Japan and the West excluding the Soviet Union and Communist China and a grant of defense bases here to the United States in exchange for a security guarantee.

ALBANY, April 26--Governor Dewey approved today the master plan of the State University Trustees for establishing four-year liberal arts colleges at Plattsburg and Endicott, and two-year community colleges at Middletown and Jamestown.
John J. Huber, missing witness of the Senate subcommittee investigating Senator McCarthy's charges, telephoned his wife last night that he was going away for a month "to get away from it all."

The first resounding shot in the 1950 waterfowl battle has just been fired by Ducks Unlimited, an extremely conservative conservation organization which has taken issue with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for its conflicting statements on the status of waterfowl on the continent.

Buoyancy was visible in the market for Government bonds yesterday as a consequence of Treasury Secretary Snyder's announcement that the Government apprehends no need for deficit financing during the present fiscal period beyond continued additional $100,000,000 weekly borrowings on discount bills.

Brooklyn College's cellar-dwelling nine tossed a slight scare at heavily favored Manhattan College before bowing to the Jaspers, 16--10, in their Metropolitan Conference game yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The losers made ten misplays and Manhattan seven.

Leroy W. Baldwin, chairman of the board and a founder of the Empire Trust Company, who died March 6, 1939, at the age of 72, left assets of $10,020 and debts of $2,778,000, according to an accountfiled in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 26--Albert W. Haigh, 72 years old, retired lawyer, banker and public official of this city and Westchester County, was found shot dead here this afternoon on the roof of an apartment house where he lived at 50 North Broadway.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 (AP) --Three more changes took place today in the all-events and doubles at the American Bowling Congress tourney.

LONDON, April 26--The Labor party squeaked through to narrow victory today in the Parliamentary by-election in West Dumbartonshire, Scotland. The Labor candidate, Thomas Steele, formerly Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of National Insurance, defeated his Conservative rival, Comdr. Robert Allan, by 293 votes out of a total poll of 48,468.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP)--E. Lee Keyser, whose colorful career stretched from peanut vendor to recognition as the "father of night baseball," died today at the age of 64.

Some hints on how to launder the new "wonder" fabrics appearing now in everything from children's clothes to curtains and blankets were offered yesterday by M. Antoinette Falcone, manager of the Bureau of Standards of the Associated Merchandising Corporation.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, April 26 (AP)--A proxy count delayed a showdown until tomorrow at least in the battle for control of Portsmouth Steel Corporation's assets.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Government's argument for a civil contempt verdict against the United Mine Workers ran into doubt and skepticism in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today.
The National Travelers Aid Society lacks sufficient funds to continue its displaced persons program beyond June 1, Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw, society president, declared yesterday.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States commander in Berlin, will join forces with the National Committee for a Free Europe in backing the appeal, made to the American Society of Newspaper Editors by President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson, for non-governmental aid in the "battle for men's minds."

Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been appointed paying agent in New York City for principal and interest of the following municipal bond issues: $1,000,000 City of Memphis, Tenn., board of education general liability coupon bonds; $2,000,000 county of Onondaga, N.Y., county war memorial bonds; $15,485,000 city of Seattle, Wash., municipal light and power ...

The lunch bell rang a little early yesterday at the Wadleigh High School nursery. Little Ira, who is only 3 years old, rotund and rambunctious, couldn't control himself --he was hungry and determined to eat.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Two comments on the briefs filed in the Supreme Court by the Attorneys General of twelve states in the cases which challenge segregated education sufficiently reveal the basic difference in the approach of the contending parties to the issue.

WASHINGTON, April 26--A big-time dopester of betting odds on contests ranging from Presidential elections to horse races told a Senate investigating subcommittee today, in effect, that the Administration's proposed move to put bookmakers out of business would fail.

Senator Harry F. Byrd, Virginia Democrat, asserted last night that adoption of President Truman's program, now before Congress, would "commit us irrevocably to a socialistic state from which there can be no retreat."

WASHINGTON, April 26--Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States, will testify tomorrow before a Senate subcommittee that is investigating Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of communism in the State Department.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 26--The United States Army will train soon more than 1,600 officers and men of the armed forces of seven European nations receiving military equipment under the Mutual Defense Assistance Program. European Command Headquarters here announced this today.
Let no junior miss mourn for a lack of style at budget prices when B. Altman Co. can put forth such an array of low-priced, young summer fashions as the store exhibited yesterday.

Tonight's events: "Don Giovanni," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Lydia Chaliapin, song recital, with Tamara Bering, Susie Matthews, Tassia Bertain, Regina Price and Raina Semeonova, singers, Town Hall, 8:30; Lidia Mendelson, piano, Times Hall, 8:30.

Burlington Mills collection of fabrics and products made of Du Pont's new Orlon fiber were placed on display yesterday at the Empire State Building. Representing four years of research and development work, the collection reveals many new end-used possibilities of the acrylic fiber that Du Pont has termed better than nylon.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 (AP)--The still-bright wreckage of a retractable landing gear, scarred by what might have been bullets, appeared tonight to be the most important clue yet to the disappearance of a United States Navy Privateer plane.

Plans for the erection of a onestory taxpayer building in Astoria, Queens, were announced yesterday by David S. Meister, realty operator, who reported the purchase of the vacant blockfront on the south side of Thirty-sixth Avenue, between Twenty-first and Twentysecond Streets, in a deal negotiated by Edward Dangler, broker.

Seven more Brooklyn youths were taken into custody last night as the police in that borough continued their campaign to keep boys off the streets. The round-up was the second one in as many nights, with sixteen having been seized Tuesday. Authorities hoped to bring in others today.

MOSCOW, April 26--Pravda described today Secretary of State Dean Acheson's proposed "six lines of action" as constituting a "delirious program for the creation of a world-wide American empire through suppressing the sovereignty of all the peoples of the world and through the unleashing of a new war."

The news that F. Trubee Davison will retire at the end of eighteen years in office as president of the American Museum of Natural History certainly calls for an expression of public gratitude for his services. His interest in the museum was inherited from his ...

Within the next few days, the State Thruway Authority will begin engineering exploration of the feasibility of bridging the Tappan Zee between Nyack and Tarrytown to bring the proposed New Yorkto-Buffalo Thruway from Rockland into Westchester and New York.

CHICAGO, April 26--New-crop deliveries of wheat and May and July corn sold at new high prices for the season on the Board of Trade today, buying of wheat being based on continued dry weather in the Southwest and official reports ...

WASHINGTON, April 26--A new anti-tuberculosis vaccine, prepared from a highly virulent strain of human tuberculosis, that has protected a high percentage of animals against killing doses of the disease, was reported here today at the joint annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association, the American Trudeau Society, and the National Conference of Tuberculosis Secretaries.

The eighth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists opened with a reception and preview last evening in the galleries of the National Academy, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street and, beginning today, will be open to the public daily through May 17.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The United States today ordered the Rumanian Government to close within two weeks its commercial offices in New York.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 26-- Rejecting King Leopold's proposal for his return to Belgium, the Socialists announced today they were resuming "full liberty of action." This was the result of the King's refusal to commit himself to leave the country after having ...

Common trust funds are likely to become more widely established among banks as a result of the United States Supreme Court's decision this week clarifying the procedure on notices for the settlement of accounts.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 --Indonesia hopes to obtain United States and other foreign loans totalling $300,000,000 over a threeyear period for the purchase of general commodities, Premier Mohammed Hatta said in an interview here today. He stated he had discussed the question with United ...

The addition of the 18,000-grosston Europa, which will be operated jointly with the smaller vessel Silver Star, will put the Bernstein Line back into the transatlantic passenger business this summer, Arnold Bernstein, president, said yesterday.

John Morrell, Lord Mayor of York, England, left yesterday morning in a British Overseas Airways plane from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for his home after a visit of a week here. He took with him a variety of American foods, nylon stockings, gloves, and "other things that ladies wear."

Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiaries, processors and distributors of foods products, had a consolidated net income of $2,142,578 for the three months ended March 31, 1950, Joel S. Mitchell, president, announced yesterday. The net is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 61 cents a common share.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Federal agencies plan to intensify the search in European shipbuilding centers for reliable information on foreign shipbuilding costs for use in computing American construction subsidies, it became known today.

Modesty nearly cost Joseph Bosotina his crown yesterday. A glass of milk, however, bribed him into taking off his shirt for an examination that showed he was the new King of Health of the Children's Aid Society.
In an expression of fidelity to American democratic principles, 100,000 persons are expected to march down Fifth Avenue tomorrow in the third annual Loyalty Day parade.

Lone non-claimer on Jamaica's racing program yesterday was a six furlong sprint for 3-year-old fillies that had not won two races. It was a program that provided nary an entry for a race tracker's memory book.

A 1950-51 budget of $1,246,382,466 was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It was the largest in the city's history and the fourth in succession to pass the billion-dollar mark. City officials said it would

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 27--The Russians are clearly seeking to make Germany a "satellite of Soviet power," John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, warned in a formal report on Germany made public today.
Negotiators reported progress yesterday in the effort to adjust differences between long-lines operators and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

LONDON, April 27--In a major move to promote political stability in the Middle East the British Government announced today the simultaneous granting of de jure, or full, recognition to Israel and also of last Monday's act of union between the Kingdom of Jordan and those parts of Arab Palestine under Jordan control.

ALPINE, N.J., April 27--The New Jersey section of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season over the difficult, hilly championship course at Aldecress Country Club today with forty-nine Class A and B players competing.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Dividend payments by corporations last month were up 16 per cent compared with those of March, 1949, the Office of Business Ecomonics of the United States Department of Commerce reported yesterday. For the first quarter

The presence of Margaret Sullavan in "No Sad Songs For Me," a softly affecting little drama which came to the Music Hall yesterday, serves to remind one how sumptuous the talents of this actress are and how foolish it has been to permit her to be absent from the

Business loans made by New York City banks, declining for the sixth successive week, dropped $37,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday, bringing the total cutback during the period to about $250,000,000. Commercial, indus

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 215 West Eighty-eighth Street, occupying a plot 100 by 175 feet at the northeast corner of Broadway, has been sold by Morton M. Rosenfeld and H. Lawrence Herring to clients of Max Weinstein, broker. The building contains eighty-nine apartments and eight stores.

BOSTON, April 27--The inability of Montia Kennedy to field a bunt and a similar laxity by Nap Reyes to hang onto a thrown ball today gave the Braves a 2-1 triumph over the Giants in ten innings at Braves Field before 5,780 chilled but contented witnesses.

A sudden, heavy demand for expensive cuts of beef and pork, which consumers have been avoiding for several weeks, has driven prices up--as much as 7 cents a pound in one instance. It may be that the recent cool weather has stimulated an appetite for meat.

ROME, April 27--Liberalization of trade as a powerful means to bring about the material prosperity of mankind was advocated today by Pope Pius XII in a speech delivered to delegates attending the World Congress of Chambers of Commerce here.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Frank Costello, who described himself as an investor living at 115 Central Park West, New York, told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that no law, Federal or state, would completely wipe out gambling in the United States.

CHICAGO, April 27--The Nineteenth National Packaging Exposition closed today after the record number of 18,500 representatives of companies in all kinds of industry had viewed the latest development in packaging materials, machinery, equipment and services, occupying three-and-a-half acres of display space.
WASHINGTON, April 27--The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company authority to intervene in opposition to a proposal of the New York, New

Using one color througout a room to give illusions or added space is a decorating trick that is being used more and more these days. Bloomingdale's shows that it is an effective method in the new Cy Williams model house at Roslyn, L.I., which will be opened to the public on Sunday.

The net income of the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first quarter of this year approximated $22,000,000, B. B. Jennings, president, told stockholders at their meeting held here yesterday. This would be equivalent to 61 cents each on the 31,801,880 capital shares outstanding.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27 (AP)--Dr. Henry Wadsworth LongFellow Dana, grandson of the poet, was found dead today in the family homestead, where he was custodian of the Longfellow and Dana family records. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 27--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today accepted from the Garden Club of America three ravines newly planted to evergreens at the National Arboretum.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The first definite experimental evidence for the existence of the neutral meson, the most elusive elementary particle of nature that dwells, as it were, on the shadowy borderland of space and time, was reported here today at the annual Washington meeting of the American Physical Society.

Many stores are asking for early deliveries of fall merchandise this year, hoping to show full lines as early as July, members of the Association of Buying Offices disclosed yesterday at a meeting in the Statler Hotel.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27--For the second consecutive year, THE New York TIMES has received the F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and press work.
Twelve hundred persons, including business, professional and civic leaders, attended a dinner last night at the Astor Hotel in honor of Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, national chairman of
Industrial products on which prices are being announced represent the largest general variety on which advances have been made in more than two years, industrial purchasing sources said yesterday.

PARIS, April 27--That the argument for the neutrality of France was worth examination and that alternative policies had proved deceptive in the past, was the theme of a first-page article in Le Monde today by Etienne Gilson, member of the French Academy and writer on history and philosophy.
The Kent-Coffey Manufacturing Company, Lenoir, N.C., will increase prices 4 to 7 per cent across the board immediately, Harold F. Coffey, president, disclosed yesterday. The company is one of the

J. Davis Danforth, executive vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has been elected new chairman of the New York Council of the American Assoication of Advertising Agencies, it was announced yesterday.

Although Mrs. Fashion Consumer has not yet put her sheer summer frock on her back, her winter coat-fleece is already rolling through the mills. At a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc. (Fabrics Division) yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel, designers, manufacturers and store buyers got a comprehensive view of fall fabrics in a striking display.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 27--For the first time in his sixty-four years as a conductor, Arturo Toscanini has directed a concert in Texas. The performance by the touring N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra took place tonight in the city auditorium here before a
Living in New York became a chore yesterday for 225,000 residents in the 754 apartment buildings where service employes walked off their jobs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27 (AP)--The United States District Court here has approved the sale of the Norwalk Tire Company, of Norwalk, to the Aetna Industrial Corporation of New York, subject to confirmation by creditors and holders of stock and debentures of

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is better prepared today "to put its fingers on people who would be dangerous to the internal security of the United States" than at the outbreak of World War II, J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General of the United States, declared here tonight.

"Wabash Avenue," Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor musical, starring Betty Grable and Victor Mature, will have its premiere this morning at the Roxy. Phil Harris, Reninald Gardiner and James Barton are among the featured players. Henry Koster directed and

NEWARK, April 27--A scorching duel with last year's winner ended in victory tonight for Nat Krupnick's aged Liberty Belle in the first phase of the Capt. Charles J. Barrie Jr. Memorial Trophy event for open jumpers that was a highlight of the Newark horse show.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., April 27-- The proposed route for the new Sprain Brook Parkway through crowded lower Westchester County was outlined here today to park and county officials attending the monthly meeting of the State Council of Parks.

LONDON, April 27--Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today that the British Government had agreed to sell its holding of shares in African uranium and copper mines with a view to the resale of some of

Between 8,000 and 10,000 high school students ostensibly backing their teachers' demands for a salary increase defied close to 200 policemen in and around City Hall and Foley Square from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. yesterday.

The alarming increase since the war in propeller shaft failures because of cracking, which has caused concern to shipping men, was discussed here last night by Arthur R. Gatewood, chief engineer surveyor of the American Bureau of Shipping.

BERLIN, April 27--Clergymen of the Synod of the Evangelical Church of Germany closed a fourday session in the Soviet Sector, this afternoon with an unprecedentedly candid appeal to their compatriots to divorce themselves from anti-Semitism and to oppose this spirit "wherever it has newly arisen."

Representative Emanuel Celler has introduced a bill which calls for the revision of our patent laws. Because it is a good bill in many respects nobody has paid much attention to provisions which would authorize the

Collecting an assortment of 15 blows that included two home runs, the Lafayette baseball team completed a successful visit to the N.Y.U. campus yesterday by defeating the Violet, 15 to 6, at Ohio Field. It was the third setback for the New Yorkers in eleven contests.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The periodic re-examination of "overage" drivers was urged today at the closing session of the third Highway Transportation Congress here. These motorists were classified in the same category with accident repeaters, habitual law violators and physically disabled, in the highway safety committee's resolution.

At the fourth anniversary party of the Council Club for Older People, 2828 Broadway, the members learned yesterday that they had chalked up an attendance record of 145,000 daily visits since the club was founded by the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women.
WASHINGTON, April 27--John Foster Dulles, new Republican adviser to the Secretary of State accused American "isolationists' this evening of being "de facto accomplices of Soviet communism.'

The "perfect neutral" for spring and summer accessories this year, according to Larry Horan, designer, of J. J. Slater, is Ecuadorian panama. Heretofore used primarily for hats, this straw has been developed into a line of shoes, bags, belts and bows, introduced by Slater yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The Senate refused by a vote of 42 to 35 today to qualify Spain for Marshall Plan aid and give that country special status as an applicant for loans from the Export-Import Bank. A last minute attempt to influence the outcome by halving the proposed $100,000,000 bank credit proved ineffective.
New York's first major apartment house strike since 1936 began yesterday, halting elevators and effectively tying up all other services in many of Manhattan's most luxurious dwellings.

BONN, Germany, April 27--The establishment of a three-power committee to review the Occupation Statute this summer in anticipation of a later revision giving greater sovereignty to West Germany is being planned here.

World peace will remain insecure until human relations improve to a point where international differences can be settled by peaceful means, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Director of the United Nations Department of Trusteeship, told a meeting last night in International House, 500 Riverside Drive.
CEDARHURST, L.I, April 27-- The marriage of Miss Adele Margaret Timpson, adopted daughter of Miss Margaret Timpson of Longwood Crossing, to Halsey E.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., April 27--Day-long fighter plane sweeps over a 7,500 square mile area of the sandhills of North Carolina put the United States "friendly" forces of Exercise Swarmer in a position tonight to open their entirely air supported assault against "enemy" aggressor forces at dawn tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 27--The National Labor Relations Board today ordered elections May 25 among 100,000 employes of the General Electric Company to determine-bargaining agents.

LIKE another Noble Experiment, baseball's new balk rule is going to be followed in the breach rather than in the observance. Increasing discontent over the enforcement of the "one second" stop provisions of the new code have led the American League--or so the rumors say--to give quiet instructions to its umpires to call balks just as they did in the past, ignoring the one-second halt proscription.

For the fourth time since its inception a few months ago the newly independent Government in Indonesia is faced with rebellion. The South Moluccas have declared their independence of the Jakarta regime, dissatisfied with the course that the new Government is taking.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 27 (AP)--Prime Minister Robert Gor lon Menzies introduced legislation today to outlaw the Communist party in Australia on the ground that it seeks to overhrow the Government.

Moss Hart, Broadway producer, will be the master of ceremonies for a new television quiz show featuring husband-and-wife teams which starts over the National Broadcasting Company Sunday evening from 10:30 to 11 o'clock.

LAHORE, Pakistan, April 24-- Soviet influence gradually is extending southeastward into Central Asia from the U.S.S.R.'s principal base for such operations, Tashkent, the capital of the Uzbek Republic.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 (AP) --Mr. Trouble indicated today that he could be just that a week from Saturday in the Kentucky Derby when he slammed down the Keeneland stretch to beat the favored Oil Capitol in the $27,850 Blue Grass Stakes.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- Charges of "demagoguery" in the White House, "police state" regulation, and "farce" ran through testimony in the Senate today as the advance guard of opposition to extension of rent control got a hearing.

An "epidemic" among engineers, involving an unnamed malady that induces great unwillingness to operate a locomotive the day after tomorrow, threatened the already troubled Long Island Rail Road yesterday.
Declaring that the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation should not be forced to "operate from one crisis to another," Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman said he would decide today how

"Woefully inadequate" library services throughout New York State deprive 2,280,000 rural residents of all access to lending facilities and give only token service to 400,000 other persons, Ralph A. Beals, president of the New York Library Association and director of the New York Public Library, reported yesterday.

The Lexington Avenue elevated line in Brooklyn, the first rapid transit passenger route there, is scheduled for the junk pile, it was learned yesterday. Borough President John Cashmore and the Board of Transportation have suggested its demolition to the Board of Estimate.

Angered by the high school student demonstrations and the teachers' "strike" against voluntary extracurricular activities Mayor O'Dwyer called upon the Board of Education yesterday to investigate the three-day disturbances.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27--The League of Women Voters adopted a special resolution today affirming its conviction "that protection of the citizen" in his constitutional rights is basic to our system of Government."

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 27 --More colleges and universities should consider offering courses in marriage counseling, it was contended at the annual Groves Conference on Marriage and the Family which closed a three-day session at the University of North Carolina yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Paper drinking cups represented steel mills and another cup the steel buyer here today as Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, sought to explain the basing price system to members of Congress.

DETROIT, April 27--With all major issues virtually resolved, representatives of the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., were reported on the threshold tonight of a settlement of the ninety-three-day strike that has seriously disrupted the economic life of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to retain the 20 per cent excise tax on cabarettype places of entertainment such as night clubs and roof gardens along with existing imposts on several other items.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 27--The Soviet Union marched out of the long-stalled United Nations disarmament talks today after failing again by a close vote to oust the delegation of Nationalist China.

NEW DELHI, India, April 28-- India has no military alliance. She seeks the formation of no "Asian" bloc nor does she encourage any such movement as "PanAsianism." There is no such thing as Indian imperialism. Peace is the nation's first requirement, and it needs fifty years of tranquility to "transform the face of this country and the future of our people."

WASHINGTON, April 28--The Senate agreed today to vote next Friday on the omnibus foreign-aid bill authorizing $3,372,450,000 for economic assistance abroad during the fiscal year of 1951. The total includes $3,100,000,000 for a third year of the Marshall Plan.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28 --Robert J. Doyle, correspondent of Time magazine, and a companion assumed to be Dr. Raymond Kennedy, professor of anthropology at Yale University, were killed yesterday while traveling by jeep in central Java. The two men were believed to have been attacked by an armed gang while en route from Bandung to Jogjakarta.

The advisability of an elected Board of Education, with fiscal independence and the power to tax real estate to finance its programs, will be seriously studied in the economy and efficiency survey of the city government, now under way.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in April expanded to the largest total for any month in more than four years, or since January, 1946, and for a corresponding month in seventeen years, or since 1933.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 30 (UP)--Shot through the heart by another youth, 16-year-old Carl Woodward died in the middle of a heavily trafficked street early today. His assailant, George King, also 16, fled in an automobile with six other teen-agers.
DETROIT, April 30--The practice of spanking children was criticized today by Dr. John C. Montgomery, pediatrician, who called spanking not only "useless" but "harmful."

LONDON, April 30--In the last week the political rather than the economic repercussions of the budget have occupied the City's attention and, much as it dislikes and criticizes the Government's financial ...

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox overcame a 7-0 deficit to gain a 7-7 tie in the second game of a double-header against the Detroit Tigers after winning the opener, 5--0, behind Lefty Bill Wight's two-hit pitching before 8,175 frost-bitten fans here today.
Unless the world's poverty and its unmarketable surpluses can be brought together, our civilization cannot last, Lord Boyd Orr, 1949 Nobel Peace Prize winner, declared in an address here last night.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harold Farquhar Hadden of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street of the engagement of her daughter, Joan Farquhar, to Edward Low Pratt, Son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Pratt of New York and Bethlehem, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Council of the Federation of American Scientists, meeting here today, formally protested the recent government ban on open discussion by atomic, scientists of non-secret scientific work.
CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP)--Mel Queen lost a two-hit heartbreaker today as the Reds scored a 2-1 Victory over the Pirates, after taking the opener of the double-header, 4--2.

ATLANTA, April 30--Dr. George S. Mitchell, executive director of the Southern Regional Council, suggested today that white churches and colleges in the South "turn to the traditional spirit of Southern hospitality" and invite African students who are attending Negro colleges in the region to appear for talks or discussion gatherings.

BOSTON, April 30 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox pounded out 19-0 and 6-5 victories as they extended their Fenway Park winning streak over the Philadelphia Athletics to fourteen straight games in today's double-header before a capacity crowd of 34,697.

Irwin Maier, publisher of The Milwaukee Journal, and Stuart M. Chambers, treasurer of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, have been named chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the newly incorporated Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced...
The Associated Hospital Service of New York announced yesterday that it would mark its fifteenth anniversary next week with 4,200,000 individuals enrolled.
DALLAS, Tex., April 30--Two of America's major musical organizations, both of New York and both touring in the grand manner, crossed each other's path today in this city.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 30--Electric utilities in nine southern states will spend more than $1,000,000,000, for new facilities during the five-year period 1949-53, according to a report prepared for the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- Policy drafters of the United States Chamber of Commerce today proposed a "drastic decrease" in the Federal payroll and adoption of a balanced budget as an every-year policy of the Government.
As everyone knows, there is nothing so soothing and refreshing as a spring day in the country.

ROME, April 30--The agreement recently signed between the Communist-dominated Polish Government and the Roman Catholic Bishops in Warsaw will be valid only if approved by the Vatican, well-informed Catholic sources said today.
The possibility of curtailed operations on the Long Island Rail Road this morning was seen last night after 107 of the road's 300 engineers reported "sick" during the day.
LONDON, April 30--Walter V. Hutchinson, one of Great Britain's most prominent book publishers, died today in a hospital at Winchester, Hampshire, after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

BERLIN, Monday, May 1--Arms and ammunition were passed out early today to 8,000 United States, British and French troops alerted to suppress any disorder during the giant rival Communist and anti-Communist May Day demonstrations.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday took action to halt what he described as a "serious" downward trend in waterborne commerce through the Port of New York and simultaneously to develop a greater volume of trade.

A movement by the food industry to eliminate the city's gross business tax on edibles, thereby reducing the public's food costs by 1 per cent, is to begin this month, it was learned yesterday. This may reduce-New York's annual food bill approximately $15,000,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 (AP) --Rain fell at Churchill Downs for the second straight day and the horse trainers began to speculate about what to expect from the weatherman for the $100,000 Kentucky Derby.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP)-- Robin Roberts struck out 11 Boston Braves' batters to lead Philadelphia to a 9-3 victory in the second game of today's double header after Boston's rookie pitcher Norman Roy limited the Phils to five hits, one a homer, and take the opener, 4--1.

The New York University's Institute of International Finance recommended yesterday that the Treasury should issue during the next three years issues of new bank-eligible bonds maturing in five to twelve years in exchange for maturing Government bonds now held by the banks.

LOCUST, N.J., April 30--Mr. and Mrs. Earle S. Snyder have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Anne, to William Seguine Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Seguine Johnson Jr. of 114 East Ninetieth Street, and Deep Roots, Bridgehampton, L.I.

PITTSBURGH, April 30--A further extension of delivery dates and a wide diversity of product demand characterized the steel market during the past week, according to steel sales officials here. They agreed, too, that the conversion arrangements of their customers were increasing.
GENEVA, April 30--Personal savings have declined and in some countries virtually disappeared as a factor in economic progress in Western Europe.

There isn't enough action in Queens, according to John Carmein, and so, the police reported, he started a fire in the doorway of a butter and egg store at 142-05 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, at 6 A.M. yesterday.

The stair-swollen feet of Manhattan's cliff dwellers eased back to normal yesterday as the last traces of the four-day strike of 12,000 apartment house workers were cleared away.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., had estimated net earnings of $2,489,000, equal to 40.5 cents a capital share, in 1949, Juan Trippe, president, states in the annual report which is being mailed today to stockholders. This compares with net income of $4,591,000, or 74.75 cents a share, in 1948.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30-- Santana Productions, the Humphrey Bogart-Robert Lord company at Columbia, has acquired "The Butcher Bird," a screen story by Guy Endore, as a vehicle for Bogart.

Sleet and rain fell upon the city's watershed areas for three and one-half hours yesterday, starting eight and one-half hours after a rain-making crew directed by telephone from Lexington, Mass., began a sixteen-hour cloudseeding operation.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30-- By the end of next year the enormous country of India, with a population of approximately 350,000,000 people, hopes to be self-sufficient in its food requirements. Traditionally until now, India has depended upon sizable imports, especially of grain.

Vassily Smyslov, one of seven Russians competing in the ten-man challengers chess tournament in Budapest, was the sole victor when play was resumed in the tenth round yesterday, according to a report from Hungary.
WASHINGTON, April 30--The sum of $1,446,732,000, the largest annual outlay yet, is earmarked this year for highway construction in the United States, the American...
WASHINGTON, April 30--Television receiver production for the first quarter of 1950 was 21 per cent higher than in the previous peak period, the last quarter of...

It was Henry Wallace, if memory serves, who, a few years back, hit upon a formula which has been enormously helpful to the type of Congressman who is making a career of being "anti-business" but who realizes that, since even business in the aggregate represents a lot of votes, such a policy can sometimes cut two ways.

The assemblage of a plot near Fifth Avenue, possibly for improvement with a large building, was reported over the week-end when Fred H. Hill bought 2, 4 and 6 East Sixty-fifth Street from the Estate of Sophia Augusta Sherman.
The strike of 12,000 Manhattan apartment-house workers ended at 5:55 P.M. yesterday.
The highest award in the Police Department, the department Medal of Honor, was granted yesterday to two patrolmen for outstanding heroism in 1949. One was posthumous.
Phumiphon Aduldet, 22-year-old King of Thailand, who is Americanborn and interested in musical composition, will be represented on Broadway in a forthcoming revue, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP)--Del Rice broke up a brilliant thirteeninning pitching duel with a home run to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 1-to-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs today. Harry Brecheen and Johnny Schmitz fought the mound battle.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The agenda for the meetings of the United States, British and French Foreign Ministers during the first half of May indicates why plans are now under way for the formation of a supreme council to coordinate Western economic, political and strategic policies in the "cold war."

Labor-management cooperation through organized groups to break a "strike" that assertedly exists between the two forces was urged yesterday by the Rev. Joseph P. Fitzpatrick, Professor of Political Philosophy of the Graduate School at Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, April 30--It seemed probable tonight that the Senate might again face a jam of legislation in the closing weeks of the session despite the fact that its long debate on the foreign-aid authorization bill would end this week.

Today we have the fascinating "pick-a-pocket" skirt for you. Meet the lady who originated it: Mildred Orrick, our American Designer Series choice for this month.

WASHINGTON, April 30--President Truman warmly welcomed today the formation of the Associated Services for the Armed Forces, Inc., a new interdenominational voluntary agency, to serve men and women of the armed services in communities near their stations.
