A hundred twenty West Point cadets, members of the choir and acolyte squads, sang at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. An Easter season visit by the Military Academy group is traditional.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Senator Millard E. Tydings said today the Senate Communist investigation that he heads might soon receive some new evidence that would make immediate conclusions "in this whole matter" premature.
MILAN, April 30--At the Milan Trade Fair high interest rates are a handicap on Italian exports.
A fictionalized biography of an "arrested alcoholic" by an author who writes under the pseudonym of Hugh Reilly will be published...

JERSEY CITY, May 1--The Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company was faced tonight with a new strike threat when 250 of its 350 trainmen voted to walk out over the company's alleged failure to observe contract provisions.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 30 --Expansion of the original Jogjakarta Republic of Indonesia to include the states of the Federal Indonesian Republic progressed further this week-end with the adherence to Jogjakarta of the entire island of Celebes.

Warren R. Austin appealed yesterday to forty-three visiting members of Congress to return to Washington and "give a little kick" to pending legislation that would help finance the United Nations' global program for technical assistance to under-developed countries.
Clark, Dodge Co. announced that William A. Hobbs, formerly with the National City Bank of Cleveland, will take charge of the research department today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30-- Abram Orlow, an attorney specializing in immigration and naturalization laws, died at his home here today at the age of 50.
The old poser, "It's pretty, but is it Art?" has mixed up court and Treasury decisions under which various abstractions are imported for the Museum of Modern Art and for dealers.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 30--The Germans cannot live much longer "half free" under an occupation system that is "extremely prejudicial" to democracy in Germany, Dr. Reinhold Maier, Premier of the state of Wuerttemberg Baden, declared in Duesseldorf today.

The investigation into organized gambling in Brooklyn will be broadened this week when the past and present commanders of the Sixteenth Division will be called before the borough's racket grand jury, it was made known yesterday by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 30-- United States Representative John D. Lodge of Westport, brother of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut.
ROME, April 3--A strong anti-Communist labor organization came into being today when the Italian Confederation of Labor Syndicates was founded in Rome.

NEWARK, April 30--Circus Rose, the young Virginia mare belonging to Mr. and Mrs. William E. Schlusemeyer, continued to cut a big figure in eastern jumper competition by taking the championship of the Newark horse show tonight.

Theological seminaries are becoming more and more aware of the value of student training in hospitals, the Rev. Thomas E. Morris, senior Protestant chaplain at Bellevue Hospital, said yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street.

LONDON, April 30--Seeking reasons why housing is so costly and slow in catching up with, demand, a committee of the building industry concluded today that Government controls had a lot to do with the problem.

WASHINGTON, April 30--In an effort to popularize President Truman's national health program, the Democratic National Committee announced today that it was distributing to party leaders throughout the country a booklet titled: "Better Medical Care That You Can Afford."
Joan Brainerd's'recital at Town Hall last night was a refreshing experience. This young soprano...

TOBERMORY, Scotland, April 30--Eighty feet below buoys floating in this cove, helmeted, rubber-clad figures are driving jet probes deep into the silt in an attempt to uncover an ancient Spanish galleon reputedly laden with a great treasure in coins.
A thousand would-be visitors to the battleship Missouri were turned away yesterday from Pier 90, West Fiftieth Street and the North River.

The future of this country lies in the virtues of its soul, the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, editor-elect of the new weekly newspaper, The Protestant World, declared yesterday in a sermon at the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn, 124 Henry Street.
Reprieve: "The Devil's Disciple" isn't going to be withdrawn May 13 from the Royale after all.

All parties involved in the apartment house dispute are deserving of praise for the public-spirited attitude they have displayed in finding a formula for preventing further interference with elevator operation and other vital services ...
James C. Forsyth, a member of the law firm of Condon Forsyth and a specialist in public utilities law, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 161 West Sixteenth Street. His age was 48.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, May 1 (AP)--Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek declared today his Chinese Nationalists were fighting an "anti-Russian war."

Numerous orders for apparel and other soft goods were recived last week and reports from stores were more encouraging, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Orders for summer wear were received in good volume.

MOSINEE, Wis., April 30--In sequel to infiltration last night by real Communist agents this paper mill town of 1,400 prepared tonight to be "taken over" tomorrow by mock Communists in a May Day Americanism demonstration sponsored by the Wisconsin American Legion.

DETROIT, April 30--With hours lengthening and tempers fraying, negotiators seeking a settlement of the Chrysler Corporation strike stuck at their table tonight in a marathon session that reportedly had brought them within reaching distance of a new contract.

PARIS, April 30--Official studies are under way concerning means of speeding up the economic development of Africa, it is learned here. Governmental circles say they attach very great importance to this problem, and a special conference on it is expected to be held here on May 8, between Government representatives and high officials of French African territories.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., April 30--Military leaders, observing Exercise Swarmer, a large-scale tactical test of a "mass strategic airlift" being staged in the Carolina sandhills, disclosed today that the new method of land-air assault was one of the high-priority studies of the country's civilian and military defense chiefs.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued their irregular upward trend last week, with all new-crop active months advancing into new high ground for the season. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York...
SYDNEY, Australia, April 30 (Reuters)--A Communist union official told a rally here today, "We will fly the hammer and sickle from the roof of Sydney Town Hall."

SAN SALVADOR, April 27-- President-elect Oscar Osorio said in an interview here that his Government would continue the democratic policies established by the Revolutionary Government Council, following the ousting of President Salvador Castaneda Castro on Dec. 14, 1948, after he had attempted to extend his term of office in violation of the Constitution.
The threat of a nation-wide telephone tie-up, scheduled to go into effect at 6 A.M. today, ended at 2 o'clock this morning when 10,000 telephone installation workers called off their week-old strike.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., April 30 (AP)--Mrs. George Zaharias won the first stage of the transcontinental Weathervane women's open golf tournament today with a thirty-six-hole total of 158.
AMSTERDAM, April 30--Considerable astonishment was caused here by the annual report of Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank, published this week.

A loud knocking yesterday on the door of the Oriental Garden in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden forced Frank Okamura, gardener and host, to lower the bar and welcome back several groups of hardy human perennials.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Argentina will get an offer of a credit of approximately $125,000,000 by the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Secretary of State Dean Acheson spent two hours today with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee discussing behind closed doors this country's plans for the Western Big Three talks at Paris and London that start next week.

The frozen vegetables, fruits and juices now in the stores are from the 1949 pack, the largest on record. Among the most plentiful items are frozen orange juice concentrate, apples and applesauce, peaches, broccoli, brussels sprouts, cauliflower and spinach.

CHICAGO, May 1--All deliveries of grain and lard except May and July rye advanced to new high levels for the season on the Board of Trade today. May and July soybeans and December rye advanced the permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, won quick approval from a House committee today for a $350,000,000 Navy modernization program covering a guided-missiles ship and an atomic-powered submarine.
TOKYO, May 1--The lower house of the Japanese Parliament by a vote of almost two to one tonight turned down a resolution of no confidence in the government of Conservative Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

ALBANY, May 1--Governor Dewey, back at the Capitol after a week's rest at his Pawling farm, tonight called the Federal Government "an unwieldy and extravagent machine" and asked to people of New York State to support the recommendations of the [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

The City Stores Company and its subsidiaries, operator of a large group of department and specialty stores, in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, last, transacted the largest volume of sales in its history, the annual report revealed yesterday. The total of $182,303,340 represented an increase of 8.4 per cent over the $168,104,985 volume of the preceding fiscal year.

The Simmons Company has obtained a court order temporarily restraining the Queens Jewelry Company, a Hoboken retailer, from selling its Beautyrest mattress below the fair-traded minimum retail price of $59.50.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 1-- Larry Adler, harmonica player, changed his tune concerning the Communist party as a world conspiracy when he learned that Communist leaders had said they would never oppose Russia in a war against the United States, he testified today in United States District Court.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., May 1--Leaders of Exercise Swarmer, the vast test of supplying troops entirely by air, have learned in the last, four days that the Army requires in the field many odd-sized and awkward-to-handle equipment items that most of the Air Force's present planes were never built to handle.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 1-- They made way for the champion in the opening tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfer's Association over the Fresh Meadow Country Club today as another year of competition began under cloudy skies.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP)-- Temperamental Russ Meyer is in the doghouse again and this time it cost him a defeat, $200 and a seven-day suspension.
A young man rang the doorbell of the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Raplh Ginsberg on the third floor of 1952 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, shortly before 10 A.M. yesterday.
HONG KONG, May 1--A British coastal steamer has returned here from a visit to Shanghai, despite the alleged Nationalist mining of the entrance to that port.

Mrs. Emma Clark Roche, widow of the Rev. Dr. Spencer Summerfield Roche, Protestant Episcopal Bishop-elect of Delaware at his death in 1916, and for thirty-seven years rector of St. Mark's Church in Brooklyn, died yesterday in her home at 41 West Fifty-eighth Street, Manhattan. Her age was 85.

NEW DELHI, India, May 1-- The immense complexity of the problems facing the Indian Government, now that its revolution has pasesd from the dynamic phase of an independence movement, is such that probably no other nation, lacking the traditional Indian talents for compromise and patience, could handle them without disaster.

There must be a good many separate and distinct reasons for spring housecleaning, but only one of them counts. That is, quite simply, because the housekeeper insists upon it, as her mother did, and her grandmother, and all her grandmothers back to Eve, who cleaned everything once and for all, with finality.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 10.5 per cent in April, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- Statehood for Hawaii was endorsed today by the Departments of State, Interior and Defense at a Senate committee hearing.

Through documentary movies made by the city in the last year civic groups, schools, colleges and libraries in the United States and abroad have been learning about the work of various New York departments.

WASHINGTON, May 1--If Congress adds to the military defense budget for fiscal year 1951 the $350 millions which a House committee has recommended, and there is every prospect it will, the original contractual and fund limit submitted by the President and Secretary of Defense Johnson will have been exceeded by only 2.48 per cent.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 1-- Dr. Leland O. Howard, entomologist, died here today in his home at 45 Pondfield Road. He would have been 93 years old on June 11. His book, "The Insect Menace," published in 1931, which attracted considerable attention, won the Second Capper Award.

Higher costs of industrial plant construction are predicted with resumption of "escalation" contracts, which are now being considered as a result of recent boosts in prices of industrial materials ranging from china lavatories to non-ferrous fabricated parts.
"Brigadoon," Cheryl Crawford's musical production, which won the Drama Critics Circle award for the best musical of 1947, returns tonight for a three-week engagement at the City Center.

Five thousand persons thronged St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday and, as part of a ceremony duplicated in churches across the nation by millions of Roman Catholics, prayed for the "return of all Communists to God."
LONDON, May 1--The week opened quietly on the London stock markets today and, apart from oil shares, rubbers and South African gold-mining issues, prices tended to sag slightly.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Theodore Lothrop Stoddard, author and editorial writer, died today after a long illness, in George Washington University Hospital at the age of 66.
Offenbach's fantasy, "The Tales of Hoffmann," was the National Broadcasting Company's fourth and final offering in the realm of television opera last night.

In line with its austerity program the Philippine Government has combined three offices in one person. General Romulo will now serve as Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Chief of the Delegation to the United Nations and Ambassador to the United States. That is a staggering assignment but General Romulo is a person of indefatigable energy and boundless enthusiasm. The roles overlap at many points, but there is reason for each.

It was a dismal, overcast day at Jamaica yesterday. But not for Frank Frankel, who has been having remarkable success with the six thoroughbreds he purchased from George D. Widener last winter. For, in the featured six-furlong test, Curtain Raiser, one of the six, accounted for a length victory over J.M. Roebling's Admiral Drake.

The property of Cartier, Inc., jewelers, at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fiftysecond Street has been purchased for investment by the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company in a cash transaction reported to have involved more than $3,000,000.

What this city needs is an elephant-sized advertising campaign to attract more tourists. Hyman B. Cantor, president of the Governor Clinton Hotel, said so yesterday in a luncheon talk to members of the Partridge Club.

Mr. and Mrs. J.T. Johnston Mali of 10 East Ninety-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire, to David Harry Forties, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ellis Fortier of Hempstead, L.I. The wedding will take place in the early summer.

The American Gas and Electric Company borrowed yesterday $27,000,000 on serial notes due from May 1, 1952, to May 1, 1965, at an interest cost of about 2.43 per cent. The notes were sold at competitive bidding to a banking group headed by the Union Securities Corporation on a bid of 100,524 for 2 s.

The sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges will be run off without qualifying heats, it was announced yesterday at the weekly rowing luncheon at the New York A.C. by Commissioner Asa Bushnell of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

With the majority, or 60.3 per cent, operating at half or less of capacity, nearly 90 per cent of New York City's machine shops have idle equipment available for urgently needed additional work, it was announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
LONDON, May 1--The precariously poised Labor government narrowly escaped another defeat tonight in the House of Commons.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1-- A faltering, war-damaged economy is considered here one of the gravest problems facing the new state of Indonesia.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 1-- The estate of Mrs. Hetty Green, left to her son, Col. Edward H.R. Green, on the financier's death in 1916, was passed on here today to a former companion of his widow.

Capital goods will comprise more than one-half of all exhibits at the Canadian International Trade Fair which gets under way in Toronto at the end of this month, it was announced yesterday by Glen Bannerman, director.

The eleven convicted Communists filed briefs yesterday with the United States Court of Appeals supporting their appeal from a District Court conviction last October on charges of conspiring to teach and advocate forcible ...

Mr. and Mrs. J.T. Johnston Mali of 10 East Ninety-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire, to David Harry Forties, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ellis Fortier of Hempstead, L.I. The wedding will take place in the early summer.

The American Gas and Electric Company borrowed yesterday $27,000,000 on serial notes due from May 1, 1952, to May 1, 1965, at an interest cost of about 2.43 per cent. The notes were sold at competitive bidding to a banking group headed by the Union Securities Corporation on a bid of 100,524 for 2 s.

The sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges will be run off without qualifying heats, it was announced yesterday at the weekly rowing luncheon at the New York A.C. by Commissioner Asa Bushnell of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

With the majority, or 60.3 per cent, operating at half or less of capacity, nearly 90 per cent of New York City's machine shops have idle equipment available for urgently needed additional work, it was announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
LONDON, May 1--The precariously poised Labor government narrowly escaped another defeat tonight in the House of Commons.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1-- A faltering, war-damaged economy is considered here one of the gravest problems facing the new state of Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, May 1--President Truman expressed approval today of the aims of the National Committee for a Free Europe and said he hoped that all Americans would support it.

The Board of Transportation's letter yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer's factfinders in the city's transit labor dispute makes it clear that there is no one-way street to improved working and wage conditions in the transit system. The employer, digging down in the passenger's pocket, cannot do it all. The Transport Workers Union also has its responsibilities to put the system on a more efficient basis.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Telephone and telegraph companies protested today against proposed legislation to make illegal the interstate transmission of gambling information.
TOKYO, May 1--Japanese labor has passed a most important turning point and henceforth must make its gains by increasing productivity, according to a White Paper issued by the Labor Ministry today.
Passenger trains on the Long Island Rail Road kept to normal schedules yesterday despite an abnormal "sick list" of ninety-eight engineers, railroad officials reported.

The nation's larger banks will be required to pay out $111,354,000 under the terms of a call on the Class B banks issued yesterday by the United States Treasury against its tax and loan accounts. The call, for 5 per cent of such deposits as of April 29, is payable on May 8. Banks in this district will supply $30,042,000 of the national total.

PARIS, May 1--Gen. Charles de Gaulle accused the French Government today of having no foreign policy of its own and of merely ratifying what had been decided in Washington, London and elsewhere. "And what it gets in exchange is never visible," he added.

The Coca-Cola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in the first three months of this year earned $5,548,369, or $1.30 a common share, after provision for taxes, Class A dividends and all other charges, it was announced yesterday after the annual meetings of stockholders and directors in Wilmington, Del.

A panel of editors and writers will attempt to find hidden cliches in amusing stories and anecdotes submitted by radio listeners in a new weekly series entitled "Cliche Club," which begins over the American Broadcasting Company Wednesday, May 10, from 8:30 to 9 P.M.

On April 14 at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Newport News, Va., a new ship known to yard employes as Hull 484 was turned over to the owner, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). Yesterday she appeared in New York harbor as the supertanker Esso New York.

TROY, N.Y., May 1--Prof. Wynant J. Williams, head of the Department of Electrical Engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, died of a heart attack this morning in the office of Dr. Paul E. Hemke, dean of faculty, where he had gone for a conference. His age was 66.

The cuts in postal service made necessary by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson's economy order will go into effect in Manhattan, the Bronx and Pelham on June 1, Postmaster Albert Goldman said yesterday.

Combined net assets of the ten Keystone Funds on March 31 totaled $203,219,200, an increase of $32,101,500 from the $173,117,700 reported on March 31, 1949, it was disclosed by the semi-annual reports of Keystone Funds B4 and S1, released for publication today. The number of shareholders was 533,011 compared with 51,108 on the same date, a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Unemployment is bound to grow unless government gives business the incentive to provide the 600,000 new jobs annually which our growing population requires, Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said here today.

MONTREAL, May 1 (Canadian Press)--The International Air Transport Association announced tonight that the first international consolidated tariffs in the history of transport and commuincations were filed simultaneously today in Washington and Ottawa.

Plans for a new community of small ranch-type houses on the former estate of Robert W. Gilmore in West Babylon, L.I., were announced yesterday by Babylon Shores, Inc. The builders, Irving Blume, Irving Kraemer and Samuel S. Friedman, opened the tract this week.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1--The business of sorting out the 3-yearolds that will go after the money in Saturday's $100,000 added Kentucky Derby nears its final stage tomorrow with the running of the $10,000 Derby Trial at Churchill Downs.

OFFENBURG, Germany, May 1 --The French Foreign Legion "processing" center in this small German city fifteen miles from Strasbourg is turning down a large number of German volunteers French officers explain that there are enough Germans in the legion at present.

More than 500 persons, including sixteen Federal jurists, attended a solemn high requiem mass yesterday at Holy Name Roman Catholic Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, for Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, who died on Wednesday at the age of 65.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., May 1-- The Mount Kisco pair of Bill Goldbeck, veteran pro, and his amateur partner, Richard W. Woolworth, teamed to fashion a 65 and win the best-ball honors in the Westchester P.G.A.'s opening proamateur competition of the season on the rain-soaked Leewood-Golf Club course today.
BERLIN, May 1--More than half a million persons, drawn from both halves of this divided city, roared defiance to the Soviet Union and German communism and pledged allegiance to freedom today.

John H. and Helena Heller have sold the building at 168 Willis Avenue, northeast corner of 135th Street, the Bronx, containing eight stores and sixteen apartments, and the building at 170-74 Willis Avenue, containing three stores and nine apartments, to Otto and ...
The stair-swollen feet of Manhattan's cliff dwellers eased back to normal yesterday as the last traces of the four-day strike of 12,000 apartment house workers were cleared away.

The mid-century May Day has come and gone and, despite all the tensions of the "cold war" and the rival demonstrations in many parts of the world, it was without major disturbances. For that the world can give thanks. But the events of the day had many aspects whose significance cannot and should not be overlooked.

Columbia University announced yesterday the resignation of Paul H. Davis, its vice president in charge of development. A member of the university administrative staff for four years, Mr. Davis will move to California to start his own public relations and development firm.
Columbia Pictures will release thirty-two top productions in the coming year, the largest number of top films ever offered by the company in a single year, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 1--Pioneer experiments revealing the existence of an integrating mechanism in the growth process of the cells that constitute the basic units of living matter were described here today at the annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation, popularly known as "the young Turks."

Paul Governali, Columbia's AllAmerica halfback in 1942, will be added to Lou Little's Lion football coaching staff as backfield assistant next fall, it was announced yesterday by Ralph Furey, director of athletics.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 1--Despite sharp criticism by several stockholders, Sewell L. Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., was re-elected a director of the United States Steel Corporation at the annual meeting today.

PARIS, May 1--In his youthful, wearable collection Jacques Griffe gives a new interest to pleats by notching them on the same level about a foot above the hemline. In motion, they sway gracefully this way and that.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 1 --The Soviet Government's economic exploitation of its Eastern European satellites, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei. Y. Vishinsky's lack of restraint in his speeches and the nightmarish propaganda ...
The "Iron Curtain" surrounding Mosinee, Wis., was penetrated yesterday by a telephone call from New York.

The annual announcement of the Pulitzer Prize winners probably arouses keerser interest than any other award in the field of American journalism and letters. Since their establishment, the Pulitzer Prizes have come to be considered as recognition of the highest professional attainment.

DETROIT, May 1--Countries directly affected by World War II have fewer psychiatric problems than the United States, according to a report today by Dr. Lothar B. Kalinowsky, New York psychiatrist, who recently finished an intensive study of war neuroses abroad.
The Board of Transportation made an urgent plea yesterday for a "very substantial" increase in transit fares to meet the $17,000,000 deficit that it expects next year even without wage rises.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1--A pediatric research program, including premature birth, will be supported by the Playtex Park Research Institute, Dover, Del., it was announced here tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1-- Miriam Hopkins and Thelma Ritter have been signed by Paramount to play the mothers of Gene Tierney and John Lund, respectively, in "A Relative Stranger," Charles Brackett's next production, which will start May 15. Mitchell Leisen will direct the film, a comedy about marriage, which Walter Reisch has written.
The Society for Forgotten Music gave its fourth concert last night in Carl Fischer Hall for the benefit of the American Fund for Israel Institutions.
The stock market yesterday broke through to new highs for the year. The moderate push needed to attain such rates was supplied by the heavy industrials and the rails.

A wide range of facilities available to residents of Manhattan in an emergency, including all-night drug stores, baby sitters, therapy for alcoholism and rentals of hats and television sets, is listed in the 1950 spring edition of the Directory of Unusual and Emergency Services, which has just been issued by the Informational Directory Company.

A large plaster reproduction of a stone head carved at the beginning of the Christian era by natives of what is now the State of Vera Cruz in Mexico was placed on exhibit yesterday afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History.

JERSEY CITY, May 1--The Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company was faced tonight with a new strike threat when 250 of its 350 trainmen voted to walk out over the company's alleged failure to observe contract provisions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP)-- American Viscose Corporation said today it reached new highs in production and shipment of both rayon and cellophane in the first quarter of 1950 and reported net sales of $61,807,000 and net income of $7,908,000 for the threemonth period.

BERLIN, May 1--Spring weather played a strong supporting role today in the Berlin May Day observance. Warm sunshine, following an unusually damp and cold April, swelled the attendance at the Western sector spectacle in the Place of the Republic beyond the most optimistic estimates.

In an unprecedented move that may spell an early end to vast Federal expenditures for public power projects, the politically influential Chamber of Commerce of the United States yesterday made the flat statement that "no private business can long endure Government competition."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1--The United States Public Health Service will ask 2,000 to 4,000 Westchester families to serve as "guinea pigs" in a summer-long test to determine the extent to which tidal bathing water is causing disease, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 1--A fivepoint program for joint financing and for taking steps to combine their electric systems was set before the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Wisconsin Electric Power Company of Milwaukee and the Wisconsin Gas and Electric Company, of Racine.
Seven armed and masked men entered the home of Dr. Jose Negron Cesteros, a physician at 5 East Eighty-sixth Street, last night and escaped with $1,500 from the doctor's safe.

Net profit of the Union Oil Company of California in the first three months of this year declined to $1,844,178 from $7,403,136 shown in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued for publication today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 1--The unusual amount of furniture that has been moved into the old Morgall estate on Matinecock Point, leased two weeks ago by a Soviet United Nations delegate, has resulted in an official protest from this town.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 1 (AP)--A spokesman for 300 weary Jewish refugees who walked into Teheran today said twelve Jews have been murdered and several Jewish girls raped in a violent wave of persecution in Iranian Kurdistan.

WASHINGTON, May 1--A Georgia law described by opponents as a curb on Negro voting was left unimpaired when the Supreme Court refused today to review the statute on the ground that no substantial Federal question was involved.
As service officer of the Marine Corps League here, John Joseph Cole has far more clients than his organization has local members.

DETROIT, Tuesday, May 2--An oral agreement to end the strike against the Chrysler Corporation has been reached, it was disclosed yesterday by Herman L. Weckler, company vice president and general manager.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons, including the Misses Jane Werner and Simone Smith, are assisting plans for the performance of "Three Sheets to the Wind," a musical comedy, to be presented by members of the "F" Society of Yale University on the night of May 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Camp Nyda in Burlingham, N.Y.
Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday challenged labor leaders who opposed him in the last election to declare whether they were really against the Taft-Hartley Act.

An estimated 2,300,000 voters will mark ballots in primary elections in four states today to select party candidates for three United States Senate seats, forty-nine places in the House of Representatives and two Governors.

MIDDLEBURY, Conn., May 1-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Benjamin Bristol of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy, to L. Duncan, Allen. Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen of La Grange, Ga.
LONDON, May 1--Brickbats and bouquets were aimed today at Maurice Webb, whose Food Ministry is continually a center of controversy.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company, center of a controversy that may culminate in the sale of the Northwestern utility to public ownership, obtained yesterday a loan of $15,000,000 from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Interest in the Senate debate of the third Marshall Plan authorization was at a low point today.

The Pulitzer Prize to "South Pacific" was awarded almost thirteen months after the hit musical play had its premiere at the Majestic Theatre here. The production opened on April 7, 1949, a week too late for consideration as a candidate for last year's award.

ST. LOUIS, May 1--A three-hit shut-out for Joe Hatten and a 2-0 triumph for the Dodgers suddenly was turned into a 3-2 victory for the Cardinals tonight under the Sportsman's Park lights, the Red Birds scoring all their runs in the ninth.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- Three Midwest steel executives said today the St. Lawrence seaway must be built to utilize efficiently the mammoth deposits of iron ore in Labrador.
Thousands of left-wing New Yorkers marched down Eighth Avenue for four hours and twenty minutes yesterday in their annual May Day parade.
"Today's Home Builds Tomorrow's World" is the theme of National Home Demonstration Week, being observed this week by 100,000 women in New York State, 8,600 of them in the metropolitan area.

Although the past week-end undoubtedly would have delighted the heart of any duck hunter, it brought little sunshine into the life of the trout fisherman, and an analysis of the reports indicates that it might be best to skip the whole thing.
Rain-making operations were resumed from the ground in the Catskills yesterday. A crew of Water Department men created more silver iodide smoke with their trailer generator.

MORRISTOWN, N.J. May 1-- Douglas M. Stanfield of Morris Plains, former Broadway actor, who inherited a fortune from his grandfather and in later years worked as a day laborer, died here yesterday in All Souls Hospital after a long illness. His age was about 77.

Opening of the Brooklyn-Battery vehicular tunnel on May 25 will begin a new era for the Brooklyn waterfront, particularly the $25,000,000 Bush Terminal, largest single operation of its kind in the United States.
District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday that his investigation into gambling in Brooklyn would develop additional transactions allegedly involving loans to policemen.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The House voted, 194--87 today to put the nation's capital on DaylightSaving Time for 1950.

Prices of rubber futures advanced again yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here, following continued strength in the London and Singapore markets. The local market closed with net gains of 80 to 150 points.

INYOKERN, Calif., May 1--The "Mighty Mouse," a 2.75-inch rocket, which is about to be put into service by the Navy and the Air Force, and a whole "fleet" of other missiles are under test and development here in the heart of the Mojave Desert at the nation's largest naval station.
CHICAGO, May 1--The typical Chicago housewife works six hours a day or less.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Freda Utley, a former British Communist, said today that she had "no proof" or knowledge that Prof. Owen Lattimore ever was a Communist.

The constitutionality of the new state rent control law, which became effective at 12:01 A.M. yesterday, was upheld eleven hours later in a decision handed down by President Justice William Lyman of the Municipal Court.
ROME, May 1--Two peasants were killed and four wounded in the small village of Celano, in the province of Chieti, during a clash with police yesterday.
COLUMBIA, Mo., May 1--Two newspapers and four individuals were named today for the University of Missouri's twenty-first annual honor awards for distinguished service to journalism.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 6 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

A fashion show of twenty-four pieces made by convalescing patients was presented last evening in the auditorium of the Triboro Hospital in Jamaica. Some of these garments symbolized the start of a new life for the maker.
The New York Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 9 on an issue of $7,130,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of three projects, as follows:

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 1--After a quiet May Day in the mining and industrial districts of Witwatersrand the situation suddenly changed after nightfall to serious rioting by Negro workers with a death roll of at least twelve and many others wounded by police fire.

Mayor O'Dwyer indirectly blamed the city's teachers yesterday for last week's student demonstrations at City Hall and charged that teachers had the moral duty to inculcate in their pupils respect for lawful authority.
For the past week a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee headed by Representative Celler has been listening to testimony dealing with competition and concentration in the steel industry.

MOSCOW, May 1--The greatest demonstration of Soviet air strength ever placed on view over Red Square today marked the annual May Day observances in which Premier Joseph Stalin took the salute of units of Soviet battle forces and more than a million Moscow civilians from a podium atop Lenin's tomb.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--A bill to increase the 1950 national rice acreage allotment by 7,965 acres was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1--President Juan D. Peron said today Argentina would not only welcome foreign capital but that foreign enterprises that came here would be able to work so freely that possibly they would enjoy "more freedom than anywhere else in the world."

The 1950 Pulitzer Prize for the best original American play was won yesterday by the musical production "South Pacific," and the award for the best novel by an American author went to A.B. Guthrie Jr. for his "The Way West."

On Child Health Day yesterday, thirty health and hospital representatives gathered in the new Alfred E. Smith Memorial Building of St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West Eleventh Street, for a preview of its center for premature babies.

WARSAW, May 1--For the first time in her history Poland today celebrated May Day as an official holiday. According to official estimates 750,000 Poles marched down the main streets of Warsaw shouting slogans calling for "Work and Peace."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 1 --While profit margins now are generally at a bottom level for the industry, the nation's hosiery manufacturers have every reason to expect a healthy and strong market by the end of summer.

As 10,000 installers returned to the Western Electric Company yesterday after a week-long picketless strike, negotiations were resumed between twenty-four units of the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., and divisions of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company across the country.

H.L. Seward, who will retire in June as Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Yale University, has accepted the post of educational consultant at the New York State Maritime College, it was announced yesterday by Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary, U.S.N., re tired, president.

Thousands of persons lined-Fifth Avenue yesterday as the body of Generoso Pope, publisher of Italian-language newspapers in this city, was borne to St. Patrick's Cathedral for a solemn requiem mass. Mr. Pope died on Friday at the age of 59.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- France and Holland today were given $28,085,000 to buy petroleum under the Marshall Plan.

The Atlantic Refining Company increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 75 cents a share for payment June 15. This places the stock on a $3 annual basis. Shareholders had received 50 cents quarterly heretofore.

WASHINGTON, May 1--A $2,300,000 tax reduction on medicinal whisky was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee today. It seemed foreclosed, however, that the excise levy on beverage whisky--10 cents and up per jigger--was here to stay, indefinitely. It brings in an estimated $1,470,000,000 a year.

HONOLULU, May 1--Both factions of a divided Democratic party in Hawaii looked to Washington today for possible official recognition as an aftermath to their bitter intra-party feud that resulted in two rival territorial conventions being held here yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 1--Dr. Irwin A. Buell of Trinity College, director of extension courses and the college's summer school, died at his home here today at the age of 54.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, appealed yesterday for the renomination and reelection of the entire Republican state administration, from Governor Dewey through Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley, Controller Frank C. Moore and Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

George M. Weiss, general manager of the Yankees, declared yesterday that Dick Wakefield, the outfielder who was dealt to the White Sox last week, but refused to report, is the property of the Chicagoans--and that's that.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1 --The antiques show at the WestChester County Center opened its spring edition here today with an assortment of furnishings and decorations dominated by the Early American theme.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 1--Communist China's application for membership in the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East was referred today to the commission, which will meet at Bangkok on May 16, for a decision.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed weaker, 5 to 17 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--The Government spent $2,588,186,000 more than it took in during the first ten months of the current fiscal year, the Treasury reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- J.B. Burton, vice president of Transcontinental Gas Transmission Corporation, told a Federal Power Commission hearing today his company is "willing and able" to supply natural gas requirements of all applicants along its Texas-to-New England main line.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation sold the twelve-story office and showroom building on plot 44 by 98.9 feet at 35-37 West Thirtyninth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, to David S. Meister, operator, the latter reported yesterday.

Because of the unequal water storage balance between the Catskill and Croton systems, Water Department engineers have reduced the city's intake from Croton to a minimum and thrown most of the consumption burden on the Catskill supplies, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, May 2--Lord Vansittart confronted a crowded and critical House of Lords today to face a motion of censure for his allegations that several public personages and institutions were tainted by communism.

With a minimum of confusion, borough offices of the new state Rent Control Commission began functioning at 9 A. M. yesterday. During the day thousands of copies of the new rent regulations were distributed and about 5,000 telephone calls were handled.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP)-- Connie Mack ignored doctor's orders today and went back to work, admitting he's concerned about the lackluster performance of his eighth-place Athletics.

Despite a substantial reduction in the outstanding Federal debt since the War, the interest charge on the debt has risen by about $500,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its Monthly Review, published today.

The Ballet Theatre began its second week at the Center Theatre last night, with a program which had as its novelties the first presentation this year--of Anthony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" and some new casting in William Dollar's new "Jeux".

A police official now with the Nineteenth Division in Brooklyn will go tomorrow before the racket investigating grand jury for further questioning on an alleged "loan," District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County said yesterday.

The devotion and patience that Mrs. McKinley Jacobs has shown in the care of twenty-four foster children was rewarded yesterday by Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard of the Department of Welfare, who named her New York's Foster Mother of the Year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 2--A United Nations plane flying southward over Israeli territory was forced down at Lydda Airport today after Israeli Army fighters had fired across its nose. The plane was permitted to continue on to an Arab field at Kallandia, in Jordan after an official check.

BERLIN, May 2--The "Congress for Cultural Freedom in Berlin," which is to be held next month, will formulate a message to the intelligentsia behind the Iron Curtain asserting that no nation should be permitted to make tools of its finest mentalities for state purposes.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- Spokesmen for publishers protested today that a proposed increase in postal rates would be unfair to many newspapers.

Ignoring the wishes of Mayor O'Dwyer, Kenneth F. Sutherland, veteran Coney Island Democratic leader, has booked former Magistrate Charles Solomon, prominent Liberal party member, for a speech tomorrow night at the Sutherland Clubhouse, 25 Bay Twenty-fifth, Street.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 3 (AP) --The top Russian in Japan today asked Gen. Douglas MacArthur to explain "the reconstruction of former Japanese naval and air bases."

WASHINGTON, May, 4--The House Ways and Means Committee today rejected proposals to reduce Federal taxes on distilled spirits and beer.

Linings finished with the new Deering, Milliken Co. metallic coating for added warmth will be distributed by five companies in the regular lining trade, it was learned yesterday. Recent reservoir storage gains have been so small that for the time being it is unlikely that water restrictions currently in force can be relaxed, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

Columbia University officials opened a small lead box yesterday morning that was sealed in the wall of the old College of Physicians and Surgeons buildings at Fifty-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue during construction in 1886.

Asserting that while the Democrats talked, the Republicans acted, Governor Dewey offered last night the seven-year record of his administration as the reason why the voters of the state should continue the Republicans in power at Albany in next November's election.

With a good deal of interest, Lillian Gish is eyeing R.C. Sherriff's London hit, "Miss. Mabel," as her next stage vehicle. If she doesn't change her mind because of unforeseen obstacles, she will gauge its potentialities during a preBroadway tryout in late August at Richard Aldrich's Cape Playhouse, Dennis, Mass., under the direction of Arthur Sircom.

"Never too old to learn and to create" could well be the slogan of the big hobby show that opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, in which 1,000 participants over 60 years old proved that age was no barrier to skills.

Whole-hearted participation in the struggle against communism as "one of the major tasks of church women" was urged yesterday afternoon in an address by Dr. Charles Malik of the Lebanese delegation to the United Nations.

Budgetary economies over and above military and foreign aid are possible and the costs of Government must be reduced, "even if some people get hurt in the process," James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, declared last night.

Certificates of merit were presented yesterday by Governor Dewey to thirteen boys and girls from Brooklyn "for leadership, interest in school and community activity and cooperation with faculty and fellow classmates."
Directors of the International Mining Corporation yesterday voted a special distribution of $3 a share to stockholders on June 2.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)-- Officials of the Department of Commerce again are considering use of a jet bomber for tests over airline routes.

The public meeting of members of President Truman's Cabinet, to be convened on Sunday, May 14, at the Civic Opera House in Chicago, will be televised for an hour by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The program will start at 3 P.M.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 5 (AP) --Eight new directors of United Dyewood Corporation were elected and six others were re-elected last night at a hectic annual meeting which lasted for 11 hours and 40 minutes.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 5--Neither rain nor fog halted the qualifying field in the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament over the Seawane Harbor Club course today, but the elements had an effect upon the scores of many of the fifty-eight starters.

WASHINGTON, May 5--The Wisconsin Electric Power Company of Milwaukee sought today from the Securities and Exchange Commission the registration of 585,405 shares of $10 par value common stock and $15,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, series due on June 1, 1980.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 5 --Reliable reports that the British Foreign Office will present a plan for the reduction of Western Allied control in West Germany at the meeting in London of Foreign Ministers of the three occupation powers have aroused deep concern in the Office of the United States High Commissioner.

The days when a white terry cloth wrap was almost a uniform for the beach are long since past. Today there is variety in fabric and style as well as color in the most of smart new jackets that will dot beaches this summer.
BREMERTON, Wash., May 5-- Capt." William Edward Sullivan, U.S.N., commander of the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard here, died yesterday, after a long illness, at the age of 52.

City consumption of water on this week's Dry Thursday was 885,000,000 gallons, or 3,000,000 gallons higher than on the Dry Thursday last week, according to figures made public yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The continued firmness and breadth of the new-issue market for municipal tax-exempt bonds of local government is turning out to be one of the most interesting developments of financial markets this year.

WASHINGTON, May 5--The United States, in another note to Moscow on the Baltic plane incident, accused the Soviet Union today of deliberately disregarding its international obligations and erecting a new barrier to world peace.

ERZURUM, Turkey, April 21-- The brightest spot in the economic future of this remote and rather backward city and province is the small modern slaughter-house and refrigeration plant, pre-fabricated in the United States and just erected here under the Economic Cooperation Administration program.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 5--The world situation has heightened the responsibilities of Americans and their institutions to sustain the new role of the United States as a leader of democracy and freedom in a crucial period, three prominent newspaper executives declared today.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)-- Last year's cotton crop was the fourth largest on record, with a value of $2,549,744,000, the Department of Agriculture reported today in its final estimate.

The Juilliard and New Music String Quartets, two of our finest young ensembles, collaborated in Columbia University's McMillin Theatre last night. They played the first local performances of Milhaud's quartets, Nos. 14 and 15, separately, and then joined forces to render the two works simultaneously.
A shouting band of fifteen to twenty youthful demonstrators, taking a lone policeman by surprise, attacked a sixteen-man German soccer team on the steps of City Hall yesterday morning.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 5--Looking to the day when disarmament negotiations can become politically realistic, United States experts have drafted a plan of safeguards that includes spot checks of military establishments and basic industries.

PARIS, May 5--In advance autumn models Balmain matches fur and fabric: midnight blue mink and wool, pastel mink and taffeta, greige fox and tweed, smoky pink fox and wool velour.

Work on the second of three express ferryboats that the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard is constructing for the City of New York, started yesterday at the Mariners Harbor plant. The new craft are to operate between the Battery and St. George, S.I.
Lynn Patrick, who guided the New York Rangers to the final round of the Stanley Cup play-offs in his first year at the helm of the local sextet, unexpectedly announced his resignation yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., May 5 (AP)-- Charles Coe of Oklahoma City, national champion, seeking his first Western Amateur title, easily stroked his way into the semifinals today as several favorites were eliminated by comparative unknowns.
The strike of 89,000 United Auto Workers against the Chrysler Corporation was settled this week just twenty-four hours short of 100 days since it began last Jan. 25.

Advertising in the seven major New York City newspapers during April totaled 14,223,632 lines, a gain of 11.48 per cent for the seven papers over the like month of 1949, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday.
The Ballet Theatre last night gave the first of its two scheduled presentations of Antony Tudor's "Undertow" at the Center Theatre.

Singing that their "strange illusion" of "foreigners" was past, the junior class of Hunter College won the thirty-fourth annual "Sing" competition yesterday, the ninth time that the junior class has won the silver baton. The senior class production, "True Confessions of a Gypsy," took second place.

The Board of Education may set a precedent by employing a prominent "outsider" to preside over the departmental trial of eight teachers suspended because they refused to tell whether they were membrs of the Communist party.

Completion of the New York Thruway by 1954 to carry a swift, steady flow of traffic between this city and Buffalo was forecast yesterday by Fred W. Fisch, director of the New York State Department of Public Works.

New life was thrown into the stock market yesterday by the television shares. The comeback in these issues was moderate in most instances but more impressive was the rise in Chrysler, in belated response to the settlement of the 100-days' strike.

With blind children, as with seeing ones, "nothing supplants what the parent can do for the child," according to Miss Ruth Butler, casework supervisor of the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 6 to 10 points net higher than on Thursday.

Leon J. Bronesky, co-producer of this season's "How Long Till Summer," has a new musical in tow called "Three Bags Full." A possibility for the fall, the snow might have the acting services of Mickey Rooney, the perennial bouncing youngster of the films.

Seymour R. Candee has purchased the five-story building at 1272-78 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, containing forty-nine apartments, from the Bonbob Realty Corporation. Pearce Mayer were the brokers and the attorneys were Barnett Monke for the seller and Jack Laxer for the buyer.

Homemakers who get the urge about this time of year to pick up their rugs and store them for the summer may be interested in the suggestions offered by two authorities, as well as some tips given in a new booklet on rug care.
Racing activities will be transferred to Belmont Park today. During the spring meeting of 31 days, a total of $392,500 will be distributed in added money for twenty-one stakes races.

Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, reported yesterday to more than 433,000 stockholders.

For the second time this week the women golfers of the metropolitan district yesterday had to play their interclub team matches under the most trying conditions of rain, fog and cold.

There has been too much pressagentry in business and the business press--and not enough public relations--it was declared yesterday at the seventh national conference of business public relations executives.
Several art exhibitions on view this week deserve special attention. Donald Burgess' drawings at the Regional Arts Gallery introduce an adept draftsman who works assuredly in varied styles.

Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Management Association, urged personnel managers and training directors yesterday to show no hesitation in demoting supervisors and rank-andfile employee when demotion is justified.

The city's 26,522 acres of parks and playgrounds are ready to welcome thousands of persons to a wide variety of outdoor recreations during the warm-weather season, the Park Department announced yesterday.

TOBERMORY, Scotland, May 7 (AP)--Royal Navy divers said today they had found a sixteenth century Spanish treasure galleon buried in the mud of Tobermory Bay. Ancient legend, not entirely substantiated by historical research, says there are 30,000,000 gold ducats aboard.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that the country's commercial banks made record operating earnings last year, while their net profits, after taxes, advanced by 12 per cent over the preceding year.

BOSTON, May 7--Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, who will assume command of the Eastern Area and the Third Coast Guard District, with headquarters in New York, on July 1, has been commander of the First Coast Guard District at Boston since Jan. 5.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 7--Playing in the teeth of a gale that swept in from the ocean, Johnny Humm of Rockville, the 1948 Long Island amateur champion, swept off with the final of the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tourney final by defeating Jim Oleska of Shoreview, 4 and 3, today.

ZURICH, May 7--Switzerland may resume the issue of gold coins. Quite suddenly many world-wide problems raised by the recent slump in the price of gold on the international free market have become the focus of discussion among experts of Switzerland.
James A. Hamilton, former Secretary of State of New York, died here early yesterday, after a brief illness, at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. His age was 74.

Dorothy Ross, a young New York soprano of taste and charm, made her local debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her program had as its featured work one of Schumann's masterpieces, the song cycle "Frauenliebe and Leben."

Water storage in the city's upstate reservoirs increased by 728,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday, bringing total storage to 214,993,000,000 gallons or 84.6 per cent of capacity. A year ago the reservoirs were overflowing.
VIENNA, May 7--Early returns of today's municipal elections in Lower Austria in the Russian zone indicate the Austrian Communist party is likely to lose what little influence it commanded.

Packard Motor Car Company reported a net loss of $259,586, after an estimated income tax carryback refund of $161,000, for the three months ended on March 31, 1950. This compares with a net income of $3,911,033, equal to 26 cents a share in the same quarter of last year.
Mayor O'Dwyer's top advisers on city finances agree with the Board of Transportation that there must be an upward revision of fares on the municipal transit lines, effective July 1.

Physically disabled housewives confined to Bellevue Hospital who thought they "couldn't even open a can" find on their return home that they can cook a whole meal and do the dishes afterward. The closely integrated, over-all airport system planned for the New York metropolitan area by the Port of New York Authority is slowly but definitely taking shape. By the end of this year the authority will have spent or committed $65,687,300 for completing or improving the four major airports it now operates.

BRONXVILLE, May 7--Joseph R. Barr, engineer and builder, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 42 Woodland Avenue. His age was 63. Mr. Barr was president of Barr Barr, Inc., 145 East Thirty-second Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Democratic leadership in the Senate has decided on the composition of the recently authorized special committee to investigate nationwide organized crime and its influence on political organizations,

New York retained its leadership as the nation's premier seaport in the handling of overseas waterborne commerce in 1949, according to a study of the year's cargo made public yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Successful employment of the first post-war grants to Germany and Italy to aid study in the classics, literature, history and philosophy was listed yesterday among the 1949 achievements of the Rockefeller Foundation. PITTSBURGH, May 7--A strong scrap market and no let-up in steel demand made last week's steel market look like that of the feverish days of 1947. Then the shortage was severe. The reason was to be found in the loss from strikes last year and early this year, and the renewed confidence shown in manufacturing circles.

Adam Clayton Powell Jr., who has been about as far to the "left" politically as any other Representative in Congress with the possible exception of Vito Marcantonio, has decided not to accept renomination by Mr. Marcantonio's American Labor party, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Powell plans to run for a fourth term in Congress in the fall as a straight Tammany Hall Democrat.

RIMOUSKI, Que., May 8 (AP)-- An army of relief workers took over today where dead-tired fire fighters left off to bring aid to 2,500 made homeless by the worst fire in the history of the region. The citizens of what is left of this fire-wrecked town tried vainly to pick up the charred thread of life among ruins that represented an estimated $20,000,000 property loss.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the resignation of Joseph A. McNamara as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and the appointment to the post of Paul P. Brennan, a Brooklyn attorney who has been serving as confidential clerk to Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. DiGiovanna.

RYE, N.Y., May 8--Mrs. James C. Maples of Apawamis returned a 94 to take the first low gross award today in the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament over the wind-swept west course of the Westchester Country Club.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 8 (AP)--Miss. Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., shattered a couple of records and won medalist honors with a 3-under-par 69 today in the thirty-fifth amateur championship tournament of the Women's Southern Golf Association.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 8-- Syria appears to be on the way to formation, for the first time since Husni Zayim's coup d'etat in March, 1949, of a Cabinet based on Parliament.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, will prefer formal charges today against the eight teachers whom he suspended last week for refusing to answer questions as to whether they ever were members of the Communist party.

A campaign to raise $25,000 for the enlargement of the scope of the Equity Library Theatre, the organization that permits performers to practice their art, has been set in motion, it was announced yesterday by Edith Meiser, recently appointed chairman of E.L.T.
HELSINKI, May 8--The strike of locomotive crews that tied up Finland's railway services for six days ended tonight.
A Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be elected today at the 168th annual diocesan convention at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Robert P. Boylan was re-elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange at the annual elections.
Abraham Brill, senior member of the law firm of Brill, Bergenfeld Brill at 11 Broadway, died yesterday in his home, 1542 Union Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

Bjoern Andreasson, violinist, and Piero Weiss, pianist, who made their debut here as a sonata team last year, last night at Times Hall gave their second joint New York program. It was marked by excellence of ensemble and a nice combination of high spirits and serious musicianship.
BONN, Germany, May 8 (UP)-- Five years after the surrender of the Nazi armed forces, at least fifty-three former Nazis are members of the popularly elected Bundestag, or Parliament, of West Germany.

The stock market was on the defensive yesterday. It had been placed in a technical position that required either an outburst of selling or bidding, and it received neither.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Charges that the Washington Real Estate Board violated the Sherman AntiTrust Act by fixing fees were sustained today by the Supreme Court. Sales of the New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 13 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash report" of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 10 per cent.

ABOARD THE HALF MOON, May 8--Fifty weather men went to sea today in this beautiful snowwhite Coast Guard boat. Designs for extensive improvements to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, costing $4,600,000 and providing for wide rehabilitation and deferred maintenance, were approved yesterday by the Art Commission.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 8-- Paul Draper made his first appearance on the witness stand today in his libel action here. The new taxpayer building on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 185-16 to 185-28 Union Turnpike in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the builder, Saul M. Siegel, to Frank Stina. The building contains seven stores, which are all rented. A.R. Ferrucci was the broker and the attorneys were Zane Lippner for the seller and Marc Shackatano for the buyer.

Curtiss-Wright Corporation's consolidated profit in the three months ended March, 31 amounted to $1,546,620, it was announced yesterday. President Frank Shaughnessy of the International League yesterday ordered a replay of the second game of Sunday's Jersey CityToronto double-header because of stalling tactics. Fines totaling $150 also were assessed.

Pollock, who had headed the Statistical Bureau of the State Mental Hygiene Department for thirty-two years until his retirement in 1943, died today in Petersburg, Va., of a heart attack. A thrilling setting of the Gloria, for chorus, orchestra and two soloists, brought the Town Hall Music Committee's Vivaldi Festival to a successful conclusion last night at Town Hall.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 9-- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, declared today that this country was on the march to socialism "as a result of President Truman's Fair Deal program of deficit spending" and "its accompanying evils."

The one-room living quarters of many New Yorkers probably account for their enthusiastic acceptance of double-purpose pieces which during the day serve as seating units but at night must convert into comfortable beds.

"The New Frontier," a series of dramatic and documentary programs designed to promote tolerance and curb discrimination, will make its bow at 7:30 P.M. Monday, May 29, over Station WNBC. It will be produced by the Institute for Democratic Education.

The prospects for passage of the Customs Simplification Act of 1950 at the present session of Congress are decidedly cloudy at this time, though the bill, sponsored by the Treasury, has the strong support of the State Department, the Commerce Department and the U.S. Tariff Commission.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 9--Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, said today that Secretary General Trygve Lie's European tour "cannot do harm" and "probably will do good."

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 10 --Renewed demands that the Soviet Government account for its Japanese war prisoners were presented to the Allied Council for Japan this morning by William J. Sebald, chairman and United States member.

WASHINGTON, May 9--A $64,000,000 economic aid program for Southeast Asia has been recommended by the State Department's special study group for that area and will probably be started as soon as Congress approves the use of pending funds.

Two intensive retail advertising training courses will be offered concurrently in June by the New York University School of Retailing and the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday. They will cover design and copy.

Strong indications that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office had pierced the silence surrounding the activities of Frank Erickson came here yesterday as Harry Richards, the bookmaker's banking dummy, was reported "cooperating" after a long week-end in jail.

A new approach to the problem of reforming the divorce laws of New York State was submitted to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night at its annual meeting at 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

Macy's, New York, will rely on a recent Supreme Court decision against General Electric Company to upset the latter's motion for a permanent injunction against the store, a representative of Macy's disclosed yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 (AP)-- Armored Israeli forces, using mortars and automatic weapons, have driven 12,000 Arabs from two villages and 55,000 acres ready for harvest south of Hebron in Palestine, an informed source reported today.

CHICAGO, May 9--The home run, long a potent force for the Giants, turned annoyingly on the Polo Grounders today as the Cubs, aided by a favoring wind, popped three balls out of Wrigley Field to win the series finale, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Sumner T. Pike, acting chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, estimated today that the chances for success in the manufacture of a hydrogen bomb lay somewhere between "probable" and "possible."

NORTH PELHAM, N.Y., May 9--Final girders of a bridge here that will be part of a new swift short cut between the Hutchinson River and Cross County Parkways were installed today by contractors and a tedious detour for Hutchinson motorists to avoid the iron work overhead was ended.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee voted today to stop a reduction in postal deliveries and other services. The vote, 9 to 0, sent to the Senate... floor legislation countermanding the order of Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson.

GENEVA, May 3--The first authentic information about postwar cartel agreements in Europe has been published by the Swedish Government after an investigation that occupied nearly two years' time of a ten-man committee.

MANASQUAN, N.J., May 9.-- Although several of the central and northern New Jersey streams are running a bit high, and a few are discolored, those we checked yesterday and today were in fair condition for satisfactory fly fishing.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9--Republican and Democratic legislative caucuses today gave general approval to a compromise government reorganization for the state. It was drafted by party leaders during the past several days.

YONKERS, May 9--The Common Council of Yonkers voted tonight to ask the operators of the new trotting race track here when the city might expect the substantial contribution they offered when the property was acquired last winter.
Nikita S. Khrushchev, Politburo member, has apparently replaced Andrei A. Andreyev as the most influential figure in directing agricultural policy in the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, May 9--Governor Dewey of New York and Governor Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, in identical statements issued at Albany and Trenton, served pointed notice today that they would not permit competition between public agencies over the construction of a new bridge or bridges across the Hudson River.

With only two more matches remaining, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team competition saw new leaders take over in two districts yesterday. In New Jersey, Somerset Hills continues to hold the advantage.

Joseph A. McNamara, who resigned Monday as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was appointed yesterday to the position of confidential clerk to Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. DiGiovanna in Brooklyn.

Plans for the erection of a sixstory apartment house at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and West Seventeenth Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale by the Seventh and Seventeenth Corporation of a plot fronting 103 feet on the avenue and 100 feet on the street.

The credit executive of today is no longer "the man with horns and whiskers," but is a "sales-minded business engineer, eager to work closely with the sales department for increased business," Sol Fuchs, national credit manager of Park Tilford, said yesterday.
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN IN WYOMING, May 9--Just what is an off-thecuff whistlestop speech. President Truman delivered one today that is regarded on this train as a classic.

The United States delegation to the fifth general conference of the International Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization left for Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

LONDON, May 9--Here in London an attempt is being made to freeze the "cold war" where it is in Europe and in Asia. Today Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, and Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, had their first talks about the world situation.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate subcommittee investigating alleged communism in the State Department was summoned today to meet tomorrow in circumstances indicating that departmental loyalty files would be made available to it then.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP)--The Red Sox virtually took command of the American League's early pennant race today by hammering out a 6-1 verdict over the Tigers behind the able pitching of Lefty Mel Parnell.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 9-- Saigon is a tranquil city, but paradoxically assassination flourishes. This is a spacious city with wide boulevards resembling many French Mediterranean settlements and business and pleasure go on as ...

CHICAGO, Wednesday, May 10 --Federal mediators were striving early today to avert a threatened strike of 18,000 members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen scheduled for 6 A.M. against four of the country's major railroads.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 9--Resenting the forced resignation of their president, the Rev. James Forrester, more than half the faculty of Santa Barbara's interdenominational Westmont College resigned today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 9-- The fourth annual technical conference of the International Air Transport Association opened in the Hotel Berkeley Carteret here today with almost 100 representatives of the sixty-seven member airlines present.
WASHINGTON, May 9--It appeared today that Republicans in Congress, watching closely President Truman's "non-political reports" on his "whistle-stop" tour, would attempt to answer him toot by toot.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)--The Administration was reported today about ready to send Congress new proposals in the home mortgage field close behind its new program of aids to small business.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 9 --A series of unexpected Soviet moves in the political field designed to nourish hopes for an armistice in the "cold war," and thus weaken United States proposals for "total diplomacy" in the international conferences in London was predicted here today.

LARAMIE, Wyo., May 9--The United States will try to penetrate Red China's Iron Curtain through private agencies to feed the starving Chinese people with our surplus food, President Truman declared this evening.

The United States should take the initiative in the United Nations for the establishment of a commission on commercial policy under the Economic and Social Council, according to members of the executive committee of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP)-- Pennsylvania Railroad officials today accused the Government of discriminating against the nation's railroads.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 9-- Paul Draper declared today that he was in favor of "routing out all conspirators" in the country but opposed to the use of non-Communist affidavits to achieve this end.

ATHENS, May 9 (AP)--Greek and Yugoslav negotiators have agreed in principle on the restoration of normal relations between the two countries and on measures necessary to make this effective, it was officially announced today.

Young women, including the Misses Cynthia Cogswell and Cherie Hollwedel, are aiding in the plans for the entertainment, known as the Graduates Ball, to be held for the benefit of the Marymount Schools scholarship fund on Friday night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

If ever a community of interest existed between New York and New Jersey it is on the question of location of a new crossing of the Hudson River that could conveniently serve both the New York Thruway and the New Jersey Turnpike. Considerable fencing for position has been taking place.
JACKSON, Miss., May 9 (AP)-- States' Rights Democrats studied a bold plan tonight for an intensive drive in the South for the balance of national political power.
Nana Gollner last night danced her only "Giselle" of the Ballet Theatre's season at the Center Theatre, with Igor Youskevitch and Diana Adams and the rest in their customary roles.
