WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)--The House Armed Services Committee today shelved a plan to permit the Government to build $97,643,000 worth of dwellings for the families of service men in this country.

WHITE PLAINS, May 9--Joe Marra of Dunwoodie bolstered his professional partner, Pat Circelli of Gedney, where help was needed today with the result that the pair walked off with the first proamateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Elmwood Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, May 9--President Truman sent four new reorganization plans to Congress today as the Senate Expenditures Committee voted for killing two more of the twenty-one plans earlier submitted.
MIAMI, Fla., May 9 (AP)--Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker predicted today that Marshall Plan aid to democratic countries would eventually extend to Asia, the Middle East and South America.

The late commission-house and trade selling that caused prices of coffee futures to lose 75 points of earlier gains in Monday's session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange appeared again yesterday.
Borough President Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens said yesterday that he favored immediate city purchase of the Long Island Rail Road's Rockaway branches.

The end of the strike against the Chrysler Corporation has given impetus to the sale of industrial fabrics and chafer cloth, according to Worth Street sources. Many types of goods utilized in automobile manufacturing are moving freely, it was learned yesterday, and June production has been fairly well sold up.

The anti-trust division of the Department of Justice "wars" only against those who strive for monopoly or who engage in restrictive practices that tend to suppress or restrain competition, Herbert A. Bergson, Assistant Attorney General, said here yesterday.

New Jersey's municipal elections were held yesterday, with few surprises except in Union City, where the incumbent ticket, backed by Mayor John W. Kenny of Jersey City as Hudson County leader, got by in the heaviest voting in the city's history.

CANEA, Crete, May 8--Eftikos Protopapadakis, a Cretan mountaineer, said today that the greatest moment of his life had arrived --at last he was able to express his people's gratitude for American aid and benevolence by presenting all he possessed of any value to President Truman.
A well digger, partly buried at noon yesterday at the bottom of a twenty-five-foot excavation in Brooklyn, was still held prisoner there by fallen earth and stone early this morning.

The parking problem in this city cannot be solved unless the police force is doubled, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan declared yesterday at the Women's City Club in the New Weston Hotel.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 9 (AP)-- Documents, names and details of a vast Soviet spy network in Iran, where the first skirmish in the "cold war" was fought, have been handed to Western authorities and the Iranian Government by a former Russian official.
CHICAGO, May 9--Liquidation in soybeans combined with more favorable crop comments on the Kansas winter wheat crop was largely responsible for lower prices on the Board of Trade today.

Since even work-weary homemakers are eligible for some sort of vacation during the coming summer months, a number of new gadgets that make short work of home repair jobs and simplify common chores are making an appearance.

BOSTON, May 9--Dr. Robert P. Blake, professor of history at Harvard University and former director of the university library, died today in a Boston hospital at the age of 63. He was an authority on Byzantine history and the Caucasian languages.

BOSTON, May 9 (AP)--Holders of eight $2 tickets won $3,651.40 payoffs, the largest daily double return in the 16-year history of Massachusetts' pari-mutuel betting, at Suffolk Downs today when the 113-1 Rosalu, a six-year-old mare, and Forever Thine won the first two races.

Mexico City's tribute to Mayor O'Dwyer last year was repaid in part yesterday when Fernando Casas Aleman, Governor of the Mexico City Federal District, received New York's traditional welcome and a formal greeting at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Earl D. Johnson, New York investment counselor, today was appointed Assistant Secretary of the Army by President Truman. His nomination was sent by the White House to the Senate for confirmation.

The progress of the press in the United States in developing responsibility and reliability will depend upon public demand for serious information in contrast with amusement, James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night.

UNIVERSITY, Va., May 9-- Edmund Schureman Campbell, head of the University of Virginia's School of Art and Architecture since 1927, died last night in Washington where he was attending a meeting of the American Institute of Architects. His age was 65.
The Right Rev. Charles Francis Boynton, 44-year-old Missionary Bishop of Puerto Rico, was elected Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday.
Testimony that friends of the Communist party had contributed funds to buy homes for some of its officials came to light yesterday in Queens Surrogate's Court.
HONG KONG, May 9--Peiping announced tonight it had filed a protest with the British charge d'affaires in that city over restrictions imposed on Chinese entering Hong Kong.

They fired a nineteen-gun salute at West Point yesterday for Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan. But, as events quickly proved, the statesman did not really need the protocol to make his visit memorable.

Former President Herbert Hoover warned yesterday that recommendations of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government faced the same "doom" that had been the fate of similar efforts during the last forty years.

CAMP PENDLETON, OCEANSIDE, Calif., May 9--On the surfswept beaches and the rugged mountains of Camp Pendleton, the largest Marine Corps reservation on the West Coast, the Marines are modernizing the doctrines and applications of their traditional specialty--amphibious war.

Generoso Pope, who, starting as a $3-a-week immigrant laborer, made a fortune and became an important figure in Democratic politics, left $4,000,000 of his estimated $5,000,000 estate for charitable, philanthropic and educational purposes.

Fifteen winners of the $1,000 grants made annually by the National Institute of Arts and Letters to non-members in the fields of art, music and literature were announced yesterday by Douglas Moore, president of the institute.

Pink and white cherry blossoms crowned a May queen yesterday in Brooklyn Botanic Garden and-- in breath-taking tints against blue sky--formed a backdrop for hundreds of whirling, sunlit dancers who performed before the royal court.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Robert Ramspeck of the Air Transport Association of America told a Senate committee today that United States plane manufacturers were unable to compete with the heavily government-subsidized British and Canadian aircraft industry in developing jet-powered transports.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9--William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed confidence this afternoon that committees of the A.F.L. and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would meet "in the near future" to discuss merger proposals.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 9-- Mrs. Edith Dunham Foster, widow of William Horton Foster, lawyer, died yesterday in Hackensack Hospital, at the age of 86. Her home here was known as Seven Chimneys.

Hammered from pillar to post in his last previous outing, Ed Lopat came back with a masterful threehit performance last night as the Yankees turned back the Browns, 4--2, in the first nocturnal presentation of the season at the Stadium.

New Coast Guard regulations limiting the handling of commercial explosives in the Port of New York will virtually ban such shipments here and will divert other cargo to rival ports, it was charged yesterday.
LONDON, May 9--The stock markets were quietly steady today with rises outnumbering falls after early hesitancy.

You can now put it down as official that Herman Levin and Oliver Smith, producers of the bonanza musical, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," are planning to offer two shows next season--Sean O'Casey's comedy, "Cock-a-DoodleDandy," and the Harold J. RomeArnold Auerbach revue, "Bless You All."
LAKE SUCCESS, May 9--Erwin Lange, Social Democratic member of the West German Parliament, criticized the Western Allies today on the ground that they had failed to purge Germany of leading Nazis.

The stock market adhered yesterday to a steady course, with emphasis on the oils and coppers while trading broadened to include many specialties. Except for the petroleum issues, price variations were small, with the composite rate up 0.15 point on the day.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 9--The name of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, head of the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton, N.J., was dropped into proceedings of the State Senate Committee on UnAmerican Activities here today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9 --Doubt that the present Congress would take any action to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act was expressed here today by Vice President Alben W. Barkley.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)-- More short line roads will go out of business unless Congress changes the nations transportation policies, a railroad official said today.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 9--Two of the most eminent musicians of our time met this morning in the Civic Auditorium here when Ernest Bloch, the composer, came backstage after a brief rehearsal of the touring N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra to chat with Arturo Toscanini.

The president of a $16,000,000 utility system yesterday chided business men who foresee an economic slump this year with the statement that the 20,000,000 increase in population since 1939 to 151,000,000 represented market opportunities "never before witnessed in the history of this country."

ROME, May 9--Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza will discuss the problem of Trieste and other questions that particularly interest Italy with his Western colleagues during the forthcoming Foreign Ministers' meeting in London.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier and closed barely steady 19 to 30 points net lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Federal Advisory Council of the Bureau of Employment Security is in unanimous agreement that defects and gaps in the Federal-state system of unemployment insurance require speedy correction, it was disclosed today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 9--The National Economic Council today said that the new regulations for the distribution of imported farm machinery could in no way hamper private importation.
The New York Housing Authority borrowed yesterday $7,130,000 on temporary loan notes to help finance state-aided projects at interest rates ranging from 0.90 per cent to 0.92 per cent.

LONDON, May 9--King George VI, accompanied by Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret, visited the twenty-ninth annual British Industries Fair at Earl's Court here today. The fair opened yesterday at Earl's Court and Olympia in London and at Castle Bromwich in Birmingham.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 9--A policy opposing strikes by nurses to back demands for higher wages and better working conditions was adopted today by the American Nurses Association.

Plans for procuring better cooperation between the business community and Columbia University's Graduate School of Business Administration were announced yesterday at a luncheon attended by about seventy prominent business leaders, at the Union League Club.

Discovery of a new antibiotic compound, Illudin-M, which inhibits the growth of human tuberculosis bacilli in test-tube experiments, was announced yesterday by scientists of the New York Botanical Garden, the Bronx, at the opening of its annual five-day spring festival.

PARIS, May 10--The French Government's proposal for combining the French and German coal and steel industries under a, single supranational direction is the most important concrete project for European unification since the war in the opinion of economic experts of several nationalities consulted today.
A White Plains housewife got a judgment here yesterday for $11,195 against a man to whom she said her husband had lost twice that amount in horserace bets.

WASHINGTON, May 10--The Electric Bond and Share Company and its subsidiary, the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for a year's extension of the period within which to comply witn a commission order of May 2, 1949, directing American and Foreign Power to take appropriate steps to reorganize.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, May 10 (AP)--Dumarsais Estime resigned today as President of Haiti and was succeeded by a military junta.

A $2,000 grant of the Whitney Foundation, the progressive spirit and the intelligence and talent of the students of Sarah Lawrence College made it possible for that institution to present "The Triumph of Joan," opera in three acts, music by Norman Dello Joio, libretto by Joseph Machis and Norman Dello Joio, Tuesday night in Bates Hall.

CHICAGO, May 10--Traders placed a somewhat bearish construction on a Government estimate on the winter wheat crop issued after the market closed yesterday. The figures were above trade expectations and since the data for the report were compiled, weather conditions in the Southwest have been generally favorable.

LAURA Z. HOBSON has written another novel that should set the town talking. It is called "The Other Father"* and it is strik ingly different from "Gentleman's Agreement." In fact, apart from the drilling concentration on a single problem, the two novels can scarcely be compared at all.
Bank-eligible obligations of the Treasury were shaded somewhat in price in the dealers' market yesterday, reversing slightly the advances of the early part of the week. There was much conjecture...

G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City declared at the council's annual meeting yesterday that there was urgent need for the greatest possible service on the part of social agencies.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP)--The Cubs profited by four errors to trounce the Braves, 6 to 3, today in the opener of a two-game series.
Woman's Hospital celebrates its ninety-fifth birthday this week. The first hospital in the...

The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 25 on an issue of $25,000,000 of public works bonds to mature serially over fifteen years. Of the total, $19,627,000 is to be used for local school construction and $5,373,000 for state institutions.

LONDON, May 10--Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, tonight bade the people of Britain and Western Europe welcome Western Germany into the "family of Western civilization" as part of the process of preparing democratic institutions for what may be "the greatest test of all."

CAMDEN, N.J., May l0 (AP)-- William G. Helis' Spartan Valor, making the second start of his career, galloped to a six-length triumph today in the third running of the $10,000 added New Jersey Stallion Stakes at Garden State Park.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Western Europe's steel industry is beginning to reflect the results of the $28,600,000 in loans advanced by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development since 1947, the banking organization reported here today.

DETROIT, May 10--The World Council of Churches was sharply criticized here today by two New York Lutheran clergymen for neglecting to give individual churchgoers a "clearer understanding" of Christian thought and tradition regarding war.

CHICAGO, May 10--Large-scale disruption of traffic, together with scattered industrial shutdowns, cutbacks and layoffs marked the first-day effects of the strike called this morning by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen against four major railroads.

Directors of Republic Steel Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, an increase of 25 cents over the last payment. It will be distributed on July 3 to shareholders of record on June 9. In May, August and November of 1949 the corporations' board voted a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share and an extra of the same amount for each quarter.

The house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York voted yesterday to approve the request of the United Medical Service, the Blue Shield medical insurance group for the New York metropolitan area, to raise the income ceilings for eligibility to service benefits.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the purchase of two story properties, "The Burning Bush," written for the screen by Karl Tunberg and Leonard Spiegelgass, and "Come Again Another Day," a recent New Yorker magazine story by Edward Newhouse.

Two suggestions for arranging furniture in the L-shaped livingdining room, one with a traditional touch, the second modern in style, were presented yesterday in model apartments in the nearly completed Sutton Terrace, 450 East Sixtythird Street. In both cases, the furnishings as well as the decorative ideas were supplied by John Wanamaker's.

BERLIN, May 10--An announcement from Moscow of a major reduction in reparations from Germany or the complete cancellation of the program is expected by Western observers here on the basis of a featured article in today's Neues Deutschland, organ of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party.

In graphic design, sharply etched black on white, or white on black and navy and white in the same relationship gave the Russeks presentation its crisp quality yesterday. The summer showing of week-end companions took place in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria at the luncheon hour.
Mrs. George Bethune Adams, former director of the New York Women's League for Animals, died yesterday in Amityville, L.I., at the age of 101.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)-- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced tonight that the Secret Service had smashed a million-dollar syndicate which passed counterfeit money in twenty-eight states and in Canada.

Senator Warren G. Magnuson of Washington, whose sub-committee on maritime matters has conducted an extensive inquiry into the merchant marine, announced yesterday that the committee members were now working on twelve legislative measures and that his staff would have other needed bills ready for presentation to the Senate in the first week of June.

BONN, Germany, May 10--After a series of false starts and hesitations, the West German Government has decided on unalterable association with the Western powers in any cooperative plan brought into being, abandoning any idea of a possible rapprochement with the East, authoritative sources said today.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 10 (AP)--Youth won out over age and experience here today as Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., swept into the quarter-finals of the thirty-fifth amateur championship of the Women's Southern Golf Association with a 3-and-2 victory over Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore, Md.
The special Brooklyn grand jury investigating gambling indicted Acting Police Lieutenant James F. Reilly yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10-- Dr. Albert Einstein will present the original manuscript of his new generalized theory of gravitation to the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, it was announced here tonight on the university's twentyfifth anniversary.

Ever since the First World War the nation's railroads have been fighting with their backs to the wall against the rising tide of competition from newer types of transportation--the passenger car, the motor truck, the airplane and the pipelines.

The first comprehensive record of the advertising industry's work in self-regulation, primarily the elimination of unethical practices, was issued yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
LONDON, May 10--A Conservative challenge to the Labor Government failed tonight in the House of Commons. Labor won with a margin of twenty-three votes.
MADRID, May 10--Spain has just announced plans that, if they go through, would make the nation self-sufficient in aircraft and automobile production and modernize its badly worn railroad system.

April shipments of rayon yarn amounted to 94,400,000 pounds, 11 per cent below shipments in the previous month, which had set the record, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
Fishing reports are brighter from all quarters, and although trout fishermen still complain over the "late" season, the ice has left Maine lakes and coastal waters are improving every day.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Richard C. Cooke, specialist on smallbusiness firms for the National Security Resources Board, died today at his home in Newton, Mass., the agency was informed. He was 55 years old.

When the Big Three Foreign Ministers meet in London today to buttress the bulwarks of the Atlantic World against the menace of Russo-Communist imperialism, they will have before them what is by all odds the boldest and most dramatic European proposal toward that end advanced thus far.
Death and would-be rescuers reached Dominick Atteo the welldigger at almost the same moment yesterday. Death took him.
A daily film recording of the eight afternoon horse races at Belmont Park will be shown over WPIX, beginning next week, only a few hours after the last race of the day has been run.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Thirty Republicans and twenty Southern and border state Democrats suddenly took over the Senate late today and sidetracked the pending civil rights issue.

Donald H. Davenport, director of the division of economic development of the State Department of Commerce, was elected president of the Association of State Planning and Development Agencies yesterday at the closing session of a three-day conference.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10--Citing proposals before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which "if enacted into law will affect United States policy with regard to the United Nations," a resolution presented today to delegates to the fifty-sixth annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs called for reaffirmation of faith in the United Nations.

DURHAM, N.H., May 10--Prof. Clifford S. Parker of the University of New Hampshire and Mrs. Parker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Stetson, to Robert Warren White, son of Rear Admiral Joel J. White, Navy Medical Corps, retired, and Mrs. White.

Begum Liaquat Ali Khan, the First Lady of Pakistan known as the "Mrs. Roosevelt of the East," yesterday tackled a schedule here that might have matched the appearances of the former First Lady of the United States.

Mayor O'Dwyer welcomed yesterday at a brief reception in City Hall ten foreign mayors and other officials here to attend the eighteenth annual United States Conference of Mayors. The threeday conference opens today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP)-- Three unearned runs with two out in the ninth inning helped the Indians snap a four-game losing streak tonight with a 6-4 victory over the Athletics as Bob Lemon received credit for his third pitching victory.

Casey Stengel, manager of the New York Yankees, was the chief speaker and Nat Fleischer, boxing historian, was guest of honor last night when more than 700 City College athletes, coaches, faculty members, alumni and guests gathered in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor for the college's fifth All-Sports Dinner.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP)-- Philco Corporation today reported a record net income of $4,074,000 for the first quarter of 1950 as compared to $915,000 during the same period last year.
CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP)--The oft-beaten Reds started cleaning house today with three deals in less than twelve hours.

The stout resistance of Paul Keres, Estonian chess star, through thirteen rounds of the challengers' tournament at Budapest, broke down yesterday when he lost his first game to Alexander Kotov of Moscow, according to a report from Hungary.

WASHINGTON, May 10--President Truman nominated Dr. Roy Blough, University of Chicago professor and tax expert, to the Council of Economic Advisers today and elevated Leon H. Keyserling to chairmanship of the council.
The chemicals were a stiffening force yesterday in an otherwise limp market in stocks. Price movements again were narrow and final prices were mixed, with the motors, rails and steels easier.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)-- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, demanded today that the Administration immediately cut off "a flood" of oil which he said is being imported by "six giant profit-seeking" companies.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10--The engagement of Miss Charlotte Murray Curtis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Morris Curtis, to Dwight Lyman Fullerton Jr., son of Mr. Fullerton, has been announced by her parents.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard has submitted the loweat bid for the conversion of two P-2 type transports to passenger ships for operation by the Bernstein Line, the Maritime Commission announced yesterday. The yard offered to do the work for $6,774,990.

A novel presenting the Japanese side of the war is scheduled for Aug. 15 publication by Houghton Mifflin entitled "Long the Imperial Way." The author, Hanama Tasaki, served as a conscript in the Japanese army in China, 1936-39.
The Seaboard Air Line Railroad borrowed yesterday $30,000,000 on first mortgage bonds maturing in thirty years at an interest cost of about 3.075 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, May 10--Southpaw pitching, which seems to have become the bane of the Giants' unhappy existence this spring, poured into the Polo Grounders with more damaging results tonight as Max Lanier skillfully hurled the Cardinals to a 5-to-1 victory in the opener of the two-game series.

CINCINNATI, May 10--Shackling the Dodgers with three hits, Ken Raffensberger tonight pitched his first victory of the season as the Reds won, 4--0, while 11,736 cash customers displayed proper appreciation of this epochal fifth triumph in eighteen contests that broke a seven-game Cincinnati losing streak.
THERE is a nursery rhyme which tells the sad tale of the ten little Indians. One by one they disappeared "and then there were none." Thus it has been with the Patrick family.
The young people of the Dramatic Workshop who appeared last night at the President Theatre in "These Are the Times," an original revue, were undertaking an ambitious assignment.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Vice President Barkley appointed today the five members of the special Senate committee that will conduct a nation-wide investigation of organized crime and its influence on political organizations. In announcing his appointees, Mr. Barkley emphasized that he had not consulted President Truman in the matter.
There is an urgent need for more attendants and caretakers in the city's parks, the Park Association of New York City asserted yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., May l0-- Paul Draper, the dancer, conceded in Federal district court here today that funds he had helped raise might have aided the escape from the United States of Gerhart Eisler, the Communist.

STOCKTON, Calif., May 10-- Representative Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California, a ranking member of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, came to the defense today of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, famed nuclear physicist.

JACKSON, Miss., May 10-- States Rights Democrats, openly fighting to survive as a political force in the Southern States, met today in their third annual Southwide convention before a small crowd of 600 cheering persons.

LOS ANGELES, May 10--An opinion of the California Court of Appeal that the United Nations Charter and Declaration of Human Rights invalidated California's alien land law was formally challenged today by State Attorney General Fred W. Howser.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday that the controversy that had raged over a proposal to erect an apartment house at Washington Square North and Fifth Avenue had been settled through a compromise designed to preserve the esthetic value of the square.

Improved training and professional standards in practical nursing are of increasing importance, particularly in the light of the advancing age level of our population, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told the Practical Nurses of New York yesterday.

Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, indicated yesterday that he preferred a battle between Rocky Graziano, the former titleholder, and Champion Jake La Motta in the current lobbying for the middleweight title fight scheduled for June 14 at the Yankee Stadium.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10--The two biggest unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations pledged themselves today to a joint fight for the guaranteed annual wage, union shop, higher pensions and other gains.

Domestic steel mills poured 8,196,050 net tons of raw steel in April, the largest production for that month in the industry's history, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Five hundred persons attended yesterday ceremonies honoring the memory of Horace Greeley, first president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, founder of The New York Tribune, in Greeley Square, at Thirty-second Street, Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas. The exercises were part of the centennial celebration of the union.

WASHINGTON, May 10--In the Cabinet Room of the White House, a Senate investigating subcommittee set out today to examine the confidential loyalty files on eightyone persons accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Leo G. Carroll, the actor, is scheduled to make his entry into the producing ranks next season with a play called "Once an Actor," written by Rosemary Casey, whose recent work, "The Velvet Glove," won The Christophers' prize of $5,000.
SEATTLE, May 10--Arturo Toscanini and the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra gave their last concert on the Pacific Coast tonight and prepared to head back East for the second half of the tour.

Frederick Valiant Bauer is an American boy, not quite 6 months old, who soon may be deported with his sister Carmen, 2 and their parents, to Germany. Although both were born in hospitals on Staten Island, their only home has been Ellis Island.

Non-ferrous metal futures, except copper, continued to display strength on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. In active trading, zinc, lead and tin moved into new high price ground. Ralph S. Damon, president of Trans World Airlines, declared yesterday that because of their high fuel consumption and associated traffic control problems turbojet airliners probably will be impractical for commercial flying "for quite a few years."
New telephone rates, designed to produce an over-all increase of 3 per cent in New York Telephone Company revenues, were approved unanimously yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

In a spacious red-bricked courtyard at 154 East Sixty-eighth Street, able-bodied men, having been certified by the Civil Service Commission, are taught the skills of fire fighting.

Enjoying errorless support in a fast, well-played game, Tom Casey pitched New York University to a 4-1 victory over City College, the home team, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Violet's ninth victory in ten Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference contests, and it now leads by a full game.
EL OCOTAL, Mexico, May 10 (AP)--Hershel McGriff of Portland, Ore., won the six-day 2,178-mile Mexican race for stock cars today by 1 minute, 19 seconds.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10--A lack of uniformity in existing state nursing practice acts has caused considerable confusion over practical nurses in the public mind, the 1950 biennial nursing convention was told here today.

A record March quarter net profit of $16,295,248 was made by the International Paper Company, according to figures reported by John H. Hinman, president, at the fifty-third annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

STAN MUSIAL sat in front of his locker at Ebbets Field yesterday and ran his fingers self-consciously through his coal-black hair. He smiled sheepishly.

New clinical evidence of the significant role played by freedom from anxiety and pain in assuring a successful childbirth was reported yesterday by doctors attending the International and Fourth American Congress on Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Statler Hotel.
Fellow Taxpayers; The President of the United States has just completed a six thousand mile trip at our expense and made fifty-seven speeches, most of them political.
Four years ago Congress created a new agency in Washington, the Council of Economic Advisers, which was apparently destined for a role of considerable importance.

A ship-construction program designed to replace part of the heavy tonnage losses sustained by J. Lauritzen of Copenhagen, Denmark, during World War II is rapidly nearing completion, it was announced here yesterday by Tage Nielsen, director of the company's New York office.

WASHINGTON, May 16--The State Department today named Samuel Reber, a foreign service officer for twenty-four years, to be political adviser to John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany.

After a two-week period of price skirmishing, chain stores and mail order houses have begun to place their cotton goods orders for third and fourth-quarter delivery. These goods will be utilized mainly for spring apparel, which for the mail order houses tvill be featured in their snring catalogues.

American time-payment practices could increase exports of machine tools to Marshall Plan countries, Jerome A. Raterman, president of the Monarch Machine Tool Company, Sidney, Ohio, declared yesterday in an interview at the McAlpin Hotel.
The "mortality" in United Nations delegations, diplomats, sportsmen, choir singers and others who manage to get out from behind the Iron Curtain, even temporarily, is getting high.

Flowering white dogwood trees and mixed white spring flowers formed a garden background yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola for the marriage of Miss Millicent Travers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Elliot Travers of 23 East Eighty-third Street and East View Farm, East Views N.Y., to Stephen David Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Riverdale.

LONDON, May 16--Negotiations now going on between Eric Johnston and the British Government for revision of the AngloAmerican film agreement were described today as "extraordinarily difficult" by Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, at a conference of the National Association of Theatrical and Movie Employes, which has been meeting in Brighton to discuss the financial difficulties of the British film industry.

A central cooperative "blood vessel" bank has been established in New York, making possible replacement of diseased or abnormal sections of human arteries and opening new opportunities for surgical attack on cancer and degenerative ailments, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that he had been getting "quite a bit" of financial help during the last two or three weeks for his oneman investigation of Communists in high places in the Government.

WASHINGTON, May 16--Robert R. Nathan, former Government economist, hoisted an economic storm signal tonight by warning that some corporations are earning too great a profit for their own good and are creating conditions which bring about depressions.

WASHINGTON, May 16--President Truman dared the Republican party today to come up with a program better than the Fair Deal. He issued the challenge in the final speech of his cross-country tour at Cumberland, Md., shortly before he returned to Washington today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)-- Two coal miners suspended from union membership after differences with officials of the United Mine Workers aired their grievances tonight before a Congressional committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 17--Gov. James H. Duff and his running mate, former Judge John S. Fine, early today were conceded to have won the Republican nominations for Senator and Governor as a result of yesterday's Pennsylvania Republican primary.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., informed stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting that results for the year have been profitable. However, the management is far from satisfied with the showing of the company as a whole and is making every effort to improve these results, he said.

Every major city in the United States probably will have natural gas available to it by 1954. This was the estimate offered yesterday by H. Leigh Whitelaw, managing director of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, at a press conference at which he disclosed for the first time a study of the pipeline program of the nation, compiled from Federal Power Commission data.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 17--Gov. James H. Duff and his running mate, former Judge John S. Fine, early today were conceded to have won the Republican nominations for Senator and Governor as a result of yesterday's Pennsylvania Republican primary.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17-- Matthew Cvetic, an under-cover man for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Pittsburgh Communist circles, testified today that Paul Draper, dancer, and Larry Adler, harmonica player, had the reputation of being "Communist entertainers" among western Pennsylvania party officials.

Billed as a "tasting of hams and summer delicacies with appropriate wines," the Wine and Food Society's party on Tuesday recalled (as the weather has failed to) that warm days are ahead and that guests deserve certain seasonal food and drink.

PITTSBURGH, May 17--At the moment, the Pittsburgh Playhouse is putting on its annual musical revue. This year it is called "Fifty Grand" in honor of the first fifty years of the current ungrandish century, and Pittsburgh theatregoers are sufficiently entertained by it to support a run of seven weeks.

In a morning and afternoon "double-header," the Board of Education broke ground yesterday for two new elementary schools in Queens. They are Public School 128, Juniper Valley Road and Seventieth Street, Middle Village, and Public School 184, 163d Street and Twenty-first Avenue, Whitestone.

After trouping across the country on its thirty-ninth annual tour, Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company moved into the Center Theatre last night to open its thirteenth New York season. "La Traviata" was the opening opera and it attracted 2,500 persons.

ABOARD THE M.S. EIDANGER, May 17--"Rolling down to Rio" with the first stop at Santos, the crew and passengers on this Southern Cross Line freight and passenger carrier today celebrated Norway's equivalent of the American Fourth of July. She is a Norse ship manned by Norsemen, and they never forget May 17, 1814, when the Constitution that now rules their country was proclaimed.

J.A. Tompkins Jr. has been named general manager of the York Electric and Machine Company, York, Pa., maker of BiltWell and Foreman axle shafts. He formerly was assistant sales manager for the American Hammered Platon Ring Company, Baltimore.

The leasing by the Barricini chain of candy stores of two store units at the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and West Forty-second Street, opposite Bryant Park, was announced yesterday by Bryant Park Building, Inc., representing the Walter J. Salmon interests. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and the Salmon Management Company arranged the lease for a long-term of years.
Music by an Army band echoed in Wall Street yesterday noon from a rally marking Armed Forces Week on the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 17--Dr. Vladimir Houdek said today that he cabled his resignation to Viliam Siroky, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, late yesterday afternoon. This formality had been overlooked by Dr. Houdek up to the time he received correspondents earlier ...
The poisoned words or Joseph Goebbels are causing dissension five years after the Nazi Propaganda Minister's suicide.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17-- Gov. James H. Duff won a Republican primary victory of landslide proportions today and headed into a tough November fight to unseat the Democratic whip of the Senate, Francis J. Myers.

Carlo Goldoni's classic, "The Liar," as musicalized by Edward Eager and Alfred Drake, will be unfolded this evening at the Broadhurst Theatre under the auspices of Dorothy Willard and Thomas Hammond. William Eythe and Melville Cooper are co-starred. The curtain is scheduled to rise at 8 P.M.

Miss Harriot Gruner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Harry Gruner Jr. of Hewlett, L.I., has completed plans for her marriage to Henry Lawrence Ross Jr., son of Mrs. Olivea White Ross of Pine Orchard, Conn., and of Henry Lawrence Ross of Delray Beach, Fla.
Johnny Saxton, 145 , Brooklyn, wasted no time with Bert Linam, 148, Austin, Tex., in the main bout listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., May 17 --Needle-pointed planes and triangular-wing aircraft with both a camber and a twist in the wing are under test here in the supersonic wind tunnels of one of the world's greatest aeronautical laboratories.
A heightened interest in religion has become evident lately, according to the annual report of the four district superintendents of the New York East Methodist Conference made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17--This morning's news that Gov. James H. Duff of Pennsylvania had won a stunning victory in the Republican primary over the faction long led by Joseph R. Grundy made this just the day to call on a certain politician and ask for his view of the portents.

GENEVA, May 17--Hungary and Czechoslovakia have walked out of an intergovernmental meeting in Berne, called to revise the conventions establishing the legal framework for all international railway traffic in Europe--the socalled Berne conventions.

Conscious of the urgent need for greater efforts to strengthen the defenses of the West, the twelve Foreign Ministers meeting in London have agreed unanimously to reorganize the work of the North Atlantic Council "so that it can exercise more effectively and continuously its role as the principal organ of the North Atlantic Treaty."

WASHINGTON, May 17--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, May 17--A consortium of Argentine banks today obtained a loan of $125,000,000 from the Export-Import Bank of Washington. The money is to be used to clear up the major portion of a blacklog of dollar payments due to United States exporters since late last year.

EAST HADDAM, Conn., May 17 --The Rev. Roy Alvin Welker, a Congregational-Christian clergyman, died last night in his home here after a two-year illness contracted when he was doing relief work in Italy. His age was 60.

With rayon yarn and staple sales beginning to fall off, the rayon industry has reason to fear foreign competition, according to the Rayon Yarn Producers Group. Government officials who will negotiate trade agreements at Torquay, England, in September are urged, therefore, to fight for a restoration of the 25 per cent ad valorem duty on rayon staple plus a 9 cents a pound specific duty.

No further material reductions in unit selling prices in the immediate future are seen by A.L. Cornwell, president of F.W. Woolworth Company who expressed his views at yesterday's annual meeting of stockholders at Watertown, N.Y.

Plans for altering the five-story dwelling on lot 20 by 102 feet at 30 East Seventy-fourth Street into apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the resale of the property by the Harab Realty Corporation after an ownership of two months. The buyer, an investor, intends to occupy one of the apartments, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers in the deal.
Fantasy, mass-produced, took full shape in an improvised studio in the Astor Hotel yesterday when thirty-five artists, throwing seriousness to the winds, put their skills to work for fun's sake.

A glimpse of the nation-wide gambling operations of Frank Erickson was revealed yesterday when the bookmaker was listed as the partner of "notorious underworld characters" in a Florida gambling casino that netted its backers a $685,538 profit in one year.

A vacant plot containing 89,000 square feet on Thirty-second Avenue, between 132d Street and Higgins Street, Flushing, Queens, was purchased by the Gussack Holding Company for improvement with a one-story factory building for its own use. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker.

WASHINGTON, May 17--This country has a "deplorable lack of passenger ships that can be quickly converted to troop transports in event of an emergency," the Joint Committee for the American Merchant Marine declared today in announcing May 22 as national Maritime Day.

Forty members of the first high school graduating class in Manhattan attended their fiftieth anniversary dinner last night at the New York Athletic Club. Since the group finished 44,000 students have been graduated by the institution, now known as De Witt Clinton High School.
WASHINGTON, May 17--Gov. James H. Duff's big victory for the Pennsylvania Republican Senatorial nomination struck a considerable fear today into the Democrats of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Capus M. Waynick, Ambassador to Nicaragua and former North Carolina editor and publisher, was named by the State Department today to direct the first stages of the Point Four program for aiding economically underdeveloped countries.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The new Truxtun-Decatur Naval Museum, dedicated to the story of sea power and the men who created it, will open its doors here tomorrow.
More than 125 executives from eighteen states yesterday saw new magnetic inspection methods which cut costs as much as 50 per cent.

CHICAGO, May 17--With a stunningly played program at the Civic Opera House here tonight, Arturo Toscanini and the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra prepared for departure on their special train tomorrow for the final lap of the transcontinental journey which will take them to Detroit, Cleveland, Pittsburgh, Washington and Philadelphia.
CLEVELAND, May 17--Mayor O'Dwyer of New York attacked the Democratic-controlled Eightyfirst Congress here today, demanding that it stop stalling.

BALTIMORE, May 17 (AP)-- There's a three-way division of opinion today on the probable winner of Saturday's $50,000-added Preakness Stakes, but agreement that a new Pimlico track record is a good bet. Middleground, Hill Prince and Mr. Trouble are as close Preakness choices as they finished in the Kentucky Derby-- one, two, three.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 17 (AP)-- Chinese Communist troops swarming over the abandoned Nationalist blockade base of Chusan Island were attacked today by planes from Formosa.

Kling Factories, Mayville, N.Y., may increase prices of its two cherry bedroom furniture groupings within two weeks, George Dudley, general sales manager, revealed yesterday. He said the company, one of the largest bedroom furniture manufacturers, is carefully studying its new cost position since the recent 15 per cent price increase of cherry lumber.

Fanciers of fine silver will be pleased to learn that the first pieces of Danish silver in the famous Georg Jensen designs to be shown in this country in ten years are available now at the Jensen store, 667 Fifth Avenue.

The stock market continued yesterday to reflect the settlement of the railroad strike. Gains, however, were more selective than on Tuesday and spread over a greater variety of issues. Additions of a point or more were few and the composite average rose 0.77 point on the day.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 17 --David Marvin Goodrich, honorary chairman of the board of the B.F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, died early today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

CHICAGO, May 17--Grain markets closed on a strong rally on the Board of Trade after showing weakness in the early trading. May oats acted congested and finished at the top with a gain of 1 7/8 cents, the future and the cash article going into new ground since July, 1948.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries yesterday announced, in a preliminary statement covering the March quarter, net income of $7,903,479 after all changes but before depletion. This is equal to 91 cents each on 8,674,332 shares of capital stock outstanding and contrasts with $14,005,005 or $1.61 a share earned in the first three months of 1949.

The green light is beginning to shine a bit in that recently congested part of the securities market which is assigned to the distribution of new high-grade bonds. Question marks first raised as to the pricing of $58,000,000 of new Ohio Edison Company bonds were dispelled yesterday when word got ...

An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $58,000,000 of firstmortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds of the Ohio Edison Company due in 1980 at a price of 102 to yield 2.764 per cent. LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17-- J. Dan Talbott, who was the "power behind the throne" of three Democratic governors, died here today at the age of 67.

ALBANY, Calif., May 1 (AP)-- Mighty Citation, making his first start since last March, was beaten in a six-furlong sprint at Golden Gate fields today. Roman In defeated America's No. 1 horse by a length in the world record equaling time of 1:08 2/5.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17-- Khaled el-Azem, Syrian Premier, has decided to go to Riyadh to see King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia instead of returning to Damascus from the Cairo Arab League meeting.

ROME, May 17--Several speakers at today's meeting of the International Federation of Newspaper Editors expressed fear that a proposed United Nations convention on the freedom of information might restrict rather than advance freedom of the press.

Trade buying of rubber futures in large volume sent prices on the Commodity Exchange sharply higher yesterday following reports that the Government had canceled dealer options to buy the commodity from the stockpile. Futures prices were 70 to 135 points higher at the close.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson and Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will confer with Gen. Douglas MacArthur in Tokyo next month in a Defense Department effort to break the impasse here on a treaty of peace with Japan.
Negotiations between the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., and a group of deep-water tanker companies opened yesterday morning at the Commodore Hotel. Another session was set for Tuesday morning.

The "appropriate wines" at the Wine and Food Society's recent tasting of summer delicacies were mostly whites, still and sparkling, with some California roses included. For this tasting, under the chairmanship of the society's secretary, Mrs. Jeanne Owen, about thirty-five wines were set forth in the Belvedere Room of the Hotel Astor.

There is an urgent need today for better community planning and development of civic pride, Edward D. Stone, architect, said yesterday. He and Charles W. Wood of the Associated Merchandising Corporation spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Home Furnishings Division of the Fashion Group at the Biltmore Hotel.
The ivy-mantled walls of Fordham University echoed the sounds of gunfire yesterday as the University Reserve Officers Training Corps held its eleventh annual Demonstration Day exercises.

CRUGERS, N.Y., May 17--Detailed plans for dedication of the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Hospital here at 2 P.M. Sunday were completed today by the Veterans Administration, but they provided for no participation by an member of the Roosevelt family.
WINNIPEG, Man., May 17 (AP) --Flood-stricken Winnipeg was 17 per cent under water today and more areas were threatened as sandbagged dikes weakened under the added burden of a light rain.
Justice Robert H. Jackson of the United States Supreme Court stayed yesterday the deportation of Mrs. Ellen Knauff, the Germanborn wife of a former American soldier.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 17-- France introduced a resolution in the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women today asking that Germany provide assistance to a small group of women, now in Paris hospitals, who had been used by the Nazis for "medical experiments."

WASHINGTON, May 17--President Truman led a group of distinguished men in lauding the brilliant accomplishments of Thomas Jefferson as the first volume of the papers of the great third President was published today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 17--The fishing is so good in Lake Sebago right now that when you stand on the bank with only a crust of bread for bait, you have to beat off the sunfish with a club, practically.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 17--The United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and the Press today deplored the restrictive measures taken by governments under the guise of a state of emergency.
COPENHAGEN, May 17 (AP)-- The International Olympic Committee today ended a three-day meeting devoted more to discussion than decision.

Two new pictures will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the newcomer is "Father of the Bride," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's adaptation of the Edward Streeter book, starring Spencer Tracy and Elizabeth Taylor in the title roles.

Racetrackers hardly expected to see the day when a Florida-bred horse would win a 76-year-old stakes race at Belmont Park, but it happened yesterday. Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Liberty Rab, foaled in March of '48 only a flamingo flight away from Hialeah Park, won the seventy-fourth Juvenile Stakes for 2-year-olds and paid a whopping $66.80 for $2.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Bitterness between supporters and foes of the bill to create a Fair Employment Practices Commission mounted today as the Senate received a petition to force a showdown on the measure at 1 P.M. Friday.

A score-tying two-run homer by Gil Hodges in the sixth inning and a four-run splurge in the eighth inning that drove the old Brooklyn jinx, Max Lanier, to cover last night gave the Dodgers and Don Newcombe a 6-2 victory over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field.

Plans have been completed by Miss Melissa Weston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Weston of 555 Park Avenue and Southampton, L.I., for her marriage to Edwin Richards Bigelow, son of Mrs. Eugene S. Taliaferro of 116 East Sixty-third Street and Oyster Bay, L.I., and of Edwin Hicks Bigelow of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced two new projects for production during the coming year; an untitled film dealing with the declaration of human rights in the United Nations Charter and a picture about the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, "The Story of Constable Pedley."

HOUSTON, May 17 (AP)--Glenn McCarthy today said he is sorry if his comments on negotiations with the Equitable Life Assurance Society and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company offended Thomas I. Parkinson, president of Equitable Life.
Nothing can halt the spiraling increase of sex crimes in New York State except drastic steps to expand diagnostic and treatment services, two leading psychiatrists said here yesterday.

PEARL HARBOR, May 17 (AP)--A couple of "rice fat" United States fliers today considered offers totaling a possible $100,000 for their story of eighteen months as captives of the Communists in North China.

Beginning Aug. 1, travelers entering the United States will be subject to new restrictions on the amount of perfumery they bring through customs, it was announced yesterday at the Toilet Goods Association convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The first study of the quality of medical care provided to middle and lower income groups by the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York was made public yesterday at the International and Fourth American Congress on Obstetrics and Gynecology.
The majority of Bulgaria's peasants are not yet convinced of the superiority of collective farms, Vulko Chervenkov, head of the Bulgarian Communist party, acknowledged in a recent speech.

Outstanding paintings by young members of the Girl Scouts, Children's Aid Society Lower West Side Center and the Police Athletic League will be on view in the children's section at the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, which opens tomorrow. This annual event offers varied and colorful exhibits displayed along the sidewalks, fences and front steps in the heart of Greenwich Village.

NEW CASTLE, Northern Ireland, May 17 (AP)--The last American was eliminated from the British women's golf tournament today, leaving the champion of France and a former British links queen to fight it out in tomorrow's thirtysix-hole final.

ALBANY, May 17--Governor Dewey said tonight that political control of the healing arts would wreck the health of the nation by halting the vast strides in medical research accomplished under free enterprise.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, seeking to encourage investments and thus stimulate business, voted today to reduce taxes on profits from the sale of such assets as stocks, bonds and real estate, and otherwise to liberalize the tax treatment of capital assets.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17-- The Federal Reserve Board today ended the San Francisco phase of its hearing of "monopolistic tendency" charges against Transamerica Corporation, with Mayor Elmer E. Robison appearing as a voluntary defense witness.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The Senate Finance Committee voted today to recommend to the Senate a bill to increase Social Security coverage to about 10,000,000 individuals not now covered and to increase the old-age and survivors benefits.
Automatic reinstatement of the United States duty of 2 cents a pound on copper imports on June 30 will be a severe blow to Chile, Alfonso Grez, Chilean Consul General in New York, said yesterday.
