ST. LOUIS, May 17--For a protracted period of bewildering activity today, the Browns were in imminent danger of scoring their first home victory of the campaign at the expense of the Yankees.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 17-- Stephen A. Bissett, who worked up from cabin boy to become captain of a West Indian square-rigger before he was 24, died last night at the home of a daughter in Hamilton, R.I., at the age of 103.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The United Mine Workers and other independent unions will be temporarily excluded from labor unity conferences between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Some of the promises, dangers and alternatives of "welfare state" policies were discussed yesterday by Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University.

The strife-ridden and bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation found itself confronted with a new strike threat last night in a row over economies ordered by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman to get the city's biggest private bus company out of the red.

WASHINGTON, May 17--President Truman today refused to grant the Senate an opportunity to reconsider its confirmation of John W. Kern of Indiana for reappointment to the United States Tax Court for a new term of twelve years.
TRENTON, May 17--The New Jersey Legislature ended its 1950 session tonight after approving the principal measures of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's program.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The Columbia Gas Systems, Inc., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authorization to sell $110,000,000 of debentures, Series A, due in 1975, at competitive bidding.

CHICAGO, May 17--The popularity of self-service of prepackaged meats is increasing in stores throughout the country, Dr. Nelson Allen, suervisor of packaging research for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said today. He spoke before the convention of the Super Market Institute on effective marketing of foods.

In a garden setting of white lilies, carnations, gladioluses and greens in the Cottage of Hampshire House yesterday afternoon Miss Jacqueline Lehrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lehrich of Brooklyn, was married to Herman David Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Becker of Terre Haute, Ind. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Sack.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Dr. William Adams Slade, first director of the Folger Shakespeare Library and retired chief reference librarian of the Library of Congress, died at his home here yesterday. His age was 75.

Gov. James H. Duff's stunning primary victory in Pennsylvania has important national as well as local implications. The issues were clear cut and the verdict was decisive. It was a victory for the faction of the party that regards itself as progressive, and a setback for the "Old Guard" conservative leadership.

PARIS, May 17--The British Government formally proclaimed today its willingness to become a full member of the projected European payments union. Until now Britain had insisted upon a special status for herself and her sterling payments system that would have made her far less than a full member.

An attractive program of chansons was presented by Beatrice Waghalter in Times Hall last night. She is the daughter of Ignatz Waghalter, German-Polish composer-conductor, and this was her first American recital.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The Senate killed late today President Truman's proposals for the reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal Communications Commission.
Chester I. Barnard, president of the General Education Board, said yesterday it is now using its resources almost exclusively to improve education in the South.

In a Frank Merriwell finish, Columbia scored four runs in the ninth to tie the game and then, behind by 9--7, sent three more across the plate in the twelfth to defeat Holy Cross, 10--9, for the first time since 1930 yesterday at Baker Field.
SALISBURY, L.I., May 17-- The newest of post-war golf courses, which will be for the use of Nassau County residents and property owners, was opened officially today.

On the strength of a first-class pitching performance by Sheldon Jones and a bit of concentrated activity at the plate in the first three innings, the Giants evened their current series with the Cubs before 5,631 witnesses at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The latest battlefield in the perennial struggle for freedom of expression is Montevideo, where a subcommission of the United Nations is meeting. That all delegations should have condemned Russian jamming of foreign radio broadcasts is both gratifying and natural.

Any effect of New York City rain-making operations to date has been felt only in the Catskills, if anywhere, and has had nothing to do with the weather in the city or immediately surrounding area, Dr. Wallace E. Howell, the city's consultant meteorologist, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (U.P.)-- Agriculture officials said today that it would take only a slight boost in per capita turkey consumption during the next sixty days to save the Government from a multi-million-dollar price-support loss this summer.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 17-- Aubrey S. Eban, Israel's chief United Nations delegate, today urged the Western powers to ship arms to his country to restore the "military balance" in the Near East.

Outstanding members of Alpha Delta Sigma, honorary advertising fraternity, from forty-one colleges will be guests of the Association of Advertising Men here June 1216 at a special "inside advertising" program, it was announced yesterday.

The earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation this year should compare favorably with those of 1949, P.C. Spencer, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. He said also that recent improvement in prices of oil products and the economies put into effect by the corporation make prospects for second-quarter earnings very encouraging.

Publication of a Braille edition of the Hebrew Scriptures, completed after five years of painstaking effort at a cost of more than $20,000, was announced yesterday by the Jewish Braille Institute of America.
DETROIT, May 17 (AP)--The Tigers beat the Red Sox, 6--3, today, behind the nine-hit pitching of Ted Gray. It was the left-hander's second triumph of the season over Boston.
NEWARK, May 17--Chiefly with pennies collected from the students of Arts High School here, Aaron Burr, controversial figure in early years of the United States, was honored here today as a patriot.

The sudden suggestion that Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie be chosen to run against Representative Vito Marcantonio in the Eighteenth Congressional District ought to have a beneficial catalytic effect on coalition. It instantly elevates the standard of candidateseeking to an eminence not previously reached, and should wash out of the ...

Authentic case histories of the use of the lie detector in solving crimes will be featured in a new series of radio programs over WOR-Mutual, beginning on Wednesday from 8 to 8:30 P.M. Entitled "The Hidden Truth," the episodes will be adapted from the files of the late Leonarde Keeler, a criminologist who perfected the lie detector.

American Airlines plans to use electronic reservation machines that will keep an inventory of the 1,250,000 seats aboard its planes flying the 10,000 legs of an aerial network that covers the United States and Mexico, it was announced yesterday.
A material witness before Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury was warned yesterday that he faced a contempt citation or prosecution on a perjury indictment if he did not "tell the truth."
An emergency medical service that will make general practitioners available on a twenty-fourhour basis for persons who cannot get their own family doctors was started yesterday in Staten Island.

Returning from a four-week tour of leading cities in all parts of the country. Pricess Gabrielle de Liechtenstein, producer of white wines in the Moselle Valley, put it up to two groups, waiters and retail dealers, to encourage Americans to drink more wine.

The Giants yesterday announced the purchase of Third-Baseman Johnny Jorgensen from the Dodgers and the sale of veteran Catcher Ray Mueller to the Pirates. Both were straight cash transactions, the amount involved being undisclosed.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 17 --The Women's Long Island Golf Association was the last group to open its season of one-day tournaments but it certainly produced the best golf as three players broke 80 yesterday over the Piping Rock Club course.

WASHINGTON, May 17--State Department and other Government authorities began their study today to determine whether Dr. Vladimir Houdek, Czechoslovak United Nations delegate who resigned from his post yesterday, would receive political asylum in the United States.

An employer who calls a meeting on company time to advise his workers to vote against a union need not give the union an opportunity to answer at a similar meeting inside the plant, the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday.
The New York Adult Education Council took steps yesterday to strengthen its organizational structure to meet the demands of an expected heavy growth in adult education.

Expanding health needs of the district served by Roosevelt Hospital at Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue will necessitate a substantial enlargement and expansion of hospital facilities, Gayer G. Dominick, president of the institution, said yesterday in his annual report.
The Bankers Securities Corporation resumed the payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of $1.50 a share against accumulations, payable on June 30.
Mayor Donald W. Kramer of Binghamton charged last night that the administration of Governor Dewey had more than doubled the state budget and put the state debt at a record high.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce tightened its export controls today over nylon parachute cloth and some other strategic materials to prevent their shipment to Communist areas.

ROME, May 18--Donna Ida Einaudi, wife of President Luigi Einaudi of Italy, smashed the traditional bottle of champagne against the steel bow of the liner Giulio Cesare at Monfalcone in the Free Territory of Trieste this ...

The United States Government will embark on a long-range and intensive study of ship tonnage measurement as a step toward eliminating costly and confusing international variations in tonnage interpretations, it became known yesterday.

The one-story store building at 705--709 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Sterling Broadway Corporation, of which Edward Benenson is president, to an investing client of Tart Brothers Wald, attorneys.
The boomlet in non-ferrous metals pushed forward yesterday with a one cent, a pound rise in copper prices, increased scarcities in zinc and a firmer tone throughout other metal markets.

ALBANY, May 18--Governor Dewey has told Republican State leaders he will not run for a third term this year but he has agreed to meet with them again to discuss the matter on June 9, his secretary, James C. Hagerty, announced today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 18--Enlightened self interest should spur the outside world to consider making vast investments in Germany, despite the fact that the spot money yields cannot measure up to the risks involved.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18-- Once more the historic Garden City Golf Club course proved an enigma to most of the 129 who participated today in the qualifying round of the Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney, the fortieth spring invitation event of the club.
WASHINGTON, May 18--President Truman told his news conference today that the advance of $125,000,000 made to Argentine banks yesterday by the ExportImport Bank of Washington was a good loan.

A flurry of orders has bolstered the sagging market for rayon textiles, it was learned yesterday, and suppliers are confident that a good volume of business will be transacted for summer and fall. Prices are inching up from their recent lows and off-price purchases are confined to smaller lots, according to rayon goods converters.
Continuing their downward movement for the second successive week, business loans made by banks in this area dropped $18,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

Several hundred members of the New York Athletic Club were among 18,164 winner-seekers at Belmont Park yesterday. The main event, a mile-and-a-sixteenth run for 3-year-olds, was named for Harry L. Lindquist, the Winged Footers' president.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 18 --Obstacles never bfeore envisaged have popped up to slow down if not halt the progress of jet-propelled air transport planes, it was brought out here today at the meeting of the International Air Transport Association.

Panels that may be pulled out to close a room off for privacy or pushed back and hidden in the wall to make one spacious room of two smaller ones are a novel feature of an exhibition house that opens to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art.

GENEVA, May 18--Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, returned to Geneva today from Moscow, where he tried to break the deadlock in discussions of East-West trade.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP)-- Middleground, a heavy blanket of fog and a driving rainstorm arrived simultaneously today at Pimlico. It looked as if the Seventy-fourth Preakness Stakes on Saturday could be a battle of mud runners.

All-weather flying will be practical ten years from now provided the country develops enough airports, it was said yesterday by John B. Bartow, developer of an approach lighting system, at the opening of a permanent aeronautical exhibit at La Guardia Airport.
LOS ANGELES, May 18--The National Association of Credit Men, concluding its national convention here today, urged in a resolution that the Federal Government return to a balancedbudget policy.
Twenty thousand Boy Scouts from throughout the country are expected to swoop down on New York soon and arrangements are being made to set out the city's welcome mat for them in the grand manner.

CHICAGO, May 18--Reports that 40-pound-a-bushel dark-colored Argentine oats were being offered at 84 cents a bushel duty paid at New York started a selling movement in that grain today that resulted in the close being 1 5/8 to 2 cents lower after May and July had sold at new seasonal peak prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 18--Bernard M. Baruch, former United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight that an agreement to prohibit the use of atomic bombs, without inspection to see that it was carried out, "would not be anything."

Stirrings in the movement for more adequate representation of the interests of the individual investor in the political economy of the nation were reported yesterday by rival investors' associations --the Investors League, Inc., and the new Independent Investors, Inc.

In a bedlam of shouted protests yesterday, the Board of Education opened the way for appointing a leading jurist or other qualified person to preside over the departmental trials of eight teachers suspended recently because they refused to say whether or not they were members of the Communist party.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 4 to 18 points higher.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 18-- The insistence of schools on teaching the "slow learner" subjects in which he cannot succeed often damages his self-confidence, leads to his rejection by teachers and classmates and makes him vulnerable to neurotic or delinquent behavior.

At the fourth session of the Atlantic Council in London the foreign ministers of the twelve nations of the North Atlantic Treaty considered the principles on which their association is founded and the objective toward which they are working.

The birth of a baby should be a real family affair with father helping his wife in the labor room --in some cases even being present at the delivery--and with young brothers and sisters allowed to visit their mother and the newcomer in the hospital.

Testimony on the feasibility of changing the specifications of the projected bridge between Welfare Island and Thirty-sixth Avenue, Queens, was presented yesterday to the Army's Corps of Engineers by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

McAlister Coleman, Socialist leader, author and newspaper man, died yesterday in his home at 115 East Ninetieth Street after a long illness. Mr. Coleman, who was 61 years old, was an almost perennial candidate for offices ranging from Alderman to United States Senator.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18 --A division of opinion among Westchester library officials concerning the type of state aid they should seek under the library bill signed six weeks ago by Governor Dewey broadened today as a steering committee prepared for a decisive meeting Monday night in the Mount Vernon Public Library.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 18 (AP)-- The Chinese Nationalists went all out today to give a heroes' welcome to the troops withdrawn from the Chusan Islands.
First quarter earnings of the American Export Lines, Inc., were lower than the similar period a year ago, John E. Slater, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--A one-year extension of Federal rent controls--but only in cities and other localities that want to keep them--was approved today by the Banking Committee of the House of Representatives. The vote was 18 to 4.
A tiny item tucked away in our newspaper a few days ago has, somehow, says a chap with cherished memories of
"Simple Simon," heralded as the world's smallest, dumbest mechanical "brain," had his debut here yesterday.

The servicing of more than 1,300 American ships with libraries and a marked rise in attendance at the organization's shore library, were reported yesterday by John F. Noble, executive director, at the 123d annual meeting of the American Seamen's Friend Society, at 175 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 18--A "monorail" elevated railroad that would carry Long Island commuters from Montauk Point to Manhattan in fifty minutes for $1 fare was pictured to a Senate subcommittee today by John A. Hastings, former New York State Senator. Its trains would be capable of 150 miles per hour.
Mrs. Norman Tishman, wife of the builder, has purchased a fifteen-acre homesite on the high point of Old Mamaroneck Road in Mamaroneck, N.Y., from Crystal Brothers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 18--Senator Owen Brewster of Maine, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, disclosed on the floor of the Senate today that the airplane that bore the Republican "shadow" along President Truman's western itinerary was paid for by John W. Hanes, one-time Under Secretary of the Treasury under President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, May 18--About $353,000,000 will be spent in construction or renovation of super markets throughout the country this year, according to the annual report of the Super Market Institute, presented today at the final session of its convention.
That velveteen and corduroy are fabrics for all seasons was made clear yesterday afternoon at the Merrimack show held on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The stock market was able to make only limited progress yesterday. Price movements through the greater portion of the session were irregular, with best strength exhibited by the oils and an array of selected issues.

LONDON, May 18--Declaring that "the free man can never be vanquished by the slave" Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, laid down tonight the moral and spiritual basis for the Western world's resistance to the Soviet Union.
Digging back into the eighteenth-century commedia del arte of Italy, a band of earnest people turned up with a musical version of Carlo Goldoni's "The Liar" at the Broadhurst last night.
New York City began yesterday looking for new Catskill field headquarters for its consultant meteorologist, Dr. Wallace E. Howell.

Observances emphasizing the unity of the Army, Navy and Air Force and their close ties with civilian activities were held yesterday as Armed Forces Week moved toward its climax--the first Armed Forces Day in the nation's history tomorrow.

Sidney Sherwood, secretary of the Export-Import Bank, asserted yesterday that the granting of loans to Israel was not enough to build the nation's economic structure and that "expression of confidence in the new state by private business men in the form of actual investment of private funds is essential."

Frank Erickson's financial data, including a series of records that indicated he had transferred valuable oil interests in Texas to Frank Costello, gambler, were subpoenaed yesterday by the grand jury investigating gambling in New York County.

Spring is a season when we become more conscious of the conditions in our parks and, as usual, there is considerable criticism. The Park Association of New York City, which is certainly not given to exaggeration and has always been sympathetic to the Park Department in its many problems, says that "deplorable conditions" have developed in many parks and playgrounds.

A formal complaint that situations-wanted advertisements in the Journal of the American Medical Association stimulate and encourage racial and religious discrimination was submitted yesterday to the State Commission Against Discrimination by the American Jewish Congress.

THAT there is a connection between the words authors write and the ills of their flesh has been suspected for a long time. But whether any serious effort to study that connection and to form artistic and psychological conclusions has ever been made I do not know.

WHENEVER the Kentucky Derby is a rousing race the Preakness assumes added glamour and appeal. Whenever the Run for the Roses is a cakewalk, the run for the Black-Eyed Susans lacks interest. The Churchill Downs classic was a dilly this year. Therefore, the Pimlico classic, the second gem in turf's famed Triple Crown, should be a thriller. The entire proposition practically fits into syllogism form.

LONDON, May 18--The twelve foreign ministers forming the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty concluded their London meeting tonight with an announcement that they had taken six specific steps for strengthening the alliance of the free nations of the West. These were:...

HONG KONG, May 15--With the exception of Portuguese Macao, the British colony of Hong Kong is the last open door into and out of Communist China. All along the coast, from Hainan to the Yellow Sea, normal maritime trade with the great Asiatic heartland is drying up. As a result Hong Kong is booming.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)-- The Federation for Railway Progress tonight honored the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for "outstanding achievemnet in progressive passenger service" during the past year.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 18 --Western Allied and German officials are considering lifting the three-month-old embargo on the shipment of Ruhr steel products to the Soviet zone.
WASHINGTON, May 18--On an overwhelming voice vote, the Senate rejected tonight President Truman's proposal for reorganization of the Department of Agriculture.

WINNIPEG, Man., May 18 (AP)-- Southern Manitoba's flood fighters, barely holding their own, faced a threat of heavy thunderstorms throughout the Red River Valley tonight. The weather bureau forecast half an inch of rainfall.

WASHINGTON, May 18--President Truman told his news conference today that he wanted an absolutely independent Congress, freed of "obstructionists," whom he defined as Senators and Representatives of both parties who were against every measure for the welfare of the people.

BOSTON, May 18--Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, called today for a complete overhaul of Federal anti-trust laws, branding them as a "hodge podge" that made "potential jailbirds" out of American business men.

Though fewer cuts are affected in this, the fifth successive week of higher meat prices, that is small consolation for shoppers. Tariffs on most items at the butcher's are forbidding and from the United States Department of Agriculture comes word that they're likely to stay that way for another week.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The House Ways and Means Committee, dealing a major new blow to President Truman's tax program, rejected today the Administration's recommendations for reducing special tax allowances available to producers of oil, gas and other minerals.
WASHINGTON, May 18--Department store sales in the week ended May 13 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A Grand Guignol Theatre, with all its gory aspects, is being planned for Broadway next fall by George K. Arthur, comedian in the silent-film days.
Evidence of the first organized efforts to raise fradulently checks drawn on the Treasurer of the United States was reported here yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ALBANY, May 18--The Public Service Commission approved a certificate of incorporation for the new Niagara Frontier Transit System, Inc., today, thus bringing the reorganization of the International Railway Company of Buffalo nearer completion.
Staten Island taught the rest of New York an object lesson in public service yesterday as the borough's twenty-four-hour emergency medical service went into full operation on its first day.
MEMPHIS, May 18 (AP)--Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that 1950 "will be one of the most profitable business years in our history."

WASHINGTON, May 18--President Truman today hailed the French plan for pooling French and German steel and coal industries as an act of "constructive statesmanship" that would foster the regeneration of Europe.

Young women headed by Mrs. Charles N. Breed Jr. are serving on the junior committee for the tea and cocktail party, known as "Salute to Summer" to be held Monday afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.
Many parties were given at the dinner dance held last night to mark the formal opening for this season of the St. Regis Roof.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 18--The United Nations Human Rights Commission, which has been trying laboriously to convert some of the principles of the Universal Declaration on Human Rights into a binding document, agreed unanimously today, but with little enthusiasm ...

The various productions at the New York City Center grossed $1,125,555.08 at the box office during its latest fiscal year, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday at the seventh annual meeting of the incorporators of the center.
CLEVELAND, May 18--Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York charged here today that some elements in this country favored "a floating pool of unemployed" to keep wages down.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 18 (AP)-- Super-Salesman, racing in the silks of Henry Lewis 3d, won the featured Reciprocity Purse by two lengths at Garden State Park today before a rainy-day throng of 11,000.

The former chief attorney in the Lower Manhattan office of the Housing Expediter and the owner of the London Terrace apartments were convicted yesterday at 6:25 P.M. by a Federal jury of conspiracy to obtain rent increases for 300 London Terrace apartments.

Columbia University's sixth annual festival of contemporary American music was launched last night with the first of four programs to be given at the McMillin Academic Theatre. The opening event consisted of a recital of songs for voice and piano and the composers were John Edmunds, Howard Swanson and Aaron Copland.
The legality of union rules barring Communists from membership was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer.

Shortages and skyrocketing prices for many construction materials have thrown the home building industry in New York and throughout the nation into confusion and have brought on a new "gray" market for some key products.

The loss of jewelry valued at $75,000 and $600 in cash was reported to the police yesterday by Mrs. Ammenouito Nisirian of Essex House, who is one of the owners of the Orian Tobacco Corporation, 15 William Street.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The Senate Armed Services Committee announced today that hearings on an extension of the peacetime draft would be opened June 1, twenty-three days before expiration of the present law.
A weekly trip to the Bronx Zoo will be offered for television viewers by the American Broadcasting Company and WJV-TV, beginning Sunday afternoon, June 4. The hour will be from 4:30 to 5 o'clock.

New studies indicating that fresh and not long-stored blood from a blood bank should be used to help stop excessive bleeding after childbirth, which is often fatal, were presented yesterday during the International and Fourth American Congress on Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Statler Hotel.
DETROIT, May 18 (AP)--The Red Sox nearly tossed a 10-run lead away today as they beat the Tigers, 13--12, to topple Detroit from its tie with the idle Yankees for the American League lead.

Tiberio Mitri, middleweight battler from the Free City of Trieste, will make his first appearance in an American ring when he tackles Dick Wagner of Toppenish, Wash., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The United States will build up the size of its Air Force and Navy under the strategic plans for the collective self-defense of Western Europe shaped at the London... meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty nations, Administration sources said today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP)-- The lead shifted again today in the vote for the presidency of the International Typographical Union, A.F.L.

Bernard M. Baruch renewed last night his pleas for the immediate passing of stand-by economic mobilization laws, covering prices, wages, profits and manpower, to be put into effect in case of a national emergency.

WASHINGTON, May 18--Leo Teplow, associate director of the Industrial Relations Division of the National Association of Manufacturers, today testified that the association had completely endorsed the principle of equal pay "not only as a matter of policy but as practice."

Dick Wakefield is back on the Yankee payroll but by no means back in the good graces of General Manager George Weiss, who suspended the outfielder for refusing to report to the Chicago White Sox, to whom he had been traded on April 29.
CINCINNATI, May 18--The Rev. Dr. Hugh Ivan Evans, pastor of the Westminster Church of Dayton, Ohio, was elected Moderator of the 162d General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. today.
"Ticket to Tomahawk," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy in Technicolor, starring Dan Dailey and Anne Baxter, will have its premiere this morning at the Roxy.

A compromise proposal for settlement of the dispute over the projected layoff of 300 workers on the bankrupt Third Avenue Transportation System was put before management and union representatives yesterday by Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the City Labor Relations Division.

WASHINGTON, May 18--Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, of which he is chairman, would start its inquiry by delving into the extent of concentration of money, property and wealth in the hands of gamblers, racketeers and criminals.
NEW HAVEN, May 18--Yale University has developed plans for a ten-year improvement program for which it seeks $80,000,000, Dr. Charles Seymour, president of the university, announced here today.

The American Cyanamid Company opened yesterday an offering of nearly $50,000,000 worth of new convertible preferred stock to the company's stockholders at terms which included a yield of 3.43 per cent as preferred stock and a tenyear call on the company's common ...

The Miltar Realty Corporation, representing Jack Tarr and Milton Adler, son of Louis Adler, builder of the office skyscraper at 100 Park Avenue, yesterday bought the five-story tenement house on lot 25 by 103 feet at 532 East Fourteenth Street for improvement with a one or two story taxpayer.
ALBANY, May 18 (AP)--The Conservation Department said today that liquid cyanide from a defunct electroplating plant was responsible for killing thousands of fish in the Mettowee River.

PARIS, May 18--Since the British agreement to become a full member is considered to insure creation of the European Payments Union, officials here foresaw early further steps toward what Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administration head, has called the integration of Europe.
The students of the Parsons School, 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, did themselves proud in a presentation of original designs shown yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel.

NEWARK, May 18--The trial of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's suit against two score defendants to invalidate the sale by private owners of two toll bridges to the Burlington County Bridge Commission for $12,000,000 in October, 1948, opened today in Superior Court before Judge Walter J. Freund.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 18-- Miss Alethea Kunhardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley Kunhardt, has chosen June 17 as the date of her marriage to Harry Webster Walker 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster Upson Walker of Fairfield.

A new state-wide health program designed to aid the State Health Department and local communities in establishing modern local health departments has been organized by the State Charities Aid Association, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, executive director of the association, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18-- Jean Sablon, French actor, will make his English-language screen debut in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "An American in Paris," with Gene Kelly and Oscar Levant, it was learned today.

Mayor O'Dwyer denounced Communists in the public welfare field yesterday for employing fear and insecurity as weapons with which to turn the needy against their country. His attack was... made in addressing the Northeastern regional conference of the American Public Welfare Association at the Astor Hotel.

Whether compulsory employe insurance will be administered by state or private insurers is a critical issue for the future of free enterprise, James S. Kemper, chairman of the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company, informed policyholders yesterday.

In his tax message of last January President Truman proposed that Congress grant a moderate amount of relief from wartime excise levies on a selective basis. His own specific suggestions added up to some $655 millions.

WASHINGTON, May 18--Marion B. Folsom of Rochester, N.Y., was elected chairman of the Committee for Economic Development today. In his inaugural address, he called for help from all groups in the economy to keep production expanding and employment at a high level.
Reports that a bid of $1,250,000 has been made for the needlepoint carpet made by Queen Mary of Great Britain and now being shown on a tour of the United States were denied officially yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18--During the week ended May 17 member bank reserve balances increased $216,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, May 18--A story of nineteen months of imprisonment by Chinese Communists during which a mild but determined attempt to indoctrinate them was made by their captors, was told here today by Marine Master Sgt. Elmer C. Bender and Navy Chief Electrician's Mate Elmer C. Smith.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, described yesterday as "confused and garbled half truths" a statement made Wednesday at a State Charities Aid Association meeting that thousands of beds were idle in voluntary and private hospitals while city institutions faced serious overcrowding.
WASHINGTON, May 18--Synthetic yarn workers decided today to seek an "across-the-board" wage increase of 25 cents an hour and old age pensions of at least $100 a month.

PARIS, May 18--Reform of the French electoral system and a possible reorganization of the Government to include the Socialists are the chief issues before a series of party meetings that started today with the Popular Republicans of Premier Georges Bidault in a Congress at Nantes.
