Four Cincinnati home runs, one of them bitterly disputed, were the chief instruments of destruction for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Reds winning,10--9, to snap their losing string at six games and at the same time shatter a Dodger winning streak of the same number.

MADISON, Wis., May 21--An incident occurred at the University of Wisconsin the other day which suggests that at least part of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges against the State Department have stuck in the middlewestern mind.
CLEVELAND, May 21--The biggest "all-purpose business show" in the thirty-one-year history of the National Office Management Association got under way here today with 1,500 delegates in attendance.

All-Star teams representing the American Soccer League were able to repel a European invasion only partially yesterday when the Kearny-Philadelphia combination held the powerful Manchester United eleven to a 2-all tie. In the preliminary, the Besiktas Club of Istanbul trounced the New YorkBrooklyn eleven, 5--3, at Randalls Island.

MADRID, May 21--Zionism has established the state of Israel through "gold, blood and injustice," the Bishop of Teruel, Friar Leon Villuendas, declared in a signed article published here today. He asserted that the Zionists aimed at world domination and at the destruction of the Christian Church.

BABYLON, L.I., May 21--Another five-mile section of Northern State Parkway will be opened without ceremony tomorrow, Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Parkway Commission, announced today.
Thousands of New Yorkers gathered in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park yesterday afternoon to mark "I Am An American Day."

PARIS, May 21--The belief that the British Government would not oppose his proposal for pooling the French and German coal and steel industries was expressed today by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, in a speech to the national congress of his party, the Popular Republican Movement, at Nantes.

The estate of Charles S. Danzer sold the four-story building on lot 18 by 105 feet at 38 East Sixtythird Street to the Jaruth Holding Corporation, William Cholst, president, for $47,000. Droisen Marcus were the attorneys for the buyer.
ZURICH, May 21--At Turin, after three days of debate, the fourth annual congress called by the Confederazione Dell Industria to discuss lowering of costs of production in Italy closed last Wednesday.

Patterns of The Times offers tops in fashion for this week's sew-your-own suggestion. That extra "little" bodice is one of the most valuable additions to your summer wardrobe from the point of view of the mix-and-match casual outfit for beach or even evening wear.

National Maritime Day, which is celebrated today for the seventeenth time since it was authorized by Congressional resolution in 1933, honors the American shipping industry and directs public attention to its importance to the nation's economy and security.
An increase for the seventeenth consecutive month in this city's relief rolls was reported yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.

To clarify certain of the regulations under the new State Rent Control Law that have resulted in a deluge of inquiries since the law became effective May 1, five informative bulletins will be available today at local rent offices for tenants and landlords.

Canon George Wallace Briggs of the Worcester Cathedral, England, until recently co-chairman of the Hymn Society of Great Britain and Ireland, which he founded, expressed his thanks yesterday to the American people "for their exceeding and undeserved kindness to me."

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 21 --The victory of Gen. Anastasio Somoza, Liberal candidate, over Emilio Chamorro Benard, Conservative, in the Presidential election held here today is indicated by early returns.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Important questions of economic policy are posed by the failure of employment opportunities to keep pace with the 800,000 to 1,100,000 persons added to the nation's labor force each year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

LONDON, May 21--At their weekend house party in the country the leaders of the Labor party resumed the concentration on domestic policies which was only partially interrupted by the conferences of the Foreign Ministers.

A new television series, in which charades are drawn by a cartoonist rather than acted out, will become a weekly feature over WNBT, beginning Saturday evening at 10:30 o'clock,immediately after the special Bob Hope show. On succeeding Saturdays the show will be presented from 9 to 9:30 P.M.

Protests over consideration of further cuts in tariff rates were voiced in statements released yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers and the National Knitted Outerwear Association.
Major crime in New York dropped last year by 0.6 per cent, as compared with 1948, the annual report of the Police Department showed yesterday.

LINDRITH, N.M., May 21 (UP) --The hundred-and-some inhabitants of this New Mexico town were split into two bitter factions today over a question that has been argued since last September: Is it legal to pray in a schoolroom?

Mr. and Mrs. F. Cliffe Johnston of 927 Fifth Avenue and Forest Oaks, Smithtown Branch, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann, to Emilio B. Knechtle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Knechtle of St. Gall, Switzerland.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 21-- Abolition of racial segregation and discrimination in the armed services was demanded today by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, and Representative Herman P. Eberharter, Democrat of Pennsylvania. They were the principal speakers at a public memorial service for Negro war dead in the Gettysburg National Military Park.

Five nationally known experts on water supply, hydraulics and sanitary engineering have accepted the city's invitation to serve on the panel of consultants who will study the city's water supply problems and policies, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21-- Another calm, this one sandwiched in between breezes, exasperated sailors on Long Island Sound today. They went out in the second Yacht Racing Association regatta, held, as was the one yesterday, by the New York Yacht Club, had a ...

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Lord Tedder, Marshal of the Royal Air Force, said today in an interview that a Western victory in the race to rearm adequately before Russia had many atomic bombs depended heavily on increased military power in France.

CLEVELAND, May 21--Nearly everyone who has seen Jo Sinclair's "The Long Moment" at the Cleveland Play House comes away with a feeling that something of penetrating insight has been said. Miss. Sinclair has dramatized the spiritual ...

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 21-- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Narden's black gelding Trader Horn was adudged the jumper champion during the Brookville horse show at J.T. Bragg's Stables here today. The Narden's black gelding Trader Bedford was reserve.
LONDON, May 21--The various elements that make up the Labor party agreed today to present a "moderate" program to the British electorate at the next election.

LONDON, May 21--The Russian fishing fleet of thirty-one vessels that anchored off Falmouth yesterday sailed round Lizard Head today and put into Mounts Bay. The mother ship Tambov sailed from Mounts Bay tonight but the trawlers remained at anchor.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21--An airlift organized to transport an estimated 100,000 Iraqi Jews to Israel is now in full swing.
The Rev. Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, who recently withdrew as a sponsor of the Mid-Century Conference for Peace scheduled to ...

CRUGERS, N.Y., May 21--The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Hospital, built by the Veterans Administration at a cost of $25,000,000 and named for the late President by Act of Congress, was dedicated here this afternoon by Maj. Gen. Carl R. Gray Jr., Administrator of Veterans Affairs.
A varied program is promised by art exhibitions in local galleries and museums this week.

CINCINNATI, May 21--This country is making "steady and broad" progress in its efforts to combat racial discrimination and segregation, Charles P. Taft, Cincinnati attorney and former president of The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, said today.

MADRID, May 13--The United States Information Service here is facing a contest of wills with Falange officials who object to allowing Spanish citizens access to uncensored books and other publications.

Strong pressure is being brought on leaders of both the Democratic and Republican parties for nomination of Jonathan B. Bingham, until recently state chairman of the Americans for Democratic Action, as a coalition candidate to oppose Representative Vito Marcantonio ...

CLEVELAND, May 21--The Joe DiMaggio label was plastered all over expansive Municipal Stadium today where, before the second largest crowd of a regular season in local history, the Yankees strengthened their hold on first place by grabbing both ends of a double-header from the Indians.

Despite the unparalleled financial burden of the worst poliomyelitis epidemic in the nation's history, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was able to authorize $3,455,559 in research and education grants in 1949. It also came up with several "promising leads" to the possible control of the feared disease.
Columbia University's Sixth Annual Festival of Contemporary American Music ended yesterday afternoon at McMillin Theatre with an orchestral concert broadcast to a nationwide audience.
Vincent G. Bush has been named a general superintendent for the Philadelphia office of the Turner Construction Company. He has been with the company since 1928.

CARLSTADT, N.J., May 21-- Surprisingly close heats, with blanket, neck and neck finishes, gave added thrills this afternoon to the crowds along the banks of the Hackensack River watching the first of the season's outboard regattas, held traditionally by the New Jersey Outboard Association.

WASHINGTON, May 21--A committee of the American Political Science Association circulated today a draft report suggesting that the Republican and Democratic parties hold national conventions at least once every two years. The report urged this and other steps to give more responsible policy leadership to the parties' own members and to the public as a whole.
DETROIT, May 21 (AP)--Righthander Chico Marrero pitched a neat three-hitter against the Detroit Tigers today as the Washington Senators bagged two homers while posting a 6-2 victory.
AMSTERDAM, May 21--The monetary situation of the Netherlands continues to improve. Last week the note circulation fell 36,000,000 to 2,898,000,000 guilders-- a new low for the last two years.

With the momentous decisions of the London conferences of the Atlantic Powers spread upon the record of history, there devolve upon the Atlantic Governments and peoples the task and the duty to take speedy and concrete action to transform the paper agreements into living reality.
BOSTON, May 22--A woman leader of the Unitarian Church today castigated "witch hunting" and the hydrogen bomb as "completely diabolical" threats to the safety of the United States and the world.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 (AP) --Mrs. Hester R. McCullough testified today that she still believed Paul Draper, the dancer, and Larry Adler, the harmonica player, were traitors, but not Communists.

Employment agencies for models were directed yesterday by Edward T. McCaffrey, License Commissioner, to limit their business activities to finding jobs for models. Any sidelines, catalogues or accessory business must cease after, June 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 --The first eliminations to select a team of amateur riders to represent the United States at international horsemanship competitions were held at Secor Farms Riding Club today as a field of thirty-nine was reduced to fifteen in the New York zone.

The four-story dwelling at 12 West Ninth Street,, in the Greenwith Village section, has been sold by Jean MacLare Johnanson to the West Ninth Corporation, which plans to alter it into small suites. The property, on a plot 32 by 94 feet, is assessed at $55,000.
DETROIT, Mich., May 22 (AP)-- Lefty Hal Newhouser showed lots of his old-time form today as he pitched the Tigers to a 5-1 victory over the Senators, scattering eight hits along the way.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and final prices were 3 to 17 points net lower.

BOSTON, May 22--Miss Susan Furlow, daughter of Mrs. Harris J. Nelson of Boston and the late Floyd Charles Furlow of New York, has completed plans for her marriage to Josiah Humphrey Child Jr., son of Mrs. Nathaniel Parkinson of Dover and Mr. Child of Westwood, which will take place on June 22 in the Lindsey Memorial Chapel of Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP)-- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, today discounted any national significance in liberal Republican victories in two Senate primaries last week.

A mortgage loan of $1,051,700, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, on the Waxbro Apartments, a sixstory building under construction on the northeast corner of Avenue L and East Fifth Street, Brooklyn.

Ned Dunn, Inc., in an expansion move, has purchased the two-story factory building on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 258 Cumberland Street, brooklyn, from the Cairn Operating Corporation and will use it in connection with its welding business.

BOSTON, May 22--Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts today dedicated the new $5,000,000 Hoosac Marine Terminal as the first step of a program for the preservation of the commerce and industries of the Commonwealth.

Lew Worsham of Pittsburgh, 1947 National Open champion, cracked the 18-hole record for the Butler (Pa.) Country Club in qualifying trials yesterday for the annual P.G.A. golf tournament next month, The Associated Press reports.

LONDON, May 22--A steady investment demand for British Government securities and high-class equities gave a cheerful tone to the London stock markets today. Business generally was on a small scale, but in the present "thin state" of the markets the demand was soon reflected in widespread small gains.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 22-- Nassau County Executive J. Russel Sprague, expediting action on a project that would allow the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation to lengthen an air strip at its Bethpage plant, said...

CHICAGO, May 22--Many persons believe that beef cooked with the bone has a flavor superior to a similar cut boned before cooking. You can cook your beef with or without the bone, and the flavor is not affected.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP)-- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill designed to tighten up Federal anti-monopoly laws. The bill would forbid corporate mergers in which one com pany bought the aasets of another if the merger would tend to create a monopoly.

TRENTON, May 22--As an outcome of an anti-trust action against the General Electric Company, Federal counsel asked today in Federal District Court that the concern be required to cease onehalf of its manufacture of electric lamas and parts.
An offering of common and preferred shares of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., will be made to common stockholders today.

RICHLAND, Wash., May 22--A modernization and expansion program that will virtually double the nation's dollar investment in the Hanford Works of the Atomic Energy Commission here and that will greatly increase production of plutonium is now more than half completed.

"Benjamin Franklin's Letters to the Press, 1758-1775," collected and edited by Verner W. Crane, will be issued on June 2 by the University of North Carolina Press. The volume is a record of one of Franklin's most important services--explaining the colonies to England and England to the colonies.

Several important things emerge from the report of the President's Committee on Equality of Treatment and Opportunity in the Armed Services, created in midsummer of 1948. The report was made public yesterday.
Two more names were added yesterday to the roster of missing and presumably dead in Friday's munitions explosion at South Amboy, N.J., raising the toll to twenty-nine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22-- R.K.O. today confirmed the resignation of Sid Rogell as executive producer, disclosing that he will leave the studio tomorrow and that Howard Hughes, controlling stockholder and managing director, will handle production operations himself without any intermediate executive for the time being.
A dozen teen-age boys gathered last night in one of Brooklyn's tough districts and plotted more murder and mayhem.

Proposal to move to the site of the Claremont, just above Grant's Tomb on River side Drive, the house known as Hamilton Grange, built as a country seat by Alexander Hamilton, and his residence during the last two years of his life, invites a glance at the era of rebuilding and expansion of New York...

THE British Amateur golf championship began yesterday on the sacred turf at St. Andrews, the holy of holies to every divot digging enthusiast. The almost legendary Royal and Ancient course was in use even before Columbus thought about discovering America. And the only American amateur ever to discover this famous Scottish links, which he was to love above all others, was Bobby Jones.

On the first anniversary of his first major-league victory--against the same club, too--Don Newcombe hurled the Dodgers to a 5-1 triumph over the Reds last night before 20,075 at Ebbets Field. It was on May 22, 1949, that the big right-hander made his first start for Brooklyn and blanked the Reds, 2--0, with a five-hit performance at Cincinnati.

Louis Hand, Inc. of Fall River, Mass., manufacturer of curtains, has leased the second floor for executive offices and showrooms in the six-story and penthouse business building being built by Henry Goelet at 55-59 East Thirty-fourth Street. The lease was negotiated by Cross Brown Company and L.V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
A light, non-greasy meal before flying and abstinence from alcohol were recommended yesterday for avoiding air sickness by Dr. Kenneth L. Stratton, director of American Airlines' medical division.
CUZCO, Peru, May 22 (AP)-- Earthquake relief crews dug two score bodies from the tumbled stones of this city's ancient relics today and sought to bring aid to the homeless.
A new high record in earnings was achieved by the Lionel Corporation in the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28, the company's fiftieth year of operation.
The president of the Department of Welfare local of the left-wing United Public Workers of America was taken off the city's payroll late yesterday afternoon.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 22--A field of 116 teams that set a new high for amateur-pro entries in a Long Island Professional Golfers Association tournament reported at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 22--The appeal court in Bloemfontein, which has supreme jurisdiction in South Africa, entered a judgment today invalidating certain regulations for racial segregation on railroads. The court laid down a general principle that may affect other discriminatory regulations.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 22 --President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua will be in the market for a foreign loan either under the Point Four program or from some other source.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 22 (AP)--Bing Crosby won everything but his match in the British amateur golf tournament today.

Price levels are continuing to move higher in industrial supply and equipment lines, purchasing executives in large companies disclosed here yesterday. On large contract purchasing, less than 20 per cent of suppliers will quote "firm prices," it was learned in a canvass of sales policies.

WASHINGTON, May 22--President Truman told Congress in a bluntly critical special message today that the $1,800,000,000 authorization which it passed recently for development of rivers, harbors, hydroelectric and other natural resources was "seriously deficient."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 5 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was also 5 per cent.

Five new members were elected to the board of directors at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday at the Opera House. They are Howard S. Cullman, Floyd W. Jefferson Jr., William J. Keary, Henry P. Mcllhenny and Mrs. John Barry Ryan.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22--The executive board of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, C.I.O., today called upon the leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to adopt "a program of unity and solidarity instead of a program of wreck and rule."

With such diverse fabrics as denim and lace making their bow in bathing outfits, there'll be never a dull moment at the beach this summer. It promises to be a season rich in amusing novelties and variety.

In March President Truman sent to Congress twenty-one plans covering as many departments and agencies in pursuance of the general reorganization of the Executive branch of the Government contemplated in the report of the Hoover Commission. Altogether, if approved by Congress, these twenty-one plans would have put into operation...

Next Move showed herself the best of eight fillies who competed in the Creole Maid, the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday. Under a front-running ride by Eric Guerin, the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt colorbearer scored by a full length over the little-regarded Busanda in the mile and a sixteenth test for 3-year-olds.
Prices of non-ferrous metal futures on the Commodity Exchange again moved higher yesterday in broad trading. Tin rose 50 to 90 points, copper 5 to 20, zinc 10 to 15 and lead 5.
BOSTON, May 22--Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, warned today that way was inevitable if America, continued "along the muddy-minded road of materialism."

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 22--The United States intends to remain in Germany "for some time" and to take an active role in forcing basic changes in the German society in pursuit of democratization, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared today.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--Eddie Malone's pinch single scored Jim Busby, a substitute base runner, with the winning run tonight as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Boston Red Sox, 10--9, in a 3-hour 31-minute ten-inning game.

TINTON FALLS, N.J., May 22 --Tinton Falls Mill, built in 1674 and recently turned into a ceramics designing and development laboratory, will become an unofficial art center next month for Monmouth County.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The United States took felicitous note of post-war economic and political progress in Greece and Turkey today, the third anniversary of United States aid to these countries.

A plea for doctors to take part openly in the coming national election by opposing candidates who support President Truman's health program was made here last night by Dr. John H. Keating in his report as retiring president of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

Artists both adult and junior were rewarded yesterday for their displays in the thirty-seventh annual outdoor art show in Greenwich Village. The exhibit opened on Saturday for a run through June 11. It will offer, besides paintings and other art works, features of cultural and entertainment interest.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--A softening of durable goods' buying caused April retail sales to dip slightly under March, the Department of Commerce reported today. Total retail turnover in April was $11,095,000,000. The department called it about equal to April, 1949, but fractionally below March of 1950, after adjustment for seasonal factors.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Railroads operating in the East have filed tariffs with the Interstate Commerce Commission effective on June 19, increasing charges on certain less-than-carload traffic and making the minimum charge on a shipment $2 instead of the present $1.43.

PARIS, May 22--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, went to London tonight after having proposed to the French a meeting of the Big Four powers within the framework of the Security Council to put an end to the impasse caused by Soviet refusal to sit with the Chinese Nationalists.

PARIS, May 22--In linking the French-German industrial merger with the hope of making Europe a "third power" able to preserve peace, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the Bonn regime echoed yesterday a conception that has been revived in France since Foreign Minister Robert Schuman proposed to pool French and German coal and steel resources.
Larry E. Coen has been appointed Midwest sales manager for Tracy Manufacturing Company maker of kitchen equipment.

Most progressive companies have adopted a five-point program to prepare their second line executives to move into top positions, it was declared last night by Stephen Habbe of the division of personnel administration, National Industrial Conference Board. He spoke at a dinner-meeting of the New York...

Well-known women of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., headed by Mrs. Edward King Davis, are aiding in the arrangements for the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital Ball to be held Saturday night at the Tuxedo Club, Tuxedo Park. Among her aides is Mrs. Kenneth M. Seggerman, who is also in charge of a group of young women who will sell balloons at the benefit.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Maj. Gen. Leo Donovan, retired Army officer who served as president of the War Crimes Commission which tried and convicted the Japanese Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma, died yesterday in the station hospital at Fort Belvoir, Va., after an illness of three weeks. He was 54 years old.

Manhattan's unionized apartment house service staffs were described yesterday by union groups as working under "substandard" conditions and by employer groups as earning wages that were more than average.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat of Maryland, said today in urging a long-range ship construction program that unless prompt action was taken the merchant marine might well be the nation's "Achilles heel" in another war.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Mock atomic-bomb attacks on Washington, Chicago and Seattle will be used to map an emergency civil defense plan for American cities. Arrangements for the stopgap program were completed today by the National Security Resources...
ATLANTIC CITY, May 22-- Vast strides in the International Ladies Garment Workers Union welfare program were celebrated today.

Four boys and twenty-three girls representing twenty-seven high schools took part yesterday in the twenty-eighth annual citywide high school poetry contest. Each student appeared at the Washington Irving High School to read his work.

CINCINNATI, May 22--The Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. today warned its members against contracting marriages with Roman Catholics, particularly when such marriages involve a promise to educate children in the Roman Catholic faith.

CLEVELAND, May 22--With the diminutive Phil Rizzuto a positive menace and Vic Raschi celebrating his return to action with a sparkling five-hit pitching performance, the Yankees roared into their seventh straight victory tonight, humbling the Indians, 7 to 2, before 23,035 fans.

Dr. Charles C. Tillinghast, retiring principal of the Horace Mann School, was the guest of honor at a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at which it was announced that the school's board of trustees had contributed $40,000 toward a $250,000 "Tillinghast Fund."
BERLIN, May 22--The famous statuary group on the Brandenburg Gate in East Berlin has disappeared.
Seaboard and Western Airlines, an all-cargo airline operating to Europe and the Middle East, yesterday celebrated three years of flying in which it made 870 crossings of the North Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The Veterans Administration said today it would build a 1,000-bed neuropsychiatric hospital at Van Nuys, Calif.

The constructive activities of the United Nations, President Truman reported to Congress yesterday, "have been overshadowed by the unsolved problems arising from the policies and acts of the Soviet Union which lead to tension and impairment of security in international relations." For this reason, he indicated, he proposed to give in the report the "fuller attention" that these activities of the United Nations merit.
A star-spangled trailer caravan rolled into Washington Square yesterday to tell--"cracker-barrel" style--about efficiency and economy in government.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Democratic chairman of a House of Representatives subcommittee that in 1946 investigated the Government's prosecution of the Amerasia case declared today that he now believed the magazine Amerasia had "a vital connection with Soviet Russia."
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 22 --The West German Socialists gave a guarded welcome today to the Schuman plan for pooling the basic industries of Germany and France.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Department of Agriculture was accused today of exchanging $7,600,000 worth of cotton for $4,600,000 worth of soybeans grown in Communist Manchuria. Representative Fred L. Crawford, Republican of Michigan, who made the allegation, said that at the time the exchange was made the department had $2,800,000 worth of surplus soybeans in storage here.

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, in an angry rebuke yesterday to Dr. William Jansen, declared that the Superintendent of Schools "should issue whatever directives are necessary to re-establish his control over the high schools."
Clear, sunny skies streaked with faint cumulus clouds formed an ideal setting yesterday for the city's traditional observance of National Maritime Day.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 22-- Henry P. Warren Jr., stockbroker with W.C. Langley Co., 115 Broadway, New York, was killed here today at 5:35 P.M. when his convertible automobile overturned.
CHICAGO, May 22--Trading in May grain contracts ceased at the close of business on the Board of Trade today and as frequently the case in expiring deliveries, price changes were very rapid.

Thomas F. Murphy, Who as Assistant United States Attorney successfully prosecuted Alger Hiss, has informed friends, it was learned yesterday, that he is willing to run as a coalition nominee against Representative Vito Marcantonio.

LONDON, May 22--By another narrow majority--this time of six votes--the Labor Government beat back tonight a Conservative motion challenging its housing record. Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, who has been in charge of the housing program for the past five years, saw his Government avert defeat by a vote of 299 to 293.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22-- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today that "as far as the Navy is concerned" the greatest need of the American merchant marine was "fast passenger ships capable of conversion into transports, and fast tankers."

ANKARA, Turkey, May 22-- Jelal Bayar, founder and leader of the Democratic party, was elected today by the National Assembly as the third President of the Turkish Republic. Ten minutes later he took the oath of office and assumed his functions as the guns of Ankara's garrison sounded the Presidential salute.

I transmit herewith to the Congress, pursuant to the United Nations participation act, my fourth annual report on the activities of the United Nations and the participation of the United States. This report for the year 1949 tells an impressive story of accomplishment, much of which we are prone to overlook in the clamor of daily difficulties. I commend it to the careful reading of all our citizens.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The securities and Exchange Commission today gave the Washington Gas and Electric Company of Tacoma ten days in which to amend its proposal for the sale of its stock interest in the Southern Utah Power Company of Cedar City, to provide equal opportunity for all interested persons to bid for the securities.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 22-- Children would be better off in many cases if parents were not so solicitous of them, the fifty-fourth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers was told today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22-- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Shields have made known the engagement of their daughter, Aileen, to Alexander Bryan, son of Mrs. Wilbur P. Bryan of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Bryan. The wedding has been planned for July.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22-- Behind the effective six-hit pitching of Jack Mackmull, Army remained a contender in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League, defeating Cornell, 10 to 3, on windswept Doubleday Field today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.)-- The United States intends to 'coldshoulder' any move at this time to set up a world cotton pact aimed at alloting markets or fixing prices.

FLORENCE, Italy, May 22-- Czechoslovakia and Hungary marched out of the opening session of the fifth annual conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization here today in protest against the continued presence of delegates from Nationalist China.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The National Labor Relations Board, which has clashed with the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals several times, today said it would ignore a decision of the appellate court until the Supreme Court had passed on the issue.

Those who made a trip to Peconic in search of weakfish over the past week-end returned home with bulging sacks of porgies and an unexpected bonanza of fluke, but the weakfish were as scarce as salmon in the Hudson.

An agreement reached yesterday, at the direction of Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, on projected economy layoffs by the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, appeared to dissipate the threat of "action" made over the issue by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O.
A $65,000,000 second series of bonds will be sold on June 21 by the General State Authority of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Tuesday May 23 (AP)--A jury of five women and seven men was locked up early today after failing to reach a verdict in the case of thirteen union members charged with riot and conspiracy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 --A new peace-time use for radioisotopes to trace the course of bacteria leaving sewage treatment plants on Long Island Sound and Hudson River shores of Westchester was outlined this afternoon by county officials.

The stock market quieted down yesterday after its splurge of last week and turned easier in slower trading. The pause in the forward movement, however, developed only after prices started out strong and pushed nearer to the 1946 highs.

Three cotton textile groups, as well as the Textile Export Association, went on record yesterday as opposed to a policy of tariff cuts as a device for closing the "dollar gap." They are: the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, Inc., National Association of Cotton Manufacturers and the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

When the domestic steel industry operated at 100 per cent of theoretical capacity, or better, for ten consecutive weeks between the middle of January and the third week of March last year, a record for sustained high output was established.

DETROIT, Mich., May 22--Two million new salesmen are needed to keep 60,000,000 workers on the nation's payrolls, it was declared here today at the opening of the fifteenth annual convention of the National Sales Executives by Walter C. Ayers, executive vice president of Brooke, Smith, French Dorrance, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Insistent on a Fair Employment Practices bill despite the Administration's defeat in the Senate last week, President Truman today issued a report on the progress in wiping out racial discrimination in the armed services and marked it recommended reading for Senators.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22-- Ralph J. Cordiner, executive vice president of the General Electric Company, New York, said here today that American industry is in "the phase of ottr marketing plan when maximum effort must be placed on the selling end of the job."
WASHINGTON, May 22--The Senate approved today President Truman's plans for reorganization of the Federal Trade and Power Commissions.

DETROIT, Mich., May 22--An increase of $2,700,000,000 in corporate profits after taxes in 1950 over last year was predicted today by Dr. Philip Wernette, director of the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Michigan, before the store management and personnel groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Tennessee Williams' prize-winning play, "A Streetcar Named Desire," will begin a two-week engagement this evening at the New York City Center, under the auspices of Irene M. Selznick. The curtain is scheduled to rise at 8:30.

HONG KONG, May 22--An appeal addressed to the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan people has been broadcast from Communist China promising Tibet regional autonomy and urging that an allegiance be given peacefully to Peiping to avoid "unnecessary losses."
A man and his wife who held jewelry valued at $22,000 and $600 in cash that they found in a taxicab last Wednesday were paroled yesterday in Felony Court to await hearing on a grand larceny charge.
A plea for United States aid in arming Israel was made yesterday by Dr. Nahum Goldman, chairman of the American Section of the Jewish Agency of Palestine.

LONDON, May 22--The Soviet Government, which has made it clear before that it does not want to conclude a treaty with Austria at this time, threw a monkey wrench into the machinery for negotiating one today. As a result the meetings of the Deputy Foreign Ministers have been suspended, with no date set for their resumption.

I have just received the report of the President's Committee on Equality of Treatment and Opportunity in the Armed Services. For the past two years, this committee has been working quietly to find ways and means to bring about true equality of opportunity for everyone in military service.

With another entry yesterday, the number of yachts registered for the race from Newport to Bermuda, starting on June 18, totaled sixty-five, a record-shattering list. As G.W. Blunt White, chairman of the Cruising Club's race committee, figured it out, all he had left to do would be to enlarge the Atlantic Ocean. That organization and the Royal Bermuda...

WASHINGTON, May 22--An excise tax of $1.05 a barrel on imported residual oil was urged today by D.T. Buckley, of the National Coal Association, in testimony before a Senate Labor subcommittee. He said such a tax was essential to enable coal to compete with foreign oil in the United States market.

Many dinner parties will be given at the entertainment, known as "A Night in Old St. Petersburg," to be held tonight in the Carnaval Room of the SherryNetherland. Countess Alexandra Tolstoy, daughter of the noted novelist and president of Tolstoy Foundation, Inc., will be the guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A $625,493,694 deficiency appropriariation to cover obligations made under many domestic and foreign programs was approved and sent to the Senate by a voice vote of the House of Representatives today.
BRUSSELS, May 22--As a step toward re-establishing freedom of foreign exchange Belgium and Luxembourg authorized today purchases and sales to any amount of all foreign bank notes and coin.

WASHINGTON, May 22--In this space there was published on May 16 an analysis of the decision of the California Court of Appeal that invoked a general pledge in a treaty signed by the United States to invalidate a specific California statute. It was noted that, when this court held that the state law which restricts Japanese from owning land was nullified by our promise in the Charter of the United Nations...

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 22--The United States professional viewpoint on journalistic ethics won an important victory this morning in the United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and the Press.

As reservoir gains resulting from recent heavy rains tapered off to 789,000,000 gallons yesterday, officials announced that last week's average daily consumption had dropped to 891,000,000 gallons from 899,000,000 the week before.

In fruit stalls the first crimson cherries and in shops the first of the cherry wine. It comes to summer tables as a cherry Collins, with sparkling water and lemon peel as a tall refresher, as a sweetening for a bowl of cut-up fruit, as a sauce for ice cream.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- Harvard captured its fourth Eastern Intercollegiate League victory in six games today, beating the University of Pennsylvania, 11--9, in a free hitting affair.
NASHVILLE, N.C., May 22 (AP) --Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the country needed a farm program that would assure consumers better diets at prices within "easy reach."

WASHINGTON, May 22--The civil rights issue as well as opposition to communism today entered into discussions among delegates to the fifth National Citizenship Conference here. The meeting is under joint sponsorship of the Department of Justice and the National Education Association.

LLOYD LEWIS "heard the guns of Shiloh" and gave up his work as a Chicago newspaper man to spend the rest of his life working on a biography of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant. No man ever began a vast literary project with better qualifications or more enthusiasm for the job. A former drama critic and sports editor, the author of one of the distinguished biographies...

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., May 22 --A two-man survey team representing the operations research office of the Army began here today a study of the psychological effects of mass blast destruction in an urban community.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 22-- The United States will soon open a consulate at the little northern Thailand city of Chiengmai to watch American interests in an area of increasing importance in Southeast Asia.

William W. Remington, Commerce Department ecnomist, whose loyalty has twice been questioned by Washington authorities, denied there again yesterday to the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities that he had ever been a member of the Communist party.

MONTREAL, May 22 (AP)-- Champion Savings Corporation, Montreal, announced today that its president, Lloyd R. Champion, had obtained financial backing for a $200,000,000 oil and natural gas pipeline from Alberta to the Pacific Coast.

Manufacturers at the fourth annual New York Stationery Show, being held in the New Yorker Hotel this week, charged yesterday that distribution is meeting its biggest bottleneck at the retail point of sale.

With a 1950 budget triple that of last year, Motorola, Inc., will spend an estimated $15,000,000 for national and local advertising. Ellis L. Redden, director of advertising, sales promotion and training, said the heavier expenditure has been decided upon to enable the company to keep abreast of increasing sales.

An hour-long variety program patterned after the music hall revues of the early Nineteen Hundreds will make its debut over WOR-TV Thursday, June 1, at 8 P.M. Entitled "Bowery Music Hall," the weekly series will be produced and directed by Jack Linder, the original producer of "Diamond Lil."
A key witness who appeared yesterday before a New York County grand jury investigating organized gambling was reported to be "cooperating" in the inquiry into Frank Erickson's operations.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 21-- International diplomatic sources here are uncertain over the prospects of the Southeast Asia conference scheduled to open next Friday in Baguio, the Philippines.

KANSAS CITY, May 22 (AP)-- The Government today indicted Thomas (Tano) Lococo, who rode high as an underworld enforcer back in the late "Boss" Tom Pendergast's day and came back under the Northside rule of Charles Binaggio.

Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net profit for 1949 of $1,710,944 after taxes and all charges, including $1,389,690 profit on sale of capital assets and losses of $1,660,400 on investments in independent productions.

A concentrated drive that amassed ten runs in the third inning carried Fordham to an 11-3 Metropolitan Conference baseball triumph over the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Fordham Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Protesting what he termed a return engagement of this "fantastic road show," Abe Fortas, counsel for Otis Co., Cleveland investment house, moved before the Securities and Exchange Commission today for dismissal of the charges against his client.

Wool goods manufacturers have either officially or unofficially withdrawn their prices on both men's and women's fabrics for fall delivery, it was learned yesterday. Orders are being taken subject to confirmation by most of the leading houses, and it is predicted that a 10 cents a yard advance will prevail generally over the opening fall prices.
Prospective travelers looking forward to summer holidays will find several items available that should ease their worries about laundering difficulties wherever they may be.

Allen Will Harris, management consultant, said last night that it was time that statistical reality replaced the "Alice in Crimeland" reports of the Police Department with which it "lulls the public each year."

NEW DELHI, India, May 22-- The partition of Kashmir, as a solution to the dispute between India and Pakistan, might be acceptable to India if this were the will of the people of Kashmir, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated at a press coonference today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 22 (AP)--The Soviet military mission in Frankfort was fenced in tonight after five Russians were picked up outside their compound for violating a United States ban on their travels.

Kid Gavilan of Cuba and Georgie Small of Brooklyn, who tangle in the main bout listed for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden Friday night, yesterday were pronounced fit following an examination by Dr. Vincent A. Nardiello at the State Athletic Commission offices.

WASHINGTON, May 22--While castigating Russia for boycotting United Nations activities over the Nationalist China issue, President Truman reported to Congress today that the United Nations had made constructive gains toward peace in 1949.

Chancellor Adenauer's pledge of German support for all projects leading toward European unification, including Germany's entrance into the Council of Europe and the proposed merger of French and German coal and steel interests, is in welcome contrast to the bitter growls that emanated from Germany during the controversy over the Saar. It is also in welcome contrast to the vagaries of the only man who could displace Chancellor Adenauer...

WESTBURY, L.I., May 22--The trotting scene moved from Yonkers to the Roosevelt Raceway tonight where a crowd of 16,619 turned out to see the unveiling of the eleventh season. The opening session marked the start of a long stand during which 105 nights of racing is scheduled at the Nassau County plant.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Vice President Alben W. Barkley said today he saw no prospect for an expansion of American occupation forces unless some North Atlantic pact countries asked for United States troops.

A five-year strikeless period for General Motors was guaranteed in a comprehensive, new contract agreed upon yesterday with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O. The new contract, hailed as a milestone in labor relations, may not be reopened until May, 1955.
LONDON, May 23--The stock markets here kept a firm front today despite a drop in turnover before the approach of the Whitsuntide holiday. Steadiness of British Government securities was...

New York's thirty-eight miles of bathing beaches are "on the whole generally safe and inviting," Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday in releasing the 1950 official beach classification chart based on water samples analyzed in departmental laboratories.

Simple untortured forms and studied intricate glazes are characteristic of a collection of ceramics now on view : Wor-De-Klee, 35 East Forty-ninth Street. Gertrude and Otto Natzler are the husband and wife team who are responsible for the large variety of bowls, vases and ashtrays.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, warned a subcommittee of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today against attempting to reverse the Democratic Administration trade policy of the last seventeen years. It would be doing this, he said, if it recommended an excise tax, or a quota, on imports of foreign residual fuel oil.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 23 (AP)-- Milon Marusic, playing his home course, and Joe Creavy of Bolton Landing today won Northeastern New York qualifying berths for the national Professional Golfers Association tournament.

CINCINNATI, May 23--The Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. A. warned here today that unless an extensive program of church building and development were undertaken "immediately," American Presbyterianism stands in grave danger of becoming a "dischurched" denomination.

After running in New York and throughout the country for two and one-half years, "A Streetcar Named Desire" is headed for the last round-house. It turned up at the City Center last evening for the final engagement. The City Center is a huge auditorium for so intense a play, put together out ...

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., May 23 --The Mayors of twenty-nine Middlesex County communities will meet here at 5 P.M. Thursday to back Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll in a demand he made today that the Department of Defense ban the storage and shipment of munitions and explosives in this heavily populated area.

AKRON, Ohio, May 23 (UP)-- Because of the increase in the cost of crude rubber, five large tire manufacturers boosted retail prices today 2 per cent on passenger car tires and 5 per cent on truck tires, and hinted more increases may not be far off.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23-- David Dubinsky declared here today that, unless the free labor movement mobilized all its forces in the forefront of the fight against Communist tyranny, "the cold war can never be won by the democracies."

RALEIGH, N.C., May 23-- Three Democratic candidates for a four-year Senate term today entered the home stretch of a bitter primary campaign marked by widespread charges of Communism and open efforts to divide white and Negro voters.

They let Three Rings take the early lead in the Valley Stream Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, and that's all the 5-year-old son of Blue Larkspur wanted. Staying up front all the way in the mile-and-furlong event, Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins' campaigner had little difficulty beating three others, while 18,172 looked on.

New issues of securities of the Interstate Power Company and the Iowa Public Service Company, consisting of flotations of common and preferred stocks and bonds valued at more than $15,000,000, will be placed on the market by underwriting syndicates today.

Six months ago fifteen young hoodlums in the Cherry Street gang--offshoot of its namesake that terrorized the lower East Side waterfront during Prohibition -- raided the neighborhood center, Hamilton House at 72 Market Street, They looted, robbed children and stabbed the acting head worker.
GENEVA, May 23--Labor and management cooperation at the factory level is increasing, the International Labor Office reported here today.
William J. Farthing, landlord, has applied to the State Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday, to fix "reasonable" rent for offices at 210 Madison Avenue occupied by the Amtorg Trading Corporation.

At 7:30 A.M. tomorrow play will start simultaneously at the Cherry Valley Club, Garden City, and the Hempstead Golf Club, Hempstead, in the Metropolitan District's sectional qualifying rounds for the United States Open championship at the Merion Golf Club. Ardmore, Pa., June 8 to 10.

PARIS, May 23--Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, told the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assembly today that he was "almost certain" that Britain would he represented in any negotiations for the merger of the coal and steel industries of Germany and France that he had proposed.
Contributions of $1,357,631 toward the $10,000,000-goal of the Barnard College development fund were announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank Altschul, national chairman, ...

Guided by caution, the outgrowth of experience as a producer and/or director, Shepard Traube isn't waiting until the last minute to get the scenery built and painted for "The Gioconda Smile," which he is aiming to bring into the Lyceum on Oct. 3.
More than 200 industrialists saw yesterday how they can use scientific methods to determine when it is profitable to buy new plant machinery and equipment.

The Pennsylvania Railroad and six other railroads have agreed to lease a new type of box car which ite producers contend will virtually eliminated damage to freight, speed deliveries and increase materially railroad profits.

Three months ago the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives light-heartedly put aside --apparently as irrelevant and unimportant--a bill to extend the Selective Service System (due to expire next month) for two more years.
Four rooms that should offer many suggestions to homemakers seeking summer decorating inspiration go on view today at the Mayhew shop, 603 Madison Avenue.
Operations of the Glidden Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with April resulted in a net profit of $2,721,712 after all charges, the concern announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23--A 39-year-old Philadelphia man was arrested on espionage charges tonight, accused of "dealing" with the British spy, Dr. Klaus Fuchs. The new prisoner, Harry Gold, was held in $100,000 bail and put in Moyamensing Prison.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (U.P.)-- Senate Democratic leaders laid out a legislative time-table today that was expected to forestall another test on President Truman's bill to create a Fair Employment Practice Commission for at least three weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Senate subcommittee investigating alleged communism in the State Department has begun a broadened inquiry into the "Amerasia case" of 1945, a case involving secret Government documents.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission said today the National Tea Co. of Chicago violated so-called "fair trade" laws during a special coupon sales campaign run last year by the grocery chain.

Special promotions by manufacturers of brand lines of full-fashioned hosiery are bringing a good volume of business into an otherwise dull market, it was said yesterday. Producers have introduced their fall colors but retailers are not looking ahead more than sixty days for inventory needs.

Joseph Sicker, president of Sicker Co., commission merchants of 204 Franklin Street, who conceived the idea of having unemployed workers sell apples during the depression of the 1930s, died of a heart attack early Monday morning at his home, 140 East Eightyfirst Street.

BASLE, Switzerland, May 23-- The leading central bankers of Continental Europe are convinced that the three major European currencies, the French franc, the Belgian franc and the Italian lira, could be made freely convertible into dollars now.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP)--The Senators broke loose with an eightrun, seven-hit barrage in the ninth inning to upset the Tigers, 8--2, today behind Sid Hudson's eighthit pitching.

New York University made a move toward a return to big-time football yesterday, announcing that athletic scholarships would be increased by 50 per cent. The number of scholarships now in effect was not disclosed.

The Commonwealth Edison Company, one of the largest utilities in the nation, is rushing to accumulate a 120-day reserve of coal, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

A lavish display of flowers and plants turned the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral into a brilliant garden yesterday when the Outdoor Cleanliness Association held its eighteenth annual flower mart.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 23--The creation of a new "Ministry of National Security," headed by Ladislav Kopriva, member of the Central Committee of the Communist party, was announced by the Czechoslovak Government tonight.

WARSAW, May 23--Provincial and county governors, mayors and other Western trappings of government, passed into Polish history today as "People's Councils" of the Soviet type were formed and elected to the Presidium to take over their duties.

All branches of the television industry will achieve a total volume of at least $2,000,000,000 this year Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 23 (AP)--The Union of South Africa has launched a uranium production project that Government leaders hope will help the West in its goal for atomic supremacy.

Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the New York State Mediation Board, will be 70 years old today. At the end of this month, the man whose quiet but persuasive voice spoke the conciliatory role in countless labor-management dramas will retire.

New York University, behind Tom Casey's superb pitching in the pinches, defeated Fordham, 3 to 0, on the latter's field in the Bronx yesterday and clinched its seventh Metropolitan Collegiate Conference championship. The Violets, with one game remaining, have won twelve games and lost one.

Four thousand men in search of city jobs as laborers stood in line yesterday to file their applications with the Municipal Civil Service Commission. Additional applications may be filed today and tomorrow at the special receiving office set up in the Park Department swimming pool at Fifty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue.

Once again the highly critical and dangerous dispute over Kashmir is coming to the fore, this time with some hope of solution. Sir Owen Dixon, United Nations mediator, is on his way to India and Pakistan for one more try.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Joseph W. Frazer, now vice chairman of the Kaiser-Frazer Automobile Company, said here today that he gave up his $118,000 a year job as president of the company because of policy differences with Henry J. Kaiser and the latter's son, Edgar.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 23 --A thirty-six-foot gondola, with an ornately carved gold and black cab, a coin-studded pole and a blue and brown lateen sail, left here this morning on a 325-mile trip by rail to Virginia.

A Long Island real estate developer was identified yesterday by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County as his "man of mystery" who is cooperating with his office in its in vestigation into the workings of an alleged policy headquarters.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The United States agreed today to ship arms and supplies to Iran in an effort to strengthen that country against the threat of Soviet communism in the Near East.

Marked with the freshness and casual simplicity beloved in American fashions for summer, the David Crystal designs offered yesterday in a showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel presented frocks for town and country, as well as a group of tennis styles by Alice Marble.

Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty turned down all suggestions that he leave Hungary prior to his arrest and refused to the last to believe he might break down under police grilling. Msgr. Sigismund Mihailovics, former director of Catholic Action in Hungary said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Air Force cut some administrative red tape today from its Continental Air Command. The move was designed to "strengthen air defense capabilities" and to step up training in close air support for ground troops.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)-- Representative Paul J. Kilday, Democrat of Texas, said today he would ask subpoena power to summon Mrs. Sally Dewey as a star witness in the current House of Representatives investigation into alleged multi-million-dollar overpayments to Army families.

CUZCO, Peru, May 23 (UP)-- About 15,000 of Cuzco's 50,000 inhabitants are homeless and face the threat of epidemics as a result of Sunday's disastrous earthquake, officials said today.

ALBANY, May 23--Governor Dewey left the state tonight for a rest and vacation after denying, through his secretary, James C. Hagerty, that he had informed Republican national leaders he would run for a third term this year.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 23 (Reuters)--The Dutch Government accused the Indonesians today of using unconstitutional means to achieve a change in the structure of their republic, until lately a Dutch colony.

Dr. Paul H. Nystrom arrived promptly at 8:55 A.M. yesterday for his Columbia University graduate marketing class. As a matter of fact, he was going to administer a final examination. The 100 students greeted him with applause, cheers and gifts.

She admitted frankly the other day that babies frightened the life out of her. "So fragile looking," she said. "I thought if I handled one it would break."
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)-- Senators argued today whether a "basing point" pricing bill already approved by the House would stimulate small business or destroy it.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee voted unanimously today to report a stringent bill forbidding the transmission or reception of "gambling information" across state lines.

New York's twenty-first Dry Thursday this week resulted in a consumption of 888,000,000 gallons of water, 14,000,000 more than the 874,000,000 used on last week's Dry Day, according to Water Department figures compiled yesterday.

In the belief that a new method of studying tooth structure may be evolved through the use of radioactive isotypes, the First District Society of the State of New York announced yesterday the formation of an atomic energy program committee.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 26--The Western Allied letter to Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet commander, calling for free elections in Germany, constitute part of a planned program for countering Soviet propaganda maneuvers in Germany, authoritative sources said today.
GENEVA, May 26--The Coal Committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe decided today to cease allocating coal and coke among the European importing countries.

Executives of the plastics manufacturing industry are taking steps to "stamp out" abuses of product uses in a new industry-wide quality control and standards development program.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The special committee of the House of Representatives investigating lobbying activities issued subpoenas today designed to force three national organizations with headquarters in New York--the Committee for Constitutional Government, the National Economic Council, and the Constitutional Educational League--to disclose their financial backers.

WASHINGTON, May 26--President Truman today nominated Edward Lee Norton, banker and radio official, of Birmingham, Ala., for a full fourteen-year term as a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 26--The physical condition of most Americans is "pretty poor," even though medical care is improving, Dr. C. H. McCloy, Research Professor of Physical Education at the State University of Iowa, asserted here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26-- More than 400 staff members of the University of California, including forty-two full professors, have failed to sign a non-Communist contract prescribed by the Board of Regents last month as a substitute for a controversial, special non-Communist loyalty oath.

PARIS, MAY 26--A proposal by Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin that the French and Germans should open talks on the coal and steel merger plan, with the British sitting in as observers, caused disappointment and indignation here today. The proposal was made in a brief note from Mr. Bevin to French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, who found it unacceptable.

LONDON, May 26--The Western Allied deputies for Austria turned down today a Russian demand that would have made satisfaction of the Soviet Union's complaints on the Allied use of Trieste a prerequisite to further progress on the long-delayed Austrian state treaty.
WORTHINGTON, Mass., May 26 --The Rev. Dr. Harlan Creelman, well-known theologian, died here today in his home. His age was 85.

WASHINGTON, May 26--Robert M. Hitchcock, who prosecuted the Amerasia case in 1945, testified today that he had been gravely handicapped because the Government's best evidence had been produced by illegal seizures by Federal agents.

The twentieth Morris and Essex Kennel Club event, America's most splendid dog show outdoors, will be held today on the Giralda Farms estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge at Madison, N.J. Judging of 2,587 dogs will begin in thirty-nine rings at 10 A.M. It will last continuously through the day. At 6 P.M. Hugh A. (Bud) Lewis of Pasadena, Calif., is scheduled to enter a specially reserved enclosure to pick best in show.
LONDON, May 26--An arrangement with two United States oil companies to supply extra gasoline for sterling enabled the British Government to announce the end of gasoline rationing today.

Some business men in Bayside, Queens, were angered last night over what they believed to be "politics" in the Police Department involving Patrolman George S. McClancy, 31 years old, a member of the force for eight years and one of four candidates for the $6,000-a-year post of president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

BOSTON, May 26--Manager Barney Shotton's confidence in Jack Banta, lean and hungrylooking Kansas righthander, was not misplaced tonight. Making his second start of the campaign, Banta spun a neat five-hitter for his first complete game and third triumph as the Dodgers beat the Braves and their ace, Johnny Sain, 5--1, to retain their one-game National League lead over the Phils.

Louis H. Saltzman, retired restaurateur and hotel man and former Long Beach (L.I.) police commissioner and councilman, died Thursday in his apartment in the Franconia Hotel, 20 West Seventysecond Street, after a brief illness. His age was 74.
Teen-agers and children who are looking forward to long summer vacations at camp, in the country or at the seashore will find a well designed assortment of fashions to meet their every necessity.

PARIS, May 26--Dangers to French democracy from communism and from a rightist dictatorship were emphasized in the political report to the French Socialist party today by Guy Mollet, secretary general, in addressing the annual national congress of the party.

Motorists enthusiastically accepted the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel yesterday, pouring through the $80,000,000 facility at an estimated rate of 2,000 vehicles an hour. A reading of the counters in the collection booths at the Brooklyn end at Thursday midnight showed that 24,283 vehicles had passed through in the first eleven and a half hours of operations.

The tenth annual interschool music festival of children's choirs of Jewish religious schools will be celebrated at 3 P.M. tomorrow in Hunter College Auditorium. There will be 1,500 young singers representing seventy schools.

Word of a new cheese cake, superbly rich, fluffy and delicious, yesterday sent a member of this department to the shop at 350 East Seventy-fourth Street where it is prepared. With the scarcity of natural crude rubber for near-by delivery more pronounced, prices advanced yesterday to new seasonal highs in both the local and international markets.

An agreement was reached yesterday by Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, and William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, on the procedure to be followed in an effort to persuade the city's high school teachers to resume the extracurricular activities they abandoned on April 17 in protest against allegedly inadequate pay rises.
A 27-year-old suspended police detective was acquitted last night of charges of assault and discharging a revolver illegally by a Bronx County Court jury that had deliberated three hours.

HARTFORD, May 26--After six hours and a half of deadlocked deliberation today, the jury in the $200,000 libel suit brought by Larry Adler and Paul Draper against Mrs. Hester R. McCullough was excused for the night at 10:45 P.M.
ALBERT EINSTEIN'S "Out of My Later Years" is a wonderful garland of papers on all kinds of things under the sun and moon that have interested that contemporary immortal.

BERLIN, May 26--A member of the East German Free German Youth candidly declared here today that 70 per cent of the members of the organization were not in agreement with the Communists.

WASHINGTON, May 26--Terming Southeast Asia a world danger spot "where we haven't any time to lose," Paul G. He added that the cost of the assistance would be comparatively small "but we cannot afford not to spend it."

The announcement of the forthcoming trip to Japan by John Foster Dulles brings the various problems of a peace treaty for Japan into greater prominence. It will be a mistake to interpret these problems merely as an inter-departmental dispute over timing.

MOSCOW, May 26 (AP)--The other day Tikhon Khrennikov, secretary general of the Soviet Composers Union, criticized Russian composers and Russian music critics. Today he found some music critics were perfectly right. He criticized himself.

WASHINGTON, May 26--For the first time in its twentythree-year history the National Spelling Bee ended in a two-way draw today because the judges ran out of jawbreaker words with which to carry on the spelldown.

CHICAGO, May 26--Dr. Harry S. Gradle, Chicago eye surgeon, who retired in 1944, died yesterday in his home at Sherman Oaks, Calif., a suburb of Los Angeles, his associates here were informed to day. He was 66 years old.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 26--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said this morning that his talks with Premier Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders had convinced him that the Soviet Union retained confidence in the United Nations and wanted it to be a "working organization."

Formal approval was given yesterday by the Board of Estimate to leases for three North River piers and one East River dock. Under negotiation for some time, the leases will be signed next week by Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The State Department's decision to restrict Rumanian diplomats to within thirty-five miles of Washington during the summer not only is the hottest decision of the "cold war" but raises a number of intriguing questions.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would appoint Lloyd B. Reid of Detroit to head the city's Department of Traffic at an annual salary of $20,000. The announcement was made at City Hall two hours after the Board of Estimate had approved a local law passed by the City Council on Thursday, creating the new city department.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 26-- North Carolina's bitterly fought Democratic Senatorial primary campaign came to an end tonight and an estimated 450,000 to 500,000 voters will give their verdict tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP)-- Connie Mack named two of his old stars to key positions in the Philadelphia Athletics high command tonight in a sweeping shake-up designed to get the club back into the American League pennant race.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 26--Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that he had found the crowd at a soccer match in Moscow well enough dressed to be transplanted straight to Ebbets Field on a Sunday afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26--The security of American Jews is linked directly with the preservation of civil liberties and when these individual liberties are under attack the Jewish group is imperilled, speakers warned here today as the National Community Relations Advisory Council opened its eighth annual meeting.
The stock market stayed close to the middle of the road yesterday, except for the rubber issues, which showed gains that ranged to 4 points in Goodrich.

Charles A. Butcher will join the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation as assistant to the president on June 1. He formerly was general manager of CrockerWheeler Electric Manufacturing Company, and vice president of its successive parent companies, Joshua Hendy Corporation, and Elliott Company.

MORRISTOWN, Tenn., May 26 (AP)--A new flare-up of violence occurred today in the strike at the rayon plant of the American Enka Corporation and police accused five persons of violating an antiviolence injunction.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26-- Robert K. Bell of Ocean City, president of the New Jersey Bar Association, called on the state's lawyers today to do all in their power to combat the tendency in this country toward nationalism.

"Kill the Umpire," a Columbia comedy featuring William Bendix, Una Merkel, Ray Collins and Gloria Henry, twill open today at the Rivoli. Bendix plays the role of a rabid besaball fan who grudgingly becomes an umpire at the behest of his family and eventually discovers that the game wouldn't quite be the same without the boys in blue.

A variety of group and one-man shows continues to keep art galleries in the city busy although the season is drawing to a close.

Score another triumph for American industrial know-how on the diplomatic front. Early this week General Motors and its 275,000 United Auto Workers reached an agreement, without benefit of Government intervention of any kind, that not only removed the most serious threat to the nation's economic stability, but replaced that threat with the assurance of five years of labor peace.

Led by Jim Fuchs, Vic Frank and George Wade, its senior stalwarts, Yale last night was riding high, wide and handsome in its bid to regain the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. team title it yielded to Michigan State last year.

LOS ANGELES, May 26--Frank M. Jenifer, president of the Pacific Coast Borax Company, which manufactures Twenty Mule Team borax, died today of a heart attack at his home in suburban Sherman Oaks. His age was 72.

BERLIN, May 26--The blue-shirted boys and girls milling today around the Potsdamer Platz where Berlin's East and West sectors converge are only a sample of the 175,000 already assembled for the great Whitsuntide parade of Soviet power over German youth.
BAGUIO, the Philippines, May 26--Economic, social and cultural relationships were emphasized as the conference of Southeast Asian states and neighboring nations formally got under way here today.

CHICAGO, May 26--Despite stiff competition from the air lines and other forms of transportation, the Pullman Company expects to be in business fifty years from now-- it isn't going to sit back and watch the parade go by--Carroll R. Harding, president, said today at a press conference.

WASHINGTON, May 26--An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended that it approve a plan by which Pacific Intermountain Express Company of Oakland, Calif,, would purchase the rights and properties of Keeshin Freight Lines of Chicago and its subsidiary companies, and thus be able to put together a transcontinental motor truck service.
The Amtorg Trading Corporation has signed an agreement to vacate its offices at 210 Madison Avenue by July 31, it was announced yesterday by Herman M. Glassner.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 26--Former Foreign Minister Vladimir Clementis, in a speech before the Congress of the Communist party of Slovakia today supplemented self-criticisms that previously had been rejected as inadequate by the Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist party of Czechoslovakia.

The State Labor Relations Board made public yesterday a decision dismissing the petition of the Char-Sol Seafood House, Inc., operators of Larry's Cafe, 711 Eighth Avenue, which asked that a bargaining election be held for the tavern's employes, including three female bartenders.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee voted 8 to 3 today to report out a bill to legalize preferential hiring halls in the maritime industry. Senate action on the bill this year was considered unlikely.

Although food sales are declining noticeably at manufacturing levels, consumer buying is continuing at a rate about even with last year, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, reported yesterday upon his return from a study of food conditions throughout the nation.

BERLIN, May 26--Assuming the initiative in the struggle for Berlin and all Germany, the three Western occupation powers proposed today that the Soviet Union join them in framing an election late as the first step toward the political and economic unity of this partitioned country.

WASHINGTON, May 26--The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to report a bill intended to provide an up-to-date organization for the Army. The bill would abolish the cavalry and the Coast Artillery. Some regrets were voiced at the disappearance of the cavalry.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 26 (AP)--Sam Snead, golf's high and mighty from West Virginia, took over the lead in the $15,000 Colonial national invitation tournament today although he shot a two-over-par 72 on a windy, rainy course.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26-- Declarations from Washington, London and Paris indicating that the statement of the three major Western powers guaranteeing the use of measures within and outside the framework of the United Nations to prevent future aggressions in this area as a turning point for the Near East have fallen rather flat here.

The battle that a 20-year-old Coast Guardsman put up early yesterday in resisting alleged attempts by three men, after they had offered him a lift in their car, to beat and rob him, resulted in their arrest.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 26--United States compliance with the Czechoslovak demand that the United States Embassy reduce its staff by one-half was indicated today by orders issued to twelve of the staff of twenty-four to pack and stand by for departure on June 5. WASHINGTON, May 26--The dollar volume of retail, wholesale and service business in the United States expanded threefold in the years from 1939 to 1948, according to a preliminary census of business released today by Roy V. Peel, Director of the Bureau of the Census, United States Department of Commerce. The expansion brought with it a substantial increase in employment, he added.

Two teen-age gangs exchanged about forty shots from zip guns yesterday morning in a Brooklyn street in which there were many pedestrians on their way home from the Memorial Day parade that had just passed near by.
