The incident itself was fortunately held to minor proportions, thanks to prompt action by both the American Military Police and the Japanese police.

HARTFORD, May 30--The major parties in Connecticut accused each other today of responsibility for the almost complete collapse of the state government reorganization program in the special session of the General Assembly, which adjourned in confusion last Friday.
BAGUIO, The Philippines, May 30--The gathering of seven South Asian nations adjourned today with a round of speechmaking and adoption of a resolution embracing the conference decisions.
WASHINGTON, May 30--United States officials reported today that the Schuman plan to pool the coal and steel resources of France, Germany and other European nations had run into its first difficulty.

A statement expressing opposition to the Havana Charter has been filed with the House Committee on Foreign Affairs by the American Paper and Pulp Association, it was announced over the holiday. The association declared that the International Trade Organization ...
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)-- The Senators today traded Ray Scarborough, Eddie Robinson and Al Kozar to the White Sox for Cass Michaels, Robert Kuzava and John Ostrowski.

SPRINGFIELD, Col., May 30-- The Federal Government poured millions of dollars into the first Dust Bowl fight. Now, with millions of acres in a five-state area of the Southwest threatened with a recurrence of the devastation of the Nineteen Thirties, the belief is general in the stricken regions that the Government will have to do it again.
DEVON, Pa., May 30--Before the largest crowds in the history of the six-day show, eleven champions were crowned today at the fifty-fourth annual Devon Horse Show and County Fair.

WARSAW, May 30--A complete break in Polish-Yugoslav relations was in the making today when the Warsaw Government announced that President Boleslaw Bierut had recalled Ambassador Jan Wende from Belgrade.
John T. Danaher, a veteran steamship passenger man widely known in the industry here and on the West Coast, has been named vice president of the American President Lines, the company ...
SEOUL, Wednesday, May 31-- Early results from Korea's second general election in 4,283 years of recorded history indicated independents had made virtually a clean sweep.
Fifteen non-scheduled air carriers have survived among more than 100 such companies that mushroomed in the nation at the end of the war, a canvass of the industry showed yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30--A strong final spurt enabled the oarsmen of Washington and Lee High School, Arlington, Va., to beat Ecorse High School, Ecorse, Mich., in the eight-oared title race of the National Schoolboy Rowing Association's sixteenth annual American championships at Princeton's Lake Carnegie today.
New York A.C. oarsmen won four of the seven races yesterday in the forty-ninth annual Memorial Day Regatta on the Harlem, sponsored by the New York Rowing Association.

Death and discomfort rode the nation's highways last night as the Memorial holiday accident toll, having set a record, continued to mount by the hour. Motorists who had delayed starting for home to enjoy fully the fine weather that had come belatedly were inching cityward, bumper to bumper, over jammed highways.

The House Ways and Means Committee has accepted a recommendation of Secretary of the Treasury Snyder to liberalize the corporation income tax by permitting increased tax credits for operating losses. At present the law permits such losses to be "carried back" (that is, applied as an offset to profits) for two years, and similarly "carried forward" two years.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP)-- Three home runs in the last two innings gave the Cardinals an 8-5 victory over the Pirates in the nightcap today and a sweep of their double-header. St. Louis took the opener, 17--13. Pittsburgh now has lost eight in a row.
TORONTO, May 30 (AP)--Steady demand lifted a wide list of industrials into new high price ground on the Toronto Stock Exchange today.
HELMSTEDT, Germany, Wednesday, May 31--Milling thousands of anti-communist residents of Helmstedt fought pro-Communist German youths in the streets last night.

TOKYO, May 30 (UP)--Japanese Communists mauled and stoned four United States Army men, knocking one down, during a Leftist demonstration in the Imperial Plaza today. The assailants escaped in the crowd but eight Japanese were arrested later by United States military police. The arrests precipitated several other minor skirmishes.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., May 30-- What may turn out to be the fastest Gold Cup speed boat in America this summer won the season's first big league inboard race meet today.

The many questions that have piqued the curiosity and interest of generations on the subject of Emily Dickinson, whose mystery and genius have been only partly revealed through the years, will receive in the not too distant future the most comprehensive answers so far provided by the extant publications of the New England poet's work.
French-American ties were hailed yesterday in a dual memorial service conducted by French groups on Pier 88 of the French Line.

After five years of slow and painstaking effort, the work of restoring $3,000,000 worth of portraits and other art treasures at City Hall is nearly done. Georg J. Lober, executive secretary of the Art Commission, said yesterday that a "priceless heritage" had been protected for future generations.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 30--The former United States, British and French Ambassadors headed the list of twenty-one Western diplomats, officials and newspaper correspondents who were named tonight in an indictment of thirteen Czechoslovaks on charges of treason, espionage and attempting the overthrow of the Govermnent. The trial of the thirteen will begin tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Leading the observance of Memorial Day, Gen. George C. Marshall, who as Secretary of State put forward the plan to strengthen democracy abroad, urged today that the United States match the material aid it had given, the post-war world with the "inspiration of great principles."

Plans have been completed by Miss Lucetta Gilbert Crisp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp of 33 East Seventieth Street and Brookville, L.I., for her marriage to Northrup Rand Knox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Knox of Buffalo.

New York needs the water for cooking, so any rain whatsoever must be regarded as good. On Monday last, it was pos sible to think this over very carefully, ultimately arriving at the only honorable conclusion-that even Monday's ...
LONDON, May 30--Ceremonies commemorating United States service men who fell in the last two World Wars and are buried here were held at several places in Britain today.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., May 30-- Tens of thousands of soil samples are being gathered from eastern Long Island potato and tomato croplands in a survey designed to test the efficacy of the state-imposed quarantine that so far has confined the golden nematode to central and northern Nassau County and the western fringes of Suffolk.

The term of the Third May Grand Jury that has been sifting evidence in the activities of Frank Erickson will be extended for atleast a month when it expires on Friday because of "unfinished business," it was learned yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30-- Johnny Parsons of Van Nuys, Calif., driving a Kurtis-Kraft Wynns Special with a cracked engine, today won the fastest race ever run on the Speedway here. A downpour of rain abruptly ended the contest when 345 of the allotted 500 miles had spun away, but in the meantime automotive history had been made.

A public information program to increase familiarity with the Hoover Commission's recommendations for reorganization of the executive branch of the Government will be started "as soon as possible," it ...

ROME, May 30--The new Israeli proposal to accept United Nations authority over the Holy Places in Jerusalem instead of the internationalization of the whole city was considered inadequate today by well-informed Vatican circles. They made it clear that the Pope's views concerning the Palestine question were unchanged.

Thomas G. Spates, vice president of personnel administration for General Foods Corporation, has been named first chairman emeritus of the Advisory Council on Personnel Administration by the National Industrial Conference Board.
BOSTON, May 30--A four-point program for keeping the United States strong was suggested today by the unopposed candidate for the presidency of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

Cooking with ripe black 'olives, somewhat of an innovation, at least in the East, is attractively proposed in a booklet published by the Olive Advisory Board of California. Thirty-four recipes show how this mellow, nut-flavored fruit enhances salads, casseroles, sandwich fillings and a variety of other dishes.

A legacy of nearly $450,000 that the late William Nelson Cromwell left to the Russian War Relief, Inc., has been reallocated by the executors of the will to the Columbia University Law School, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Further drastic reductions in mail service, involving not only business and home deliveries but the general country-wide postal transportation, have been threatened by economies voted recently by the House in passing the $29,000,000,000 omnibus appropriation bill, it was learned today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30-- Graduate officials of Princeton University's upper class eating clubs have taken steps to prevent a repetition of the uprising by sophomores early this spring demanding 100 per cent club membership for their class.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP)--The Cubs and the Reds divided their twin bill today. The Cubs took the nightcap, 7--4, after dropping the opener, 4--1. Chicago rallied for four runs in the seventh inning to take the second contest.

Synthetic rubber has made "a permanent place" for itself in transportation, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday upon his arrival with Mrs. Firestone from Europe on the Queen Elizabeth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30-- Marina Berti, Italian actress who was seen in "Deported" and "Prince of Foxes," both American films made in Italy, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to play Eunice in "Quo Vadis," which is now before the cameras in Rome.

HYDE PARK, May 30--The name of Franklin D. Roosevelt grows with the years and to millions he lives on as a symbol "of faith in brotherhood and understanding," Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat-Liberal of New York, declared here today in a Memorial Day address at the grave of the late President.

Three five-story buildings at 2686 to 2690 Broadway, southeast corner of West 103d Street, have been purchased by an investor from T.V. Searing, who took the entire property back on a fortytwo-year net lease. Assessed at $350,000, the corner consists of ...

Mathieson Hydrocarbon Chemical Corporation will offer today to holders of common stock of Tennessee Gas Transmision Company rights to subscribe to 466,667 new shares of Mathieson Hydrocarbon common stock at $10.50 ...

BERLIN, May 30--The great youth rally passed off without disturbance in either half of Berlin. Still waving flags and chanting hymns of hate against American imperialism, truckloads and trainloads of weary boys and girls left today on the rough trek homeward.
Impressive as they appear on a sheet of clean white paper, Boston's power-laden Red Sox still seem to have no means with which to combat the cumulative skills of Casey Stengel and his Yankees.

Ice cold in the morning, when he went 5 for 0, Duke Snider turned red hot in the afternoon, blasted three consecutive homers and paced the Dodgers to a 6-4 victory over the Phillies yesterday at Ebbets Field. Having captured the curtain-raiser, 7--6, in a ten-inning thiriller, the Brooks regained first place, one game ahead of the Cardinals, while the Phillies fell from the National League lead into third place.

STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) --Sam E. Wilson Jr.'s Bugledrums won the $10,000 added Christiana Stakes today in a driving finish before a Memorial Day crowd of 22,000. The favored Count Turf was second, a nose off the pace.

FLORENCE, Italy, May 30-- Czechoslovakia and Hungary marched out of the fifth annual conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today after members refused the Soviet satellites' demand to expel Nationalist China from the session.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 30-- Minx of San Miguel, belonging to Julia Cameron Chisholm of Wynnewood, Pa., came up from the classes to get beat of breed today in the third annual specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 30--The Golden Jubilee Convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union adopted today a broad program as the basis of a policy for winning the "cold war."

Americans everywhere honored their war dead yesterday, the eighty-second anniversary of Memorial Day, and prayed anxiously that there might be no more wars. The graves of hundreds of thousands of soldiers and sailors in the United States and its possessions, ...

PARIS, May 30--Another French note was handed to the British Ambassador here tonight in an effort to clarify the argument between Paris and London over the terms of possible British participation in discussions of the French proposal for a European coal and steel pool.

KILLINGWORTH, Conn., May 30--Although many of the Connecticut trout streams were high and discolored as a result of the recent rains, the temperature was just about right today, and there were quite a few heavy creels on some of the more popular streams.

Although strong support of proposed legislation to revise taxing in rectification of whiskies has been pledged by the industry, opposition will come from large distillers, it was learned here on Monday.

The announcement that the Soviet Union favors a European grain agreement and the expansion of trade between the Eastern and Western European countries is welcome. It would be cheered if it could be taken at its face value. Unfortunately, the Russians have said such things befog and done nothing.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., May 30-- All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Jean Lillie Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. John Arthur Brown of Haverford and Samuel Bowman Wheeler of Wynnewood, to William Barclay Parsons Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Parsons of New York.

Democratic socialism is the only force that can stem the twin tides of communism and "reaction," speakers told delegates yesterday at the fiftieth convention of the Workmen's Circle, Jewish laborfraternal group representing 70,000 members in the United States and Canada.

A rush for summer dresses in the low-end price field has taken the New York market by surprise, it was learned on Monday. Manufacturers found themselves largely unprepared for the sudden demand brought on by warmer weather in ...

WASHINGTON, May 30--A new type of publication, an "economic development atlas" reflecting recent economic development of various regions and states, was offered to business men today by the United States Department of ...

Having caught on in the hinterland, the "arena" or "theatre-in the-round" vogue of stage presentation, which doesn't rely on scenery, will be demonstrated on Broadway tonight, starting at 8 o'clock, when "The Show-Off," starring Lee Tracy, opens its engagement at the Arena, which is located in the Hotel Edison.

A Government maritime compensation suit that may have bearing on a number of similar actions resulting from wartime ship losses is pending in Federal District Court here and may go to the Supreme Court for determination, it became known yesterday.
Mrs. Laura B. Prick, who gave a lifetime to the commemoration of events in American history, died yesterday at the age of 75. She was known as the "Mother of National Flag Day."

"A successful plan for a house can develop only from the needs of the family who will occupy it," H. Vandervoort Walsh, architect, said yesterday in explaining why he had written a handbook for amateurs on the highly professional subject of house planning.

BERLIN, May 30--Two days behind the original schedule and pacific rather than menacing in character, the long-predicted Free German Youth invasion of West Berlin is in full swing today. Since last midnight--as promptly as the barrier of the people's Police was withdrawn and their freedom of movement restored--East German ...

What a mother thinks in advance about breast-feeding her baby may have a definite effect on how successful she will be when she tries, according to a study of ninety-one women reported in the latest issue of Pediatrics, the journal of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

Misgivings as to the future of American town planning, found to be wasteful, monotonous and illconceived, were expressed here last week by Joris In 't Veld, Netherlands Minister of Housing and Reconstruction, who has just returned to his homeland. He was delighted, however, with the "alert and lively" civic consciousness of this country.

Runoffs from rain in the watershed area added 1,334,000,000 gallons to the city's reservoirs in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday, according to Edward J. Clark, chief engineer of the Department of Water Supply.
AT high noon yesterday the attendants began to roll down the screen in front of the center-field bleachers at the Stadium and the white-shirted bleacherites swarmed into the seats.

Secretary Acheson has again assures Secretary General Trygve Lie that the United States will not use its veto power to keep Communist China out of the United Nations. This has been our Government's position from the start of the present controversy.
Television adaptations of wellknown stories will be presented by the National Broadcasting Comparry on alternate Fridays from 8 to 8:30 P.M., beginning this week, under the title "The Magic Slate."

NEW DELHI, India, May 30-- Some of India's best known Communists have split from the party and with hundreds of followers are organizing a deviationist Marxist group forswearing the violent tactics that have brought the party into widespread public disrepute.
HONG KONG, May 30--The Chinese Communists, traditionally foot soldiers, are gradually moving out to sea at a number of points along China's coast.

Although a large segment of the population of the United States assumes that the Americans are about the most popular people in the world, neither they nor Washington's policies can be so categorized. The average man abroad does not always distinguish between the American and his Government.

We publish on this page today a letter from a hotel man who feels that New York City, officially, and its business men as well are asleep to the op portunities for promoting the city. Mr. Cantor, as the operator of several hotels, has an obvious self-interest in encouraging visitors to come here.
BOSTON, May 30--Resorting to desperate measures to avert another nose-dive, Leo Durocher salvaged one game of today's twin bill at Braves Field before 16,112 onlookers.

Leon Monroe Schoonmaker, former member of the United States Olympic fencing team, executive member of the United States Olympic Games Committee and consulting engineer to the Queens Planning Commission, died yesterday at his home, 111-21 Puritan Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 68.

FARGO, N.D., May 30 (UP)-- Representative William Lemke, Republican of North Dakota, died on the way to a hospital tonight soon after he collapsed in the Power Hotel in downtown Fargo. He was 71 years old.

MERCEDES, Uruguay, May 30 --An American who has successfully bridged the temperamental gap between Paul's Valley, Okla., and this agricultural center in southwestern Uruguay drove off through the mud yesterday on the first leg of a 7,500-mile journey to the University of Wisconsin, where he will study for a year on a State Department scholarship.

MADRID, May 30--Further moves to reduce government control of private enterprise and liberalize Spain's policy toward foreign capital are attracting much attention here and arouse warm approval among Spanish business men.

TORONTO, Ont., May 30--Industrial buyers from the United States and Canada are placing large orders for plant equipment with exhibitors at the Canadian International Trade Fair here which opened officially yesterday.

The impending resignation of Federal District Judge Alfred C. Coxe of the Southern District of New York was reported widely yesterday in political and judicial circles. Judge Coxe, a Republican, is 70 years old. He was not reached for confirmation.
The European manufacturer can enter the American market at relatively low cost, according to a study of dollar trade prospects prepared by the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency.

GENEVA, May 30--The Soviet Union has advised Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, that the Soviet Government has "favor-... ably received" a proposal of the commission for a European grain agreement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP)-- Home runs by pitcher Bob Hooper and Sam Chapman featured the Athletics' 5-to-1 second-game victory today after Sam Mele's threerun circuit clout had helped Washington take the opener, 4 to 3.

"ROOSEVELT IN RETROSPECT," by John Gunther, is the story of the great renais sance of the rambunctious and triumphant American spirit that an Italian philosopher has called "The Long Presidency." It is unquestionably the Roosevelt biography for our generation: as intimate as Boswell, as garrulous as Sandburg, as dependent on the words and ...
RYE, N.Y., May 30--An easterly breath of stirring air sufficed today to start the fleet in the American Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., May 30 --In the First Presbyterian Church of Haddonfield today Miss Lois Sherrerd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D.M. Sherrerd of Whiteacre, was married to William Frederick Clements of Los Angeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Clements of Kansas City, Mo. The Rew. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony.
DARLINGTON, S.C., May 30-- Four years ago, James Francis Byrnes of Spartanburg, S.C., was engaged in a great talk marathon in Paris, France.

New York was a generous host yesterday to its Memorial Day visitors, offering clear, sunny skies and wide-open thoroughfares. There was room to travel and romp, with Central Park and Rockefeller Center as principal meccas for tourists.

Recent tests indicate that pregnenolone, a hormone-like drug, has no effectiveness against rheumatoid arthritis, according to a report published yesterday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

The sandbox set, from 3 to 6 years old, will make a colorful picture at their play this summer with the many gay sun suits and dresses now in the stores. Bright cottons, both plain and printed, rank first in fabrics, while pique and sturdy sailcloth also are popular.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP)-- President Truman's one-man pollster said today he would have another try at testing the public political pulse as soon as Congress adjourned.

Like many well-known French dramatists, Jean-Jacques Bernard does not aim his work at the literal-minded. His "The Unquiet Spirit" ("L'Ame En Peine"), which opened last night at the Hotel Sutton's Little Theatre on East Fifty-Sixth Street under the sponsorship of "Q" Productions, is a play that makes demands upon the imagination.

The city administration offered yesterday to have the question of high school teachers' salaries investigated by a fact-finding group consisting of members of the Board of Education and outside citizens. Pending the survey, the teachers would be expected to resume the extra-curricular activities that they dropped some time ago.

BERLIN, May 30--This troubled city settled into an uneasy calm today disturbed mainly by the claims of the East and West as to the true victor in the events of the last week-end's Free German Youth demonstrations.

The last of this season's crop of big annual group exhibitions-- paintings, sculpture and graphic art by members of the National Association of Women Artists-- will open with a preview reception this evening in the galleries of the National Academy. Mrs. Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxembourg, will be guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP)-- The soft-coal industry, troubled by the competition of other fuels and periodic work stoppages, is overcrowded with miners even though 39,000 have left the field in the last eighteen months, the Government said today.
HONOLULU, May 30--Hawaii honored the nation's Pacific war dead today with an unprecedented display of flowers even for these islands of floral profusion.

The so-called problem of small business, as such, is mostly imaginary, according to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. There is no basic conflict of interest between big business and small business, the bank asserts in the ...
Dismissal of 165 employes of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation on June 15 was recommended yesterday to Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman by Prof. Emanuel Stein of New York University.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The Peruvian Ambassador, Fernando Berckmeyer, reported today that Spain has offered to restore the historical monuments of ancient Cuzco, one-time capital of the Inca empire, which were destroyed or damaged in the recent earthquake in that Andes mountain region.

MONTREAL, Way 31 (AP)--President Truman cited the International Civil Aviation Organization today as a "striking example" of how free people could advance cooperation among nations and promote world peace.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The House Ways and Means Committee, responding to complaints of business men, agreed today on a proposal to simplify the operation of a previously approved 10 per cent withholding tax in dividends.

The General American Transportation Corporation has sold the ten-story office building at 8-10 East Forty-ninth Street to the Stuart Control Corporation and has leased back the upper floors of the structure. The lease provides that during the tenancy the property will be known as the General American Transportion ...

New York's weather has played a foul trick on Mr. and Mrs. William P. Crowe of Honolulu. Since Easter of 1948, twenty-six months, they have been "following the sun" for 40,000 ocean miles in their 39foot schooner, Lang Syne, always planning to reach this city for thesunshine in May.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 31--The main defendant, Dr. Milada Horakova, pleaded guilty today to charges of high treason, spying and sabotage at the trial of thirteen Czechoslovaks accused of fifth column treachery.

Two yong thugs armed with revolvers escaped with $12,000 worth of unfinished gems and $150 after binding and gagging six diamond polishers in an office on the seventh floor of a twelve-story loft building at 145 West. Fortyfifth Street yesterday afternoon.

If, as many important leaders believe, the outbreak of a new world war is not imminent, the United States still has time to complete the process of shaping its foreign policy. The Soviet Union, it is held, is too preoccupied with the vast problems of Asia and is succeeding too well in its current political aspirations to desire a "shooting" global conflict now.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Farm prices advanced about 2.5 per cent between mid-April and mid-May to reach the highest level since September, 1949.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)-- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, accused importing oil companies today of "robbing our country" but said he would like some of their spokesmen to testify before the Senate Labor subcommittee which he heads.

Gold, silver and bronze medals were awarded yesterday to young artists whose works done in the various centers of the Police Athletic League have been on exhibition in the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit since it opened on May 20.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31-- Spectators of many nationalities broke into prolonged applause today as Rameshwar Dayal, Deputy Commissioner and Chief Magistrate of Delhi, acquitted John K. Edwards, 27-year-old former major in the British Army, of having assaulted Argentine Ambassador Dr. Oscar Tascheret by pouring water on the envoy's head in a New Delhi night club on May 5.

LONDON, May 31--United States bombers and jet fighters will take part in a two-day Western European Union air maneuvers in August to test the air defenses of industrial and communications areas of Western Europe.

Seven men and four women who engaged in a "sit-in" demonstration at Welfare Department headquarters, 902 Broadway, on April 3, were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday by Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Lower Manhattan Court.

With attention centered on the Yankees, who are in position to blast the American League pennant race wide open following their brilliantly successful road trip and their stirring double Memorial Day triumph over the Red Sox, baseball activity will resume today after a general post-holiday break in the major league schedule.

Receipt of belated entries yesterday from Alf Holmberg, Tennessee's Swedish freshman, and Joe Barry, the Irish star who is attending Villanova, lends an international aspect to the James A. Norton Mile, which features the program of the New York Athletic Club's Spring Games at Travers Island on Saturday.

JOHANNESURG, South Africa, May 31 (AP)--Vic Toweel, speedy young South African, won the world bantamweight championship tonight by scoring a clear-cut 15round decision over aging Manuel Ortiz of El Centro, Calif.

A special three-hour all-star television show, with Milton Berle as master of ceremonies, will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company Saturday, June 10, beginning at 9 P.M., in behalf of the United Cerebral Palsy Association.

A burst of strength in the television group supplied new life yesterday to the stock market. While the rest of the list was steady, with a few spurts in some of the key issues, the TV stocks returned to favor after a lapse of several weeks and registered gains of more than 2 points. Scattered issues matched the increase in the television section, while the rise in the composite rate held to 0.30 point.
The Long Island Rail Road moved yesterday to abandon sections of the Rockaway Beach and Far Rockaway branches that include the Jamaica Bay trestle. The over-water link was destroyed by fire on May 7.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 31-- Federal Judge John F.X. McGohey of the Southern District of New York told the graduating class of Marymount College and 1,000 guests today that he did not long for the "good old days" of past decades, because great progress was being made in the world.

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation, will recommend that the city remove from its port rehabilitation program three of the eleven new pier structures projected when the program was approved in 1949.

The Czech Government is making another move in the dark process of cutting its people off from the world to which they belong. The latest espionage trial, like previous ones and like all the complicated moves eliminating consulates, cutting down diplomatic staffs, ousting foreign correspondents and closing foreign libraries, fits into a pattern. There is no use trying to deal with the reasons given by the Czech ...

Timothy Newell Pfeiffer of the firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley was elected yesterday as president of the Legal Aid Society. He succeeds Whitney North Seymour, who resigned after his election as president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Recommendations clearing the way for a fare rise on the municipal transit lines on July 1 by adding $13,188,515 to their annual operating costs for the next two years were submitted yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer. They were made...
Prison terms of six months to a year and fines totaling $2,750 were imposed yesterday in Kings County Court on three men convicted as bookmakers in Brooklyn's gambling investigation.

ZURICH, May 31--A new attempt to obtain legal protection for interests of non-enemy ordinary shareholders in Interhandel A.G. (International Industrie and Handelsdeteilighongen A.G.) has been started in Switzerland.

A minor sales decline, more in the nature of a readjustment, is now taking place in the candy industry, it was reported yesterday at the annual convention of the National Candy Wholesalers in the Commodore Hotel. It was estimated that 1950 total sales will fail to meet last year's $1,000,000,000 figure at the wholesale level by only a small percentage.

A dealer who has sublet a subway news stand from the Union News Company for the last sixteen years was summoned into Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court yesterday morning charged with the unlawful sales of newspapers and other commodities. Magistrate Harry G. Andrews adjourned the case for a hearing on June 15.

The price of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange advanced yesterday the daily permissible limit of 200 points, or 2c a pound, in the July and December positions as the market reached its highest level since 1928.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31--Federal Judge James P. McGranery asserted today that Harry Gold was ready to plead guilty to acting as a courier for a Russian atomic bomb spy ring.

BARNWELL, S.C., May 31-- Both candidates for a Democratic Senatorial seat from South Carolina gave the impression today that their chances for election in the July 11 primary rested upon the vehemence with which they could denounce President Truman and his civil rights program.

Three pages of financial advertising space in the international air edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES will carry today to Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and Latin-America formal notice that $26,400,000 of the Cities Service Company's 3 per cent debentures not due until 1977 have been called for redemption on July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The hope of Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, that an effective meeting this summer of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Soviet Russia, Great Britain and France can be held within the framework of the Security Council, and the recent tentative moves of the Kremlin toward formal resumption of East-West trade, which Secretary of State Acheson addressed Congress today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31-- Howard Hughes, managing director of R.K.O., has engaged Sam Bischoff, independent film producer, as executive producer at the studio, a post vacated last week by Sid Rogell. It is understood, however, that Bischoff's authority will ...

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Sharon Kerley Bonner, daughter of Mrs. Foeko van der Laan of 10 East Eightyfirst Street and Charles Bonner of 55 East Seventy-third Street, to ...

On the eve of its target date of June 1, New York yesterday still had a water shortage but the Catskill and Croton reservoirs, at 230,813,000,000 gallons or 91.2 per cent of capacity, were far better off than had been thought possible at the low point last December.

WASHINGTON, May 31--Cloyd Heck Marvin, president of George Washington University, said tonight that the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace had turned over its library of 70,000 volumes to the university.

Arturo Toscanini gave a party for the members of the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra and their wives at his home in Riverdale late yesterday afternoon. It was his way of thanking the men for the spirit in which they played on the transcontinental tour that closed last Saturday night in Philadelphia.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP)-- Record prizes were distributed tonight to participants in yesterday's 500-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race.

The Brooklyn Dodgers are back at the head of the parade, apparently ready to take charge. The New York Yankees are at the head of the other parade, beginning to gain respect.

A toughening of the official attitude toward teen-age gangsters was put into words yesterday by Magistrate Benjamin Brenner, who told participants in the zip gun fights that marred Memorial Day in Brooklyn: "We're not going to treat you like kids any more."

Apparently Dame Nature has made up her mind to mix up the fish migrations this season. For while the weakfish are long overdue, the bluefish are making an early appearance, and in fair numbers as well as large sizes.

Installment lending by Federal Reserve member banks of this district now amounts to two-fifths of such credit in the country as a whole, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The Japanese Government's paper on the conclusion of a peace treaty is a significant document. This year's graduating class at New York University will be slightly larger than the 1949 record, it was announced yesterday. At the commencement exercises on June 14, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will confer degrees on 9,100 candidates from the fourteen schools, colleges and divisions of the university.

NEWARK, June 4--A $25-aplate Labor Day dinner, aimed at thwarting Taft-Hartley Law limitation on political contributions by unions, is planned for Sept. 4, by the New Jersey Political Action Committee of the State Congress of Industrial Unions Council.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 4--The "enormous social responsibility" of the handful of United States newsreel producers in the era of the "cold war" is stressed in "World Newsreels," a study by the United Nations' Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, made public here today.

Clifford E. Hicks, president of the New York Dock Company, largest, enterprise of its type in the Port of New York, declared yesterday that prospects for the future development and expansion of Brooklyn's vast waterfront facilities were more promising now than at any time in recent years.

Deputy Postmaster General Vincent C. Burke delivered an implied rebuke yesterday to officials of the National Association of Letter Carriers for allegedly starting a country-wide propaganda campaign to discredit the Post Office Department's recent curtailment of mail service.

The Baireuth Festival, known to the music world as the Richard Wagner shrine, will be revived next year, according to a cablegram received yesterday by Carleton Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation, from Wieland Wagner, grandson of the composer.

PITTSBURGH, June 4--Under the critical gaze of President Horace Stoneham and 14,534 Forbes Field's loyalists, the Giants today dislodged the Pirates as the National League's sixth-place tenants by spiking the Buccaneers' guns, 4 to 3.

MONTREAL, June 4--Canada's primary role in the air defense of the North American Continent is the provision of a "ground plant," the airports and the navigational and flight control systems capable of immediate use by both the Canadian and United States air forces.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP)--The Red Sox pounded four pitchers for twenty-one hits today while overwhelming the White Sox, 17--7. Pinch-hitter Gordon Goldsberry banged the game's only homer, which provided Chicago with two runs in the sixth inning.

CHICAGO, June 4--The fiftyfirst annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers began here today with the opening of the world's largest "grocery store," more than a mile of exhibits up and down the length of ChiCago's Navy Pier.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The State Department proposed today the assembly of outstanding American scientists in a Science Office here and in diplomatic missions abroad for the encouragement of free, international scientific inquiry and exchange of information essential to the peace and welfare not only of the United States but of the world.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP)--Max Lanier pitched and batted the St. Louis Cardinals into a first-place tie with the Brooklyn Dodgers as the Redbirds downed the Philadelphia Phils, 6 to 2, today.
SEASIDE PARK, N. J., June 4 --Mrs. Francis Parkman Freeman, author of many children's books under the name of Augusta Huiell Seaman, died today at her home on Island Beach. Her age was 71.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman today signed into law the bill that authorizes $3,200,000,000 for five foreignaid programs. He declared that it was "a memorable step forward in our program for peace."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 5 --The American family, which is rumored to be suffering a breakdown, can look to many agencies for aid in understanding and helping children, one of the nation's few lay analysts said today.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The hitherto easy-going observance of the "separate but equal" doctrine, which the Supreme Court in 1896 (Plessy v. Ferguson) decreed as satisfying the "equal protection" mandate of the Fourteenth Amendment, and which the states and interstate carriers have relied on to ...

In the ninety years since the first sailing ship tankers put to sea the world's tanker tonnage has grown until today it approximates 40 per cent of the total tonnage of all other types of merchant ships, according to The Lamp, publication of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

A bleak picture of the industrial unpreparedness of the United States was presented yesterday at the opening of a two-week course in economic mobilization arranged by the Industrial College of the Armed Forces at the Astor Hotel.
An attack on the Federal Administration's national health insurance plan as "bureaucratic, rigid and inflexible" was made yesterday by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance.

An issue of new electric power revenue bonds of the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority is being prepared for marketing in the near future, it was revealed here yesterday by D.R. Bonniwell, finance director of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico. Mr. Bonniwell spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum at the Lawyers Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5--In an unprecedented display of unity, more than 3,000 members of the utility industry today unanimously ratified a fifteen-point power policy program that has little likelihood of being adopted by the Federal Government at which it was aimed.

I. George Goldstein, Newark accountant whose name was listed on records detailing the financial interest Frank Erickson shared with several underworld figures in the Colonial Inn, a gaming casino at Hallandale, Fla., testified yesterday for more than two hours before the third May grand jury.

One of the lesser lights from the Christopher T. Chenery Stable that includes the famous Hill Prince had his chance to shine yesterday when Bryan G., a 3-year-old son of Blenheim II, scampered to victory in the featured Confectioners Purse at Belmont Park.
Ilona Massey has been signed by the National Broadcasting Company to play the role of a spy in a new radio series entitled "Top Secret," which begins Monday evening at 10:30 o'clock.
CHICAGO, June 5--The general commodity price trend on the Board of Trade here was lower today, with erratic and decidedly wide swings in soybean futures tending to unsettle the other pit markets.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today upheld the validity of a patent licensing agreement which calls for royalty payments whether the patents are used or not. The high tribunal, splitting 6-2, rejected Government arguments that the agreement should be overturned.

Vincent Flemming, a member of the Police Department for thirteen years, was held yesterday in the prison ward of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn charged with homicide in the fatal shooting of a prospective policeman in a hold-up.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 6--Gen. Douglas MacArthur this morning ordered the Japanese Government to ban all twenty-four members of the Central Committee of the Japanese Communist party from public affairs in Japan.

King Leopold of the Belgians is said by a member of the royal household to be "very satisfied" with the elections that have just given the Social Christian (Catholic) party a bare majority in both houses of Parliament. There can be little satisfaction to anyone else.

Bluefish not only seem to be as unpredictable as the weather, but are influenced by it, and those who made the trip to the New Jersey coast over the week-end found the wind as well as the bluefish had shifted.
Cancer should be made the "problem number one" of the dental profession, Dr. Kurt H. Thoma said yesterday at the eighty-second annual meeting of the Dental Society of New York State.

The Supreme Court did not overturn the "separate but equal" doctrine in the three decisions involving segregation handed dowm yesterday. What the Court did seem to be saying in one opinion was that Negroes entering the Southern Railway Company's dining cars did not in fact receive facilities equal to those given white travelers.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- The Federal Government has decided to turn its Chicago white elephant--the wartime DodgeChrysler aircraft engine plant-- into a Government warehouse and offices.

Anticipating final Congressional action to force a cut in the administrative expenditures of Federal agencies, the National Labor Relations Board has distributed tentative dismissal notices to forty of its field examiners and fifteen of its staff attorneys, it became known yesterday.

Harvey G. Perine, 74-year-old vice president of James W. Elwell Co., general shipping agents, ran a practiced eye over the latest Department of Commerce foreign trade report yesterday and conceded that the world cargo situation was "spotty."
From the consumer's point of view, the cold weather that has delayed the New Jersey strawberry crop this spring may have an economic advantage.

Copper prices were boosted 2 cents a pound here yesterday by custom smelters, while a number of producers were described as "out of the market" on refined new copper. The new price level was quoted at 22 cents a pound, Connecticut Valley, and was promptly reflected in higher prices for brass casting ingots, raised 1 to 2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, June 5--an increase of 1,063,000 in the number of persons gainfully employed in this country occurred from midApril to mid-May, the Census Bureau said today. Its report showed that an estimated 59,731,000 held civilian jobs in the week ended May 13, the largest total at work since August, 1949.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5-- Gregory Peck was named today by Twentieth Century-Fox for the role of David in "David and Bathsheba," which Philip Dunne is writing for production next year by Darryl F. Zanuck.

With both Schoharie and Ashokan Reservoirs in the Catskills overflowing, the city's water reserves rose by 563,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday to a new total of 236,318,000,000 gallons or 93.4 per cent of capacity.

World demand for wool is at record levels, with every indication that demand will continue greater than production, Douglas T. Boyd, chairman of the Australian Wool Board, said here yesterday. He was guest of honor at a reception given by Rupert R. Ellen, Australian Government Trade Commissioner, at 630 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Following is the text of President Truman's statement today as he signed the $3,121,450,000 foreign aid bill for the fiscal year begining July 1:
WASHINGTON, June 5--A spokesman for twenty-one standard railway unions today opposed compulsory arbitration of disputes affecting the nation's railroads.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular toward the close yesterday and ended 10 points lower to 7 points net higher.

Carpet manufacturers may increase prices from 5 to 10 per cent at the Chicago home furnishings market which opens July 19, retailers reported yesterday. Spokesmen for several mills said such increases are definitely being considered.

Described as the largest offering of stock in banking history, L.M. Giannini, president of the Bank of America, announced yesterday that the bank's offering of more than $70,000,000 of new common stock to its shareholders has been substantially oversubscribed.

The arrival of four prominent New York bankers in Spain over the week-end was described as merely "coincidental" in financial circles here yesterday. Downtown bankers especially well informed on Spanish developments said they knew of no imminent changes in that country's credit situation.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 6 (UP) --The text of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's letter to Premier Shigeru Yoshida:

WASHINGTON, June 5--The United States and other North Atlantic Treaty countries agree that their information programs should be stepped up in the face of evidence that the Russians are becoming "panicky" in the information field, Edward W. Barrett, Assistant Secretary of State, reported today.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, New York Hospital Commissioner, warned yesterday that adequate preparations for medical treatment of civilians in case of an atom bomb attack on the metropolitan area could be made only if the Government assumed leadership and assisted in stockpiling supplies and equipment in outlying districts.

ST. LOUIS, June 5--The Rev. Dr. William Gustave Polack, editor of The Lutheran Witness, official journal of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, one of the country's largest Lutheran bodies, died here today after a brief illness. He was 59 years old.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 5-- Plans have been completed by Miss Margaret Yeomans Compton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Compton Jr., for her marriage here on the afternoon of June 24 to Foster Bam, son of Mrs. Foster Bam of Westport and Frederick Bam of New York.

Being able to visualize a completely furnished apartment by looking at spick-and-span but empty rooms is difficult enough for some people. But to stand in the midst of rubble and scrap and imagine something worthwhile in the way of a home coming out of the mess is a staggering proposition to almost anyone.

The current election for the upper house in the Japanese legislature is coming out largely as expected. The result would have been dramatic and perhaps alarming if there had been some sort of decisive repudiation of the Government of Premier Yoshida. Nothing of the sort happened.
BERLIN, June 5 (AP)--A gigantic Communist youth rally in West Germany was planned tonight by Red leaders desiring to scuttle the Schuman plan.
WASHINGTON, June 5--In the last few days a distinct note of optimism has been evident in the Administration's official statements about maintaining peace.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Both exports and imports fell off during April, according to statistics made public today by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce. Imports totaled $583,300,000 in April, compared with $664,400,000 in March, and exports declined to $808,100,000 from $867,800,000 in March.

DETROIT, June 5--Mass evacuation of civilians from potential targets in the event of another war would produce "national chaos," Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding officer of the Air University, said today. He urged that cities begin immediate planning to meet the problem.

WASHINGTON, June 5--In the Supreme Cour of the United States today Harold Halpern, James Hall Brooks, Ira Kaye, George L. Hubbell Jr., Benjamin Spiegel, William J. Drohan Albert E. Hadlock Jr., Howard R. Hawkins of New York City and Shirly P. Mehl of Brooklyn, among others, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:
WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman nominated Henry F. Grady today to be United States Ambassador to Iran.

A new engine which employs a radical change in combustion technique, eliminating "knock" and points to a 30 per cent increase in miles a gallon, was described by Texaco engineers in a paper read before the opening session yesterday of the summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers at French Lick, Ind.

GENEVA, June 5--Despite repeated boasting that they have ended unemployment, the Communist countries of Eastern Europe suffer from large concealed unemployment, or unemployment by another name, Andre Philip, French delegate, charged today before the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

A telephone subscriber has an "absolute right" to protect the use made of his telephone, the Apellate Division, Second Department, ruled unanimously yesterday in reversing the conviction of three men accused of illegal wiretapping. In a three-to-two decision, the court dismissed the indictments.

The twenty-family apartment house at 35-45 Ninety-fourth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by John and Mary Tirassa from 35-45 Apartments, Inc. The property is assessed at $60,000. William Bodine Co. were the brokers.

For the first time in the history of American medicine, a direct frontal attack on the problem of preventing--rather than curing--disease through the combined forces of clinical medicine, social work, psychology, psychiatry and education will be made here next fall.
Additions to capital funds by the national banks of the United States totaled more than $270,000,000 last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Bankers Association.
BRIDGETON, N.J., June 5-- The Western Union Telegraph Company was named in five indictments returned today by a Cumberland County grand jury in connection with the transmission of racing bets.

Mass hysteria over the possibility of sex crimes can injure youngsters emotionally and the best protection a parent can offer his child against such harm is the security of a close relationship, Mrs. Irma W. Hewlett said last night.

The price of the top grade of steel-making scrap metal jumped $4 a ton at Pittsburgh yesterday to a new all-time peak of $46 to $48 a ton as consumers continued to exert pressure for supplies in a tight market.

MIAMI, Fla., June 5--A nonscheduled C-46 plane with sixtyfive persons aboard fell into the Atlantic Ocean 330 miles northeast of this city tonight. A life raft later was reported as having been sighted in the vicinity of the crash.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Reargument of the issues involved, in the price discrimination suit brought by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana against the Federal Trade Commission was ordered by the United States Supreme Court today. The reargument will take place at the resumption of the court's sessions after the summer recess.
Further manifestations anent the summer theatre were made known yesterday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5 (AP)-- Under Secretary of State James E. Webb said today that the world was approaching a new era, one in which totalitarianism would disappear.

A revival of the musical "Of Thee I Sing," which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1932, will be one of the attractions at the Chicago Fair of 1950, scheduled to open on June 24, it was announced here yesterday.

Japan's revitalized shipbuilding industry has expanded production of merchant ship tonnage to the point where it threatens to surpass the output of United States yards, it was made known yesterday in statistics released by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 5 (UP)--The Louisiana Senate voted tonight to appoint a committee to determine whether Clayton Fritchey, editor of The New Orleans Item, was guilty of disrespect for printing an editorial which said that some Louisiana legislators "have about as much independence as trained seals."

Calling for the nomination of a Democrat to oppose Representative Vito Marcantonio in the Eighteenth Congressional District, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he did not believe Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, meant "a word of it" when he said he was willing to back a coalition candidate.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 5 (UP)--Zdenek Peska, 50, a stoopshouldered former Professor, described the Communist regime today as the "dregs of society" as he and all twelve other defendants pleaded guilty in a mass treason trial.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5--Ray Robinson of Harlem earned himself a piece of the world middleweight championship tonight. The speedy New Yorker, who also holds the welterweight championship of the world, gained the recognition of the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission ...

CLEVELAND, June 5--Moved to Cleveland from Forest Hills, L.I., the venue for the past four years, the national professional tennis championship opened here today on the clay courts of the Skating Club in Shaker Heights.
The Congress of Industrial Organizations will give its formal blessings today to negotiations with the American Federation of Labor for a healing of the fifteenyear-old breach between the two groups.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, will make a personal plea to Mayor O'Dwyer this afternoon for prompt approval of the report submitted to the Mayor last week by his transit fact-finding committee.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation moved yesterday to split the corporation's common stock two-for-one. Their action, which must be ratified by shareholders, would raise to 88,208,688 the number of the corporation's common shares outstanding, making it the leading American corporation in that respect.

NEWARK, June 5--Superior Court Judge Walter Freund reserved decision today on defense motions to dismiss Gov. Alfred F. Driscoll's suit to ovoid the sale of two bridges to the Burlington County Bridge Commission by a group that included Clifford R. Powell, Burlington County Republican leader.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5-- The Brannan farm plan appeared tonight to be winning endorsement in this agricultural state.
ROME, June 5--Pope Pius consecrated today a new altar in the Vatican Grottoes over the place where St. Peter is believed to have been buried in 67 A.D.

Openings of fall apparel lines yesterday drew hundreds of outof-town buyers to New York showrooms. Larger attendance and retailers' inclination to place sizable initial orders indicate that a good season is in prospect for the women's and misses' apparel trades, according to manufacturers.

The Greater New York Division of the National Committee for Fair Play in Bowling honored Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday for his "outstanding service in eliminating discrimination in bowling."
WASHINGTON, June 5--The Supreme Court declared today that the United States Government had first rights to the enormously rich oil-bearing submerged lands off the coasts of Louisiana and Texas.

CINCINNATI, June 5--Comic magazines published in the United States have shown a marked improvement in their acceptability as reading material for children during the two years of activity of the Committee on Evaluation of Comic Books, according to the Rev. Jesse L. Murrell, pastor of the First Methodist Church of Covington, Ky.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 5--A "steadily growing program of direct technical assistance for the economic development of the countries of Latin America" under the auspices of the United Nations was forecast here this morning by David Owen, Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations for economic affairs.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 5--The next few weeks are expected to determine whether Syria can reestablish genuine civilian government or whether the Army will become the permanent seat of authority because of the politicians' incapacity to set up a stable state and the overwhelming burden of military expenditures.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Supreme Court refused today to review the legal fight of Negroes against exclusion as tenants in the $90,000,000 Stuyvesant Town housing project on New York City's lower East Side.
STANTON, Del., June 5 (AP)--Justin Funkhouser's Noble Impulse held on to a head advantage in the Queen Anne Purse at Delaware Park today to repel Edgar A. Nicodemus' Laran in the six furlong dash.
Issues of three public utility bonds amounting to $31,500,000 were sold at competitive bidding yesterday to investment banking syndicates. The awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 5--Unable to expand the living quarters and teaching facilities at Annapolis because of the defense economy program, the Navy is planning to cut the number of appointments to the Naval Academy.

BOSTON, June 5--Walter S. Cross of Fitchburg, Mass., for many years a Christian Science practitioner, was named president today of The Mother Church, The First Church of Christ, Scientist. He succeeds Miss Emma C. Shipman of Brookline to the one-year presidential term.
Rockefeller Foundation grants for the first quarter of 1950 totaled $1,254,433, Chester I. Barnard, president, announced yesterday.

Continuing at their all-time record pace, domestic steel mills this week will operate at 101.3 per cent of theoretical ingot capacity, a decline of 0.2 point from last week's rate, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It will mark the eighth consecutive week in which the industry has run at 100 per cent, or higher.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today by a 5to-0 vote upheld the conviction of Edward F. Prichard Jr., on charges of stuffing ballot boxes in the 1948 presidential election.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Supreme Court, in a 6-3 decision, ruled today that the Federal District Courts may not issue writs of habeas corpus for war criminals imprisoned in Germany on sentences by American military tribunals.

The execution of sentences on three convicted bookmakers in Brooklyn's gambling investigation was put off indefinitely yesterday because two of them were assisting the inquiry by identifying their associates.

When Governor Dewey appointed Charles D. Breitel, his counsel for seven years, to be a Supreme Court Justice in the First District there was general applause. Justice Breitel assumed his post in January, and it is satisfying to learn from members of the bar that he has made an excellent impression. This is hardly a surprise.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--In three primaries tomorrow California Democrats will say whether they want James Roosevelt as their nominee for Governor, South Dakota Republicans will pass on the bid of Senator Chan Gurney for renomination and New Mexico Democrats will choose among four candidates for Governor.

Only moderate selling was necessary yesterday to administer a sharp setback to the stock market. Liquidation was touched off by softness in the steels and motors, and the resulting decline proved the worst since April 20, as measured by the averages.
The establishment of a repertory company on Broadway by Sam Wanamaker, an idea that has been with him since September, is expected to be realized this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman is expected to enlarge the Government's Loyalty Review Board tomorrow by naming a panel of three new members, specifically charged with re-examining Federal Bureau of Investigation loyalty files on eighty-one State Department employes.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 5 --Willie Goggin, Century Country Club, and Ray O'Brien, Bonnie Briar, fashioned a 64 to lead home a field of fifty-four teams in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day proamateur best-ball tournament at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today.

The threat of television to the book industry and the mounting demand in recent years for religious and inspirational books were studied yesterday by 650 members of the American Booksellers Association, which opened a three-day convention at the Astor Hotel celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the group.
Officials of nine unions, representing 20,000 workers in phases of the newspaper business in this city, met yesterday for their second joint session and agreed to respect one another's picket lines.

LONDON, June 5--Last week's buoyancy of industrial stocks was fully maintained on the stock markets here today. The little profittaking that occurred was absorbed easily and prices generally closed with widespread gains of as much as 1s.

LAKE, SUCCESS, June 5--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has decided to submit to the fifty-nine members a report on his efforts to compose differences among the Big Four and restore the effectiveness of the organization.

There is no reason to fear of communism in India if employment can be furnished for the upper middle and middle classes, Durga Das of New Delhi, an editor of The Hindustan Times, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the India League of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A move to require City Planning Commission approval of offstreet garaging and parking facilities for a minimum of 150 cars instead of the 200-minimum now provided under the zoning law was made yesterday by the commission.

Consolidated income of the American and Foreign Power Company Inc., and subsidiaries for 1948 was $16,734,652, the annual report, released yesterday by W. S. Robertson, president, disclosed. This was an increase of 30 per cent above the previous year's income of $12,852,095.

Sixteen naval officers of six Latin-American nations arrived yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn for three weeks of study of Navy Yard procedures, ordnance and electronics. They came from Annapolis, where half of them had completed one year and the others two years of engineering courses in the United States Naval Academy.

CHICAGO, June 5--The food industry is the greatest industry in America, and it is a growing business, A.C. Nielsen, Chicago market research authority, told the convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers here today.

WASHINGTON, June 5--One grave war-time disaster in a major American city would not only require the nation's complete stock of whole blood but would require more than the country is now able to produce in an entire year.

DANBURY, Conn., June 5-- Frederic Buel Bard, secretary and a member of the board of directors of the Bard-Parker Company of this city, manufacturers of surgical instruments, died here today in his apartment at the Hotel Green. He was 91 years old.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 5-- Belgium emerged from yesterday's general election, essentially a contest between those who oppose and those who favor the return of King Leopold III to his throne, with both sides claiming success today and with the country's politics more confused than ever.
PITTSBURGH, June 5--Andy Hansen made one pitch, a winning one, on Forbes Field tonight and touched off a Giant demonstration that almost brought him bodily injury.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued an order authorizing the sale by the Cities Service Company, at competitive bidding, of 302,075 shares of the common stock of the Toledo Edison Company.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP)--Robin Roberts gave up thirteen hits tonight but managed to squeeze out a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals to push the Philadelphia Phillies into second place in the hot National League race.
LONDON, June 5 (AP)--Lee Savold caps eleven years as a heavyweight contender tomorrow night with his first shot at the title.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- The Supreme Court split evenly again today in upholding the legality of the Taft-Hartley Law's provision requiring union leaders to swear they did not believe in communism. But each side picked up a supporter. The vote today was 4 to 4. On May 8, it was 3 to 3.

LONDON, June 5--Fresh from a holiday in France, Prime Minister Attlee called on Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin at the hospital today and shortly afterward it was made known in positive fashion that no changes, interim or otherwise, were contemplated at the Foreign Office.

In signing the act authorizing the expenditure of $3,200,000,000 for foreign economic assistance during the coming fiscal year, President Truman emphasized yesterday that the major new step forward in it is represented by one of its smallest items--the $35,000,000 for the Point Four program.

MONTREAL, June 5--Canada's new role as an able contestant in the world-wide competition between the producers of military and commercial turbojet aircraft and power plants has been made evident at the twelfth annual convention of the Aviation Writers' Association.
CHICAGO, June 5--Their outraged feelings still smarting from the indignities heaped upon them by the Cubs yesterday, the Dodgers laid a heavy hand on Frankie Frisch's youngsters today.

Almost 70 per cent of the state highway system is inadequate to meet traffic demands, while hundreds of miles have deteriorated into menaces to motorists, Charles D. Henderson, executive vice president of the New York State Automobile Dealers, declared yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5-- Stephen T. Early, Under Secretary of Defense, and Frank C. Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, watched the colorful graduation parade at the United States Military Academy today as 671 members of this year's graduating class marched for the last time with the Corps of Cadets.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 5-- Miss Arabella Halsey Miller, founder in 1923 of the Pioneer Club, devoted to youth welfare in the downtown section of Elizabeth, and organizer in 1909 of the city's first visiting nurse program, died last night at The Brittan, the family homestead, 1025 East Jersey Street, after an illness of several months. Her age was 87.

Their ninth-inning rally falling short, the Yankees, after eight straight after-dark victories, dropped a 3-2 decision to Bob Feller and the Indians before 57,629 fans at the Stadium last night. With the tying run at second and only one out, two pinch-hitters failed to come through and forthwith the New York lead over the Detroit Tigers was cut to a length and a half.

Since record-taking began in 1823 Mauna Loa has been erupting on an average every three and a third years. In fact, geophysicists on the spot find no difficulty in predicting when one of Hawaii's three active volcanoes is likely to erupt again.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 5 --A record class of 222 graduates received diplomas this afternoon at commencement exercises on the campus of the College of New Rochelle, one of the largest Catholic schools for girls in the United States. Cardinal Spellman presided.
One out of every four workers covered by the State Unemployment Insurance Law registered as unemployed at some time during the "benefit year" that ended last Friday.
ATLANTA, June 5 (AP)--Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia shouted defiance today in the first Southern reaction to Supreme Court decisions hitting at racial segregation.

The bidding yesterday for $31,500,000 of new utility bonds was taken in the financial district to evidence the readiness of banking syndicates to face up to the heavy schedule of corporate and municipal borrowing, rather than to back away.

The largest representation of European-made candy producing machinery shown here in more than fifteen years was one of the features of the twenty-fourth annual Confectionery Industries Exposition which opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, June 5--In three unanimous opinions dealing with racial discrimination, the Supreme Court, on the last day of its term, struck down today barriers separating Negroes in railroad dining cars and in two educational institutions.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman pleaded today for renewed efforts to prevent losses from industrial accidents so that the nation could muster its full resources against the challenge of totalitarianism.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- Daniel C. Mahoney, Portland, Ore., Federal Court law clerk, told a Senate judiciary subcommittee today he believed acting United States District Judge Gus T. Solomon of Portland, was a Communist.

BONN, Germany, June 5--The West German Federal Government today assailed the occupation costs, which pay for the defense of Germany by United States, British and French troops, as an "unstable" factor in West German economy.

A group of service men on an island in the Pacific recently sent a contribution to the United Negro College Fund. The sum represented, according to the accompanying letter, donations and a "10 per cent rake-off from all dice games."

Three thousand persons adopted a resolution last night calling upon President Truman to free eleven members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee and two Hollywood writers sentenced to jail for cantempt of the House Committee on un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- The House Ways and Means Committee today voted a further $66,000,000 cut in excise taxes in the face of increasing doubts that Congress will enact any new tax measures this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5-- William C. Mullendore, president of the Southern California Edison Company, disclosed here today that he had sent a stinging rebuke to the special House committee investigating lobbying.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 5-- Westchester's cost-of-living bonus for 2,637 employes was frozen at $720 a year until next January by the Board of Supervisors this afternoon. This was the first time since 1943 that the bonus had not been increased or lowered in accordance with the current Federal index of living costs.

THE, years which Van Wyck Brooks called "The Flowering of New England," 1815 to 1865, were glorious in Concord and Boston, where plain living and high thinking flourished. But they wore a different aspect throughout most of the six Yankee states.
BONN, Germany, June 5 (AP)-- The Western High Commissioners turned control of the West German chemical industry back to the Germans today except for products that could be used only for war purposes.

MONEY may not be everything in life. Having lots of it, though, certainly helps. A potential millionaire, the first of his kind in history, ran up his earnings over the weekend to $924,630 and the million is well within his reach. This newest cash collector is Citation, a horse.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, told three committees of Congress today that the United States, in its efforts to arm nations resisting Communist aggression, was "well started" on "the only remaining road to peace and security." He added, however, that this road was a long one and might require three or four more years to traverse.

WASHINGTON,June 5--Vice President Alben W. Barkley east the vote today that broke a 30-30 tie and gave Senate approval to an Administration-supported bill expanding operations permitted in Foreign Trade Zones in this country.
WASHINGTON, June 5--President Truman today appointed a special committee of three members to review certain veterans' problems, "especially those of the paraplegics and amputees."

ARDMORE, Pa., June 5 (AP)-- The wails were loud and long on Merion's historic East Course today as a number of the nation's leading golfers, including Defending Champion Dr. Cary Middlecoff, got in a few practice licks for the fiftieth United States Open Golf championship.

HONG KONG, June 5--As one British ship completed today its first scheduled round-trip voyage to Shanghai since the disintegration of the blockade of that port another British coastal steamer was shelled in Formosa Strait and six passengers were killed.

The Public Education Association urged school authorities yesterday to expand the program of experimental classes in the city's high schools as one method of curbing the large number of student "drop-outs," which now average 40 per cent of the high school enrollment.

The taxpayer building at 11941198 Morris Park Avenue, the Bronx, completed in 1948, has been sold by the Arlington Construction Company to the Charet Realty Corporation. The building contains a super market and several other stores. Halford Realty Company was the broker.

The proposed extension of subsidies to tramp operations would be "a wise investment" for the United States and preserve an essential segment of the merchant marine, according to a statement issued yesterday by F. Riker Clark, chairman of the Committee for Promotion of Tramp Shipping Under the American Flag in Foreign Commerce.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 6--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, reported to the fifty-nine members today that the question of which government should represent China at ... Lake Success was blocking any "significant progress" on his "twenty-year program for achieving peace through the United Nations."

The New York Chiefs eliminated the Chicago Westerners, 19 to 15, and the Jersey Jolters upset the Brooklyn Red Devils, 31 to 28, as the round-robin phase of the roller derby world series came to a close before 14,852 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, June 6--Ralph Straus, well known literary critic, novelist and authority on Charles Dickens, died here yesterday at the age of 67. He also published articles and privately printed books from his own press.

Tooth pastes and powders containing ammonia have been sold to the public with extravagant claims, Dr. Robert G. Kesel, originator of ammoniated dentifrices, told the eighty-second annual meeting of the Dental Society of the State of New York at the Statler Hotel yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6-- James Roosevelt, in his first bid for public office, gave evidence tonight on the basis of incomplete returns of having survived the California primary election by winning the Democratic nomination for Governor.
A million-dollar facial improvement of Central Park is in the mud pack stage right now.
At its recent conference in Montevideo, the United Nations Subcommittee on Freedom of Information and the Press adopted a code of ethics whose first article begins with these two statements:

WASHINGTON, June 6--President Truman tonight struck out at critics of his economic planning. In an address at a dinner of the Better Business Bureaus, the President charged that "enormous amounts of money" were being spent to create the idea that his ...

WASHINGTON, June 6--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, declared today that the State Department was still employing in "high positions" at least three individuals listed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation three years ago as Communist agents.

No matter what their politics, their religion or their opinion about "Finnegans Wake," most poets and novelists share a common concern with the transience of life and the cruelty of time. Since Horace lamented the fleeting years, writers have continued to yearn for the dewy radiance of childhood and the confident enthusiasm of youth.

To meet the needs of the city's rapidly growing school population, the Board of Education's building committee offered yesterday plans for a record six-year construction program. It calls for 298 new buildings and additions to schools, estimated to cost $550,000,000.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP)--Curt Simmons walked Johnny Lindell in the eighth to force in the winning run as the Cardinals defeated Philadelphia, 5 to 4, tonight. Howard Pollet struck out all three Phillies to face him in the ninth to gain his fifth triumph.

Dr. Donald E. McKenna, 56 year-old chief orthopedic surgeon of Brooklyn Hospital, was found dead at 9 A.M. yesterday in the kitchen of his home, at 590 Third Street, Brooklyn, of illuminating gas poisoning.

The advantages of common stock investments for pension funds are featured in the tenth annual edition of "Investment Companies," issued for publication today by Arthur Weisenberger Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Summer T. Pike, acting chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, urged last night that scientists in all categories pool their efforts toward development of atomic energy for both wartime and peacetime uses.

ST. LOUIS, June 6--Bernard M. Baruch, noted statesman and adviser to Presidents, today called for continuance of the search for Communists in the Government and schools. He delivered the commencement address at Washington University and received a Doctorate of Laws.
