WASHINGTON, June 7 (Wednesday) (AP)--The Senate voted early today to authorize an additional $2,000,00,000 for Government support of farm prices after beating down a Republican attempt to cut back immediately the level of price props.
Fares for a daily average of 1,500,000 riders on city-operated bus and trolley car lines will go up from 7 cents to 10 cents on July 1, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP)-- Sammy Snead slowly changed into his playing clothes at the Merion Golf Club today, fingered a new putter he had just shucked from its wrapping, and said reflectively: "So here I am in Philadelphia again."

Acting at the direction of General MacArthur, the Japanese Government has moved swiftly to eliminate from public life the twenty-four members of the Communist party's Central Committee, or "Politbureau," including seven members of Parliament.

Mrs. Martha Sharp left New York last night by plane to visit her 20,000 children. In the next month she will help some of them move into the only real homes they have ever known and watch others learn to play children's games for the first time.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The Civil Aeronautics Board, in a decision long awaited in the aviation industry, today ordered out of business one large nonscheduled airline operating extensively over domestic routes and called on two others operating to overseas points to end some types of service.

It wasn't till the sixth race at Belmont Park yesterday that the backers of favorites had a chance to whoop it up. Then, in a mileand-a-sixteenth contest for 3-yearolds, the Sanford Stud Farms' Schroon made the grade at even money, with credit for the assist going to Jockey Ovie Scurlock.

DELHI, N.Y., June 6 (AP)--A New York Central Railroad engineer said today that the railroad would have to spend at least $200,000,000 to make track changes if a proposed dam-highway were built across the Hudson River at Chelsea.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 7-- The Japanese Communists today denounced Gen. Douglas MacArthur's order banning all members of their Central Committee from public life and called on all workers to support them by striking.

Maintenance of a close liaison between American and Japanese textile producers is the only hope for keeping Japanese competition in line, according to Robert C. Jackson, executive vice president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute.

In two important decisions the Supreme Court has declared that the Federal Government has "paramount rights" to the rich oil-bearing lands off the coasts of Louisiana and Texas. These decisions are in accord with the Court's ruling three years ago in the California marginal sea-lands case.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6 --Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks won low gross honors in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Class A one-day tournament, with a 38, 43--81 over the Fenway Golf Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 6--A resolution was introduced in Congress today calling for a five-year disarmament program that would turn funds destined for weapons to a world program of scientific advance and reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture said today that wholesale marketing facilities in most major cities are inadequate properly to handle fruits, vegetables and other perishable commodities.
Deputy Mayor William Reid signed a five-year, $40,000-a-year contract yesterday effective Oct. 1 to "rehabilitate" the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company.

The Rev. John W. Dunn, C.M., former director of libraries of St. John's University, Brooklyn, an authority on Catholic school and college libraries, died on Monday at Brooklyn Hospital. His age was 54.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 6-- A signal for an all-out assault on the Roman Catholic Church in Hungary was sounded in a report of the Workers (Communist) party published today in the newspaper Szabad Nep. The report was presented to last week's meeting of the party's Central committee by Josef Revai, Education Minister and editor of Szabad Nep.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6 --Four hundred members of the Westchester County Republican Committee, meeting this afternoon at the County Center, endorsed the achievements of Governor Dewey and called for the election in November of a Governor who possesses his abilities to give "efficient and economical" administration.

Advertising in the seven major New York City daily newspapers for the first five months of 1950 totaled 65,045,532 lines, a gain of 7.58 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 6 --Two student petitions protesting the dismissal of Assistant Prof. Lee Lorch from the faculty of Pennsylvania State College were received today by the president's office at the institution.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP)-- President Truman displayed considerable irritation today over a protest about the affiliations of his appointees.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, was labeled "City Construction Obstructor" last night by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, in a controversy over rebuilding Chinatown.
MIAMI, Fla., June 6--Thirtyseven survivors of a twin-engine C-46 plane that plunged into the Atlantic were safe aboard a Navy destroyer today.

Secretary of the Treasury Snyder, commenting on the current business scene, finds evidence on every hand, he says, that "an era of dynamic progress is under way." The present advance, he observes, "is a soundly financed movement, deriving its basic strength from a broad and expanding consumer demand."

Although various diversions have reduced the American per capita purchase of books in the last year, "they are not going to put the book out of business," Robert B. Campbell, outgoing president of the American Booksellers Association, yesterday told representatives ...

WASHINGTON, June 6--A highly organized combine that is directing a nation-wide narcotics ring with inter-related interests in gambling, counterfeiting, white slavery and extortion, was described today to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report held today that only two of President Truman's reorganization plans now pending in Congress carry out specific recommendations of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Congress today that within the last year chances for the free nations to defend and hold Western Europe against aggressive attack had been improved.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 6-- Following the resignation of Premier Gaston Eysken's caretaker cabinet today, leaders of the Social Christian (Catholic) party immediately went into a huddle to map strategy for restoring King Leopold III to the Belgian throne ...

A proposed local law imposing a city sewer rental charge that for the average homeowner would amount to about a third of what he pays annually for water was introduced in the City Council yesterday at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer. The measure was referred to the Finance Committee, which will hold a public hearing on it Monday morning.
Dr. Joseph Weinberg, 71-yearold chief medical examiner of the Department of Sanitation, celebrated yesterday his fiftieth anniversary as a physician.

New term and serial obligations of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company and the Pennsylvania Company totaling $120,000,000 were marketed with success by investment banking syndicates here yesterday following a morning of competitive bidding tension without precedent in the financial district.

CHICAGO, June 6--Our youthful Dodgers strove desperately today to get Frankie Frisch's rambunctious Cubs out of their hair, but it was no go and by the time it ended elderly Burt Shotton's locks had turned snowy white.

CHICAGO, June 6--The National Association of Retail Grocers next year will bring to Chicago the world's first international food show, Mrs. R.M. Kiefer, secretarymanager, announced today at the fifty-first annual convention at Navy Pier.

The State of New York borrowed yesterday $70,310,000 at interest costs ranging from 1.843 per cent for $58,310,000 of housing bonds maturing from 1961 to 2000, to a cost of 1.4214 per cent for $12,000,000 of grade crossing obligations due from 1951 to 1970.

ROME, June 6--The Chamber of Deputies decided late tonight after seven hours of heated and sometimes dramatic discussion to appoint a committee to inquire into accusations of corruption leveled at Giuseppe Spataro, Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, and at Christian Democratic Deputy Paolo Bonomi.

Among the most popular dishes at Da Cinta, 313 West Forty-sixth Street, is shrimp Fredericka, for which the shellfish are marinated overnight in a pungent garlic sauce, then quickly broiled to a golden brown and brought to the table-- still in their papery shells--piping hot.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6-- One hundred and nineteen degrees were awarded here today at the 138th annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary, Dr. John A. Mackay, president, presented the degrees, the largest number in the seminary's history.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 6-- Our Army not only is outnumbered by "our most dangerous antagonist," but also is "at a disadvantage qualitatively in certain categories of equipment, most notably in tanks," Frank C. Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, said today in an address at the 148th commencement exercises of the United States Military Academy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 6 --Faced with the realization that the East German Communists have formed a well-disciplined youth movement, the West German Government and the Western Allied High Commission are turning their attention to West Germany's young men and women.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 6--A three-man court today sentenced two confessed traitors, a former major general and a colonel, to twenty years hard labor on the charge of having plotted with the Russians to overthrow Marshal Tito.
HONG KONG, June 6--The British steamer Cheung Hing arrived here today with her decks a shambles and was greeted by a squadron of ambulances waiting on the dock to remove her ten wounded.

LONDON, June 6--Prime Minister Attlee presided today at the first Cabinet meeting since his return from a ten-day holiday in France. The French plan for the integration of European coal and steel was not discussed at the brief session partly because of the absence ...

Studio 7, the off-Broadway group whose recent presentation of "The Father" caught the fancy of some of the professional appraisers, has come up with a second noteworthy offering. The latest product is "Earth Spirit," an adaptation of Frank Wedekind's controversial ...

Sharp criticism of encouraging imports at the expense of home industries was made yesterday by Harry R. Chapman, chairman of the Washington committee of the National Confectioners Association, at the association's annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 6 --An attempt by the Socialist opposition to weaken and possibly thwart entirely the Western Germany Cabinet's decision to join the Council of Europe was blocked in Bonn today although the issue was not settled finally.

CLEVELAND, June 6--Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., one of the most striking shot-makers in tennis, was put to a stiff test today in his opening match in the national professional championship at the Skating Club.

Earnings of the Paramount Pictures Corporation for April and May were maintained close to the average for the first quarter, although it was expected that the normal pre-summer decline would affect earnings in the second quarter, Barney Balaban, president, informed stockholders yesterday.

The Mayor's Joint Committee one Port Industry agreed unanimously yesterday to devote special attention to the problems of pier traffic, with emphasis on both cargo and passenger movements; also to rail rate differentials and the question of adequate dredging of harbor waters.
Mortimer Murrey felt so desperate Monday night that he just had to take a bus ride.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 6 (AP) --The attempted assassination of a Cabinet member yesterday moved ex-Emperor Bao Dai's Vietnam state today to embark on total war against Ho Chi Minh's Moscow-backed guerrillas.

Dr. Luis Esteves Fernandes, a career diplomat who was recently appointed Portuguese Ambassador to the United States, arrived here yesterday aboard the Portuguese motor vessel Vila do Porto. The ship docked at Pier 38, East River and Clinton Street, at 12:30 P.M.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 6-- The work of planning adequate health defenses to meet the possibility of atomic and bacteriological warfare has been hampered by toplevel secrecy and the difficulty of obtaining adequate information, Dr. John F. Mahoney, New York City Health Commissioner declared today.

JENKINTOWN, Pa., June 6-- Miss Sally Gimbel, daughter of Col. Richard Gimbel, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Gimbel of this place and Miami Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Ralph James Taussig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Taussig of Elkins Park, at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Bertram Korn.
Six hundred and fifty Columbia College seniors and their families will gather in Vam Amringe Quadrangle this morning for Class Day exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The National Labor Relations Board today continued its feud with Robert N. Denham, its general counsel, by opposing his plan to waive union-shop elections in the building and construction industry.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 6--(UP)--A prosecution witness at the treason trial of thirteen Czechs said today that former United States Ambassador Joseph E. Jacobs had carried secret "underground" plans to the London conference of American Eastern European diplomats.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., June 6--Mal Galletta of North Hills, playing in the last foursome to finish, posted the best score in the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Rockville Country Club today. It was 35, 37--72, which exactly equaled par.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday and closed firm, to 28 points net higher than on Monday.

BONN, June 6--This was the day set for the debate in the Bundestag on the adherence of the German Federal Republic to the Council of Europe. But what occurred at this afternoon's session was a debate on whether there should be a debate.

Medals for exemplary behavior could well have been handed out yesterday to a batch of well-mannered dogs as well as prizes to artists who were sketching them in the annual contest sponsored by the Village Dog Owners Association at the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your excellent editorial on "selling" New York City to business, industry and the tourist calls attention to the need of expanding this type of activity, which, as you point out, at present is entrusted to the city's Commerce Department, "a two-by-four operation under an unpaid Commissioner, Joseph V. McKee."

The Daughters of the American Revolution, Mecca Temple and others yesterday sold to Frederick Brown the property at 1241-49 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-fourth Street, consisting of a four-story and a twostory taxpayer on plot 102 by 36 feet.

Irmgarde Remme, a flaxen-haired German lass, saw yesterday that what newspapers in the British zone of Berlin said about America was true. Since her arrival in New York on Sunday, she has heard everyone speak without fear. Irmgarde, 18 years old, also saw Negro and white men on the same team at a baseball game at the Yankee Stadium.
The following figures, as of 8 A.M. yesterday, give the number of gallons of water in the city's reservoirs. The difference in the two days is the net after intake and the day's consumption:
A raid on a sequestered bookmaking establishment in a suburb of St. Louis has uncovered visual evidence of the operations of a national telegraphic betting syndicate, it was made known yesterday.

The medical and dental care provided to persons of limited means through proceeds from the Opportunity Shop of the Community Service Society were commended yesterday by Bailey B. Burritt, former administrative head of this welfare organization.

GENEVA, June 6--The problems of unemployment can be solved without sacrifice of freedom, Paul R. Porter, chief of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Greece, told members of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe here today.

Several style notes were stressed when winter furs by Russeks Design Studio were presented in the Fifth Avenue specialty store yesterday afternoon. Most important was the fact that Ralph Marano, designer of the collection, seemed convinced that women are going to want luxurious furs.
It looks as though the city will have a prosperous tourist trade this summer.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6-- Charles S. Howard Sr., a pioneer automobile dealer, who turned to horse racing and became internationally known as the owner of Seabiscuit, Kayak II and Noor, died of a heart attack today at his home at Hillsborough, near here. His age was 70.
Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury is expected to get a first-hand account this morning of bookmaking operations in the metropolitan area, it was indicated yesterday.

A young American musician will receive on-the-spot training as an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera next season, it was announced yesterday. It will be in the form of a scholarship from the Anna E. Schoen-Rene Fund, made available to the Metropolitan by the New York Community Chest.

PARIS, June 6--Negotiations on the application of the Schuman plan for merging the coal and steel resources of Western Europe under an international authority are expected to begin between June 20 and 25. France, Western Germany, Italy, Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg will take part.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6-- Acquisition of screen rights to two properties, Fay Kanin's Broadway play, "Goodbye, My Fancy," and "Come Fill the Cup," an unpublished novel by Harlan Ware, was announced today by Warner Brothers. Both projects were assigned to Henry Blanke for production.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Reactions here today ranged from gratification to anger and curiosity over what will happen following the three Supreme Court opinions yesterday outlawing racial segregation for Negroes in railroad dining cars and at two state universities.
Active demand by commission houses and the trade for the July, September and December deliveries pushed prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange sharply higher yesterday.

Leon's 44th Street Corporation has leased space for a cafeteria in the Fawcett Building, 67 West Forty-fourth Street, which is being enlarged and modernized by its owner, the Tishman Realty Construction Company. The Esso Realty Company negotiated the lease.

LONDON, June 6--Minister of Defense Emanuel Shinwell warned today that Britain's national economy might have to be "impaired" to provide an adequate defense for the country. He said he hoped this would not occur for it would be "playing into the hands of a potential enemy."

PARIS, June 6--The bill directed against Coca-Cola, which passed the French National Assembly in February and provoked lively comments on both sides of the Atlantic, was rejected unanimously today by the Council of the Republic, the advisory second house of the French Parliament.

On the site formerly occupied by the Wavecrest Convalescent Home of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, ground-breaking ceremonies were held shortly before noon yesterday for one of the largest apartment centers ever planned in the Rockaway section of Queens.

Merchandise valued at $1,000,000 will be offered for sale by 220 West German concerns at the first International Trade Fair in Chicago from Aug. 7 to 19. This was reported yesterday by Rheinhold Krause, chairman of the German Committee for the International Trade Fair, which comprises 100 German business men.
WARSAW, June 6--The port of Szczecin (Stettin) may again become Germany's most important outlet on the Baltic Sea.

Robert Whyte, custom bootmaker to hundreds of prominent Americans for several decades, died yesterday at his home, 68-60 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens. Poor health had kept him inactive in the last few months, but until recently he had operated his shop at 38 West Forty-eighth Street. His age was 79.

A thorough study by the City Planning Commission of the merits of a midtown cross-Manhattan underpass as compared with the proposed overpass was urged on Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by a committee representing twenty civic and trade associations.
Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., announced yesterday a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1. The company previously paid 25 cents on March 1 and June 1.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 6-- The Truman Administration accomplished its chief purpose in the Midwest farm belt today. It set up the Brannan farm plan as the top issue in Iowa's November general election to provide a national test in the continuing effort to hold the farm vote.

Mrs. Mary Stillman Harkness, who shared the interest of her late husband, Edward S. Harkness, in philanthropy and gave generously on behalf of health and education, died yesterday at her home, 1 East Seventy-fifth Street, after a brief illness. She would have reached her seventy-sixth birthday on July 4.

RACINE, Wis., June 6--Alexander J. Horlick, last of the immediate family of William Horlick Sr., founder of the Horlick Malted Milk Corporation, died today at his home. He was 76 years old. He had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on May 14.

WARSAW, June 6--The Department of State has ordered a 50 per cent cut in the number of Americans attached to the Warsaw Embassy. The orders from Washington, which were issued without any Polish request for such action, call for the exodus to be completed by the end of the month.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6 --The Washington Administration's foreign as well as its domestic policies were assailed today by two speakers at the Edison Electric Institute's convention here.

CHICAGO, June 6--Grain futures led by July oats registered an impressive recovery in the late trade, after free early selling had caused much weakness. Soybeans, as usual, had wide swings, but closed strong on reported sales of 120,000 bushels for export from here, probably to Canada.
William Wadsworth, veteran actor, died yesterday in Queens General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 77.
WASHINGTON, June 6--New doubts over the prospect of excise tax reductions arose today as the House Ways and Means Committee lost more ground in its efforts to provide revenue to compensate for cuts.
WEST POINT, June 6--With a warm sun beaming overhead, thirty members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy took wives today in the annual post-commencement marital rush.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The special House committee that is conductig an investigation of lobbying today told the officers of three national organizations to identify their financial backers or risk prosecution for contempt of Congress.
RYE, N.Y., June 6--William H. Hotchkiss of 60 Lake Road, Greenhaven, a pioneer automobile traffic expert, died here today at the age of 85.

Miss Caroline Converse Linherr of 157 West Twelfth Street, former president of the Catholic Big Sisters of the Archdiocese of New York and long prominent here in child welfare work, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness. Her age was 80.

Earnings of Continental Motors Corporation for the quarter ended with last April were the best since the 1948 period and almost double those of the previous quarter of this fiscal year, C.J. Reese, president, reported yesterday. The gain in the latest quarter over the preceding three months almost paralleled a 100 per cent increase in engine shipments, according to Mr. Reese.

Lever Brothers Company, manufacturer of soaps and detergents, which always has been one of the most active sponsors in broadcasting, announced yesterday major changes in its radio and television plans for next fall. These were the highlights:
WASHINGTON, June 6--A Federal deficit below $5,000,000,000 was forecast today by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6-- Howard Kennedy, director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees who returned from Israel today, has warned the Syrian Government that if Syria continues to interfere with the transport of relief ...

New administrative programs of the Federal Trade Commission will expand cooperation of this agency with business, according to Lowell B. Mason, member of the F.T.C. Mr. Mason spoke before more than 300 members at the seventy-second annual meeting of the United States Trade Mark Association yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, June 6--The arrest of Msgr. Luigi Boga, Vicar General of the diocese of Alba Julia and the recent death of Msgr. Mark Glaser, titular Bishop of Cesaropolis and Vicar General of Jassy in Rumania have left 3,000,800 Rumanian Roman Catholics without ...

PITTSBURGH, June 6--The Giants did it the easy way today for a change. They plastered Pirate pitching, or what passed therefor, with a 14-hit fire that held three gaudy home runs, and soared to their fourth straight victory, touching the season's high, with a sweep of the three-game series on Forbes Field.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is embarking on a $32,000,000 expansion and modernization program at its plant in Johnstown, Pa., Arthur B. Homer, president, disclosed last night.

Andrew G. McLaughlin, who as a vice squad patrolman figured prominently in the Vivian Gordon murder case almost twenty years ago, was found at 3:45 P.M. yesterday shot to death in the basement of his home, 68-39 Selfridge Street, Forest Hills, Queens.
The way was cleared yesterday for peace talks between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 6--Mrs. Hattie M. Strong, philanthropist and friend of education, died early today in Baptist Hospital after an illness of three months. She was the widow of Henry Alvah Strong, for many years president of the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, N.Y. Her age was 85.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)-- Assistant Secretary of State Willard L. Thorp said today proposed curbs on imports of foreign oil would "seriously affect" this country's trade program and might endanger national security.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 6--Despite the importance of expanded trade among the nations of Latin America as a means of lessening restrictions and controls on imports from other areas, such intra-regional trade has "deteriorated" during the past four years.

LONDON, June 6--The Transport and General Workers Union, biggest labor union in Britain and which Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin built up and headed for nineteen years, announced today a modification of its hith-erto wholehearted support for ...

The chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Cynthia Whitehead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman T. Whitehead Jr. of Syosset, L.I., to Charles Dodd Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nelson Cole of this city and East Hampton, L.I.

In the seventh inning at the Stadium yesterday Don Johnson fanned Mike Garcia, after which both Dale Mitchell and Bob Kennedy grounded to Phil Rizzuto. These were the only peaceful five minutes the Yankees had all day. At nearly every other turn, the home side was buffeted all over the Bronx by the Indians, who slashed their way to a twenty-two-hit, 16-2 victory over the world champions.

In a two-and-a-half-hour blimp trip over the city and Long Island, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator and chairman of the Long Island State Park Commission, gave a group of editors yesterday a birdseye view of existing and contemplated housing and traffic relief projects in the area.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)-- The Tigers beat the Senators, 11 to 8, today, ringing up their seventh straight victory and taking first place in the American League. Detroit now has won twenty of twenty-three games on the road this season and eleven of its last twelve contests.

FLORENCE, June 6--United States Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today called upon the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to equip itself to counteract Soviet efforts to destroy freedom of thought, science and education.

Russia is spending $45,000,000,000 a year for military purposes, according to an analysis of the Soviet budget presented yesterday by Comdr. William T. Greenhalgh, U.S.N., of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 6 (UP)--Willy Klapproth, chairman of the United States zone German Police Chiefs Association, warned today that a reported Western Big Three proposal to set up a West German federal police force might "pave the way for another Hitler."

What may create a precedent-- and at the same time introduce a new chapter in the theatrical investment field--is the proposed backing by the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiary, the National Broadcasting Company, of the entire capitalization of "Call Me Madam," which is looked upon as one of the new season's major song and dance contributions.

LONDON, June 6--Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., won the British version of the world heavyweight boxing championship tonight when Britain's Bruce Woodcock retired after the fourth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout with a bad cut over his left eye.
WASHINGTON, June 6--A soldier, like a bullet, is supposed to go farther in Washington if he's smooth, but Gen. Omar Bradley demonstrated again today that this could be a fallacious doctrine.

SANTOS, Brazil, May 28--Shipping has always been the greatest revenue producer for Norway, and in these days of strenuous struggle for the dollar the descendants of the Vikings are sailing every sea and carrying everything the world's commerce offers to produce the dollars their country needs.

THE newspaper stories decorously related yesterday that Jim Russell of the Dodgers accused Paul Minner of the Cubs of throw ing a beanball at him. Firmly taking justice into his own hands, Russell rushed out to the mound with the obvious intention of knocking Minner's ears off. The Dodger outfielder is a switch hitter and could have been expected to swing with either fist.
MEXICO CITY, June 6--All public offices and the majority of private business remained closed today as Mexico started its seventh general census.

Two extremes were touched yesterday by the stock market. First it underwent such a heavy assault as to reduce prices to the worst levels since mid-May. Then in a quick reversal in the afternoon it rebounded sharply, wiped out most of the morning's losses and closed with a average increase of 1.49 points.

The International Boxing Club made no new offer to the Boxing Managers Guild of New York regarding a radio-television contract at a meeting held yesterday between the guild's negotiating committee and I.B.C. officials at Madison Square Garden.

SOMERS, N.Y., June 6--Despite the objections of a Roman Catholic clergyman and an adverse ruling from a counsel of the New York State Department of Education, the Board of Education of the Somers Central School District 1 voted tonight to hold a ...

The striped bass fishing in the Cape Cod area should be the major salt water lure for the coming week-end, for during the past two days the bass moved in toward the beach in good numbers, with fish ranging from eighteen to thirty pounds taken by surfcasters.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., June 6 (AP) --Representative Francis Case, a veteran of fourteen years in Congress defeated Senator Chan Gurney today in the South Dakota Republican primary.

Brooklyn's Central Courts Building, 120 Schermerhorn Street, had a bomb scare yesterday morning when a small carton, with electric wire protruding from one side, was found in the corridor on the fifth floor of the building.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6--After two postponements, Michael Todd's "Peep Show" had its world premiere here last night at the Forrest Theatre before a packed house, including many Broadway celebrities.
CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP)-- Ninth-inning disaster overtook the Reds once again today with the Braves scoring five times in the final frame for an 8-to-3 victory.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 6--Mr. and Mrs. W. Murray Wilshire have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Perkins, to Leslie Combs Bruce 3d, son of Mrs. Curtis Shears of Washington, D.C., and Leslie C. Bruce Jr. of Greenwich. The wedding will take place in the autumn.
The City College Midtown Business Center graduated last evening 1,408 men and women, the largest total in its history.

The girl with the junior-size figure has a wealth of smart, wearable cottons from which to pick for summer. Designers of clothes for small figures chose their fabrics with an eye to hot weather and styled them for the girl who appreciates smart fashion.
The manager of a restaurant and bar was killed, and his son-in-law, who owned the establishment, was wounded at 4:09 P.M. yesterday in a shooting in the Ocean Hill section of Brooklyn.
PARIS, June 6--Roger Peyre, central figure in the French scandal over the loss of secret documents concerning Indo-China, has been seen in Brussels, according to a report to the newspaper Figaro.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the issuance on June 5 of a supplementary opinion in the reorganization proceedings involving the consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company and its subsidiaries.

Ernest Bevin is one of those Englishmen who can qualify as an example of John Bull. He looks the part and has what it takes. The news that he is not going to retire because of health from his position as Foreign Secretary is gratifying. If Britain has a better candidate he has not yet come up.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had issued an order approving the amended plan of the Middle West Corporation for the corporation's liquidation and dissolution under the Holding Company Act.

Masks, paintings, kites and constructions of shells and driftwood are among the art works placed on exhibit yesterday in the Young People's Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, all projects of the new experimental parent and young child class at the People's Art Center. Doors open at noon on weekdays; 1 P.M. on Sunday. Admission for children 14 cents, adults 44 cents.

Additional plans for the burgeoning summer theatre, outposts of which will dot the countryside, were announced yesterday. The well-known Barter Theatre, Abingdon, Va., operated by Robert Porterfield, will open its eighteenth season next Monday night with "The Heiress," which is being staged by Margaret Perry. The succeeding bill on June 19 will be "Life With Father."

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 7--Western German steel magnates are turning a wary eye on the French plan for pooling the French and Western German heavy industrial resources. The bright enthusiasm and optimism over the plan's economic and political results evident in Bonn are not shared by the men who slowly are regaining control of the Ruhr.
JERUSALEM, June 7--United Nations officials are becoming gravely concerned over what they described as "serious deterioration" of conditions on the Southwest Jordan-Israel borders.
FAIRFIELD, Ill., June 7 (AP)-- An assassin hiding in bushes cut the fast-shrinking Shelton brothers clan down to two members today.

WARSAW, June 7--Eastern Germany has recognized the Oder-Neisse frontier with Poland, embracing former German territory, in an agreement announced here today by the Polish Government. The agreement was reached with an Eastern German delegation headed by Vice Premier Walter Ulbricht.

Erling B. Stockmann has been named president of the Arnessen Electric Co., Inc., maritime electric supplies and equipment. He formerly was purchasing agent and later executive assistant to the vice chairman of the board of Consolidated Edison Company.

May dollar volume of metropolitan area home furnishings stores increased 1.5 per cent compared with the corresponding month last year, James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New York, reported yesterday. As against the like month in 1948, a banner year, volume dropped 0.3 per cent. The report represents a weighted average of volume done by thirty local outlets with due weight given to larger operations.

GENEVA, June 7--Yugoslavia blasted a big hole today in propaganda with which the Russians have been trying to blanket Europe to the effect that the United States is ruining intra-European trade by its "discriminatory" trade policy.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Dr. Edward K. Barsky and ten other persons, including Howard Fast, the novelist, all members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, began serving sentences today for contempt of Congress.
ARDMORE, Pa., June 7--Over the sun-drenched East course of the Merion Golf Club 165 golfers today ended their final preparations for the United States open championship.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 7-- The "hysterical" approach to atomic warfare, with "fanciful tales of total destruction" and creation of "a race of monsters and misfits" was attacked today by experts in the atomic energy field as instilling fears in the public that would vastly increase our problems in the event of atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The House Ways and Means Committee, dismissing complaints that the dumping of foreign oil in this country was injuring domestic producers, today rejected a proposal to increase taxes on petroleum imports.

WASHINGTON, June 7--If the United States should back away from military aid to free nations and, instead, "arm to the teeth" at home, it would invite disaster here and abroad, Gen. George C. Marshall testified today. The cost of maintaining the country as an armed camp would be more than $30,000,000,000 a year, he estimated.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Vice Admiral Harley H. Christy, retired naval officer who simultaneously headed the Naval Examining Board and the Naval Retiring Board, died Sunday of a heart ailment at Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. His age was 79.

The influence of Greece and Spain made itself felt in a pleasing manner yesterday in a sizable group of hats created by members of the Millinery Designers League. The hats were presented at noon in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

"We are living in the most energetic period in home design since the golden era of the eighteenth century," Lazette Van Houten, fashion editor of the trade paper Retailing Daily, said yesterday at the June luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League at the Roosevelt Hotel.

ROME, June 7--European business leaders are sabotaging the Economic Cooperation Administration's effort to bring about recovery of this continent and at the same time are unwittingly furthering the advance of communism through their own selfishness and narrow-mindedness, Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, said today in a speech before the American Chamber of Commerce for Italy.

Long Island Rail Road commuters, who face the line's recent demand for a 32.5 per cent rise in rates, found some comfort yesterday in a ruling of the Public Service Commission. The commission ordered the Long Island to honor restricted monthly tickets for the first two hours of a day on which they are not otherwise valid. This must be done not later than June 20.

THEY are generally called "The Four Marx Brothers" because there are really five of them and nowadays you usually see only three. In any prudently civilized country any two of them publicly gathered together would constitute unlawful assembly. Yet they represent America's outstanding human triumph in rugged individualism, for they have long since proved ...
HONG KONG June 7--Spectacular production goals in heavy industry to make Manchuria "the Ruhr of Asia" were revealed today in several official Communist reports received from China.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7-- Randolph Sevier, executive vice president of Matson Navigation Company since September, 1948, was named to the presidency today by the board of directors.

Industrial users of electrical motor starters have been notified by two suppliers that price increases of about 5 per cent now loom in the near future. Prices of copper electric wire lines were raised yesterday.

After only thirty-six hours of "negotiations," the Communist puppet regimes of Eastern Germany and Poland announce a broad politico-economic agreement which, in addition to various other provisions, proclaims the OderNeisse demarcation line as the permanent frontier between Germany and Poland.

CLEVELAND, June 7--Frank Parker of Milwaukee, amateur titleholder in 1944 and 1945, made his first appearance in a national professional tennis championship today and defeated John Faunce of Burbank, Calif., 6--2, 6--3, on the clay courts of the Skating Club.

The city's upper Manhattan area, embracing the congested tenements of Harlem as well as the intellectual sector of Morningside Heights, is the scene of an intensive "grass roots" project aimed at promoting closer ties between the schools and the community and also at developing civic pride.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)-- The Senate today took up a bill to continue Federal rent controls, and Senator Henry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, immediately started a filibuster, trying to talk it to death.

Expectations that a new tax bill will be enacted before adjournment of the present Congress, while not abandoned, are definitely waning, according to the latest reports from Capitol Hill. The Ways and Means Committee hasn't yet completed the task of writing a bill, and there is no definite indication of how much longer that will take. Meanwhile, Senate leaders agree that unless ...

WASHINGTON, June 7--President Truman declared today that the United States, in the cause of permanent peace, was at once the moral leader and the servant of all the peoples in a world that had room and abundance for all of them.

The first financing of a public housing project in the State of New York under the new United States Housing Act of 1949 will consist of a borrowing of $2,500,000 by the New York City Housing Authority on June 15, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the Authority, announced yesterday.

The scope of "horse play" in the hands of bookmakers operating on an interstate basis continued to be divulged yesterday in a series of investigations that ranged from Brooklyn to St. Louis, with Washington and New Jersey ramifications.

Having completed 30,000 miles of travel through the missionary centers of nine countries in Africa in the last six months, Dr. Frank C. Laubach, foreign missionary and literacy expert, declared yesterday that a blending of the Christian religion with language teaching was a most important factor in this pioneering field.

Milk made the front page last week with the news that "more cows are giving more milk than ever before in the six-state milkshed serving the metropolitan New York area." A quart bottle purchased at the store costs 16 cents, as compared with 19 cents a year ago.

A new high production record, advancing an unprecedented number of public improvements, was set in 1949 by the Department of Public Works, Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen told Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday in an annual report.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7-- President Truman was cast today by Democratic strategists for a major campaign role in California next fall.

LINDEN, N.J., June 7--Addressing 1,600 stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) at their annual meeting here today, Eugene Holman, president, disclosed that net income of the company was about $145,000,000 in the first six months of this year, compared with $137,000,000 in the same period a year ago. The attendance set a record for such gatherings in the annals of American corporate history.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Secretary of State Dean Acheson, in a cool reaction to the recent Moscow mission by United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie, asserted today that the current world tensions were the result of Soviet policies that must be continually resisted by the free world.

LONDON, June 7--The growing importance of Australia in the defense of British Commonwealth interests in the Far East was reflected in the King's birthday honors list, published today, in which Gen. Sir Thomas Blamey, wartime Commander in Chief of the Australian military forces, was made a field marshal. This honor, conferred in the King's name with the ...

With sterling now more plentiful in South Africa, the Union may ease its import controls on goods from the sterling areas before the end of the year, it was reported yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7-- Susan Hayward will play Bathsheba to Gregory Peck's David in the projected Twentieth CenturyFox film, "David and Bathsheba," the studio announced today. Philip Dunne is writing the photoplay, which will be filmed in Israel with frozen funds, according to the studio's present plans.

OLSO, Norway, June 7--In a simple impressive ceremony Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt unveiled here today a granite statue of her late husband on a site overlooking Oslo Harbor before the walls of Akershus fortress.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 7-- Jean Duvieusart, 50-year-old member of the Social Christian (Catholic) party, accepted today a mission from Prince Regent Charles to form a government.
A revised version of Sammy Kaye's "So You Want to Lead a Band" program will make its television debut Sunday evening from 8 to 8:30 over the National Broadcasting Company.

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L., which for three years has been providing free concerts in hospitals, public halls and institutions, has asked the city to finance this program.
The man from East Pinetree was in the mood for adventure in big, anonymous New York. The woman in the hotel lobby was pretty, so he worked up a conversation and suggested a drink.
PITTSBURGH, June 7--The Dodgers, threading a perilous course through the West, moved into the lair of the Pirates tonight and found it at once a cure for all their ills.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 7--Mrs. Anna Kaufman Openshaw, 44 years old, admitted to Bronx detectives tonight that she had been near the scene of the fatal shooting of her estranged husband, Martin, 70, in a Bronx park early Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A consent order through which the Corn Products Refining Company of New York and fifteen other leading manufacturers and sellers of corn derivatives agree to abandon allegedly discriminatory pricing practices has been entered with a Federal Trade Commission trial examiner.

The current business boom may last a year longer, Summer H. Slichter, Professor of Economics at Harvard, predicted yesterday at the National Confectioners Association convention in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Columbia University will award 8,108 diplomas this afternoon in graduating a new record class at its 196th commencement.
The Board of Education's twoyear "ban" on the magazine. The Nation from the city's public school libraries probably will be continued during the forthcoming school year, it appeared yesterday.

MANILA, Thursday, June 8-- President Elpidio Quirino vigorously rejects the idea of United States intervention in the Philippines, and he believes the idea does not represent the correct position of the United States either officially or as the opinion of the American people.

PARIS, June 7--The creation of a vast European market in which there would still be competition, with a premium upon efficient management, is the principal aim of the Schuman plan for a merger of the coal and steel production of Western Europe, French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said today.
BERLIN, June 7--The Russians have shifted local control of the City of Berlin and the provincial areas of East Germany from military to civilian leaders.

Pupils in the city's elementary and high schools, whether public or parochial, will continue to ride to and from their classes on the municipal transit lines at reduced fares after July 1, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday. The Mayor announced on Tuesday that regular fares on the rapid transit lines ...

Charitable, educational and social organizations benefit under the will of Maurice Wertheim, financier, philanthropist and sportsman, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Wertheim, who was 64 years old, died May 27 on his estate in Cos Cob, Conn. The value of his estate was not disclosed.

Testimony that the Cities Service Oil Company hired men to go board its tankers and report on the strength and membership of the Seafarers International Union, A.F.L., was introduced yesterday to the National Labor Relations Board began an action alleging unfair labor practices by the company.

Miss Virginia Murphy, a member of the New York public school system for thirty-four years and for the last nine years director of art education for the Board of Education, died on Tuesday in her home at 20 Fifth Avenue after a year's illness.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A twoyear fight for liberalization of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 neared successful conclusion today as the Senate passed and sent to the White House a bill providing haven in this country for 341,000 European refugees.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A former Assistant Secretary of State told Senate investigators today that he seemed to recollect that it was Capt. James K. Vardaman Jr. former naval aide to President Truman, who asked that prosecution in the 1945 Amerasia case be delayed.

The Sharon Steel Corporation of Sharon, Pa., the nation's ninth largest producer of steel, announced yesterday increases of $3 to $7 a ton in the price of sheet and strip steel due to recent rises in the cost of raw materials.

It was medical rounds as usual yesterday for Dr. Arthur S. Abramson, paraplegic veteran who is chief of physical medicine and rehabilitation at Kingsbridge Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx.

The assistance of landlords in furnishing information which may be used in preparing the revised rental control and eviction regulations was asked by Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, at a meeting of the Realty Luncheon Club of New York yesterday in the Brass Rail Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

LONDON, June 7 (U.P.)--The world's largest passenger plane, Britain's eight-engined Brabazon I, will fly from Bristol to London tomorrow to test its performance on standard commercial runways, officials of the Bristol Aeroplane Company announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Concerned by a shortage of specialists in many military fields, the Army soon will announce special enlistment inducements to qualified veterans, it was learned today. The recruiting lure, to go into effect July 1, will be the promise of rapid promotion to corporal and a corresponding rise in base pay from a starting $75 to $117.60 monthly.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June 7-- Kenneth Wolcott of Trenton, the New Jersey senior champion, tied today for low gross honors in the Spring tournament of the New Jersey Senior Golf Association over the Glen Ridge course.
The stock market yesterday finally crossed the barrier of the 1946 highs and went to the best levels since 1931.

The big show will be back as usual next year, it was announced last night, as representatives of Madison Square Garden and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus reached an agreement. This year, for the first time, the circus had closed an engagement before arrangements were made for a return the following season.
Eddie Dowling has acquired the production rights to Alexander Lidor's play, "A Springboard to Nowhere," and plans to put it on the Broadway stage early next fall.

Mayor O'Dwyer approved yesterday the local law creating a Department of Traffic in the city government and swore in Lloyd B. Reid, traffic expert, as Commissioner of Traffic at an annual salary of $20,000.

CHICAGO, June 7--If the Federal Government persists in deficit spending, private banking will be the first element of the economy to fall by the wayside. Joseph Stagg Lawrence, vice president of the Empire Trust Company of New York, said today. He spoke at the closing session of the Illinois Bankers Association's annual convention.
The blow-hot, blow-cold methods of Washington, with the alternations of elation and despair that inevitably result, seemingly produced over the last few days a paper defense of Western Europe.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 7 --Yugoslavia has approached the West German Government with a request for a long-term credit of $80,000,000 to $100,000,000 for the purchase of capital equipment. With Western Allied sanction, the Germans are seriously considering the request.
Sales of private dwellings and small apartment buildings formed the bulk of realty activity on the East Side reported yesterday.

Because economies of American Cable and Radio Corporation have not caught up with the decline in communications volume, the company has been operating at a loss, Admiral Ellery W. Stone, president, declared at yesterday's annual meeting of shareholders. The company's word volume improved in May.
The classes of 1890 and of 1900 held reunions last night in connection with the 196th annual commencement exercises of Columbia University today.
Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York admitted its 999,999th and 1,000,000th patients yesterday afternoon.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 7--The establishment of a nuclear physics laboratory, complete with cyclotron, in Western Europe was proposed today to members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization by Prof. Isidor I. Rabi, United States representative.

Mink, fashioned with a casual air, otter in such attractive new colors as navy and beige suits of broadtail with sable muffs and seal elaborated with Persian lamb in the manner of braid--these and many more were in Maximilian's collection of furs viewed yesterday at the salon at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 7-- A five-day program of alumni and senior class activities will begin Friday at Princeton University and end with the 203d commencement next Tuesday.

Buyers' reaction and orders have placed manufacturers of higher priced dress lines in an optimistic mood, it was learned yesterday. Fall line showings have been unusually well attended, the dress producers said, and initial orders are from 10 to 30 per cent a greater than they were a year ago.

Mayor O'Dwyer's criticism of Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, and his assertion that any coalition candidate for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District must be a Fair Deal Democrat, has not stopped the attempt to get the Democratic, Republican and Liberal parties to agree on a candidate to oppose Representative Vito Marcantonio at the November election.

The resolution introduced by eleven Congressmen on Wednesday calling for a five-year disarmament program seems bound to do more harm than good. It is sad to have to say so, for every well-disposed and well-intentioned person in the world would like nothing better than a workable plan for global disarmament with more money being spent on all the wonderful advances of peace.
The Dewey Almy Chemical Company announced yesterday a 40-cent dividend for payment to common stockholders on June 30. Shareholders had received 25 cents a share in the last three quarters.

Upsets marked the semi-final round of the Roller Derby world series last night at Madison Square Garden as 15,301 spectators saw the New York Chiefs bow to the Jersey Jolters, 23--20, and the twice-defeated Brooklyn Red Devils topple the heavily favored Philadelphia Panthers, 25--21.

The late spring tended to slow up the opening of the bass season in northern Maine, but reports from the Princeton area, where the smallmouth is undisputed king, indicate that these fish are responding in their usual manner.
The owner of an 8-month-old white, gray and yellow cat called to it softly "Missy, Missy." The cat hesitated for a moment, then went straight into its owner's arms.

New Yorkers either basked or broiled yesterday, according to their taste, in the hottest weather so far this year. The mercury soared to a 1950 high of 89.6 degrees at 2:50 P.M., leaving the majority of perspiring city-dwellers thankful only that it stopped short of the 94.3 record for the date, set in 1925.

WASHINGTON, June 7--At the request of President Truman, Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing today called the first nation-wide Conference on Aging, to be held here Aug. 13, 14 and 15. The President in a letter last Friday asked Mr. Ewing to "explore with all appropriate groups, both within and outside the Federal Government, the problems incident to our increasingly older population and to report to me on your findings and recommendations."

The City Planning Commission reserved decision yesterday on a proposed amendment to the zoning resolution that would require parking facilities with virtually all types of dwellings to be built here in the future. But most of the members showed little sympathy with objections raised by a few speakers.

Charles Laughton has received permission from Bernard Shaw to do the first American presentation of the playwright's "Don Juan in Hell" scene from "Man and Superman," with himself and Charles Boyer starred, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 7--The Giants today swamped Frankie Frisch's Cubs, 13 to 4, and charged closer to the first division berth that is their immediate objective.

PARIS, June 7--Rumania's Communist Government is now conducting a brand new and still more violently extensive purge of all national leaders in political, military and economic life who cannot be considered entirely trustworthy according to the standards of the Bucharest Politburo as dictated by the Kremlin.

As the total amount of water lost by overflowing of the Catskill reservoirs rose to 1,090,000,000 gallons as of 8 A.M. yesterday, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said that the current warm yeather spell was continuing to drive water consumption to new highs.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Since the 4 to 3 decision of the Supreme Court in the Texas tidelands case, extending to all states its 1947 ruling that the Federal Government has "paramount" rights over the lands, minerals and other products underlying their marginal seas, an important question has fully materialized.

CHICAGO, June 7--Passage by the Senate of the Commodity Credit Corporation bill expanding funds available for price support by $2,000,000,000 helped grains here today, especially as the measure may finally carry an amendment which would ban imports of grains into this country if domes-- tic prices should be below certain levels.

Credit the After Dinner Opera Company with enterprising spirit and enthusiastic musicianship. The young company, which was heard hereabouts six months ago, last night presented three one-act operas in the Master Theatre, up on 103d Street near Riverside Drive.

LONDON, June 7--Winston Churchill told 9,000 cheering Conservative women here today that while their efforts in the last election had failed to change the Government of Britain, they had helped to force the Labor Government to change its policy. The outstanding lesson of the February election, he said, was that British people did not want socialism.

MADRID, June 7--Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, in a press statement here today, advised the Spaniards to concentrate on raising the country's food production. He cast some cold water on their hopes of immediate large loans from United States banks.
LONDON, June 7 (AP)--Promoter Jack Solomons said today that Lee Savold would defend his British and European version of the world heavyweight title in London, probably in September.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 7 (AP) --Thirty-seven weary survivors of an airplane crash in the Atlantic were brought here this afternoon by a United States destroyer.

In contrast to its unpreparedness in 1939 and 1940, the United States is in much better shape today to expand its economy to possible war-time needs, speakers in the economic mobilization course said yesterday.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., June 7 (AP)--The South Dakota Republican party may require an official canvass next week to decide whether it has a nominee for Governor.

With their happy penchant for winning the important ones, the Yankees surged from behind to edge the Tigers, 5--4, before a Ladies' Day assemblage of 37,734 at the Stadium yesterday. In regaining first place from Detroit, the Bombers snapped a Bengal winning streak that had extended through seven games.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Capitol, the attraction is "The Asphalt Jungle," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer melodrama directed by John Huston from the story by W.R. Burnett. Sterling Hayden, James Whitmore, Louis Calhern, Sam Jaffe, Jean Hagen and John McIntire head the cast. Arthur Hornblow Jr. produced from a screen play by Ben Maddow and Mr. Huston.

TOKYO, June 7--Gen. Douglas MacArthur today ordered the Japanese Government to remove from public life the seventeen top members of the staff of the Communist party's official propaganda organ Akhata (Red Flag).
Retail sales of refrigerators reached the high point of the year in the city yesterday. Dealers said three consecutive days of hot weather had precipitated the longawaited seasonal upturn.

LONDON, June 7--This empire capital, which has bade a ceremonious farewell to not a few heroes, paid a rare funeral tribute today to Field Marshal Earl Wavell, scholar, former Viceroy of India and soldier, whose desert victories marked the resurgence of British military might after Dunkerque.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7--With the inroads of oil and gas hurting the coal industry, a worried leader pleaded today for support of one of its biggest customers.
