AUSTIN, Tex., June 7 (AP)--The University of Texas accepted two Negro students today, bowing to the United States Supreme Court's segregation ban.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP)-- The House Post Office Committee approved 12 to 8 today, a bill to force Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson to cancel his order cutting big city mail deliveries to one a day and reducing other postal services.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 8-- William Y. Dear Jr. of Montclair celebrated the golden jubilee of the New Jersey Golf Association's amateur championship by winning his fourth qualifying medal with an even par 35, 35--70 over the No. 2 and No. 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club course today.
An increase of activities on the bucolic circuit is evidenced in the number of plans announced yesterday for the forthcoming outdoor season. They are as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- Agreement on a $596,000,000 military construction program was reached today by a Senate-House conference committee. It includes $189,241,000 in projects inserted after it had passed the Senate, some stamped "highest priority" by the Defense Department.

The above-par premium of the Treasury's longest-term 2 per cent bonds callable in 1967 slipped below 1 points yesterday as the Federal Reserve System "made bonds available" at 101 15/32. Other long-term non-bank Government obligations moved down 1/32

CHICAGO, June 8--As 500 delegates opened here today the first national report conference of the United Jewish Appeal for this year, a report disclosed that American Jewish women had contributed a record $66,000,000 since 1946 for the Appeal's reconstruction programs in behalf of refugees in this country and throughout the world, especially in Israel.

British politicians are in the happy position these days of quarreling over the credit for improved living conditions and a minor boom in economy. According to Winston Churchill in London and Lord Woolton, chairman of the Conservative party, who is in the United States, the Labor Government is merely doing what the Tories proposed and the housewives imposed.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 8 (UP)--Four of the thirteen Czechs accused of plotting with Western diplomats to overthrow the Communist regime in Czechoslovakia were sentenced to death tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to send to the floor for a showdown a proposed three-year extension of the peacetime selective draft. The form of the bill was viewed widely as clashing head-on with President Truman's program for racial parity in the defense forces.
HONG KONG, June 8--The Shanghai branch of the Sovietoperated Moscow Peoples Bank (Narodny Bank) has petitioned for permission to suspend operations.
LONDON, June 8 (AP)--Britian announced tonight a new agreement with the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and SoconyVacuum Oil Company for the marketing of Iraqi oil for sterling.

CHICAGO, June 8--Nearly 9,500,000 television receivers will be in use in the United States by the end of 1950, R.C. Cosgrove, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association, told delegates of the association at their annual membership luncheon today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP)-- A United States District Court Judge today issued a permanent injunction ordering eight of the nation's largest wallpaper making companies to stop illegal price fixing in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law. The injunction also named the Wall Paper ...
With the arrival of warm weather, the demand for play clothes for sports is as great as the vast selections that await the shopper.

Rubber futures continued in moderate decline on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. At the close of trading the market was 1 to 15 points lower than final levels on Wednesday. The volume of transactions also declined.

B. Brewster Jennings, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, have been elected directors of the Brand Names Foundation, Inc. The elections took place yesterday at the ...

LONDON, June 8--The United States representative on the Council of Deputies to the Atlantic Pact foreign ministers, who will be elected chairman, will probably be named in the next few days. The council set up by the foreign ministers of the twelve North Atlantic Treaty nations as an executive committee to carry out their policies.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, 83, author of the Townsend pension plan, is among those invited by Federal Security Administrator Ewing, at President Truman's request, to a mid-August conference in Washington on "Programs for an Aging Population." Dr. Townsend's proposals have always seemed, especially to those who would have to pay the bills, wildly impracticable.

Warm weather drove water consumption to 1,000,000,000 gallons on Wednesday, close to the 1,015,000,000-gallon "dependable yield" of the city's water system, Commissioner Stephen J. Carney announced yesterday.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 8--There were four places available in the Birmingham, Ala., qualifying round for the United States Open. Lee Mackey Jr., a 26-year-old unemployed professional, barely squeezed in as the fourth qualifier with 75, 74--149. But he won't have to go searching for a job now.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Safeway Stores, Inc., of Oakland, Calif., today filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 321,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value, and 257,064 shares of common stock of $5 par value.

FORT MYER, Va., June 8--Miss Ann Haviland Lastayo, daughter of Brig. Gen. Edward H. Lastayo, U.S.A., and Mrs. Lastayo of Alexandria, was married to Lieut. John Darby Howard, U.S.A., son of Col. Willis T. Howard, Chaplains Corps, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Howard of Albertville, Ala., tonight in the post chapel. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

GENEVA, June 8--Yugoslavia threw the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe into turmoil today by introducing a resolution demanding a United Nations investigation of the "economic war" on Yugoslavia by the Soviet Union and its satellite states on the basis of facts to be submitted by each Government.

Alfred Shawl is a jeweler who creates "heirloom pieces" out of a deep knowledge of feminine psychology. He believes that by making articles that can be disassembled, the same ornament may be adapted to six or eight different uses. He scorns mass production methods as the bane of individualism.

The City of New York has borrowed $29,000,000 from twenty-six local banks and trust companies on 1 per cent tax anticipation notes maturing over one year, City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 7--A steady increase in the number of veterans associations in northern Germany has moved British authorities to consider asking the Military Security Board to tighten the regulations licensing this sort of group.

Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, General Marshall has added his voice to those of other top-ranking political and military leaders in support of the foreign military aid program under the North Atlantic Pact.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors, said today the corporation's agreement with the United Auto Workers, C.I.O., was a fiveyear plan to exploit machines, not men, and to share the bounty among employes, employer and customers.

WASHINGTON, June 8--A memorandum describing an officer of a now bankrupt Florida company as "a very close personal friend" of President Truman was read into the records of a Senate subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance ...

One of the most talented showings of work by part-time and "Sunday" painters, who find time on at least one evening a week to attend classes at the Brooklyn Museum Art School, opened last night in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, June 8--Motor Vehicle Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher said today that personal-injury accidents on the state's highways were increasing "shockingly," although motor vehicle deaths were about the same as last year.

The signing of an agreement between waterfront loaders and truck operators, which was described as a pact with "enough teeth to assure stability on the piers," was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 8-- A Social Christian (Catholic) Government, pledged to restore King Leopold III to the throne of Belgium, was formed and sworn in today. The new Premier is Jean Duvieusart.

Sharked by a 5-point coup by Leo Duckworth in the last period, the Jersey Jolters defeated the Brooklyn Red Devils, 24 to 22, in the final of the roller derby world series at Aiadison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--Joe Adonis, gambler, refused to answer questions before a Federal grand jury today about his stamp deals with a former Post Office official.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- The Senate passed and sent back to the House today a bill permitting the Treasury to buy up to $1,000,000,000 in obligations of Federal Home Loan banks. These functions as a reserve banking system for mortgage lending institutions.

NEWARK, June 8--David N. Wood, New York lawyer and bond counselor, who is a key defense witness in Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's suit to dissolve the sale of two toll bridges in Burlington County, admitted in cross-examination today that he had prepared the by-laws for the Burlington County Bridge Commission two months before the commission was created and without consulting county officials.
WASHINGTON, June 8--During the week ended June 7 member bank reserve balances increased $253,000,000, the Federal Reserve Beard reported today.

Management expects to realize a profit from company house magazines in the form of improved employe understanding and goodwilsl, James Tanham, vice president of The Texas Company, declared yesterday. He spoke before the eleventh annual conference of the House Magazine Institute in the Roosevelt Hotel.
PITTSBURGH, June 8--At long last the Pirates won a ball game, defeating the Dodgers in the second game of their current threegame series tonight by a score of 4 to 3.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 8--A vast new program for Germany that could bring millions of dollars from governments and private organizations into a major democratization movement was approved in committee today by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Dr. Stanton Lautenschlager, Presbyterian missionary to China, died on Wednesday in Wooster, Ohio, while on furlough to visit his family there, according to word received yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. His age was 62.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8-- "Room for One More," a new novel by Anna Perrott Rose, has been purchased for the screen by Warner Brothers and assigned to Henry Blanke for production. The yarn deals with a married couple who adopt a neurotic child and finally succeed in creating a normal life for him.

A new method of paying hospital bills for persons covered under group hospitalization plans of private insurance companies in the metropolitan area will go into effect Monday, it was announced yesterday.

A proposed local law requiring business concerns and private industries to pay fees if they use city policemen for payroll guarding and other special services was submitted to the City Council yesterday by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat.

Judging from the number of apartment houses springing up in the Forest Hills vicinity, that section of Queens will soon have its share of new residents shopping, for home furnishings. To help people moving into the area with their planning problems, a shop called New Horizons upens this morning at 102-11 Queens Boulecard. The owners are Josif Marcu and Arthur Dall.
A formal contract for the construction of a $20,000,000 Statler Hotel and office building in downtown Los Angeles was awarded yesterday to Robert E. McKee, General Contractor, Inc.,
Ten mushroom-hatted young chefs at the Madison Square Boys Club had a visit yesterday from a fellow maestro, Philippe of the Waldorf.

PARIS, June 8--The World Organization for Brotherhood, an outreach of the National Conference of Christians and Jews in the United States, was launched at the beginning today of a four-day international meeting here, with appeals by world leaders for greater fraternity among nations and men.
The mother of the 17-year-old youth held in the fatal shooting of his father last Saturday in a Bronx park told authorities last night that her son had confided to her he had killed his parent.

There is an impression in some quarters that the United States is being unreasonably stiff-necked on the matter of the recognition of the Chinese Communists and their representation in the United Nations.

CLEVELAND, June 8--Welby Van Horn of Philadelphia, a power in professional tennis since he won the title in 1945, went down in crushing defeat tonight in the quarter-final round of the National championship at the Skating Club.

Counsel for the Cities Service Oil Company of Pennsylvania refused yesterday to make available its ship crew reports, as a National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges against the company went into the second day.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- Low-priced oil imports were pictured again today as not only threatening economic "disaster" to the coal industry but also as endangering the health anu education of miners' children.

CHICAGO, June 8--Wheat futures reversed an early trend and closed higher today. Commission buying absorbed early offerings and forced shorts to cover later. Some hedge pressure was indicated early in wheat, but so far offerings have not been burdensome. Spring wheat developments are ...
A grave picture of the situation in the Far East was painted yesterday by Commdr. William T. Greenhalgh, U.S.N., veteran of the Pacific war and of the occupations of China, Japan and Korea.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York presented a check for $1,000,000 yesterday in the national campaign for $272,455,800.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The votes needed to get an extension of rent control through the Senate have been obtained, it was learned today, by a sharply administered warning to the Democrats that they might find themselves in the minority next year if the bill failed to pass.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The State Department assailed today the Oder-Neisse boundary agreement announced yesterday by East Germany and Poland.

ST. LOUIS, June 8--President Truman arrived here tonight for a two-day pilgrimage to his native state to deliver two major addresses in which he is expected to reaffirm his faith in our foreign policy as a sure course to peace.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The New York brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Beane, was held technically guilty of violating the Anti-Fraud Act by the Securities and Exchange Commission today, but the commission dismissed any proceedings against the firm on the grounds ...

WASHINGTON, June 8--Between the public and the renewed inquiries into the Amerasia case of 1945 there are so many locked doors and other silencers that what has come through thus far has not answered the chief questions.
TRENTON, June 8--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed municipal reform legislation today designed to streamline local governments and increase public interest in self-administration.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 8-- Three ex-convicts, one of whom figured in the Vivian Gordon murder investigation in New York City in 1931, were held on firstdegree murder charges here to night as suspects in the hold-up of a Reader's Digest truck on April 3. A helper on the truck was shot dead in the robbery.
Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler said last night he did not think the proposed Sunday night game between St. Louis and Brooklyn at St. Louis, July 16, would be played.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)-- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, today proposed a purchase of all of the outstanding capital stock of the Boston and Providence Railroad.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 8--A record-breaking round, the lowest in the fifty-year history of the United States Golf Association's open championship was produced in the initial round of the golden jubilee tourney today when Lee Mackey Jr. of Birmingham, Ala., scored a 64 on the Merion Golf Club's east course.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 8-- White flowers and ferns formed a garden background for the marriage here this afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less of Miss Mary Eleanor Tandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nelson Tandler of Scarsdale, to Lieut. Kenneth Walter Hall, U.S.A., son of Walter A. Hall of Nashua, N.H., and the late Mrs. Hall.
Two of Manhattan's teen-age gangs, whose warfare has drawn blood and brought arrests, are now at peace because of a treaty negotiated under unusual circumstances.

Commissioner Moses was host to some editors on a blimp ride over Kings, Queens and adjacent counties on Long Island this week. He was, as usual, a genial and disarming host, never so much as mentioning money needed for large future plans.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8--At the request of Secretary of State Dean Acheson the Israeli Government is investigating Arab reports of mistreatment approaching a point of torture allegedly perpetrated against infiltrators into Israel. The reports came from Jordan, and were supplemented by declarations from United Nations observers.

Although clearly reflecting crosscurrents, business borrowings from banks in this area have registered the first increase in five weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the bank's figures, covering the reporting New York City ...

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP)--Three Lustron Corporation dealers tonight blocked--temporarily atleast--sale of the big Columbus, Ohio, fabricated housing plant to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for $6,000,000.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 1--Haile Selassie I, Emperor of Ethiopia, said in an interview today that he hoped "all peace-loving countries will see that Eritrea is reunited with Ethiopia, although Ethiopia has unjustly lost Somaliland."

Seventy per cent of the rentable store space in the $24,000,000 Port Authority bus terminal has been leased to twenty-three highly selected tenants, the agency announced yesterday. Although the building, one block west of Times Square, is not slated to open until ...

The first evidence that the wild upward spiral in scrap metal prices this year might have reached its zenith developed in Pittsburgh yesterday wnen one dealer lowered his price $2 a ton and others were flooding the market with supplies previously withheld in expectation of further price advances.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8-- Gov. Earl Warren, in his third term bid, had amassed a primary election vote, in an incomplete tabulation today, that surpassed his total in the 1946 primary when he won both the Republican and Democratic nominations to set a precedent for California politics. This year his victory was confined to the Republican ticket.

In a cash deal reported yesterday the property at 1145 to 1149 Avenue of the Americas and 10204 West Forty-fifth Street was sold by the estate of John Dunston to Henry Goelet, operator, for improvement with a tall building. Assessed at $481,000, the holding forms an "L" around the ...

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP)--The patched-up Cardinals scored eight runs in the first inning tonight and went on to beat the Braves, 18--6, lifting St. Louis again into a firstplace National League tie with the Dodgers. Each team collected seventeen hits.
A group of college students announced yesterday that they had chartered a 6,700-ton ship from the Norwegian Government.
ST. LOUIS, June 8--Carlos F. Hurd, a leading member of the news staff of The St. Louis PostDispatch for half a century, died of cancer today at his home in suburban University City. His age was 73.

PARIS, June 8--The accord reached in Stockholm between members of French and West German private agricultural organizations for the creation of a common farm market in the spirit of the Schuman plan for coal and steel was received here today as a step toward clearing away one of the chief obstacles to French-German trade.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 8-- For one hour and fifteen minutes today five State Senators and the publisher and the managing editor of The New Orleans Item engaged in a wrangle on the Senate floor over freedom of the press. The wrangle ended with one of the legislators being restrained by his colleagues from punching the editor.

Bob Hope, released this week from his contract by Lever Brothers Company, has signed an exclusive long-term agreement with the National Broadcasting Company covering his radio and television appearances. The comedian's radio program will be sponsored next fall by Chesterfield cigarettes on Tuesdays at 9 P.M.

Despite the warning of the senior Senator from Nevada that the new and liberalized Displaced Persons Act would set up "an open door for the infiltration into this country of subversives," the measure has finally escaped from Capitol Hill and landed safely on President Truman's desk.

PITTSBURGH, June 8--Business in the Pittsburgh district held about unchanged last week, according to the Bureau of Business research of the University of Pittsburgh. There were slight increases in industrial production and in ...

ATLANTIC CITY, June 8 (AP)-- Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, was named today recipient of the Joseph A. Sprague Memorial Award of the National Press Photographers Association.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 8--Recent controversies over whether Federal funds should be used in the transportation of parochial school children have served to awaken many Americans to the dangers of excluding religion from education, the Rev. Robert C. Hartnett, editor in chief of America, national Roman Catholic weekly review, said here tonight.
Ample credit exists for the financing, of increased imports to the United States, Wilbert Ward, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, said here yesterday.

"You are a generation which has few illusions," Dean Millicent C. McIntosh of Barnard College told 303 seniors at the diploma ceremony held yesterday afternoon in the college gymnasium after they had taken part in Columbia University's commencement exercises.

Present social security benefits are inadequate and should be increased, Cyrus S. Ching, director, Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, declared here yesterday at closing sessions of the National Confectioners Association convention in the Waldort-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Senate investigators, seeking to determine whether Communists have infiltrated the State Department, debated today whether Justice Tom C. Clark of the Supreme Court should be called to tell what he knows about the Amerasia case.
CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP)--Ken Raffensberger, "the old professor" of the Cincinnati pitching staff, racked up his fourth straight victory here tonight as the Reds drubbed Philadelphia, 8 to 4.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The drunken driver was described today as "death's chief handyman" on the highways.

The pale blue and white flag of Argentina waved proudly over New York Harbor yesterday, displayed from the masthead of a modern passenger liner for the first time. The bearer of the colors was the trim, yachtlike Rio de la Plata inbound on her maiden voyage from Buenos Aires.

LONDON, June 8 (Reuters)--A threat to "wipe from the seven seas" owners of Panamanian ships and others trying to "escape the social reforms for which seamen were fighting" was made here today by Omer Becu, acting general secretary of the International Transport Federation.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Details of a reorganization of the Department of Commerce Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce were made public tonight by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce. He said the aim was to make the services of the bureau more readily available to the business community.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that America was no place for "blind obedience to a corporate state."
DAVAO, the Philippines, June 5 --The promised land of the Philippines, the big, rich, sparsely populated southern island of Mindanao, is slowly filling with settlers.
Citing the city's public housing as an example for the entire city and the nation in racially unsegregated living, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that New York's goal was 500,000 units of such homes.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 8 --The Western German Government received far-reaching authority today to negotiate and conclude international treaties without prior approval of the Western Allied High Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Thomas Whittemore, archaeologist and professor at Harvard University, died this morning while paying a call at the State Department.

For the third consecutive year, the Board of Superintendents has omitted the magazine The Nation from the list of publications recommended for public school libraries, it was announced yesterday by Miss Freda Kirchway, editor and publisher of The Nation, who released ...

Jockey Joe Snyder still is batting 1,000 in steeplechasing. On May 25, in his first ride over the big jumps, he won the Appleton with Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Darjeeling. Yesterday at Belmont Park, again combining his talents with those of Darjeeling, he made his record two for two.

Four hundred exuberant but parched youngsters went through a series of weird paces yesterday afternoon. Their elders, drenched and sun-sodden, ringed the fences surrounding four different Police Athletic League playgrounds, forming an enervated audience.

MENLO PARK, N.J., June 8-- This village, where Thomas Edison experimented to bring light to the world, today is the scene of an experiment aimed at bringing a different kind of "light" to the world --a light into the nature of men's minds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP)-- James P. Clark, trucking executive and president of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, said today he had organized a syndicate to purchase the Athletics "if and when they are for sale."

"TOO LITTLE LOVE," by Robert Henriques, is not a great or flawless novel. It is a novel of major substance, of ambition, skill and vast vitality. VENICE, Italy, June 8 (Reuters) --Art connoisseurs from half the world flocked by gondola and motor boat along Venice's canals today to see thousands of pictures and other works at the opening of the world's biggest international art exhibition.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The United States told the Soviet Union again today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur had full authority to parole Japanese war criminals.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The National Labor Relations Board ruled out today an agreement between an American Federation of Labor union and contractors on the $20,000,000 construction job at the Hanford (Wash.) atomic energy works.

BUENOS AIRES, June 8-- Copies of the Argentine Congressional Record for May 31, which contain a long list of charges against the regime of President Juan Peron, are to be withdrawn from circulation and, whenever possible, copies already distributed are to be rounded up.
An Army ordnance expert testified yesterday that the type of land-mine involved in the disastrous May 19 explosion at South Amboy, N.J., had been discontinued by the Army in 1942 as "unsafe."
Nearly 100,000 children marched in Brooklyn yesterday as the borough observed the 121st anniversary of its Sunday School Union. Thousands in Queens also celebrated the event with similar processions.

Plans for unified support of prolabor candidates in this year's elections were advanced last night at a meeting of 3,000 delegates of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 8--New discoveries in Egyptian archeology hitherto unreported in this country are revealed with the opening at the Smithsonian Institution of a series of fifty paintings by Joseph Lindon Smith of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

WASHINGTON, June 8--J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, warned Senators two months ago that unprecedented numbers of Communists were seeking United States atomic, military and industrial secrets.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP)--Offensive baseball records were shot to bits today when Boston's Red Sox slashed four St. Louis pitchers for twenty-eight hits and a humiliating 29-4 victory over the last place Browns.

Dr. and Mrs. Irving Sherwood Wright of 943 Lexington Avenue, and Point O'Woods, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Mansfield, to Robert P. Ball Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ball of 460 Riverside Drive.

Families moving into low-cost houses usually are faced with budget limitations on furnishings as well. Suggestions on how to cut corners on some things, while choosing other long-term investment pieces, are offered in a model house opening this week-end at Albertson, L.I.

Because of their initial success, the "Rendezvous With the Theatre" benefit parties, given last summer by the American Theatre Wing in aid of hospitalized veterans, will be resumed this summer, it was announced yesterday.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers will offer to investors today a new issue of $25,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Southern California Gas Company due in 1980 at 102,542 to yield 2.75 per cent:

LAKE SUCCESS, June 8-- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, today reiterated that he does not agree with the Soviet walkouts on the China question. However, he said that he had not advised the Soviet Government to return to United Nations meetings and accept the decisions of the majority on whether the Nationalists or the Communists should represent China.

PARIS, June 8--On the heels of a lull in the dispute over electoral reform a new conflict broke out today in the National Assembly over the pay of civil servants between the Socialists and Popular Republicans.

TOKYO, Friday, June 9 (UP)-- Fifty Japanese police today raided the offices of Sanzo Nosaka, Japan's No. 2 Communist. Mr. Nosaka, the Communists' chief theoretician, was one of the twentyfour members of the party's Central Committee banned by Gen. Douglas MacArthur from public life.

Already the only metropolitan police force in the world to use helicopters, the New York Police Department yesterday increased considerably the size of its "windmill" fleet.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 8--A pair of home-club entries staged a one-two finish today in the low gross competition of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

Governor Dewey returned to the city yesterday morning from a two weeks' vacation at White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., and went directly from the train to Roosevelt Hospital for a checkup.

The Federal Communications Commission requested the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday to keep messages, which it would otherwise destroy, for possible use by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee headed by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the graduating classes at Columbia University yesterday that "there is nothing wrong with America that the faith, love of freedom, intelligence and energy of her citizens cannot cure."

NORWALK, Conn., June 8 (AP)-- The sale of the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company for $2,600,000 to Albert M. Kahn of New York City was confirmed by Judge Carroll C. Hincks in United States District Court today.
LONDON, June 8--Strength of British Government securities was again the principal feature of the stock markets here today. They rose steadily to gain up to one-half point.

In the Little Church Around the Corner yesterday morning, Miss Jill Lipsky, daughter of Mrs. Jack S. Peliks of Copacabana, Rio de Janeiro, and Longin L. Lipsky of 35 Fifth Avenue, was married to John Burr Fairchild, son of Mrs. Richard W. Suydam of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Louis W. Fairchild of 40 Fifth Avenue.

Changing clothes has always been a necessary evil to John A. Parsons, policeman, minister and scholar. And though each of the jobs still will require a different wardrobe, all apparent distinction between them disappeared yesterday when he donned cap and gown to receive his Master of Arts degree at Columbia University.

RED BANK, N. J., June 9--A live land mine was discovered at 2 P. M., today in the automatic coal stoker of a Pennsylvania railroad passenger locomotive a few seconds before the New York-bound train was scheduled to leave here.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 10 (UP)--Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, halted his filibuster early today and said he would be ready to talk again in a few hours.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today scheduled for June 29 a hearing on a stock distribution proposal involving Eastern Kansas Utilities, Inc., of Fort Scott, Kan.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP)--The owner of the Cardinals said today he would ignore an order by Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler to cancel a Sunday night game until the club received a hearing on the matter.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)--The Government reported today that bad weather had cut wheat prospects to the lowest level in seven years. Unless the outlook improves, farm income from wheat will drop about $400,000,000 below last year's.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 9-- Joseph A. McBride of Arcola, the defending champion, was stopped in the second round of the New Jersey State amateur championship over the hilly Montclair golf course today.

MOSCOW, June 9 (UP)--Finnish Premier Urho K. Kekkonen, arriving today for an official visit, said that successful conclusion of a trade agreement with Russia augurs well for the future of Soviet-Finnish relations.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 9-- Mr. and Mrs. Willard Ingham Emerson of New York and Greens Farms, gave a dance tonight at the Fairfield County Hunt Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Barbara Harwood Emerson.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 9 --The question of Germany's eastern frontier remains open and can be settled only through a peace treaty between all of Germany and the occupation powers, the West German Federal Government declared today.

The five-story building at 1520 Crotona Park East, the Bronx, accommodating sixty-two families, has been sold by the Pinkay Realty Company to an investing client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker in the transaction.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 9--Nassau County will oppose the application of the Long Island Rail Road trustees to increase commutation fares unless that increase is to come as a part of a complete program for a restored railroad, it was announced here today by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.

DANSALAN, Mindanao, the Philippines, June 6--The Moros, once the bitterest foes of the United States in the early years of the American occupation of the Philippines, gave an enthusiastic colorful community demonstration here today of their regard for the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Dale E. Doty and Vernon D. Northrop, both Government service career men, took oaths as new assistant Secretaries of the Interior Department today.
Charged with giving atomic secrets to Soviet Russia, three men were indicted by the Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn yesterday for conspiring to violate the National Espionage Act.

SCULTHORPE, England, June 9--The pilot of a United States Air Force B-29 Superfortress bomber lost in the North Sea said today that the plane had been set afire by bullets from one of its own gun turrets.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Gen. Jacob L. Devers, managing director of the American Automobile Association Foundation for Traffic Safety, today termed the New York City traffic situation a hopeless muddle "with cars backed up to West Point when motorists try to get home on a Sunday night."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9--The desire not to see Jordan expelled from the Arab League appears to have gained the upper hand in Syria and Lebanon.

With many of the nation's topranking stars in the field of 297 athletes, the Metropolitan A.A.U. outdoor track and field championships will be staged at Triborough Stadium, on Randalls Island today. Twenty-one district titles are at stake in New York's last major spiked-shoe carnival of the 1950 season. First post is at 1 P. M.

The head of the Police Waterfront Squad, who has matched his rapid rise in the Police Department with advancement in the academic field, will reach another milestone next Wedneseday. He will receive the degree of Bachelor of Laws at New York University's 188th Commencement.

Stanley Openshaw was indicted yesterday for the premeditated slaying of his 70-year-old father, Morris Openshaw. A Bronx grand jury handed up the true bill to County Judge Samuel Joseph on the youth's seventeenth birthday.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Six American Ambassadors appealed to Congress today to approve the $1,222,500,000 program for providing military aid to free countries through a second year.

For an hour and a half yesterday afternoon several thousand guests and visitors at the twenty-eightstory Statler Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street, had to shift for themselves as 750 union employes engaged in an unauthorized work stoppage.

The Chinese Communist Government is without legal standing here and therefore not entitled to the $791,123 postal remittances "frozen" by the Chase National Bank, Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch ruled yesterday after ownership had been disputed by the Nationalist Government.

If the last few days may be taken as an indication, this weekend should see a city-wide exodus to local beaches. From the array of handy aids now available, the days of "roughing it" on such jaunts are gone forever.
A union of 16,000 maintenance and installation employes of the New York Telephone Company rejected yesterday a company contract proposal and demanded a general wage increase.

Church leaders representing an estimated 160,000,000 Protestant and Orthodox Christians in sixty countries will gather in Toronto, Canada, this summer to formulate plans for the future and to weigh accomplishments of the past.

The forward motion of the stock market continued uninterrupted yesterday. Peak gains of more than 3 points appeared in a few stocks, increase in the averages was 1.71 points. The automotives roared into leadership after a somewhat hesitant start and held it throughout the session.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Oil importation into this country cannot be held responsible for the economic difficulties of the coal industry, a Senate committee was told today by Charles L. Harding director of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company.

President Truman's speech at the commencement exercises of the University of Missouri yesterday provided another sensible and cogent appeal for Point Four and our economic aid to Europe.

The Olddens arrived in New York yesterday in their thirtyeight-foot ketch Acorn, six months and one week out of their home port of Catalina Island. They had exactly thirty-five cents in their pockets.

The nine-story building containing offices and professional suites at 147 East Fiftieth Street has been sold by the 147 East Fiftieth Street Corporation, Edward Levy, treasurer, which built it in 1926. The new owners are investing clients of Morway Picket, attorney. L. V. Hoffman Co, were the brokers.

For the Yankees, yesterday was the "losingest" afternoon of the season. Not only did they drop a 13-7 decision and a length of their lead to the Tigers, but they lost the services of two players, Bob Porterfield and Charley Silvera before 18,579 at the Stadium.
Miss Margaret Webster, executive director of the Young Women's Christian Association here, made her farewell public speech last night before retiring, after forty-two years of Y.W.C.A. service.

SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 9 (AP) --State police pressed a manhunt through woods tonight for two gunmen believed hiding in the area after staging an $8,500 holdup in a bank in Woodbury, half a dozen miles away.
PITTSBURGH, June 9--Having tasted victory last night over the Dodgers, the Pirates strove desperately under a blazing sun today to reward 9,510 of the faithful with a two-game winning streak.

Steel warehouses here fear increases may occur in "black market" price quotations which are now starting to rise because of scarcities in some items needed for current contracts by building contractors.

MADISON, Wis., June 9--Dr. Edward Asahel Birge, president emeritus of the University of Wisconsin and an authority on lake life, died today at his home here after a two-month illness. He was 98 years old.
A heavy influx of visitors here this summer was predicted yesterday by members of the Hotel Sales Management Association of New York at their monthly luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 9--At the insistence of the Allied High Commission, the West German Government will open a definitive dollar-earning program next week. The principal target will be dollar-bearing tourists.

Beck of the University of Oregon, has been judged "inadequate in many important respects" by a group of psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, nursery school teachers and educational consultants.

PARIS, June 9--The Communist-controlled General Confederation of Labor has lost ground, but still remains the dominant labor force in France.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9--Between 35,000,000 and 40,000,000 pairs of sun glasses worth nearly $90,000,000 will be sold this year, it was estimated here today by J. Chester Crowther of Philadelphia, president of the Sun Glass Institute.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 (AP)-- Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, said tonight it was a right of the people to see pictures of "justice at work" in the courts.

The tournament season seems to be getting in full swing now, and whether you care to fish for trout in Quebec, bass in Florida, stripers at Cape Cod, or tuna practically anywhere, you may fish and compete at the same time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9-- "Son and Stranger," a new novel by David Demarest Lloyd about an American Air Force flyer and an English girl, has been acquired for the screen by Hal Wallis for production in England next year with Charlton Heston, Wallis' new leading man, as the star.
BERLIN, June 9 (UP)--The Western occupation powers pledged themselves today to ward off new Communist threats to West Berlin.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9--Israel's answer to the reported mistreatment of Arab infiltrates is simply: "Keep on your own side of the border."

The most expert of the pricemakers have the idea that Christopher T. Chenery's Hill Prince, the Preakness winner, will be the oddson favorite in today's eighty-second running of the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park. Nine others, including the King Ranch's Middleground, who beat Hill Prince in the Kentucky Derby, are in the race.

PARIS, June 9--The inaugural conference of the World Organization for Brotherhood voted today to transmit to foreign offices a plan to create an international council of cooperation "for the purpose of furthering understanding and teamwork among nations."

Gen. Walton H. Walker, commander of the United States Eighth Army, said today.

The Lone Star Gas Company has borrowed $85,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company of America and eleven banks, it was announced yesterday.

One of the best pieces of news in the field of public safety is the announcement by the Board of Education that driver training will begin in the fall in practically every public high school in New York City.

With the announcement that water consumption for this week's Dry Thursday had set a conservation-drive peak of 999,000,000 gallons, Commissioner Stephen J. Carney dispatched inspectors yesterday to check on compliance with air conditioning and refrigerating regulations.

The Thor Corporation may distribute its appliances in the northern New Jersey area only through Mayflower Industries as a result of a ruling handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia.

The fantastic story behind the sinking of the liner Westerdam, which was sent to the bottom on three different occasions during the war to prevent her use by the Germans, was disclosed here for the first time yesterday by the man responsible for two of the sinkings.

The 137th annual conclave of the Grand Commandery, Knights Templar, State of New York, will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today and tomorrow. It is expected 3,000 members, about 20 per cent of the full enrollment in seventy-two commanderies, will attend.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)-- Gus J. Solomon, Federal District judge in Oregon, denied to a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that he was a Communist and said he absolutely opposed communism.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 10 (AP)--Mrs. Arthur H. Vandenberg, wife of the Republican Senator from Michigan, died early today after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Average primary market prices rose 0.4 per cent in the week ended June 6, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 157.4 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.5 per cent above four weeks ago and 0.8 per cent above the comparable week of 1949.

Coffee futures reacted sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange as a result of the report of the Gillette subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee, calling for widespread restrictions on trading in the coffee futures market.

NORWICH, N.Y., June 9-- James P. Hill, former presiding justice of the third department, Appellate Division, New York State Supreme Court, died here tonight in his home. His age was 72. He had been ill since Memorial Day.
WASHINGTON, June 9--The United States spoke out sharply today to the rubber-producing countries against "speculative" rises in the price of natural rubber.

WASHINGTON, June 9--A Senate subcommittee today delved fur ther for reasons why the Reconstruction Finance Corporation ad vanced $300,000 to a Florida concern which went bankrupt within six weeks of getting the advance.
The special Federal grand jury's investigation of the Amerasia case, now under way here, was instituted without the sanction of Federal authorities here and in Washington.

The task of fashioning a play dealing with the tabulous business career of Mrs. Lydia Pinkham, whose herb medicine became a national institution, is being handled by Reginald Lawrence and Francis I. Curtis, who also is doubling as producer of the project. They have succeeded Elaine Ryan, who has had to bow out.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Republicans piled accusation upon demand today in the five-year-old Amerasia espionage case.

PARIS, June 9--Facing a hostile National Assembly that was threatening to defeat him on the issue of revising the civil servants' pay scale, Premier Georges Bidault tonight obtained a postponement of debate until Tuesday.
First indications of a reaction against soaring prices in metal products have appeared among a number of large New York industries in which "hand-to-mouth" buying methods are being adopted.
BERLIN, June 9 (AP)--Communist Governments in East Germany and Hungary took new steps today to black out radio programs and news from the Western countries.
WASHINGTON, June 9--William W. Remington resigned his $10,000-a-year job as an economist in the Department of Commerce today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 9--Dr. T.V. Soong, millionaire brother of Mme., Chiang Kai-shek, has quit the Kuomintang--Nationalist China's ruling party--rather than come to Formosa where his sister and Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek have pledged to die resisting the Communists if need be.
LONDON, June 9--British Government securities continued to take the limelight on the stock markets here today and ended the week's advance at a new peak in terms of turnover.

Awarding of a Bachelor of Arts degree to Robert J. Smithdas, a totally blind and deaf student, will be an event in the eightieth annual commencement exercises of St. John's University tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 9--The United Nations turned down today a Polish demand that Communist China be seated at the largest conference ever called by the world organization--a meeting to raise money for technical assistance to under-developed countries.

The Senate Armed Services Committee has put an ugly blot on an otherwise sound piece of work in accepting an amendment to its new Selective Service bill that would perpetuate racial segregation in the armed services.
COLUMBIA, Mo., June 9-- Harry S. Truman poked his sister today for fumbling a tune they were playing on the piano. It was a typical act of a big brother.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Senators investigating the high price of coffee said today there has been no shortage and demanded sharp curbs on speculators.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Three small New York state communities, Gloversville, Johnstown and Camillus, one-industry communities, told the Committee for Tariff Reciprocity Information that they already have felt the impact of foreign competition.

CHICAGO, June 9--With a sixteen-hit assault in which every member of the squad participated, the Giants today smothered the Cubs before 14,058 at Wrigley Field, chalking up their seventh straight victory as they charged past Frankie Frisch's harassed band into fifth place in the National League standing.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)-- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath announced today that a grand jury in Alaska had returned ten indictments charging antitrust law violations in a halfdozen important business fields. He said they were handed up sealed at Anchorage last Monday.

A combination of spring, an upsurge of confidence in the immediate economic future and unsatisfied demand left over from the war years has swamped automobile dealers in New York and most other sections of the country with orders for new cars.

A two-and-a-half-hour show for the benefit of the Cerebral Palsy Association will be carried by N.B.C. television at 9:30 o'clock this evening.
NEW ORLEANS, June 9 (UP)-- Meigs O. Frost, who divided a long career between fighting and writing, died today in his home at the age of 67.

CHICAGO, June 9--Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the, United Jewish Appeal, declared here today that "a state of emergency" existed among 235,000 Jewish men, women and children in Rumania, Iraq, Poland and Israel. He stressed that American Jews held the key "to the fate of these people who must receive priority help."

WASHINGTON, June 9--Linked by handcuffs, John Howard Lawson and Dalton Trumbo, two of the ten Hollywood figures charged with contempt of Congress, were taken to jail today to start a year's imprisonment.

MADRID, June 9--Considerable alarm has been aroused in Spanish industrial circles by the announcement that the Government plans to enter the steel industry. June 19 this year is a pleasant date to keep in mind. For on that day the Stadium Concerts begin their thirtythird consecutive season, and for those of us who have to spend the better part of the summer in the city the Stadium Concerts have long been a place of refuge.

In a Philadelphia suburb this week some 165 expert golfers have gathered at the Merion Golf Club, Ardmore. LONDON, June 12--The Labor party, which rules Britain, rejected today all existing plans for merging its politics or economics with Western Europe.

Dr. Joseph Collins, neurologist, psychiatrist, psychologist and author of many books and articles, died Sunday night at his home, 36 East Seventy-second Street, after a brief illness. His age was 84.

In addition to receiving his degree summa cum laude at New York University's 118th commencement tomorrow, Mitchell Parish, author of the lyrics of "Stardust" and a song writer for more than thirty years, will carry the great silver torch, symbolic of academic purpose and authority.
The Michigan Public Service Commission approved yesterday plans of the Consumers Power Company for an offering of 499,903 additional common shares to the common stockholders of the utility.

The city pays tribute today to a unique and distinguished woman jurist, whose ability, example and integrity over the years have made her a civic symbol to men and women alike. She is Judge Anna M. Kross, a city magistrate, who will be reappointed as judge of the Home Term Court today.

Steel production in the United States averaged 94 per cent of capacity in 1948 and 81 per cent in 1949. Recently the weekly figures on operations show them at 101 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity as of Jan. 1, 1950, and still there doesn't seem to be enough to meet current demands.

The work week began yesterday for this column with a hard nut to crack. But one worth the effort. It was a green almond, here from California for its short season that started a week ago and will last through this month.

The Soviet-and-satellite boycott of the United Nations Point Four Conference, which opened yesterday, should be the cause of no great concern. An artillery piece that would fire an atomic weapon, and atomic war heads for guided missiles are under development, Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Staff of the Army, said recently.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 12-- Governor Dewey, in a series of speeches here and in Oswego today, assailed Federal farm and fiscal policies.

The steel industry's' cycle of greatest production is now in its ninth consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Steelmaking furnaces are scheduled to operate this week at 101.1 per cent of capacity, equivalent to 1,927,200 tons of ingots and steel for castings.

Air transport to Puerto Rico has been beset by stark tragedy on the one hand and, on the other, by some of the most complicated Gordian knots in all the economy of air commerce. Its people, Americans, must be protected against the recurrence of tragedy.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was operating one of the biggest international airlifts in its history to get 3,500 Puerto Ricans to the Michigan sugar beet fields before a June 20 harvest deadline.

ROBERT ABIAL ROLFE is a level-headed young man who isn't afraid to look a fact in the face. The sophomore manager of the Detroit Tigers doesn't wear rose-colored glasses so that the world appears bathed in a ruddy glow. Nor does he wear dark-tinted glasses so that the situation shows up in somber hues. He just doesn't wear any glasses at all and to him things are just as they seem.

Fordham University's College of Arts and Sciences yesterday conferred 627 bachelor degrees on the largest graduating class in the college's history. The ceremonies, held on the quadrangle in front of Keating Hall, marked the 105th commencement of the Bronx institution.

In a garden setting of white flowers yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Miss Harriot Gruner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Harry Gruner Jr. of Hewlett, L.I., was married to Henry Lawrence Ross Jr., son of Mrs. Olivia White Ross of Pine Orchard, Conn., and Henry Lawrence Ross of Delray Beach, Fla.

There is a pleasant warmth to the new walnut furniture introduced yesterday by John Scalia, Inc. Hand-finished in a soft, light brown honey tone called "chiffon," the pieces may be ordered now through decorators from the Scalia showroom, 410 East Fifty-fourth Street, and will be available after Aug. 1 at Altman's.

Edward Johnson will vacate the office of the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow after occupying it for fifteen years. Though his contract expired on May 31, he remained at his post to complete his final report to the aboard of directors and to clean out his personal effects.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Senate opened debate today on liberalization and expansion of the Social Security System in an atmosphere of nonpartisanship. Leaders of both parties supported the pending bill as a step in the right direction.

For the second consecutive day rubber prices declined on the Commodity Exchange yesterday the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound. Heavy price declines also were recorded in the London and Singapore markets.

Mrs. Harriet Rutter Eagleson widow of William A. Eagleson, a commission merchant, died Monday night in her home at 160 Riverside Drive. She celebrated her ninety-fifth birthday on Jan. 1, and was the oldest alumna of Hunter College, from which she was graduated in 1871.

A total of fifty-three soloists and fourteen conductors has been scheduled to appear at the Stadium Concerts this summer. The Philharmonic-Symphony series will run for eight weeks, beginning Monday evening at Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the sale of $110,000,000 of Columbia Gas System, Inc., debentures due 1975. The sale is to be at competitive bidding with bids to be opened June 20.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 13-- A new golfing trophy went to a Columbia team as the first intercollegiate championship sponsored by the Metropolitan Golf Association was won by a squad of Lions at the Nassau Country Club today.

The stock market alternated between strength and softness yesterday and closed irregularly lower on the day. Movements were not too impressive although the rails managed to outdistance other divisions at the highs of the session. Even the carriers, however, felt the force of the late selling.

New types of finishes and new styles of fall fabrics may be the answer to sluggish apparel sales, Arthur Wingate, piece goods buyer for Bloomingdale Brothers, declared yesterday. He spoke at the fall fashion conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 14--The first reaction of Congress and the Administration to the flat rejection by the executive committee of the British Labor party of the Schuman coal-steel pooling plan was, as published today in a Washington dispatch to this newspaper, one of mixed anger and disappointment.

PARIS, June 14--Paul van Zeeland, Belgian Foreign Minister, reported to the Belgian Cabinet today on the deadlock in the negotiations for an European payments union here, in which Belgium's creditor position is the principal issue.

WASHINGTON, June 14--As a result of the Russian atomic explosion last September, the United States, Great Britain and Canada are contemplating the joint release of the largest single collection of atomic energy data since the issuance of the Smyth Report of 1945.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Counterfeiting of American dollars both here and abroad has increased to such proportions that more than $100,000 of illegal currency is being spotted and seized every month by the United States Secret Service, Congressional testimony disclosed today. How much has escaped detection and remains in circulation was not even guessed.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Increases in postal rates on second, third and fourth class mail substantial enough to wipe out the Post Office Department's entire annual deficit was urged tonight by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson.

Governor Dewey flew here yesterday from Watertown, N.Y., in a state airplane to consult his physician, Dr. A. Wilbur Duryee, before his return to Albany, Friday morning.

The three--story taxpayer building at 716-20 Broadway in Brooklyn, containing two stores and two lofts, has been sold by Marvin Sayer to an investor through Paul P. Zinner, Inc., and Harry Friedman, brokers. Sale was for cash above mortgages of $26,500.

Frank J. Schaffeld has been named assistant district sales manager for the New York district of the Ford division, Ford Motor Company. George C. Giger has been named district service manager.

The 173d anniversary of the adoption of the United States flag by Congress was observed yester day. Throughout the metropolitan area Flag Day parades and exercises were sponsored by patriotic and fraternal organizations, and the flag was flown from thousands of flagstaffs and windows.
The Appellate Division voted three to two yesterday to dismiss the complaint in a $200,000 libel suit brought by Representative Vito Marcantonio against. The New World-Telegram Corporation.

LONDON, June 14--Little scattered selling imparted a slightly dull appearance to the stock market here today and business fell off. Virtually all British Government securities were slightly lower.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 14--The Board of Education of this village canceled plans today for a baccalaureate service in the high school on June 25 because of objections from two Roman Catholic priests and a recent ruling by the State Department of Education.

City College will confer Bachelor and Master degrees on 3,710 students, the second largest class in the school's history, at the college's 104th commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium this evening. The 1950 total falls only nine students short of last year's record of 3,719.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 14-- Communists and police fought fiercely during a demonstration today at the Sydney Town Hall, where Prime Minister Robert A. Menzies spoke in support of the New South Wales opposition's election campaign. Five men and one woman were arrested, charged with offensive behavior.
