CHICAGO, June 15--The Government can make security a "gift" for the aged, disabled and shiftless only by confiscating the earnings of young productive workers, L.W. Dawson, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)--A Republican Senator today sharply criticized Guy Gabrielson, national chairman of the Republican party, who turned up as head of a company which got an $18,500,000 Government loan.

Advertising and store display support will be given the fifteenth National Swim for Health Week campaign, June 19 to 24, by more than 9,000 retail stores, it was announced yesterday by Martin Stern ...

WASHINGTON, June 15--When the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations next week takes up the report of its subcommittee conditionally approving ratification of the United Nations convention against genocide, another aspect of the most interesting and important constitutional issue in our recent history will appear for critical inspection.

"At the Mayor's Desk," a television program featuring Mayor O'Dwyer and members of his administration and describing the workings of the city government, had its premiere last night over Station WPIX from 8 to 8:30 o'clock.
Harry Richards, the fiscal "dummy" for Frank Erickson's sizable account in a midtown bank, left the City Prison at 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a $10,000 bail bond was put up by his wife.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Congress was asked today by two Senators to set up a system under which investigations of "urgent public importance" would be made by commissions which would include men from private life.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Final success in a three-year scientific campaign to break up a fake olive oil racket was claimed today by Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing in a report on fifty-five convictions during May for violating the Food and Drug Act.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 15 --New York was described here today as the "greatest pagan city in the world."
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP)-- Consumer spending plans for 1950 promise record sales of new homes, motor cars and television sets, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TOKYO, June 15--Allied Headquarters announced today that the Japanese nation, grounded by Occupation order since 1945, again could have an internal air service. This service, however, will be operated by international aviation companies that maintained transocean lines here prior to January, 1950.

Electronic "brains" designed to relieve travelers of much annoyance in making railroad reservations are being installed at Pennsylvania Station, where the first public demonstration was held yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15--The House Judiciary Committee today reported favorably on a bill that would give New York State clear title to forty-five acres of property at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. A 1948 agreement between the state and New York City would give the city more than a third of the oceanfront property as a public park.

MARIETTA, Ohio, June 15--The University of Washington is the overwhelming choice of the coaches to win the three-mile varsity race in the forty-eighth annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, to be held here Saturday on the controlled water of the Ohio.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Paul G. Hoffman, administrator of the Marshall Plan, opposed "unalterably" today proposals that about $5,000,000,000 in economic recovery counterpart funds be used to expedite the program for arming western Europe against aggression.
Halves of $2 notes were used by operators of a Brooklyn policy bank as a means of identification in the event they were accosted by the police, it was charged yesterday in Kings County Court.
The Administration's handling of the Amerasia case was endorsed by the special Federal grand jury that for eighteen months investigated subversive activities.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who will return here on Wednesday from England aboard the Queen Mary, are understood to be planning a new production of "The Heart of the Matter," the dramatization of Graham Greene's best-selling novel.

Spot tin prices were reduced cent here yesterday, metal importers said. At the close, spot tin sales were priced at 77 cents a pound. Volume of orders was fair, merchants said. In other metals, demand for copper continued strong, lead demand was good and zinc scarcities continued.

As a spur in the drive against water waste the Board of Estimate yesterday passed the administration bill increasing from $5 to $50 the penalties assessed against property owners who neglect to repair leaky pipes and faucets.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Senators at key posts in providing further aid to Europe insisted today that Prime Minister Attlee of Britain give an official explanation of his Labor Government's plans for participation, or nonparticipation, in the economic integration of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 15--The State Department made public today the text of a note delivered to the Soviet Union inviting it to join Great Britain, France and the United States in shifting the occupation authority in Austria from military to civilian hands.

DOVER, Del., June 15--Senator Harry Darby of Kansas, one of the competitors in the second annual National Chicken Cooking Contest held here, went with the majority today in preparing fried chicken as his entry. Of the 122 women and nine men who participated, more than half chose to cook the birds in fat in a sizzling skillet.
MADRID, June 15--Spain's stormiest monarchist, the Duchess of Valencia, was acquitted here today of a charge of conspiring to distribute subversive tracts.

QUANTICO, Va., June 15-President Truman today inspected the United States Marine Corps at this training base. At the close of a six-hour rapid-fire demonstration of everything the Leathernecks can do on the ground and in the air the Commander in Chief declared in effect:

FLORENCE, Italy, June 15-- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet withdrew his resignation today as director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization at the unanimous request of the delegation chiefs.

Nancy Jackson, blonde, 6 years old and blind since birth, struggled to "see" with her tiny hands the cornerstone for the new Lighthouse. She raised her hands overhead, pressing them against the Alabama limestone and the etched letters that read: "Lighthouse for the Blind 1950."
Kipper, patched-up 7-year-old gelding bought for $400 last year, won first money of $7,600 in the $11,225 Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

The proposed local law providing for a new sewer rental charge amounting to one-third of the existing water rate was passed by the Board of Estimate yesterday and sent to Mayor O'Dwyer for his signature.
CHICAGO, June 15--Walt (Billy) Pierce, 23-year-old southpaw, pitched a gaudy one-hitter at Comiskey Park today as the White Sox beat the Yankees, 5--0, to complete ...

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP)-- Representative Frank Buchanan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today that the special House Lobby Investigating Committee would call on labor unions for an accounting of money they spent to influence legislation. Mr. Buchanan is chairman of the committee.

BONN, Germany, June 15--The West German Bundestag voted swiftly this morning to join the Council of Europe and send German representatives to an international political body for the first time since Adolf Hitler walked out of the League of Nations in 1933.

Kenneth Roduner, a 37-year-old post-graduate student at Teachers College, Columbia University, was found dead yesterday on the floor of his furnished room at 611 West 113th Street. A turkish towel gag was in his mouth and his hands were tied in front of him with a strip of the same material.
After a brief ownership the fivestory store and apartment building on lot 20 by 100 feet at 22 East Sixty-sixth Street, near Madison Avenue, has been resold by a group ...

For the second consecutive week, business borrowings from New York banks ran counter-seasonal and registered an increase. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering the reporting member banks in the city for the week ended on ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15-- Ellis Arnall, president of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers, received authority from the members of the organization at the annual meeting today to accept or reject the British proposal for a renewal of the expiring film remittance agreement.

Five individuals were cited for outstanding accomplishment in the field of marketing yesterday at the fifth annual awards luncheon of the American Marketing Association's New York chapter. About 300 persons attended the event at the Commodore Hotel.
The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on an issue of $2,500,000 temporary loan notes which marked the first new-money borrowing under the new Federal Public Housing Act.

The marriage of Miss Joan Farquhar Hadden, daughter of Mrs. Harold Farquhar Hadden of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street and the late Mr. Hadden, to Edward Low Pratt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Pratt of New York and Bethelehem, Conn., ...

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)-- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, today won the first and possibly decisive round of his fight to block the seating of an old political foe on the Federal Trade Commission.

William McCormick, 13 years old, started spinning wet clay into a new vase yesterday at the potter's wheel in Greenwich House Pottery. He came down really just to put some glaze on a bowl that might be sold tonight at a block party to raise money for the school.

With Secretary Johnson, General Bradley and Mr. Dulles en route to Japan for a political and military survey of the situation, the problem of a peace treaty for Japan appears to have entered at last into the stage of decision.
WASHINGTON, June 15--The State Department said today that it already had set in motion a modest program for supplanting alien workers in American diplomatic missions overseas.
WASHINGTON, June 15--Powerful opposition lined up today against President Truman's proposal to place the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the Department of Commerce.

MORRISTOWN, Tenn., June 15 --A strike that brought a United States Senate investigating committee to this town seemed all but broken today and the National Labor Relations Board ordered a new bargaining election at the American Enka Corporation rayon plant, focal point of the dispute.

LIMA, Peru, June 15 (UP)--The Military Government announced today that it had crushed the revolt in Arequipa, Peru's second largest city, in one day. A score of men prominent in professional, business and social circles have been arrested as leaders of the illfated revolution.

GENEVA, June 15--The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe closed a stormy two-week session here today after having agreed to all the main proposals of its Secretariat for another year's work in the field of intraEuropean cooperation, including East-West economic cooperation.

Three group shows, the customary summer fare in the New York art galleries, opened this week at the Midtown Gallery, the Levitt Gallery and the Salpeter Gallery. Taken together, they show the wide range of contemporary American art.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)-- House and Senate conferees agreed today on the terms of a bill designed to make $2,000,000,000 more in Federal funds available for supporting the prices of farm crops. The bill still is subject to approval by the House and then by the Senate.
An increase of $3,000 in the annual salaries of the three members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Additional programs designed for summer viewing are announced by the television networks, with the informal variety format being the most favored.
MILLVILLE, N.J., June 15-- Theodore H. Carter, an 18-year-old factory worker, was arraigned here today on a charge that he murdered 17-year-old Lorraine Hess on the night of May 12.
Robert Lincoln Litch will be sad for several reasons when he begins the second retirement in his fiftytwo-year teaching career today.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 15-- The National Association of Building Owners and Managers went on record today as strongly opposing "deficit spending and excessive Governmental expenditures at local, states and national level."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 15--Lawson Little of Monterey, Calif., who had not competed in the round-robin since 1947, assumed the lead in the initial round of the Palm Beach tourney, formerly known as the Goodall, with a 67 over the Wykagyl Country Club today.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 15--The Amsterdam Concert Hall returned to its pre-war splendor tonight for the inaugural performance of the fourth Holland Music festival. Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard attended the festival's opening for the first time, which meant that the canopy of the royal loge was restored.
OTTAWA, June 15 (Canadian Press)--The Seventh Imperial Press Conference prepared today to take action to extend freedom of the press in the British colonies.

A proposed contract between the city and the New York Zoological Society to construct and equip a $7,100,000 oceanarium at Coney Island was submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 15 --Banking was warned today that it must meet its "responsibility" to develop closer relations with Government in credit matters or it will lose its opportunities for public service through default.
VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., June 15 --Fifty volunteer firemen and a cloudburst saved this Comstock Lode mining capital from destruction by flames early today.
The employment of aliens in American diplomatic and other missions abroad has come under fire by a Congressional subcommittee consisting of Senators Green and Lodge, who have ...

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 15-- Closer cooperation between the schools and communities is needed to improve educational facilities throughout the country, educators and civic leaders declared here today. They urged more citizens to work for better schools.
ASCOT, England, June 15 (AP)-- William Woodward's Prince Simon got close enough to have his picture taken today but failed by a head to win the mile and a half King Edward VII Stakes.
WASHINGTON, June 15--Experts on Brazilian-United States relations are disturbed by reports of an increase in anti-American sentiment in Brazil during the last few months.

GROTON, Conn., June 15 (AP)-- Senator Joseph R. MeCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight accused John Peurifoy, Deputy Under-Secretary of State, of having arranged secret "pay-off" favors for a witness in the investigation of alleged Communists in government.

BAHREIN, June 15 (Reuters)-- American and British helicopters were tonight hovering over the almost completely submerged wreck of an Air France DC-4 that crashed last night into the Persian Gulf off this oil island.

WASHINGTON, June 15--The Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report, in its annual commentary on President Truman's Economic Message, called today for an end to deficit financing in such prosperous times as the present.
Many nurses in New York's hospitals are finding it difficult to live on salaries which, although raised in recent years, still are not sufficient to meet the steep cost of living.

LONDON, June 15--The Opposition gave Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee a bad quarter of an hour in the House of Commons this afternoon when it demanded to know where Labor party policy ended and Government policy began.

With Paul E. Fitzpatrick, its chairman, predicting the election of a Democratic Governor, the Democratic State Committee at a meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel adopted a resolution designating Rochester as the place for the Democratic State Convention on Sept. 6 and 7.

A new and horrifying picture of the damage to an American community from the explosion of an atomic bomb was given yesterday by Col. Wilfred A. Steiner, U.S.A.F. He spoke at the economic mobilization course of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces in session at the Astor Hotel.
Every two years when manufacturers of machine printed papers bring out their new lines, design trends which were first seen in expensive hand-screened papers reappear.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15--The importance of political education as a means of consolidating labor's gains during the past years was emphasized here tonight in a talk by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, June 15--The Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight announced the arrest at Syracuse, N.Y., of Alfred Dean Slack, 44 years old, an American chemist, on espionage charges.

Food processing and distributing have definitely kept pace with agricultural progress, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said yesterday after a meeting of the group's merchandising division in the Uptown Club.

The air coaches of American Airlines and Trans World Airline are operating at 91 to 96 per cent of passenger capacity as they start into the third month of the lowcost New York to Los Angeles service.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 15-- Southern California's sixteen-man squad arrived by plane late today and found itself established as a solid favorite to capture team honors in the twenty-ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships, which will be staged in the University of Minnesota's vast Memorial Stadium tomorrow and Saturday.

BELMONT, Mass., June 15 (AP)-- Miss Peggy Kirk, the 28-year-old Findlay, Ohio, golf star, took advantage of a disqualification ruling against Miss Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., and won the women's Eastern amateur championship today at the Belmont Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP)-- Robert N. Denham, General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, today recommended dismissal of charges of unfair labor practice filed by dairy workers in the capital's six-day-old milk strike.
WASHINGTON, June 15--The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today expelled two more unions, the American Communications Association and the Fur and Leather Workers Union.

The real defense against future world wars is a system of education that will give a sense of responsibility for the preservation of moral and spiritual values, speakers declared yesterday at the nineteenth annual commencement exercises of Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue at 187th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 15--A $500,000,000 increase in corporation taxes was reported today to have been agreed upon by Democrats holding sufficient voting power in the House Ways and Means Committee to decide the issue on a showdown there, probably next week.

Nick Minuskin, president of the Niku Company, Inc., 61 West Thirty-fifth Street, manufacturers of cosmetic accessories and other metal goods, died yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment in the Collingwood Hotel. His age was 44.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 15-- Judge John R. Schwartz of Poughkeepsie, presiding at the Nassau County Court trial of Jacob Kiefer, Long Island Rail Road, motorman accused of second degree manslaughter in the Rockville Centre wreck last Feb. 17, ...

A vacant plot 50 by 100 feet on the west side of Broadway, north of Kimberly Place, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been purchased by Land Properties, Inc., of which Leo Silver is president, for improvement with a onestory taxpayer.

The United Nations conference on the program to aid the peoples of under-developed areas came to a rousing conclusion. The fund drive went over the top in a fashion that had some really heart-warming aspects. One writer compared it to an auction.

LONDON, June 15--For the second night in succession, the Laborites tonight voted down more Opposition efforts in the House of Commons to amend the finance bill that gives effect to the budget of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
VIENNA, June 8--Since I left Czechoslovakia people keep asking: "What do the people of Czechoslovakia think? How much support do the Communists have?"

CHICAGO, June 15--The influence that is allegedly exerted by certain financial interests in New York to block expansion in securities trading in Chicago and other financial markets came to the surface today at a luncheon meeting sponsored by the Association of (New York) Stock Exchange firms.

In an open letter to the French people, former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts, president of the Atlantic Union Committee, said last night that the French had seized the "diplomatic initiative of the free Western world."

If the contemplated joint release by the United States, Great Britain and Canada of what our Washington bureau terms "the largest single collection of atomic energy data since the issuance of the Smyth Report" is translated into reality we shall be no nearer an atomic power plant than we were in 1945.
The hard-bitten longshoremen at the Holland-America Line pier at Fifth Street in Hoboken interrupted their routine tasks yesterday afternoon to lay their pal Blackie to rest.

WASHINGTON, June 15--In St. Margaret's Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon Miss Helen Parker Willard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradley Willard of Washington, was married to George Mallette Ferris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferris of Chevy Chase, Md.

WASHINGTON, June 15--The Philippine Republic is in no danger of collapse today but is bravely and consistently pulling itself out of the deep morass into which it was plunged by the war and the Japanese occupation.
CHICAGO, June 15--Maj. Gen. Thomas Stevens Hammond, busi ness leader and a veteran of both World Wars, died today in his home at the age of 66.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)-- Great Lakes ship and iron mine operators told Congress today that steel mills might have to curtail their output unless emergency steps to speed the shipment of iron ore were renewed.
WASHINGTON, June 15--Democratic efforts to bring to an early end the Senate's long investigation of alleged communism in the State Department were clearly foreshadowed today.
PARIS, June 15--The negotiations for a European Payments Union will face their second major crisis tomorrow when the executive committee of the Marshall Plan Council meets at the ministerial level.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 15 --Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, indicated after tonight's meeting of the league's political committee that the Arab collective security pact probably would not be signed before October.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 15-- Miss Mary Christy Pratt, daughter of Mrs. Christy Tiffany Knight of 1186 Lexington Avenue, New York, and John T. Pratt Jr. of Old Tappan Road, was married this afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown ...

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 15-- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator and a potential Democratic candidate for Governor, tonight blamed a coalition of the National Association of Manufacturers, the American Medical Association and insurance companies ...

The Publishers Association of New York City accused union Typographers yesterday of a "deliberate violation" of their contract with management in refusing to cross a New York Newspaper Guild picket line at The World-Telegram and Sun.

Homemakers looking forward to acquiring space in any of the new apartment houses springing up around the city may be interested in two model apartments opening today. About the only similarity between them, however, is that both contain a living-dining room, two bedrooms and kitchen.

City College last evening graduated the second largest class in its history as 3,710 Bachelor and Master degrees were conferred in Lewisohn Stadium. This year's class falls only nine short of last year's record total.
Like the frosting on a cake, it is accessories that turn summer costumes into beauties. As if to coax warm weather back, bevies of these charming accents have appeared, tempting in their prettiness.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 15-- Radio, despite the inroads of television, has shown its survival strength by holding a very strong daytime position and a substantial evening audience, Joseph B. Elliott, vice president in charge of R.C.A. consumer products, Camden, N.J., reported here today.

Today the Ohio River will be host to its biggest collection of oarsmen with the forty-eighth rowing of the intercollegiate championships, the first to be held at Marietta, Ohio. Since 1895 the country's top sweepswingers have pulled against the wind, tide and current of the Hudson.

The daytime ban on oversize trucks in the garment district was postponed again yesterday. Slated to go into effect Monday it was shelved for one week after labor, trucking and industry groups had appealed to City Hall.

LONDON, June 16--Representatives of nine Western European Socialist parties met with British Socialists here today for a threeday conference on the Schuman plan for pooling Western European coal and steel industries.

WASHINGTON, June 16--President Truman today urged 400 staff and field officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations' Political Action Committee to "keep up the good work" of acquainting the people with political issues.

The marriage of Miss Minna Halle Seitner, daughter of Col. and Mrs. Robert L. Seitner of Jacksonville, Fla., and the Park Lane, to Philip Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Goldman of Richmond Hill, Queens, was performed yesterday ...
The thirty-third season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts got under way before a large audience last night on the Mall in Central Park.

Mayor O'Dwyer is no novice as a television actor. The premiere of his bi-weekly evening program on WPIX found him quickly at ease as the star in a cabinet circle that included Commissioners Moses, Mahoney and Zurmuhlen and Deputy Mayor Reid.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 16 -- Dr. James Way Denton, of 1273 North Avenue, a pathologist, died today in his home of a heart ailment at the age of 63.

A panel of three Special Sessions justices was named yesterday by Chief Justice John J. Bennett to hear evidence in the trial of Frank Erickson on a sixty-count criminal information containing fifty-nine allegations of bookmaking and one of conspiracy.
The United Shoe Machinery Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with last February a net profit of $6,292,224 after all charges, including $3,150,000 for taxes.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ended a three-year investigation of the sale of Pullman space and of reserved seats in railroad ...

Price increases averaging 7 per cent were effective yesterday for some of the manufacturers of brass, bronze, iron and steel valves and pipe fittings, it was revealed by large industrial purchasing ...

Mayor O'Dwyer, welcoming to New York yesterday nearly 100 delegates to the second annual convention of the American Guild of Musical Artists, praised them for seeking practical protection for their 2,000 members.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 16 --A freakish accident today sent the polluted waters of Staten Island Sound into the municipal water supply of this city of 41,000 persons.
Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa declared last night that the Democratic party stands and always had stood on Thomas Jefferson's principle of "equal opportunity for all, special privilege for none."

White flowers formed a garden background yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church for the marriage of Miss Sharon Kerley Bonner, daughter of Mrs. Foeko van der Laan of 10 East Eightyfirst Street and Charles Bonner of 55 East Seventy-third Street, to ...

Natural, processed and synthetic rubber will be used in a project beginning here today to test the material in the building of heavily traveled roads. A strip of 440 feet on the West Side Highway will serve as a proving ground under the supervision of city engineers.

New three-year agreements were reached early yesterday by the National Maritime Union and the American Radio Association, both C.I.O., with thirty-five deepsea tanker and eight collier operating companies after several weeks of negotiations.

Edward L. McNicol, who rose from messenger boy to a vice presidency of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., died yesterday morning in St. Vincent's Hospital, Staten Island, after a brief illness. His age was 66. He lived at 65 Maine Avenue, Westerleigh, S.I.

After finding there was considerable opposition to the Long Island Rail Road's plan to abandon part of its beach area facilities, Federal Judge Harold M. Kennedy directed the objectors yesterday to resolve their differences and come before him for a formal hearing next Tuesday afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16-- Fifty-four sailing yachts, a record fleet, were checked tonight in preparation for the race to Bermuda starting on Sunday. The largest number of starters in any such race since its inception in 1906, was forty-four in 1936.
Three suspected narcotic peddlers, one of whom was said to have specialized in sales to high school students, were arrested yesterday by Customs Agents and the police.
Stanley Openshaw, 17 years old, was arraigned in Bronx County Court yesterday, accused of murdering his father, 70-year-old Martin Openshaw, on the morning of June 3.
WASHINGTON, June 16--Five major producers of anti-histamine drugs today signed agreements with the Federal Trade Commission not to advertise that their products will cure or prevent colds.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 17-- Japanese political parties moved formally yesterday for the establishment of a national front to negotiate a peace treaty with the Western Powers, an offer of which is now believed to be rapidly approaching.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16-- Murray Vernon Jr., Hotchkiss captain and Ed Garbisch of The Hill School reached the final round of the thirty-fifth Eastern interscholastic golf championship at Greenwich Country Club today. They will meet over thirty-six holes for the title tomorrow.

There is a large sigh of relief over the fact that Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet has withdrawn his impulsive resignation as director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
A package proposal on wages and working conditions, covering about 42,000 employes of the city's transit system, was accepted last night by Local 100 of the C.I.O. Transport Workers Union.

LOS ANGELES, June 16--Dr. Sidney Weinbaum, 52-year-old Russian-born physicist at the California Institute of Technology, was arrested today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on a charge of falsely concealing a Communist party connection in ...

A new all-metal sailplane that has been certificated by the Civil Aeronautics Administration has been announced by the Schweizer Aircraft Corporation of Elmira, N.Y., "soaring capital" of the United States.

ROME, June 16--The Vatican announced today that the canonization rite of Maria Goretti, an 11-year-old Italian girl who preferred to die rather than submit to a 19-year-old youth in 1902, would be held outdoors under the colonnade of St. Peter's Square at 7 P. M. June 24.
An admitted runner for a Brooklyn policy bank testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he had carried half of a new $2 note in his activities, but denied knowing the reason.

A 28-year-old former Young Communist League member who, while in the Army and working at the atomic bomb project in Los Alamos, N.M., in 1945, allegedly passed on atomic secrets destined for Russia, was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on espionage charges.

WASHINGTON, June 16--W. Averell Harriman, trouble-shooter for the New and Fair Deals ever since the depression, will move into the White House in August as a special assistant to President Truman on foreign affairs.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 16 (AP)-- Nine independent telephone workers unions, representing more than 75,000 Bell Telephone Company employes in the Northeast, voted a fund of $2,000,000 today to publicize their side of a wage dispute.

LOS ANGELES, June 16--Marive freight tonnage through Los Angeles harbor declined from 17,988,872 tons in the fiscal year 1947-48 to 17,115,867 in 1948-49, according to the annual report of the Board of Harbor Commissioners.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 16--Because of the economic needs of West Germany, the Ruhr again will be big and strong, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, assured leading industrialists of this area today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16-- "Horsie," Dorothy Parker's 1932 short story about a trained nurse with a horse-face, has been acquired for the screen by Robert Stillman, independent producer.

In what probably was the first such vigorous expression of displeasure with the findings of a regulatory body, the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said yesterday it would halt immediately its expansion program in the Dal- ...

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 16-- Pakistan has suggested to the South African Government that it postpone "administrative enforcement" of the Group Areas Bill for racial segregation until after a proposed international round table conference.

Modern-day D'Artagnans had their big show last night and before a crowded gallery in the ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt. The occasion was the grand finale of the fifty-ninth national championships of the Amateur Fencers ...
STAMFORD, Conn., June 16-- Mrs. Haryot Holt Dey, author and editor, died here today in the Heagney Nursing Home. She was 93 years old.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16-- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation got possession of the plant of the embattled Lustron Corporation today despite a Chicago Federal Court attempt to prevent it.

SNOW GULCH, Alaska, June 16 --One of the principles of successful trout fishing, which must be combined with the traditional techniques and methods, is to be at the right place at the right time, and we discovered that this applied to the Arolic River just as it did to the Beaverkill.

The two new classes for children suffering from cerebral palsy that were opened last month at P.S. 118 in Queens are making life brighter not only for the twelve boys and girls enrolled but for the rest of the school, Joseph F. Daly, principal, reported yesterday.

VIENNA, June 16--A plan under which Austria will grant commercial credits to Yugoslavia and the Economic Cooperation Administration will underwrite them is being studied by the Austrian Government, the E.C.A. mission here and the State Department.
ALBANY, June 16--Governor Dewey gave his decision on whether he will seek a third term to Representative William L. Pfeiffer and J. Russel Sprague, Republican state chairman and national ...

ST. LOUIS, June 16--The threeday starvation diet for the Yankees ended tonight when they outscored the Browns, 7--5, but even so the Browns, with their new ex-Yankees in the line-up, made it fairly close. The Brownies had the tying run on first base with two out in the ninth.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The United States rejected emphatically today Soviet charges that, with Britain and France, it had violated the Italian peace treaty in respect to Trieste.

Keeping the honors in the family, Vice President Alben W. Barkley will deliver the principal address on June 27 at the launching of the American President liner President Jackson, which Mrs. Barkley has already agreed to ...

HYNDMAN, Pa., June 16--This Allegheny Mountain town, nearly detsroyed when a Christmas tree started a $1,000,000 fire last Dec. 25, continued its "comeback" tonight by dedicating a community center building.
